HEADLINE: Saturn Stands Out Brightly Amid the Car-Sales Gloom

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
A retired Navy officer from California recently drove to the Saturn plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., to let workers know how much he loved his car and offer suggestions for future models. Another buyer liked her new Saturn so much she went to work for a dealership.
Though it's early, the Saturn car seems to be attracting an almost cult-like following. Sales, which have been strong, will grow when more cars are available and more dealers are in operation, the company says. 
 Most of Saturn's 130 dealers report brisk sales. "Demand is exceedingly strong," said Jeff Wuhlberg, part-owner of Saturn of Schaumberg, in Illinois. "We are asking for additional allocation" of cars.
 
 
Quick Customizing
 Mr. Wuhlberg said he was impressed by Saturn's ability to build models to individual customers' equipment and color preferences on short notice. Quick delivery and tailored products are also benefits of the "lean" production system at the Tennessee assembly plant.
Reviews from consumer and enthusiast magazines have been favorable but unspectacular: Saturn cars got high marks for being well put together and for delivering pleasing performance and fuel economy, but they were criticized for their engine noise and insufficient rear-seat headroom, problems that the company said it had worked on for its 1992 models.
Car sales, like movie-ticket sales, are often heavily influenced by word-of-mouth. Saturn dealers report that referrals are an important source of customers. "We've had a lot of cases where a parent buys one and then their kids come in," said Geoffrey Pohanka, a Saturn dealer in Chantilly, Va. Advertising has featured customer testimonials, partly to reinforce the word-of-mouth.
 
 
Seeking Import Customers
 By virtue of its subcompact size, advanced technology features like an optional multivalve engine, which makes the car more peppy, and a retail price of just under $10,000, Saturn has been aimed primarily at younger, better-educated buyers who value quality.
In ads, Saturn describes itself as: "A different kind of car. A different kind of company," hoping to win over buyers who might otherwise shop for a competitive foreign or American car. Saturn research indicates that 70 percent of buyers would not have bought a G.M. car if they had not purchased a Saturn. The research also shows that the most commonly cited second choices of Saturn owners were the Honda Civic and the Toyota Corolla.
Saturn searched carefully for dealers who were financially solid and had earned a reputation for satisfying customers. The dealers helped to negotiate a franchise agreement that differed greatly from those covering other G.M. dealers. Instead of receiving a franchise for only a single store, dealers won the right to geographical market areas and can add as many Saturn dealerships as they wish, in consultation with the company.
In October, when most American auto dealers were suffering from the slowest new-car sales since the last recession, 90 percent of the Saturn dealers were profitable, the company said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rise Broadly as Dow Gains 4.69

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed slightly higher yesterday, posting gains across the broad. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 4.69, closing at 2,919.05.
It was the third consecutive session in which prices advanced solidly while investors awaited more economic news. Traders said market sentiment that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates further after a meeting of its policy-setting Open Market Committee today had a positive impact early in the day. 
 Volume on the Big Board was moderate at 172.5 million shares, compared with 201.5 million shares traded on Friday. Gaining issues outpaced losers, 1,000 to 710.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.18 point, to 212.08, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down a slight 0.01 point to finish at 384.46.
The American Stock Exchange composite rose 0.97 point, to 370.45, and the Nasdaq moved up 2.83 points, to 543.73.
 
Smaller-Stock Activity
 In smaller-stock activity, the Russell 2,000 index rose 1.04 points to close at 178.55.
David S. Chao, senior vice president-trading for County NatWest Securities, noted that while yesterday's volume was fairly light compared with last week's average of about 190 million shares, most Mondays were usually slower than other days.
"A great deal of yesterday's action was in special situations," he said, "with buying in growth stocks like Philip Morris, Coca-Cola, Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer."
According to Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trades, Union Carbide, one of the 30 industrial companies in the Dow Jones average, accounted for 80 percent of the Dow's move. The company, whose stock moved up 2 1/4, to 19 5/8, announced that it would spin off its industrial gases unit to the public.
The release yesterday of figures showing that industrial production had slipped four-tenths of 1 percent in November and that capapcity utilization fell to 79.1 percent in the month from 79.6 percent in October had little impact on stocks, Mr. Chao said.
 
Marvel Entertainment Is Active
 Among active issues, Marvel Entertainment, a publisher of comic books, rose 2, to 43 3/8. Sean D. Love, an analyst at First Boston, initiated a "buy" recommendation, saying he expects a fair amount of comic book volume growth next year despite the company's price increase in January.
Birtcher Medical Systems, a California manufacturer of electronic medical instruments and other health-care products, fell 1 1/2, to 17 1/4. Robert M. Goldman, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, lowered his rating to a "buy-hold," from "buy." He said the stock had about doubled in the last six months and that the company recently announced that it was going to acquire Solos Endoscopy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President and Chief For Pacific First Bank

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Pacific First Bank F.S.B. said yesterday that it had elected John C. Dean president and chief executive, effective immediately.
A wholly owned subsidiary of Royal Trustco Ltd. of Toronto, Pacific First operates retail and mortgage banking offices throughout Washington, Oregon and California. 
 Mr. Dean, who is 44, comes to Seattle-based Pacific First from the First Interstate Bank of Washington, where he was chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Jerry Pohlman, the chief executive who resigned for personal reasons earlier this year. As president, he succeeds William D. Pettit, formerly president and chief operating officer, who has assumed a position with RT Holdings Inc., another unit of the parent company. Hartland M. MacDougall, Royal Trustco's chairman, continues as chairman of Pacific First.
Mr. Dean said in a statement that he was impressed with the financial strengths of Pacific First Bank. "Pacific First has a solid record of profitability, is capitalized well in excess of Federal requirements and has a very high-quality retail banking base," he said. "The bank has exceptionally strong financial resources and business-building capacity through its ownership by Royal Trust.
"We also have an excellent client service culture and a first-class professional staff," Mr. Dean added. "Together, these add up to a great future potential."
Mr. Dean's 18-year banking career includes 11 years at First Interstate Bancorp. He is active in the Seattle community and holds board memberships on the United Way of King County, the Seattle Symphony and the Seattle Chamber of Commerce.
He received a bachelor's degree in economics from Holy Cross College in Worcester, Mass., and an M.B.A. from the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Dean and his wife, Susan, have two children.

HEADLINE: 0.4% Skid in November Industrial Output

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
After three months of negligible change, industrial output skidded four-tenths of 1 percent in November, suggesting that the economy may now be contracting, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Although the automotive sector was particularly weak, the decline was broadly based, and analysts said it made further cuts in interest rates increasingly likely when the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee meets Tuesday for its last regularly scheduled session on monetary strategy this year. 
 "This pretty much fits with the view that the economy is dead in the water -- or even weakening," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist for Fuji Securities in Chicago. "There's no strength anywhere."
Among the various economic indicators, industrial production tends to be among the most accurately predicted since the employment report generally published 10 to 20 days earlier tells the number of people at work and their average hours.
Yet the four-tenths of 1 percent decline in the total output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities last month was barely within the low end of the estimate range. At the same time, the industrial operating rate was reported by the Fed to have skidded five-tenths of a percentage point, to 79.1, also below most expectations.
"This is a serious sign of deterioration," Morris Cohen, an economic consultant in Hacksensack, N.J., said. "It makes me very concerned about the fourth quarter, which may turn out to be a small minus" for gross domestic product instead of a small advance.
Industrial production, although covering only about one-third of the economy, is one of the primary gauges of current business activity. Factories, in particular, have tended to swing widely with economic ups and downs.
 
Reports Show Deteroriation
 This was the latest of several reports portraying economic deterioration for November. The only notable data so far for December showed that consumer confidence, as measured by the University of Michigan, steadied during the first half of the month following an October dive.
Production of consumer goods fell five-tenths of 1 percent last month, reflecting lower automotive output and small declines in food, clothing and other nondurables. Without lower car and truck production -- at a 9.5 million annual rate, down from 10 million in October -- output of consumer goods eased two-tenths of 1 percent, the Fed reported.
Business equipment fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, with the entire decline attributable to the business share of car and truck production and to a strike at what the Fed described as a major producer of construction and mining equipment, presumably Caterpillar Inc., where a labor dispute idled half its work force. A pickup in computer production in recent months has not been enough to offset the effects of declines elsewhere, even after allowing for the strike.
Construction supplies, however, which had been declining since June, rose slightly last month.
 
Factory Output Down
 By industrial grouping, factory output fell five-tenths of 1 percent after a five-tenths of 1 percent gain in September and no change in October, with factory utilization falling six-tenths of a point, to 78 percent of capacity. Both primary and advanced processing industries posted widespread declines, with the latter now hovering scarcely above their March low.
But iron and steel output climbed for the fifth straight month even as production in most other primary processing industries held steady or eased.
Mining output was unchanged after falling six-tenths of 1 percent in October and utility output spurted nine-tenths of 1 percent because of higher demand for electricity.
At 107.8, the index of industrial production now stands five-tenths of 1 percent below its level of November 1990, or eight-tenths of 1 percent when cars and trucks are excluded. Car output last month was at a 5.7 million rate, down from 5.9 million, while truck output was 3.8 million, down from 4.1, the Fed reported.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Programs For Foreign Managers

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
AMERICAN business educators are busy training managers from abroad.
Programs at Duke University and at the University of Pittsburgh and one sponsored by half a dozen Wall Street investment firms and commercial banks are educating foreigners in American techniques. 
 The recently completed Duke program, the fourth of its kind, involved a three-week stay at the Fuqua School of Business at Durham, N.C., for 25 middle- and upper-level executives from five Soviet republics and Lithuania.
Dr. Thomas F. Keller, dean of the business school, said the participants were exposed to Western-style management techniques to help equip them for what the program has described as the "pell-mell rush toward a free-market economy."
The University of Pittsburgh Graduate School of Business has a joint program in Prague under which Czechoslovak students are enrolled in a one-year management program. Afterward, they can earn master's degrees in business administration from the school by spending a semester studying in Pittsburgh.
Dr. H. J. Zoffer, dean of the school, said that among the students enrolled in Prague were one from Bulgaria, one from India, two from the United States and 21 from Czechoslovakia, including a woman associated with the Czechoslovak Republic's Ministry of Industry.
"The Bulgarian student is in the international distribution business, and the others come from such industries as heavy-truck building, locomotive building, television industry, as well as financial jobs in various industries," Dr. Zoffer said last week.
The school, known as the Czecholovak Management Center, has a campus in Prague. The program includes an internship at European companies.
Dr. Zoffer said that classes would be mainly in English but that executive development courses would be in Czech.
Tuition assistance was provided by the Czechoslovak Government, the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and two United States Government units, the Agency for International Development and the United States Information Agency, Dr Zoffer said.
Another program, sponsored by Wall Street investment firms and commercial banks, will begin in the spring. It will train 10 middle managers from South Africa, with the help of the City University of New York, said Ronald T. Gault, a managing director of the First Boston Corporation.
Mr. Gault is chairman of the steering committee for the program. He said that South African managers would work within New York companies in the six-month program, learning on-the-job techniques.
The students will attend all department meetings with their counterparts and will accompany them on sales calls, he said.
The program is tailored to the individual needs of the South African managers, he added. For example, if they need more study in quantitative analysis, the investment bank or commercial bank they work for will provide it.
Mr. Gault said that the program would include seminars and discussion groups provided through CUNY and that conversational and other communications skills would be stressed. A bibliography of books and case histories will also be available, to which the students can refer when they return to South Africa.
In New York, the companies participating include Chase Manhattan, Chemical Banking, Citicorp, First Boston, J. P. Morgan and Manufacturers Hanover, all of which will provide some financing for the program.
While plans have not been completed, the students will probably be housed in International House, adjacent to the Columbia Uninversity campus.
Their salaries, medical benefits and pension contributions will be continued by their companies in South Africa. The South African companies participating include the Development Bank of Southern Africa, National Sorghum Breweries, Southern Life Association, Standard Bank and United Bank.
The educational program was suggested by Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York City, Mr. Gault said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Slow Trading And Gold Slips in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar lost ground yesterday in extremely light pre-holiday trading, as falling interest rates continued to work against the United States currency.
Gold prices eased slightly after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $359 an ounce, down 40 cents. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $358.85, down 15 cents from the bid late on Friday. 
 Analysts said the dollar was depressed by a Government report that industrial production had fallen by four-tenths of 1 percent in November, continuing a four-month slump.
 
Could Spur Fed Action
 The report is likely to encourage the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, a bearish move for the dollar because lower rates reduce the value of dollar-denominated securities.
In addition, the German Bundesbank council is expected to raise interest rates when it meets later in the week, making marks more attractive.
"That combination spells trouble for the dollar" as investors shift funds to capture the highest yields, said Marc Chandler, an analyst at the advisory firm IDEA.
Jerry Rothman, a vice president at Merrill Lynch, said the possibility that the political troubles in the Soviet Union might be solved without violence also reduced the need for dollars. The dollar is historically viewed as a haven in times of world turmoil.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.45 Japanese yen, down from 128.73 yen on Friday. Later in London, the dollar fell to 128.35 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.40 yen, down from 129.00 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8210, from $1.8165 late on Friday. In New York, it cost $1.8245 to buy a pound, more expensive than Friday's $1.8160.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5750 German marks, down from 1.5885; 1.3935 Swiss francs, down from 1.4040; 5.3805 French francs, down from 5.4255; 1,188.75 Italian lire, down from 1,198.50, and 1.1428 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1426.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $359.50 an ounce, from $358.60 late on Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $359.25 from $358.90. Earlier in Hong Kong, it rose $1.30 to close at $361.05.

HEADLINE: Restoration of a Painting Worries Dutch Art Experts

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
When a canvas by the American painter Barnett Newman was repeatedly slashed by a vandal at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam five years ago, many in the Netherlands feared that what had become virtually a national treasure was ruined beyond repair. Now, having seen the results of a 4-year restoration by a New York City conservator that cost more than $300,000, some fear that it is the repair that has ruined the painting.
A commission from the Amsterdam city council is scheduled to meet tomorrow to consider taking action against the conservator, Daniel Gold reyer. Last week the council received a report from a Government forensic laboratory, which the city-owned Stedelijk had asked to analyze the restoration. The report concluded that Mr. Goldreyer covered Newman's original oil paints with a quick-drying alkyd coating that is virtually impossible to remove. 
 The painting, "Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue III," is an 8-by-18-foot work from 1967, consisting of a large, luminous red field flanked by thin strips of blue and yellow. The fate of the painting has received widespread attention in the Dutch media since several experts in Amsterdam publicly cast doubt on the restoration soon after Mr. Goldreyer returned the canvas to the museum in August. Among the questions raised about the restoration is why it took so long and cost so much, when the report suggests that the restoration consisted of repainting the red field with what may have been a roller. Questions have also been raised about what the report describes as "pimples" that have appeared on the canvas since the restoration.
Wim Beeren, the Stedelijk's director, who selected Mr. Goldreyer to repair the painting, declined to comment on the laboratory's report before tomorrow, when he is to appear before the commission.
 
The Restorer's Response
 In response to the report, Mr. Gold reyer yesterday sent Mr. Beeren a sparsely worded four-page letter, which insists that "the final in-painting, point by point, was done in the original materials used by Barnett Newman." The letter acknowledges that the surface of the canvas was covered with an alkyd "seal" that was applied to protect the painting "from light and airborne pollutants." It goes on to state that the work "was not overpainted." Mr. Goldreyer notes that there were "at least 12 or 13 inspections" during the restoration by officials from the Stedelijk and others, who raised no objections.
"As far as I'm concerned, this is a vendetta," Mr. Goldreyer said in an interview yesterday, "because the conservator in the museum wanted to do the painting but she couldn't do it, so she has raised these objections." He was referring to Elisabeth Bracht, the chief conservator of paintings at the Stedelijk, who is one of the critics of the restoration. "Everything can be reversed," Mr. Goldreyer said. "If they send the painting back to New York, I will gladly remove everything done -- at their expense -- and let the museum do the restoration."
Mr. Goldreyer, a private conservator who has been restoring works by artists of the New York School since that school was active in the 1950's, has worked on many paintings by Newman, including "Cathedra" and "Voice of Fire."
"He is controversial in the field," said Carol Mancusi-Ungaro, the chief conservator of the Menil Collection in Houston, who specializes in the restoration of postwar paintings. Mr. Gold reyer is known to be private about his techniques, she said.
He also has a reputation for favoring overall, rather than localized, restorations and doing treatments that have raised questions among colleagues about "reversibility," or insuring that everything a conservator does to a painting can be easily undone, if necessary. That principal is fundamental to modern art conservation, since restorations almost always need to be redone over time. Mr. Goldreyer responded: "Because other people cannot do these restorations, because they're not capable, they accuse me of doing an overall, which is untrue. Everything I do is reversible. Everything."
 
Original vs.Vs.ersus Facsimile
 The incident highlights one of the most difficult tasks for conservators: restoring works by post-World War II artists like Newman, Mark Rothko and Ad Reinhardt, which consist of large, flat, monochromatic areas. Without radical repainting, even the most carefully restored scratch remains visible from certain angles and in certain lights. Yet large-scale and irreversible repainting of the kind that Mr. Goldreyer has been accused of doing masks the artist's original surface and results in what is essentially a facsimile.
"I stand strongly against repainting, but I can understand the impetus when a work is severely damaged," Ms. Mancusi-Ungaro said. "The problem is that while society accepts the idea that Old Master paintings can exhibit signs of aging, which includes damage of some sort, people don't accept the aging process for contemporary works. I think it is a reflection of our attitudes toward aging, in general."
Margaret Watherston, a private conservator in New York City, agrees. "Restoring areas of monochromatic color that have been slashed is one of a conservator's biggest headaches," she said. "But no responsible conservator would agree with what the report said was done: repainting a surface." She added, "It would be virtually impossible to create an illusion of an undamaged surface with a painting like this without repainting."
 
A Cornerstone of a Collection
 The work by Newman, who died in 1970 at the age of 65, is the third in a series of four works titled "Who's Afraid of Red, Yellow and Blue." Presumed to have been worth several million dollars before it was slashed, according to Sabine Ruytenbeek, a spokeswoman on art matters for the city of Amsterdam, the painting was bought by the Stedelijk in 1969 for $75,000. In the next two decades it became one of the best-known works of postwar art in what is Amsterdam's premier collection of modern art.
On March 21, 1986, a 31-year-old unemployed man tore eight big gashes through the canvas with a knife. The man, unidentified because Dutch law prohibits making public the names of criminals, later explained that he was protesting Dutch museums and abstract art. The man spent eight months in jail.
For more than a year, the museum consulted with Dutch and other conservators about whether the work could be repaired. Annalee Newman, the painter's widow, traveled from New York to examine the painting. "I almost fainted when I saw it," she said. "It was in ribbons." Mr. Beeren asked her about conservators. Mrs. Newman told Mr. Beeren that she thought Mr. Goldreyer, whom she had known for many years, "had the expertise to do it."
The director recommended him to the city council, which oversees the museum's operations, and in 1987 the council drafted a contract that included a clause stipulating that disagreements about the results of the restoration were to be settled by arbitration in the United States. If the council that begins deliberations tomorrow decides to take action against Mr. Goldreyer, the city of Amsterdam and the conservator will put their cases before an American arbitrator.
 
Another Kind of Damage
 Among those to raise doubts about the restoration after its return to the Stedelijk in August were Ernst van de Wetering, a professor at the University of Amsterdam and a member of the Rembrandt Research Project, and two Dutch conservators, Ijbrand Hummelen, a private conservator, and Mrs. Bracht of the Stedelijk. Mr. Hummelen described what Mr. Gold reyer had done as a "clumsy and false imitation" of Newman's work. Reacting to the criticisms of the restoration, the Amsterdam city council asked Mr. Beeren for a report on the painting.
Mr. Beeren of the Stedelijk supported Mr. Goldreyer, and the cost of the restoration, while acknowledging that certain questions about the restoration could not be answered without chemical analyses. He then hired the Forensic Laboratory in Rijswijk, near the Hague, which is operated by the Ministry of Justice, to perform tests on the painting.
Mrs. Newman said she was "upset that the Dutch have made this such a public thing, which only invites more damage." Mr. Goldreyer states in his letter that she "was delighted" by the restoration. After hearing about the laboratory's findings, she defended the conservator. "He did a beautiful job of putting it back together, although I only saw the painting in the dark," she said. Then she added: "I'm hoping that if he has done something to the work that shouldn't have been done, somebody will be able to bring it back to what it was. It's one of Barney's great works."

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
How Fake Art Is Created and Discovered and Why

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
"The Fine Art of Faking It" provides step-by-step instructions on how to create a 16th-century German masterpiece and how to determine that the one you were sold was made just yesterday. The enterprising report from "Nova" at 8 tonight on Channels 13 and 49 also tries, with less success, to explain why it matters if a Rembrandt turns out to be not quite a Rembrandt.
The focus here is on the Cleveland Museum of Art's 1974 purchase of a painting of St. Catherine by the 16th-century German artist Matthias Grunewald. Since there was only one other Grunewald in the United States, St. Catherine was considered well worth the $1 million the museum paid for her. 
 When an art historian began to have doubts, the museum turned to a German scholar, Hubert von Sonnenburg, who leads viewers through his investigation. Using an X-ray machine, an electronic microscope, chemical analysis of pigment samples and experience, he found that the base of the painting contained processed chalk not available four centuries ago and that the work did not contain any silver, which was a component of lead white paint until the mid-1800's. These and other findings labeled the work a fake.
All this is laid out in typically clear "Nova" style. Then the program moves to the Bavarian studio of a painting restorer named Christian Goller, who demonstrates how he made the 20th-century Grunewald, which was inspired by a drawing for a lost painting. It took him a week, using mostly paints available in the 1500's, such as a vibrant purple made from cactus lice. You can see him aging a work by several hundred years in an afternoon, ending up by smearing on the dirt and grime of centuries.
"Whoever calls me a forger," Mr. Goller insists, "is lying. I only paint in the style of the Old Masters. I add patina and crackle for decoration. You can't call that a forgery." He goes on: "I think copies make art accessible. Everybody can afford to hang a Grunewald in his house." Mr. Goller emphasizes that he does not add any artist's signature to what he calls his reconstructions, and he sells them for what they are. He says he is not responsible for the claims others make for them.
The processes of creation and detection laid out here are fascinating, but the question lingers: Why, except for pricing purposes, does it matter to the art lover whether the work is an authentic Grunewald or an authentic Goller? Does a work's beauty lie in its provenance?
One answer of sorts comes from Evan H. Turner, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, which paid the million dollars for the fake: "As a matter of fact, when one passes that painting again and again it gets increasingly shallow because, you know, the factor of time as an element of connoisseurship, the fact of looking at a picture again and again; it's not unlike living with a person." He goes on in that vein and concludes, "That particular painting today is a very boring picture."
If you can get past the patina of his prose, what this expert is saying is that once you know a painting is not what it is cracked up to be, despite what seem to be its cracks of time, you look at it differently. No doubt, particularly if your museum is the one that got taken.
Granted, museums have an obligation to scholarship, but where does that leave the mere art fancier? Suppose the fake had remained unrevealed? Would Mr. Turner and others be finding increasing depth in it day after day? Isn't it somewhat unfair to the talented Mr. Goller that the painting that experts so esteemed in 1974 should be described as shallow a few years later? Doesn't it make you wonder about the esthetics, never mind the economics, of museumship?
The hour ends with a report on a disagreement at the J. Paul Getty Museum in California over the authenticity of a seven-foot Greek kouros, a marble statue of a young man from the sixth century B.C. for which the museum reportedly paid $9 million. Some art detectives say it was made recently in Rome; others say it is the real thing. Thomas P. Hoving, the former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, predicts the work will simply disappear from view.
Won't that be a loss to those who admired it until doubts were raised? Mr. Hoving puts the issue this way: "Art is like a love affair: it's passion. And if you deeply believe that your lover is your lover and when you find out that your lover cheats on you just once, it's gone. Same thing in art." Oh? An end to love because of a single dalliance? An end to one's feelings for a beloved painting because you learn it may have been done just the other day? In art, as in life, it seems you cannot trust your eyes or your heart.
Nova
The Fine Art of Faking It
 
Produced by Denisce DiIanni; Paula Apsell, executive producer. At 8 tonight on Channels 13 and 49.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Designers From East and West Plan Bomb Disposal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 16

 BODY:
In a first no less remarkable than others of late, nuclear bomb makers of East and West are sitting down together this week to seek ways to undo their handiwork and destroy their creations. The enterprise comes nearly a half century after the race to develop nuclear weapons began in an undertaking that for years commanded the best scientific and technical talents of both East and West.
The disabling of nuclear warheads is uncharted territory. Recent arms treaties have spelled out how delivery systems, like rockets and cruise missiles, should be crushed, burned, cut up or otherwise reduced to rubble. But none has addressed the most basic challenge of all, destroying the nuclear warheads that have kept the world on edge for so long.


GRAPHIC: The aim of the week-long effort, which started today in Moscow, is to develop rules for counting, disabling and destroying thousands of nuclear warheads. It brings together top weapon designers and arms-control experts from East and West in an uneasy alliance.
Photo: "It's a wonderful opportunity to try to influence history," Dr. David W. Watkins, a nuclear arms designer at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, said of the meeting. Dr. Watkins is one of 14 American experts here to attend the gathering.
For decades the two sides have vied for nuclear superiority and, because of that, to keep weapon secrets far from one another. Now, rather suddenly, they find themselves joining ranks to throw the nuclear arms race into reverse.
Viktor P. Karpov, a top official of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, told the American team today that its technology might "accelerate that process."
Dismantling Soviet nuclear arms has become a top priority of the Bush Administration and Congress as the Soviet Union has collapsed. Last week Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d pledged immediate aid for the effort, part of which could take till the year 2000 by some estimates. Last month, Congress allocated $400 million in emergency funds to help in the storage and destruction of Soviet nuclear arms.
The American delegation, organized by two private groups, includes arms designers and treaty experts from the Federal centers for warhead design at the Los Alamos lab and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. The team also includes former directors of the Los Alamos lab and the Sandia National Laboratories in New Mexico, another such center.
The Soviet delegation includes nuclear bomb designers and officials from the Ministries of Defense, Foreign Affairs and Atomic Power and Industry, which oversees the building of Soviet nuclear arms.
One topic on the agenda is how to disable weapons as a first step to eventual destruction. "Soviet society is falling apart," Dr. Watkins said. "It's in our interest, in their interest, in everybody's interest, to get these stabilized as soon as possible. It would be a terrible thing, down the road, if we lost some of these weapons."
It remains to be seen whether ideas discussed here will be acted upon, and by whom. Many questions on control of the weapons have to be worked out between Moscow and the former republics.
A different issue is reciprocity with the United States. Moscow often wants the restrictive steps that it would adopt for its own weapons to apply to American ones as well, although the Bush Administration has just as often resisted such ideas.
The nuclear arms at issue include artillery shells, land mines, short-range missile warheads, air defense warheads and naval weapons.
Organizers of the American team are the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Federation of American Scientists, private arms-control groups that more than a year ago began exploring how to verify warhead dismantling, with little Federal encouragement.
"We busted our chops to try to get the Administration interested back then," said Dr. Thomas B. Cochran, a senior scientist at the resources council and a main organizer of the current meeting. "But there wasn't a flicker."
He said the Administration joined the effort at the last minute, apparently because of the sudden collapse of the Soviet Union and after the relatively recent East-West endorsement of warhead dismantling. Secretary Baker is here this week to press the same issues.
This fall President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, announced dramatic cuts in short-range or tactical nuclear weapons and, for the first time, their planned destruction. Mr. Bush announced his initiative in September, and Mr. Gorbachev's positive response came in October. The American concern was that these widely dispersed Soviet weapons, perhaps 15,000 of a total of 30,000 nuclear arms, might fall into unfriendly hands in distant republics amid growing turmoil, a prospect Secretary Baker has called "Yugoslavia with nukes."
 
Verification Is Crucial
 So far, a central question that East and West have yet to address is how much of this promised dismantling can be verified and revealed to the other side. That is a main topic here. Other items on the agenda are finding better means of secure storage, outlining steps for destroying weapons and discussing the ultimate fate of nuclear materials, including plutonium and highly enriched uranium. Experts say the collapsing Soviet economy increases the risk that crucial weapons materials might be sold for hard currency.
Only delivery systems such as missiles were eliminated under the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Force treaty and are slated for disposal under the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty, known as Start, signed in July by Presidents Bush and Gorbachev.
The exemption of nuclear arms from these accords has been faulted by both liberals and conservatives since the weapons can be recycled and used again, giving new life to the arms race. "The only good treaty," Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, once said, "is one that actually reduces nuclear weapons."
The Bush Administration, and the Reagan Administration before it, have sought to reserve the right to do what they want with the leftover nuclear warheads and materials after delivery systems have been destroyed.
Today the delegation of American experts met with officials at the Foreign Ministry and the Russian Supreme Soviet in a round of preliminary talks. The hard technical work is expected to occur Wednesday and Thursday as American and Russian experts meet in Kiev with Ukrainian officials to discuss the estimated 4,000 Soviet arms on that country's soil and the ones in other former Soviet republics. The Ukrainian effort is expected to be a test case for the wider disarmament effort.
 
How Many Do They Have?
 "We must work together with the new governments to insure a complete inventory, secure storage and eventual dismantling of these warheads," said Christopher Paine, a senior researcher with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Remarkably, an important issue on the American side is simply to count the weapons. No one in the West knows the exact number of warheads that are deployed in Ukraine, or in Russia for that matter. Some experts suggest that even top Soviet officials may be in the dark as to the numer of weapons, because competing military groups have custody of different kinds of nuclear arms. That vagueness is seen as raising the risk of arms sales or clandestine deployments by states that arise from the ashes of the Soviet Union.
At this week's meetings, Dr. Cochran of the American delegation said he plans to promote the idea of putting a unique "tag" for identification on each nuclear weapon as well as a "seal" that would reveal any tampering with storage containers. "These measures would insure a clear chain of custody for these weapons pending their destruction," he said. The Americans have brought sample tags and seals to the meeting and plan to discuss them with officials here.
One low-tech sealing system consists of a fiber-optic cable composed of either 16 or 64 fibers that would be wrapped around a weapon storage container and then illuminated at one end. The unique light "signature" visible at the other end would be photographed. Later, in a return visit, a comparison of old and new photographs would instantly reveal if the cable had been cut or violated in any way.
High on the agenda of American arms designers is discussing with their Russian counterparts any safety systems that Soviet arms might have that would allow them to be disabled in place. In an interview, Dr. Watkins of Los Alamos said modern American weapons had several such systems, although he declined to discuss them. He added that an open discussion of design issues by Russian arms designers might be "very difficult" because of the secrecy that veils such programs.
 
How to Store Weapons
 But today Mr. Karpov, of the Foreign Ministry, told the American team that it was possible to develop disabling methods that would leave design secrets intact.
Another focal issue here is how to safely store weapons that are awaiting dismantling. Officials of the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Power and Industry, while visiting Washington in October, said that because there was no money for building new central storage facilities, some short-range weapons might have to remain in dispersed areas until the turn of the century.
Such statements helped prompt the $400 million in American aid for arms storage, transport and destruction here.
A final issue is what to do with nuclear materials after warheads have been taken apart. In its current weapons and far-flung stockpiles, the former Soviet Union is estimated to have 700 to 1,000 tons of plutonium and highly enriched uranium, a vast amount of weapons material.
One plan would be simply to leave the material in well-guarded storage areas under international supervision.
Dr. Thomas L. Neff, a member of the American delegation and a physicist at the Center for International Studies of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has suggested that highly enriched uranium-235 could be diluted with natural uranium and processed for use in commercial nuclear power plants. Processing plutonium in such a manner is considered less attractive because most countries shun reactor fuels that contain plutonium.
Dr. Neff has also suggested that the United States should consider buying the uranium reactor fuel, which could cost billions of dollars. Otherwise, he says, former Soviet ministries might flood commercial nuclear fuel markets and destroy critical Western industries.
 
Problems of Uranium Sales
 Already, the Soviets have been selling unusually large amounts of natural and enriched uranium in Western commercial markets. The sales have fed a downward price spiral that has driven some uranium producers out of business and threatened the uranium enrichment business of the Federal Energy Department, the world's largest supplier of commercial fuel.
In a final method of destruction, some Russian experts have suggested that retired arms be incinerated in nuclear blasts deep beneath the ground. A Moscow-based trading company, Chetek, which has ties to the Ministry of Atomic Power, has recently been set up to explore the commercial use of nuclear explosions for such purposes as eliminating toxic wastes.
At a reception Sunday night, Chetek officials told the American delegation that a single underground blast might destroy as many as 5,000 nuclear cores from retired warheads.; Chart: "The Path to Safety: Disposing of Weapons" shows how to dismantle a nuclear weapon (Source: Federation of American Scientists) (pg. C11)
 
Drawing (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: In Chile, Galaxy-Watching Robot Seeks Measure of the Universe

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

DATELINE: CERRO TOLOLO, Chile

 BODY:
SCIENTISTS at this remote mountaintop observatory have developed a new machine for measuring the distances to far-away galaxies and hence assembling a new map of the mysterious large-scale structure of the universe.
The machine, attached to one of the world's largest telescopes at the Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory, allows astronomers to measure distances to 24 remote galaxies at a time. 
 Measuring the distance to far-away galaxies is extremely difficult. But it is essential if astronomers are to understand the overall structure of the universe. Distances have been estimated for only a few of the billions of galaxies strewn across the universe. Astronomers are developing new yardsticks for improving their estimates of galactic distances. But the principal way at present is to gather light from a galaxy and break it up into a spectrum of colors with a device called a diffraction grating.
The lines in each galaxy's spectrum are shifted toward the red by an amount that depends on the galaxy's speed of travel away from Earth. Because of the universe's expansion, the speed of a galaxy's recession is also a measure of its distance from Earth.
But light reaching the Earth from a galaxy billions of light years away is very faint, and when broken up into a spectrum, each part of that spectrum is fainter still. Only an enormous curved mirror, such as the four-meter-diameter one in this observatory's main telescope, can gather enough light from a very faint galaxy to measure its red shift.
Even this huge mirror is not an effective solution to the problem since it takes many minutes of exposure to measure the light from one galaxy, and a whole night's work to produce just a handful of distance measurements.
So Dr. Thomas E. Ingerson, a physicist on the staff here, with the help of a team of Chilean engineers and machinists, has built a cunning device that allows the four-meter telescope to measure up to 24 galaxies in the time it used to take to measure just one.
Light from the big mirror is brought to a focus at the other end of the telescope on an array of 24 robotically controlled arms, each one carrying a pair of optical fibers. Working at a bank of computer consoles in the telescope control room, Dr. David Koo of the University of California at Santa Cruz and other astronomers can now maneuver each of the 24 arms of the device to place an optical fiber at the exact spot where light from a target galaxy is to be focused by the telescope mirror.
The device is known as the Argus, after the 100-eyed giant of Greek mythology.
When the "run" is begun, light from each galaxy is piped from the telescope along its own fiber to a lower floor of the observatory building, where it hits a diffraction grating and has its spectrum automatically measured by a "charge-couple device." This device, embodied in a light-sensitive electronic chip the size of a thumbnail, measures the photons of light harvested by the telescope far more efficiently than did the photographic plates that astronomers used until about a decade ago.
The measurements taken by Argus are transmitted back to the control room where Dr. Koo's associate in this project, Dr. Christopher N. A. Willmer, an astronomer from the Lick Observatory at Santa Cruz, subjects them to computer analysis. Within minutes the computer program calculates the red-shift distance of distant galaxies, and the measurements accumulate rapidly.
 
Like Tubes Into Cheese
 But each spectrum must be examined with an expert eye to weed out useless objects measured by accident. Dr. Koo discards objects that turn out to be mere stars. At a recent observing session he also had to discard a previously unknown quasar, some 8 billion light-years away, that fell into his telescope net because it had looked superficially like a galaxy.
Dr. Koo and Dr. Willmer, unlike many other galaxy hunters, confine their search to a "needle" corridor extending into the depths of space far beyond a "Great Wall" of galaxies that has been extensively investigated. By studying very distant galaxies in this thin core, Dr. Koo and Dr. Willmer get a sample like those that food testers obtain by thrusting sharpened tubes into wheels of cheese. Their needle also reaches to a great distance from the Earth -- some 8 billion light-years -- at which the light from galaxies is just barely detectable by the largest telescopes.
By making distance measurements to many galaxies lying along a thin line from the Earth to the outer reaches of the universe, Dr. Koo and Dr. Richard Krone of the University of Chicago discovered three years ago that in one direction, at least, the clusters of galaxies, each containing hundreds of millions of stars, seemed to be concentrated in evenly spaced layers. Whether this was just a fluke or actually means that some kind of layering pervades a large part of the universe remains to be determined from many more measurements -- perhaps millions of them -- and astronomers agree that answers are likely to be complex.
 
'Just an Observer'
 Dr. Koo and a colleague are now making more measurements to provide at least some tentative answers. Other astronomers, many of them doubtful that layering is a general feature of the universe, are examining the problem in different ways. "I'm just an observer, and I am not attempting to explain the data," Dr. Koo said. "In any case, we don't see this kind of regular spacing of layers when we look in some other directions although there are hints of it in others. It's certain that we're seeing interesting structure of some kind at great distances."
By taking core samples of the universe in several different directions, Dr. Koo and other scientists hope eventually to build up a greatly improved picture of the universe's large-scale structure. This they believe will help explain how galaxies evolved from the earliest epic of the universe to the present.
However Dr. Koo's project turns out, optical fiber devices like Argus clearly have a great future in astronomy. "This has given astronomers a powerful time-saver certain to hasten the pace of discovery," said Dr. Mark M. Phillips, acting director of the observatory.

HEADLINE: PERIPHERALS;
Computing The Means To Enjoy Retirement

BYLINE: By L. R. SHANNON

 BODY:
RETIRE ASAP is described as software for baby boomers, a financial planning program in a box. You tell it how you are doing now, and it tells you what you have to do to enjoy a comfortable retirement.
Unlike other financial planning programs, Retire ASAP deals strictly with retirement; it will not balance a checkbook or figure the interest on a loan. Elizabeth Kernan, the president of Calypso Software of Redmond, Wash., the publisher, is a graduate of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
 The opening screen is a map of the program's five main sections: Personal Information, Retirement, Current Retirement Situation, The Bottom Line and Once You Retire. The first time, the program guides you through the first four sections, asking for information like income, investments and expenses. It would be well to have pay stubs and other receipts and documents handy, although estimates may serve. The program itself must make educated guesses to calculate, for instance, estimated Social Security benefits or the effects of inflation.
The Bottom Line, to let one section of the program stand for the whole, has four subsections, titled Your Savings, Your Investments, Other Things You Can Do and The Next Steps. Each of these subsections leads to sub-subsections. The Your Investments category, to pick one, is divided into Your Current Investment Mix, A Proposed Investment Mix and Comparing Investment Mix. Just as with any other spreadsheet, investment mixes can be experimented with to see what combination yields the best theoretical return, balanced against a level of risk that will not give you the jitters. In addition, the program has a What If screen for experimenting with up to 10 different retirement scenarios.
Aside from the five sections that are the heart of Retire ASAP, there are two informational features. One is the ABC's of Investing, a primer for those of us who are not quite sure what a bond is. The other is a list of helpful resources, with descriptions, from the 800 number for the Social Security Administration to recommended business publications to ElderHostel, the travel and educational organization for people 60 and older.
Retire ASAP requires a computer running MS-DOS 3.0 or later, 640 kilobytes of internal memory and at least two megabytes of space on a hard disk. A mouse is optional. The telephone number for more information, or for ordering, at $99, is (800) 225-8246.
 
Dream Houses
 Now that a comfortable retirement is assured, it is time to build a snug hideaway, or remodel the present one. Floorplan Plus, from ComputerEasy of Tempe, Ariz., makes such projects straightforward, if not exactly easy.
Floorplan Plus occupies the middle ground between drawing programs, which are relatively inexpensive and can be used to draw anything but are generic, and CAD (Computer-Aided Design) programs, which are expensive and intended for engineers, architects and other professionals and can be tailored for specific tasks.
With Floorplan Plus, you can draw walls, wires and pipes, lines, circles and other geometric shapes by selecting them from menus, in either the metric or American scales. Representations of furniture, appliances, landscaping and more can be placed on the screen, moved and flipped, and, when things are finally right, printed out on any standard printer. You can also draw your own objects. It all works, Windows-style, from a screen with options along the top and tools along the left side although the program will not in fact work with Microsoft Windows. (They both want to take over a computer's basic functions.)
At first I was put off by the manual, which plunges into the details of the program with little preamble. But back on page 59, there is an 11-page tutorial that guides the beginner with a lesson on drawing a simple floor plan. After you understand the basics of the program, turn to chapter 10.
Working out the details of a floor plan before actually moving any furniture or knocking out walls is the most obvious use. But, according to the company, the program is used by caterers to present proposed layouts of tables and chairs to clients, by fire departments to record the location of sprinkler valves and even by a sea captain as a guide for loading crates. Anyone whose job involves planning or presenting a space containing objects could probably find a use for it. It can handle scale models of structures as large as 5,200 feet by 5,200 feet and is said to be accurate to a sixteenth of an inch.
Floorplan Plus is for computers running DOS 3.0 or later with 640 kilobytes of memory and a hard drive with three megabytes of free space. A mouse is not essential, but things are easier with one, and expanded memory will be used if available. It is $79.95, and is available at many software outlets or directly from ComputerEasy at (800) 522-3279.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: TV SPORTS;
As the Mets Turn: Plot Heats Up

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
The Mets were a bad television program in 1991, a 161-episode flop. As a soap opera, they were dishwater dull. As a sitcom, they were humorless.
So in came the new executive producer, Al Harazin, trying to be the Brandon Tartikoff of baseball, turning around his series as Tartikoff overhauled NBC's prime-time schedule. He has brought in new cast members like Barry Bonilla, Bret Saberhagen and Eddie Murray to complement Doc Gooden and Howard Johnson. 
 Bonilla and Saberhagen are hot players who jump off the screen. (O.K., maybe they're not as hunk-hot as Luke Perry of "Beverly Hills, 90210," but they're still generously heated.) Bronx-born Bonilla brings his electric smile, his 101 runs batted in and his playoff experience. Saberhagen's white-hot intensity is icing on his two Cy Young awards and one no-hitter.
Calling the games should be less wearing for the WWOR and SportsChannel crews. "I try not to get caught up in the success or lack of success of the team," said WWOR's Tim McCarver, "but I'll probably have more fun because you talk and project more positively when the team wins."
McCarver said the Mets of the past few years evinced little joy -- a baseball and television sin exacerbated by losing more games in 1991 (84) than they won (77). "They appeared to have little animation or movement or joy," McCarver said. "But Bonilla is an entertainer. He loves to play. And Saberhagen is joyful."
By being in two straight National League playoff series, Bonilla is a more renowned player-performer than Saberhagen, whose best-known television moment may have been when he sat on the bench during the 1985 World Series, patting his stomach for the cameras to signify the impending birth of his child.
Paul Splittorff, the Royals' announcer, said Saberhagen won't disappoint. "He wants to create a mismatch with every hitter," he said. "He wants to dominate."
If Bonilla and Saberhagen key a Mets revival, the results will show in WWOR's and SportsChannel's advertising and ratings. Not that the Mets telecasts have repelled sponsors, but an improved on-screen product that rebounds from, for example, last year's 14 percent ratings dip at WWOR, could attract more commercial cash despite the current advertising recession.
"The advertisers who were indifferent before are accelerating their commitments to Mets baseball, short and long term," said Tom Ryan, vice president and general sales manager of WWOR.
Mike Siegel, senior vice president of Vitt Media International, a buyer of television advertising time, said, "Advertisers will probably look less for cuts in pricing and accept some kind of increase," from WWOR and SportsChannel.
"I'd think it will also have the effect of driving down Yankees prices," he added. "Actual audience deliveries on Mets games will be tempered with optimism."
 
What Vincent Meant
 Clarification: Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent did not question CBS's and ESPN's honesty regarding losses on their television deals during baseball's winter meetings last week, as this column described his remarks to the owners last Friday. Vincent said their red-ink blues might be real, but were balanced by other concerns.
For CBS, baseball's benefit is in "maintaining affiliate relations and network integrity," which he said outweighs the effect of the losses. For ESPN, it was "to dominate cable programming throughout the summer."
The closest analysis of Vincent's speech does not alter the fact that CBS and ESPN officials are steamed at how he boldly chastised them, and how he cavalierly said about baseball's effect on ESPN, "There are only so many tractor pulls and billiard matches you can televise."
Vincent is angry at CBS's and ESPN's complaints about their losses and a paucity of CBS baseball on-air promotion. The most critical network executive of all about the CBS deal has been Dick Ebersol, the president of NBC Sports, which was overbid by $400 million for the baseball rights.
CBS and ESPN's losses effectively devalue what will likely be paid for baseball rights when their deals expire after the 1993 season, hardly sweet music to Vincent.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
A Solution For McRae Vs. N.C.A.A.

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
ALL we need in order to understand that lumbering ox called the National Collegiate Athletic Association is to observe how it has handled the case of Conrad McRae, a lengthy junior at Syracuse University.
McRae is more visible than most Syracuse students because, first, he stands 6 feet 10 inches; second, he is often seen before crowds of 20,000 at the Carrier Dome as the center on the school basketball team, and, finally, he has recently been the center of a legal battle that puts the whole absurd world of college big-time sports in focus. 
 The N.C.A.A. earlier this year charged that Syracuse improperly recruited McRae when he was a high school student at Brooklyn Tech. It said that he was fed illegally by Syracuse coaches -- that is, taken to off-campus food emporiums, and that he rode in a car to Syracuse with an unofficial representative of the university, and got tickets to the school's basketball games. The fact that McRae, as a high school student, spent $20 for gas and tickets on each of several trips was taken by the N.C.A.A. as payments "well below market value."
Of course he should have paid more, $22.50, or $32.95, or something, since we all know what inflation has done to the cheeseburger and the bleacher ticket. All of this was brought out by Syracuse University itself recently, but only after a local newspaper had published reports of nefarious dealings that included enticing large people like McRae to attend its pedagogical paradise.
Now, the N.C.A.A., a monster organization that was devised to oversee that all of the hundreds of member schools woo the high school athlete fairly, says the business with McRae gave Syracuse a substantial recruiting advantage. The way to rectify it, it figured, is to penalize the school by not allowing McRae to play for it.
The catch here is that McRae will be penalized, too, even though, as the N.C.A.A. says, he was an unwitting participant in the violation. The N.C.A.A. ruled, however, that McRae could transfer to another school and play basketball there immediately, rather than sit out a year as an ordinary transfer would.
As a result, McRae is suing the university and the N.C.A.A. (the university, to stay within the confines of the N.C.A.A., went along reluctantly). McRae thinks this is a loutish idea because, as The New York Times reported last Saturday: "I want to graduate from Syracuse University. I'm a communications major. We have one of the best schools of communication in the country."
McRae, who is scheduled to graduate with his class after four years of undergraduate work, added: "The N.C.A.A. always complains about athletes wanting to transfer because their coach is leaving, or for some other reason related to sports. They say you go to school because you want a degree, not because of the coach. So I find it kind of ironic that these same people want me to leave school in midsemester, interrupt my academic schedule, the friendships I've built. Then they say they're doing me a favor because I can play basketball right away."
Either this guy has better speechwriters than President Bush, or he is so well-spoken, and so thoughtful as to be a credit to his school. And if that is the case, he honors them in a way that they have not honored him in this suit.
Meanwhile, the N.C.A.A. and Syracuse and McRae are in and out of courts, dealing with injunctions and restraining orders, and McRae has played and not played this season depending on the most recent court decision.
The N.C.A.A., glued to its book overflowing with rules and regulations, should be more concerned with the education of the individual student than the rampant idiocies of big-time college sports.
Big-time college sports is professional sports, and few besides the N.C.A.A. even pretend it is amateur. The only thing amateur about it is the N.C.A.A. itself.
One solution for the clanking N.C.A.A. would be to dissolve itself, like the Soviet Union, and then let all of its members fend for themselves in their separate little commonwealths, or conferences. Short of that, it should at least allow McRae peace. Let him finish his schooling and his basketballing at Syracuse, and then if the N.C.A.A. is still itching for action against a school like Syracuse, punish it in another way: after all of its current recruits play out their eligibility, remove varsity basketball for the next 15 years or so. No problem.
The N.C.A.A. would then release this statement: "Basketball should be confined on campus to intramurals anyway, or at least to the level played, say, in Division II. We'll leave the rest to the National Basketball Association. Happy holidays."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Conrad McRae (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Albany Junk Mail Flows On Like the Hudson

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is almost laughable, the picture you paint in "El Al D'Amato" (Topics of The Times, Dec. 4) of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato feeding twice at the franking trough from 35,000 feet aloft. Aboard an El Al plane returning from a look-see mission during the Iraqi war, he had the political sensitivity to draft one letter to his Jewish constituents and a different one to the rest. It's a long flight, after all. Both were mailed at public expense. 
 The franking privilege lives in Albany, too, although perhaps not so finely targeted. Last week I received a handsome two-color booklet summarizing the New York law of tenants' rights, with a state senator featured on the cover as the sender. This familiar political junk mail hit a very flat note this time.
Last September, the New York City administration laid me off from a revenue-generating managerial position, where I was promoting economic development and job creation. For budget reasons -- and remember that an important part of the city's budget comes from the state -- I was cashiered along with 31 colleagues. So, with the city facing double-digit unemployment, at a time when its economic development efforts should be redoubled, it is dismissing people like me, while its sovereign in Albany pleads penury.
But the junk mail flows on down as inexorably as the Hudson.
You don't have to be a wise man in this season to be frankincensed by your mail. I guess it's too much to expect our legislators, with their formidable electoral advantages of incumbency, to ban their own mailing privileges. In some states, however, government publications are required by law to bear a legend stating how many copies were printed and distributed and at what public cost.
If our New York State legislators would adopt that simple reform, we would all be in a better position to exercise our voters' rights next November.
 
JOHN H. STEINBERG
New York, Dec. 6, 1991

HEADLINE: Russians Really Need Management Help

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Right before leaving for Kennedy Airport to catch my Aeroflot flight home to Moscow, I read "Help Russia Now" by Anders Aslund and Richard Layard (Op-Ed, Dec. 5). I hope this article influences those who can help in ruble stabilization. The matter is of utmost importance: the unstable Russian economy will undoubtedly lead to political upheaval and send waves around the world. But a growing Russian economy, with markets open to Western trade and employment, will stimulate Western economies. Western help now will reap great dividends in the nearest future. 
 Ruble stabilization is most important, yet other assistance is urgently needed. Though money, food and machinery will bring temporary relief, our main illness is the lack of management mechanism. Centrally directed methods of management have been given up, but the market mechanism has not been adopted. Western economists have tried to help us organize the market mechanism. The advice was right: free prices, give a free hand to business activity, privatize state property. Unfortunately, we were unable to carry it out.
Can a Soviet plant director, who has never worked under market conditions, turn into an active businessman instantly? Can a Soviet banker, who for years worked under orders, become a market follower in days or months? Our tragedy is that we have almost nobody to replace these people, and there is no time to wait for a new generation to grow up.
The best way then to help Russia (once the ruble is stabilized) is to send American manager-consultants to the large plants of Russia. They could help reorient each plant to market operation and at the same time train Soviet managers and give them basic knowledge of management under market conditions.
These managers should be supplied by an agency created specifically for the purpose. The agency can be financed from the resources of the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, by private investors and from Russian resources. The best human resources for such an agency would be Soviet emigres who know the language, traditions and customs of our country and are well versed in free enterprise by now.
 
VLADIMIR I. MAYEVSKY
New York, Dec. 10, 1991
 
The writer is a professor at Moscow State University and a department head at the Institute of Economics.

HEADLINE: Bush Wisely Goes Slow on Economic Change

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The day after the election of 1988, President Bush met the press and recalled the name of Martin Van Buren, the last sitting Vice President to be elected to the Presidency 152 years before. The recollection was somewhat ominous, since Van Buren was a one-term President, defeated in his bid for re-election by the inferior William Henry Harrison. Van Buren is rated by some competent judges as one of our cleverest and best chief executives. Certainly, his autobiography is a most remarkable document in American political history. 
 The reason for recalling this now is that during Van Buren's term of office, in 1837, the United States suffered what is described as its first major economic depression, and the way he handled it (or refrained from doing so) may be instructive for a successor. There were urgent calls for a special session of Congress, which he opposed but was finally persuaded to convene. The papers were filled with the most pathetic stories of human suffering, and the pundits of the day called for peremptory action to plan the nation's future instead of harking back to its glorious past.
Van Buren refused to be stampeded by the sentimentalists into mindless action. In the message he sent to Congress, he described the primary cause of the economic disturbance as "a spirit of reckless speculation," which had resulted in "the rapid growth among all classes, and especially in our great commercial towns, of luxurious habits, founded too often upon merely fancied wealth."
Van Buren stated that "those who look to this Government for specific aid lose sight of the ends for which it was created, and the powers with which it is clothed." He continued: "It was not intended to confer special favors on individuals or on any classes of them. All communities are apt to look to Government for too much, especially at periods of sudden embarrassment or distress. But the framers of our excellent constitution acted on a sounder principle. They wisely judged that the less Government interferes with private pursuits the better for general prosperity."
Holmes Alexander, biographer of Van Buren, calls this message "one of the most admirable state documents ever penned in America," comparable to Washington's Farewell Address and the Monroe Doctrine.
Yet when President Bush takes a similar stance and speaks of reliance on the natural rhythms of economic activity to restore our business health, he is mocked by Op-Ed wiseacres, who know no more about the problem or how to solve it than anyone else does, and perhaps less. Though Van Buren's course was not calculated to lead to political success, it has contributed to his historical reputation as one of the rare persons ever to reach high office who preferred being right to the Presidency.
Is it too much to suggest that Mr. Bush and modern Republicans might do worse than heed the traditional wisdom and principles of their party, as voiced by the great Democrat Van Buren, so much needed nowadays to counterbalance the conventional cant of the age of the welfare-state? How ironic it would be if the socialism increasingly rejected by the rest of the world found an unexpected home here!
 
MILTON HINDUS
Newton Centre, Mass., Dec. 2, 1991
 
The writer retired as Edytha Macy Gross Professor of Humanities at Brandeis University.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Letter From Moscow

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL; Russell Baker is on vacation.

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Every day here is so full of fear and hope, rising and fading, so many startling things happen so erratically, the present is so taut and the future so murky that life sometimes seems like the day itself -- cold, fogged over, too suddenly dark.
The city and its people seemed hard and remote at first. Then I remembered the habit I had as a foreign correspondent -- trying to jump out of the limitations of my own head by thinking local. So I practice thinking like a Russian -- not masses of Russians but just one, say a teacher in a high school. 
 As a Russian, I tell you my gorge is rising and my half-empty belly fills itself with anger. Yes, part of my anger comes from the lines, lines, lines. They make me feel grungy and poor and abused every day of my life. But I know I won't starve and I am tough. The deeper part of my anger comes from something else.
I am an educated man, a cultured man. But they -- Yeltsin, Gorbachev, all of them, they insult me every day. They don't tell me what is happening to me and my country.
Who runs this new thing, this union? What is its name and what will it be called next week? Who makes the laws? Are there laws?
Next week, what will I have to pay for bread? For a dress for my little daughter, if I can find one in the street market? What will I be paid for my job? Will I have a job? If not, who will feed my family, in Heaven's name?
Glasnost! Now it means telling me what they have decided. I thought it meant telling me beforehand, asking what I thought of a plan. But there is no plan, just decisions. I see these men on TV sometimes talking to journalists, but never to me straight on. They are acting already like the arrogant Communist czars they were just yesterday.
Never mind; I will hold on a while. I am a Russian, tough. Even the Germans were afraid of us. I know what freedom means; what fool doesn't? The world thinks I will turn to fascism unless I get some hope. No, not I, or my friends. But others will, the army generals, the K.G.B. officers, ready and waiting.
Yeltsin, or whoever, must hurry up and tell us what they plan for us, and maybe even ask our opinion. If not, they will be finished and so will our dreams. But I have hopes; things will get better, I am sure, I think.
Now I am back in my own, American, head. I check my thoughts with some real Russian heads. They say that's about the way it is; no great Moscow mysteries anymore.
Outside, the West cries doom for this place. I find myself believing Russia can pull it off, so can the Ukraine and most other republics.
There will be trouble, maybe shooting someplace. But nothing except fascism can match Communism for cruelty, criminal waste and murder.
True, fascists are waiting. But they can be blocked -- by Boris Yeltsin, if he has the courage, and by the U.S. Mr. Yeltsin's job is to come out fighting against the Russian fascists. He has to take them on as he did Mikhail Gorbachev, but he seems afraid of them, as Mr. Gorbachev was himself.
So far he has been mealy-mouthed about Pamyat, the Russian fascist organization, and never seems to notice that army funds finance some of the anti-Semitic propaganda, Hitlerian filth.
President Bush can help prevent a fascist takeover by announcing now that the U.S. will do everything possible politically and economically to destroy it -- including denying any republic's putsch government a seat at the U.N.
If fascism is fought in advance, the road should lead up. Why not? The republics could be sleek with meat, grain, oil, gold, timber when their riches no longer lie rotting in the genetic corruption of Communist production and distribution. The system could deliver military shuttles to space but not milk to children 50 miles from the farm.
In Moscow these days it seems so grievously past time that the U.S. stops seeing the end of the Soviet Union as an unknowable threat but as a reward to the people for decades of known suffering.
From what the Bush Administration is saying and doing now, maybe that is taking hold in Washington. I certainly pray so, as an American, and also my Russian head.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Synagogues Found Unemployment Nearby

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Dec. 7 front-page report that 8.5 million Americans are unemployed is painful news. It is even more distressing for New Yorkers, with a rate higher than the national average and more than 440,000 jobs lost in this state in the last two years. 
 To alleviate some suffering, the New York Board of Rabbis asked its 800 members to announce the establishment of a job bank for unemployed congregants. The announcement was made on Yom Kippur in many synagogues.
As of Dec. 1, 290 unemployed congregants requested help in finding jobs. The list includes doctors of philosophy, lawyers, engineers, certified public accountants, middle-management personnel, computer experts, secretaries. Sadly, only 22 job opportunities were brought to our attention. We prepared a letter and circulated it among our membership to make some matchups.
Thus far we have succeeded with a few, but the odds are staggering, and we are frustrated.
How long will it take for our Government to address the plight of the unemployed before the human tragedy that they bespeak overwhelms us all?
 
(Rabbi) MYRON M. FENSTER
(Rabbi) GILBERT S. ROSENTHAL
New York, Dec. 9, 1991
 
The writers are, respectively, president and executive vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis.

HEADLINE: Bush Wisely Goes Slow on Economic Change;
His Failures Abroad

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We must dispel the myth that George Bush has been exemplary in his conduct of United States foreign policy, which you repeat in "The Partial President" (editorial, Nov. 24). In reality, his foreign policy has been as disastrous as his domestic policy. 
 A successful foreign policy would be marked by avoidance of wars through peaceful resolution of international problems. This would require the skillful use of diplomacy, nowhere evident in the Reagan or Bush Administrations.
Since 1981, under Ronald Reagan and George Bush, the United States has been largely responsible for the deaths of hundreds of thousands through participating in and supporting wars in Nicaragua, El Salvador, Angola, Afghanistan, Iran, Lebanon, Grenada, Panama, Libya and Iraq.
The Persian Gulf war was the ultimate outrage. For years we had supported Iraq, providing Saddam Hussein with arms and intelligence. In 1988 we blocked a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Iraq's use of chemical warfare. Yet when George Bush believed it was in his interest, he manipulated the Security Council into supporting his brutal war in the gulf.
Mr. Bush eschewed all diplomatic means to achieve a peaceful resolution, including the efforts of Mikhail S. Gorbachev. When Saddam Hussein unconditionally released all his foreign hostages as part of his secret offer to end the gulf crisis, Mr. Bush's response was merely that now it would be easier for him (one less obstacle) to use force against Iraq.
There are countless victims in the world still suffering from what you term the "shrewdness, energy and values" of the Bush foreign policy. Let us hope that he will not have the opportunity to transfer these traits to his domestic policy. There has been no compassion evident in the Bush Presidency.
 
VIRGINIA G. CIOCCO
New York, Nov. 29, 1991

DANIEL H. WOLF
San Diego, Dec. 1, 1991
