HEADLINE: U.N. Repeals Its '75 Resolution Equating Zionism With Racism

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to revoke the bitterly contested statement it approved in 1975 that said "Zionism is a form of racism and racial discrimination."
 The official count found 111 nations in favor of repealing the statement and 25 nations, mostly Islamic and hard-line Communists, voting against. Thirteen nations abstained. Seventeen other countries, including Egypt, which recognizes Israel, and Kuwait and China, did not take part in the voting. [Roll-call, page A12.] 
For the United States, the heavy vote in favor of repeal was a demonstration of its diplomatic power. After President Bush called for the repeal in September in a speech to the General Assembly, United States embassies around the world were instructed to put maximum pressure to secure the repeal. The 111 votes recorded today were about 11 more than the United States mission to the United Nations had predicted last week.
 The vote reflected the shifting political currents of recent years, the Persian Gulf war in particular, which split the Arab and Islamic worlds, and the changes in the former Soviet bloc, fostered by the collapse of Communism.
 In 1975, in an effort to curry favor with the Arabs and embarrass the United States, Moscow took the lead in pushing through the statement on Zionism, which was one line in a longer resolution.
 With the end of Communism in Europe, countries there have by and large all re-established diplomatic relations with Israel in the last year. The Soviet Union and the rest of the former bloc, including newly independent Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, all voted for repeal today. The only Communist countries voting against repeal were Cuba, North Korea and Vietnam.
 
Asians and Africans Back Vote
 Many Asian and African nations, including India, Nigeria, Singapore and the Philippines, which voted for the Zionism resolution in 1975, reversed themselves today.
 The vote divided the Islamic and former nonaligned movements. While no Arab country voted for repeal, Bahrain, Egypt, Kuwait, Morocco, Oman and Tunisia all were absent from the vote. Algeria, Iran, Iraq, Jordan, Lebanon, Libya, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Syria, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen were among those voting against repeal. But there was no indication that those Arabs voting against repeal made much of an effort to persuade other states not to go along with the United States initiative.
 The one-line resolution repealing the Zionism statement declared that the Assembly "decides to revoke the determination contained in its resolution 3379 of 10 November 1975." It did not use the words "Zionism" or "racism" in the resolution.
 
Applause for Vote
 The 1975 statement referred to in the repeal decision said that after reviewing other international resolutions linking Zionism with South Africa's apartheid system, the General Assembly "determines that Zionism is a form of racism and racial discrimination."
Applause broke out in the General Assembly as the result flashed on the big electronic voting board high on one side of the hall. And delegates leapt up from their seats and rushed to congratulate Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, who led his country's delegation at the session.
 At a news conference later, Mr. Levy described the vote as "removing a terrible blot" and said the world community was "sobering up," with many countries "shifting their positions."
 A total of 85 countries, or just more than half of the 166 members in the United Nations, co-sponsored the repeal resolution, including the Soviet Union and all its former communist allies in Eastern Europe that voted the other way in 1975. The outcome was also at the high end of American expectations. On Friday, United States officials were predicting a maximum of just more than 100 votes for repeal but warning that there could be a 20 percent margin of error.
 
Enhancing the U.N.
 Both the United States and the spokesmen for the Arab countries voting against repeal saw the vote as important for both the credibility of the United Nations and for the Middle East peace talks. And their addresses drew loud applause from delegates.
 Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, who led the American delegation at this afternoon's session, argued that repeal would bring the United Nations better into line with the realities of the post-cold-war world.
 Equating Zionism with racism, Mr. Eagleburger said, "demonstrated like nothing else before or since, to what extent the cold war had distorted the United Nation's vision of reality, marginalized its political utility and separated it from its original moral purpose."
 Repeal, he said, could "only help and not hinder efforts currently under way" to bring peace to the Middle East, removing a 16-year-old obstacle to the United Nations' playing a more significant role in the peace process.
 
The Arabs' Voice
 Speaking against repeal on behalf of the Arabs, Lebanon's representative, Khalil Makkawi, warned that it would hinder the peace process by whetting the appetite of "Israeli extremists wishing to pursue their policy of creeping annexation."
 It would also, he went on, "fuel the passions" of those Arabs "who believe the whole peace process is an exercise in futility which gives Israel more time to expand and achieve its revisionist Zionist project."
 But he said the Arab group "will revise its assumptions" if the sponsors of today's repeal motion can now persuade Israel to comply with the Security Council's demands that it cede occupied Arab lands in return for peace.
In a further sign of the discomfort that the repeal has caused the Islamic world, today's session was presided over by the United Nations representative from Honduras, Roberto Flores Bermudez, rather than by the world organization's president, Samir S. Shihabi of Saudi Arabia, who is of Palestinian origin and who was present for the morning session today.
 
Furor in September
In September he caused a stir by leaving the podium when Israel's Foreign Minister addressed the General Assembly.
 The 1975 resolution on Zionism was approved in a smaller General Assembly, with 72 countries voting in favor, 35 against and 32 abstaining. Three countries did not take part in the vote.
 Apart from the Soviet Union and its former East European allies, countries that switched their votes from support for that resolution to support for repeal included Brazil, India, Mexico, Nigeria and Yugoslavia.
 Those that have now voted twice in favor of equating Zionism and racism include Afghanistan, Pakistan, Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Algeria, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Iran and Iraq.
 In seeking support for repeal, the United States and its Western allies have used a variety of arguments to persuade wavering countries to join their camp, diplomats say, many of them based on a belief that today's vote would increase the pressure on Israel to compromise in the American-sponsored Middle East peace talks.
 All argued that Resolution 3379 was out of date because it was a product of the cold war, pushed forward by the old Soviet Union and embraced by a militant third-world nations that saw the United Nations as a forum for attacking capitalism and propounding a new economic order that would redistribute wealth from rich to poor.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 18, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the repeal of a United Nations resolution equating Zionism with racism misstated the vote of the Philippines and Singapore when the resolution was adopted in 1975. Both countries abstained.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1536 words

HEADLINE: California Plan to Cut Welfare May Prompt Others to Follow

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
All year it has been simmering: a movement to pay welfare mothers less and change their behavior through financial threats and rewards.
It came to a boil last week when Gov. Pete Wilson of California proposed to cut welfare grants by as much as 25 percent, tie teen-age mothers' grants to their school attendance and refuse extra money for additional children. 
 Governor Wilson, a Republican, pledged to put his plan, pointedly labeled the "Taxpayers Protection Act," before the voters in a referendum next November. Both of California's Senate seats will be up for grabs on the November ballot as well as the state's huge block of electoral college votes. By placing the welfare issue at political center stage at a time of public anger, California could prompt an anti-welfare movement as potent as the anti-tax rebellion it set off with the Proposition 13 tax-limiting referendum in 1978.
"This could be the Willie Horton issue of 1992," said Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University, who argued that the attack on welfare reflected anger over all kinds of social ills, from teen-age pregnancy to drugs to crime.
"It's going to force all the Presidential candidates to address welfare and its related problems," Mr. Mead said.
By dint of California's size -- it has almost twice as many welfare recipients as any other state -- and its extraordinary political influence, its plan could unravel a decade of political consensus-building that had culminated in a 1988 law that is just now being carried out.
That law, the Family Support Act, sought a new compact with welfare recipients: it promised to give them more training, day care for their children and medical insurance, while imposing new requirements that they seek an education or a job.
Last week, aides to Governor Wilson appropriated the language of that movement, speaking of new "tools to achieve self-sufficiency." But most of what they offered was just less money.
Exchanging his usual professorial air for a mixture of glumness and anger, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the author of the Family Support Act, said there was "very much a consensus" among state and Federal welfare officials in writing the act. The New York Democrat promised to summon state welfare officials from across the country for an explanation about their planned cuts. "That's why I'm going to hold hearings and say, 'Why did you change your minds?' " he said.
 
Twin Pressures on States
 The Federal Government and the states share the costs of the welfare program, whose official title is Aid to Families With Dependent Children, with the Federal Government assuming a larger portion in poorer states. The economic slump has reduced states' revenues while swelling the number of people seeking services. Looking to trim expenses, 16 states have cut A.F.D.C. payments, tightened eligibility, or both. Six states have cut the general assistance grants, which go to single adults, and a seventh, Michigan, has virtually eliminated its general assistance program.
Some states also have proposals to change behavior, with programs dubbed Workfare, Learnfare and Wedfare. At least four states are considering, or imposing, penalties on parents whose children do not attend school. At least two want to withhold payments for new children and another has proposed cutting welfare payments if parents fail to pay their rent or get their children immunized.
All this comes as attacks on welfare played a prominent role in two Republican campaigns for governor, helping to elect Kirk Fordice in Mississippi and giving State Representative David Duke, the former neo-Nazi and grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, a majority of the white vote in his failed Louisiana bid.
 
The Motives
 The varied motives of this movement are difficult to disentangle since some analysts, looking at the proposals at their best, see a high-minded reassertion of old values and others, viewing the proposals at their worst, see simple racism.
Clearly, the immediate impetus is budgetary. California passed $7 billion in new taxes last year to help meet a $14.3 billion deficit, but already it is facing a shortfall that could reach $8 billion over the next year and a half.
In a speech announcing his plan, Governor Wilson said welfare costs were rising at a rate of almost 12 percent a year and attracting welfare recipients from other states. Without cutting $600 million from welfare, he said, the state would not have the money to keep students in college and criminals off the street.
"That's not fair to the working men and women of California," he said.
Beneath the budget numbers is an anger at a welfare system that has no defenders, only varying degrees of critics. David Ellwood, a professor of public policy at Harvard University, found that more than half the welfare recipients on the rolls at any time will spend more than 10 years there.
But it is not just Democrats who see the gathering of disturbing racial trends.
"I'm a centrist Republican, and to see the cuts so focused on A.F.D.C. is very scary," said Richard Nathan, the provost of the State University of New York at Albany and a former aide in the Nixon White House. "A lot of what they're trying to do involves a turnaround on civil rights and race."
Some proponents of Governor Wilson's proposals argue that the plan will help the poor.
"Cutting the welfare benefit will have a very positive effect on work effort and on the rate of marriage," said Robert Rector, an analyst with the Heritage Foundation, a research organization in Washington. Mr. Rector said he met with Governor Wilson earlier this year and urged the cuts.
 
The Predictions
 More striking, however, were the predictions from analysts like Charles Murray, whose book, "Losing Ground" (Basic Books, 1984), argued that social programs did more harm than good and might simply be abolished.
Mr. Murray said the California plan might deter some pregnancies, and, therefore, reduce future caseloads. But he said he doubted that cuts would push long-term welfare clients into the labor force, arguing that most lacked the needed education and discipline. "Changing work effort is tough," he said.
Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution, a research organization in Washington, agreed, arguing that the cuts would at most reduce the stay of short-term recipients who would leave anyway. "If we're thinking of the underclass mom, we're going to have to do something else," he said.
Others saw only increased misery. "I would not think you're going to change the behavior of a 4-year-old child by feeding it less," Senator Moynihan said.
California had already cut welfare benefits by 4.4 percent last year. Elsewhere, an analysis by Henry Freedman of the Center on Social Welfare Policy and the Law, a New York-based group, found that the District of Columbia cut benefits by 4.5 percent this year; Tennessee by 4 percent; Maryland by 7.1 percent; Michigan by 9.5 percent; Massachusetts by 4.3 percent; Illinois by 8.3 percent, and Vermont by 1 percent.
 
Incentive to Stay in School
 In addition, Mr. Freedman said, Kansas, Arizona, Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Maine, Minnesota, New York, Washington, Virginia and California have tightened eligibility standards.
According to figures from the National Association of State Budget Officers, the average state spends 3.4 percent of its budget on welfare. In January, the median benefit for a family of three was $367 a month. In California, it is $663.
Governor Wilson would cut benefits by 10 percent and add an additional 15 percent cut for anyone failing to leave the rolls within six months.
His plan would give teen-age mothers an additional $50 a month to stay in school and take away $50 if they refused, require teen-age welfare recipients to live with their parents and deny extra money to women who have additional children while on welfare. The average welfare family has two children.
Wisconsin and Ohio are already trying similar school incentives, which they have called Learnfare.
 
Moves in New Jersey
 In New Jersey, Wayne Bryant, a leading Democrat in the Assembly, is pushing a plan that, like California, would deny extra benefits for additional children.
In Maryland, Gov. William Donald Schaefer, a Democrat, has proposed cutting benefits by 30 percent if parents fail to pay the rent, get their children immunized or keep them in school. In Kansas, the Legislature earlier this year rejected a proposal to pay welfare mothers a $500 bonus for using the contraceptive Norplant.
All such plans run risks of unintended consequences. For instance, Mr. Murray, the author, said that denying benefits for additional children could lead to increased abortions.
Critics call the current movement one of politics, not policy. Sheldon Danziger, a public policy professor at the University of Michigan, called the national anger over welfare "a reverse class anger."
"Instead of saying, 'Look at the huge amounts of money the rich made in the 1980s; can we get some of it back in taxes?' " he said, "it's, 'Let's squeeze a little bit of money out of the most impoverished group.' "

HEADLINE: IN SHARP REVERSAL, WHITE HOUSE TELLS OF BLEAK ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Executing an abrupt about-face in response to dismal polls and bad economic news, the White House today abandoned its effort to persuade voters that the economy was recovering and acknowledged that "for all practical purposes, the recession continues."
White House officials said the political reversal was driven by Samuel K. Skinner, President Bush's new chief of staff, who has moved quickly in his first two days on the job to forge a new public relations strategy intended to stop Mr. Bush's political slide as the 1992 Presidential campaign begins. 
 In an interview with a group of reporters, his first since starting his new job, Mr. Skinner also leveled some indirect criticism at the two men who had run the White House staff for nearly three years: his predecessor, John H. Sununu, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director.
 
'People Are Hurting'
 While the Administration has yet to produce a plan for economic recovery, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, indicated that Mr. Bush had decided to stop listening to the conflicting advice from economists and his own advisers and acknowledge what economic indicators, opinion surveys, business executives, workers and Republican political strategists have been telling a reluctant White House for months.
Some advisers are urging the President to propose an income tax cut for the middle class of about $300 a family: good politics but probably bad economics. Others are telling him to ride out the recession: perhaps good economics but terrible politics. By acknowledging today that the country is still mired in economic misery, the White House seemed to be saying that Mr. Bush was inclined to act. [Page D21.]
"People are unemployed," Mr. Fitzwater said. "People are hurting. The economy is very slow. And you can get arguments from the economists, but certainly from any practical standpoint, the recession does continue."
He added, "The people of this country know that the economy is in trouble and it doesn't make any sense to play games."
 
A Far Different Tone
 Concerned that he not paint too gloomy a picture, Mr. Fitzwater later tried to leaven his comments by referring to "a recession kind of situation." But his remarks still represented a major shift for an Administration that had been contending for months that the economy was in a "sluggish" recovery, not in what is technically defined as a recession, and that if Americans would simply be more confident, things would improve.
"I am less interested in what the technical definition is," Mr. Bush said today in an interview with affiliates of ABC News. "People are hurting. When there's this kind of sluggishness and concern -- definitions -- heck with it. Let's get on with the business at hand."
White House aides acknowledge that producing an economic growth package is the President's main challenge. But Mr. Skinner, who began work on Monday and immediately orchestrated a week of events aimed at demonstrating Mr. Bush's concern about the economy, said he also intended to revamp the communications apparatus put in place by Mr. Sununu, who resigned under intense political pressure.
Mr. Skinner made no direct criticism of Mr. Sununu, but his words as he outlined his own management plans -- speaking repeatedly of his "inclusive approach" and the need to "let valued advice get to the President" -- seemed to cast a bad light on his predecessor, since that was his job as well.
Mr. Skinner suggested a less dominant role for Mr. Darman, who has had virtual control over the Administration's domestic policy. Suggesting that Mr. Darman is not necessarily speaking for the President when he testifies on Capitol Hill or negotiates in private with lawmakers, Mr. Skinner said, "Dick Darman is one of those people -- one of the people who will be up there seeking their advice and counsel."
 
'People Are Scared'
 For weeks, some Republican strategists and Administration officials, including Michael J. Boskin, Mr. Bush's chief economist, had been arguing that it was in the Administration's interest to give a more realistic picture of the economy. But Mr. Sununu had insisted on the more positive view and the White House clung to a strategy that sent Mr. Bush on a Thanksgiving weekend shopping trip to J. C. Penney's, where he bought some socks in what was supposed to be an inspiration for ordinary Americans to spend more.
"There's been an ongoing debate between a few people who thought the President could jawbone people into spending money and those who thought that's nonsense," said a senior Republican strategist. "With all due respect, people are scared. The President telling them it's a good time to buy a house doesn't change behavior, and spending 28 bucks on socks didn't start a stampede."
Mr. Fitzwater said his comments on the economy represented a conclusion that this sort of effort, along with the Administration's insistence that things were getting better by themselves, left the White House open to charges that it sounded "Pollyanna-ish" and contributed to public fears about the economy.
"All that does," said Eddie Mahe, a Republican strategist, "is leave a sense of one of two things: either the President's out of touch or he's lying, and neither is acceptable. I think this is a wise, wise, wise repositioning on his part, even if it increases the pressure both generically and specifically on them to do something."
 
A Communications Problem
 Talking with the reporters today, Mr. Skinner also said the White House had a "communications problem."
"It's pretty obvious to me, and I don't fault the media for this, we have not communicated somehow what he's been spending his time on, and what he's been doing has not become apparent," he said.
The White House was reeling today from new opinion polls showing Mr. Bush's approval ratings over all, and especially his handling of the economy, at an all-time low for his Administration. Fourth-quarter figures on the economy are expected to be disappointing and the chairman of the Federal Reserve has warned, in what Mr. Fitzwater called a "sobering" statement, that lower interest rates, on which Mr. Bush has been counting heavily to pump up the economy, will not accomplish that alone.
At the same time, a wide range of economists told the House Ways and Means Committee today that a quick tax cut would do more harm than good to the economy.
The Democrats, who have made attacks on Mr. Bush's inaction on the economy the centerpiece of their 1992 strategy, produced a news release today that listed quotations from Mr. Bush on the prospects for recovery next to similar quotations from President Herbert Hoover, whose legacy the Republicans have struggled for decades to shed.
In response to these pressures, Mr. Bush took part in several events this week intended to demonstrate that he is concerned about the economy and to meet the new challenge to his re-election in 1992.
The White House permitted reporters today to photograph Mr. Bush meeting with Mr. Darman and Mr. Boskin, a meeting that is normally closed. On Wednesday, Mr. Bush plans to fly to Texas, where he will sign a new transportation bill at a Texas highway project to make the point that the bill will create new jobs.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
YELTSIN REBUFFED BY ASIAN REPUBLIC ON NUCLEAR ARMS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMA-ATA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The President of this Central Asian republic made it clear today that in advance of negotiations with Russia and other republics on the details of the new commonwealth, he was not ready to cede any advantages to the larger, more powerful Russian republic.
Speaking to reporters accompanying Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on a visit here, the President of Kazakhstan, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, took issue with the comments made on Monday by the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, that eventually all Soviet republics would eliminate nuclear weapons except Russia. Mr. Nazarbayev declared today that Kazakhstan would retain its nuclear missiles as long as Russia did. 
 He and his spokesmen said that their republic would be prepared to put its nuclear missiles, together with those of Russia and other republics, under a unified command of the new commonwealth that would succeed the Soviet Union, but that Kazakhstan would not disarm unilaterally before Russia.
 
'We Will Keep Some'
 "If Russia keeps some nuclear weapons, we will keep some," said the spokesman, Seitcazy Mataev. Otherwise, "we want common control."
Kazakh officials also said they intended to seek a seat in the United Nations eventually and would not automatically go along with the idea that Russia would assume the Soviet seat on the Security Council -- as Mr. Yeltsin also suggested. Kazakh officials said this question would have to be discussed by the leadership of the new commonwealth, which might collectively fill the Council seat.
The leaders of the republics that have decided to join the new commonwealth are to convene on Saturday in this snowbound city nestled at the foot of the Tian Shan Mountains, near the border with China. President Nazarbayev told Mr. Baker that they would sign a new accord to replace the one agreed to nine days ago by Russia, Byelorussia and Ukraine.
The new arrangement is to be called the Commonwealth of Euro-Asian Independent States, they said.
While none of the apparent differences between Kazakhstan and Russia are insurmountable, they nevertheless gave Mr. Baker a firsthand taste of how difficult it might be for the new commonwealth to develop a coherent foreign policy. It also highlighted just how unfinished are some of the commonwealth's basic political and security arrangements.
Mr. Baker flew from Moscow this morning to visit Bishkek, formerly known as Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia, and then on to Kazakhstan. Both Central Asian republics are led by pro-American Presidents ready to adopt free-market economics. By going out of his way to visit them both, Mr. Baker was trying to signal all other republics that these are the sort of models they should follow.
President Nazarbayev told Mr. Baker that Armenia and the three original commonwealth members -- Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia -- would join the five Central Asian republics at the meeting here on Saturday.
 
Equal Membership Demanded
 The Central Asian republics -- Kirghizia, Kazakhstan, Tadzhikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenia -- insist they will not join the commonwealth as second-class members, said Mr. Mataev, Mr. Nazarbayev's spokesman. They want the commonwealth to be recast with them as founding members. "We are going to join as full members with equal rights," said Mr. Mataev.
Therefore, he said, a new agreement will be signed on Saturday forming the Commonwealth of Euro-Asian Independent States, and at this meeting the fundamental questions, including long-term nuclear controls and the United Nations seat, will be sorted out.
On Monday, President Yeltsin said at a news conference with Mr. Baker in the Kremlin that he expected that the three republics besides Russia that have long-range nuclear missiles -- Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Byelorussia -- would agree to a system of joint control in the short run. In the long run, he said, the three will "eliminate" all of their nuclear missiles and leave Russia the sole nuclear power, succeeding the Soviet Union.
President Nazarbayev, in a news conference with Mr. Baker after their talks today, said he endorsed the idea of four-republic control but would not endorse the idea that Kazakhstan, which has roughly 100 intercontinental ballistic missiles, as well as the leading missile test site in the Soviet Union, eliminate its nuclear weapons while Russia remained a nuclear power.
American officials said today that it was their understanding that a defense council would be formed by the new commonwealth members, with Gen. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, the current Defense Minister of the Soviet Union, as its head.
Mr. Baker declined to be drawn into the question of which republics would retain nuclear weapons, but he said that after his discussions with Mr. Nazarbayev, he was reassured that tight controls would be maintained. Mr. Baker has been presenting various American ideas of how nuclear missiles might best be kept in check during the period of transition. Asked whether he was urging the republics with nuclear weapons to change the targeting of their missiles so that they would no longer be pointed at the United States, Mr. Baker dodged the question, saying he did not want to go into detail about his suggestions.
 
Kazakhs Seek U.S. Recognition
 Mr. Baker said Kazakhstan, which formally declared its independence on Monday, had joined Ukraine and Russia in seeking American recognition. He said President Bush would consider this appeal after he saw how Kazakhstan handled the nuclear issue, as well as human rights questions, its adherence to outstanding treaty obligations and its assumption of responsibility for its share of the foreign debt of the former Soviet Union. The same principles will apply to the other republics, Mr. Baker said.
Mr. Nazarbayev, once one of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's closest supporters, left little doubt that he felt he was finished.
"I think President Gorbachev is a historic figure," he said, "and from the beginning to the very end I supported all of his efforts in the area of perestroika, and as far as I know no other leaders of any of the other republics have anything bad to say about Mr. Gorbachev. Whether he plays any role in the new commonwealth, that is strictly up to Mr. Gorbachev."
In Kirghizia, the Secretary of State's first stop today, Mr. Baker met with President Askar A. Akayev, who also indicated that he thought Mr. Gorbachev's days were numbered.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
Soviets Say Arms Scuttling Will Take 10 Years

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 17

 BODY:
A top official of the Soviet nuclear-arms complex said today that destruction of Moscow's short-range weapons would cost $2 billion and take 10 years.
He also said that a pledged $400 million in American aid for that effort should be used to build one of two storage sites for materials from retired warheads and that that center should be under "joint control" with Washington. 
 The remarks appeared to be the most detailed exposition to date of how Moscow wants to use the American money. The official, Viktor N. Mikhailov, directs the defense programs of the Ministry of Atomic Power and Industry, which designs and makes Moscow's nuclear arms. He spoke today to a delegation of 14 American weapon experts here to discuss the technical aspects of warhead dismantlement.
"This is an urgent, urgent problem and requires urgent solutions," Mr. Mikhailov said, adding that the sooner the storage center is built, "the sooner the liquidation of weapons" can begin.
Sweeping arms cuts threaten to put Mr. Mikhailov out of business and he is now lobbying to keep his legions busy. The ministry's construction crews, he said with mock gravity, "are almost unemployed these days." In his presentation today, he argued that the whole $400 million should go to his workers and not those of the Defense Ministry.
 
Congress Allocated Funds
 Last month Congress allocated $400 million in emergency funds to help speed the storage and destruction of Soviet nuclear weapons after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced dramatic cuts in October. Scheduled for elimination are 15,000 short-range weapons like artillery shells, land mines, air-defense warheads and naval weapons.
An important problem for American officials is insuring that American money goes exclusively for dismantlement and not new weapons.
Today, Mr. Mikhailov said that none of the $400 million should be used for dismantlement centers since they in principle could also be used for weapon assembly.
"The American people must be assured that this money won't be turned" into new arms, he said.
He added that too many people thought the $400 million would solve all the dismantlement problems. "It's not so," he said.
It would buy one central storage center, he said, that should be built near existing sites for assembly and disassembly of nuclear arms. Another new storage center facility would also be needed, he said.
The American delegation here includes Federal weapons experts but is sponsored by two private groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Federation of American Scientists. Both are private arms-control organizations that more than a year ago began exploring how to verify warhead dismantlement.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
North American Currency Links?

BYLINE: By Sylvia Nasar

 BODY:
SHOULD the United States, Mexico and Canada, follow Europe's lead and move toward a North American currency area as well as a freer regional trade zone?
The question is not on any official agendas. But the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and the Mexican central bank are quietly studying coordination to dampen swings in the peso-dollar rate. Some hard-pressed Canadian exporters are urging the Canadians to peg the Canadian dollar to the United States dollar. And the former Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, recently predicted that "in five years, you will find a fixed exchange rate among the peso, the U.S. dollar and the Canadian dollar." 
 Harvey Rosenblum, research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said: "You don't have to go all the way to a single currency to get some of the advantages. A tacit agreement to keep rates within a narrow band, absolutely fixed rates, or a single currency are all degrees of the same thing."
Since its economy is by far the biggest of the three, the United States would probably feel fewer effects of currency linkage than Mexico or Canada.
With steadier exchange rates, importers and exporters would face fewer problems, less uncertainty and lower business costs. Mr. Rosenblum compares bumpy exchange rates to pothole-strewn highways: "You can haul the goods, but it's a lot tougher."
Predictable exchange rates could also increase investor confidence, helping to broaden financial markets and bring in more investment -- particularly in Mexico where the perennial worry remains the risk of a sudden flight from the peso. "Economists always say that you can hedge," said Richard Cooper, an economist at the Kennedy School. "But you can't hedge an investment with a 10-year life."
Stable exchange rates could also help defuse a potential backlash against freer trade from business and unions by minimizing large swings in currencies.
Finally, linking currencies "puts pressure on high-inflation countries to mend their ways," said Robert Gay, an economist at Morgan Stanley. In Mexico, inflation has been running at 20 percent, multiples of the 3.5 percent in the United States.
The peso was, in fact, linked to the United States dollar during the 1950's and 60's -- "a remarkable period of growth and stability and open capital markets in Mexico," as Mr. Volcker put it.
Few economists would deny that these benefits may accrue. But many believe that the economic case for giving up floating rates and edging toward a North American currency area is much weaker than in Europe -- quite apart from the fact that the merest whisper of economic integration raises hackles in Canada and Mexico. The biggest drawback to monetary unions is the loss of sovereignty.
"Currency alignment means giving up your economic policy," said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University. Defending a fixed exchange rate can mean adopting exactly the opposite monetary policy than the one that domestic conditions call for.
"The one market of Western Europe and that of North America are very different entities," said David Laidler, an economist at the C.D. Howe Institute, a Canadian think tank. "To put it simply, the one European market is part of a broader political union and the one North American market shows no signs of developing in such a direction."
And it's far too soon to predict how free-trade agreements will evolve. The free-trade area in the agreement between the United States and Canada will not be completed until 1999 and the agreement with Mexico is not a sure thing. Further, said Miguel Mancera, president of the Banco de Mexico, "Currency areas are not essential to free-trade zones' good performance nor are the benefits of such unions self-evident."
The potential cost saving from going, say, to a single currency are probably much smaller here than in Europe. There are only three currencies in North America, not 12; the United States and Mexico depend less on foreign trade, and, in any case, business can always be conducted in United States dollars. The existing system of floating rates has also worked much better in North America than in Europe. Flexible currencies have helped the region adjust relatively quickly to shocks -- a big surge or plunge in world oil prices.
In any case, there is no compelling evidence that trade liberalization requires fixed exchange rates. "Central bankers always want to fix things," said Sir Alan Walters, vice chairman of the AIG Trading Corporation and a former economic adviser to Margaret Thatcher. "It makes them feel more important." The lack of a currency union has not prevented Canada and the United States from trading more than any other two nations.
At an international economics meeting in August, several Mexican and Canadian economists made elaborate arguments against a North American monetary union.
"It may be politically suicidal, and economically premature to say anything else," Mr. Volcker commented at the meeting. "But I also have the feel that they doth protest too much."

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
In Moscow, Too, a Liberal Mayor Feels Besieged

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Gavriil K. Popov, the liberal economist elected Mayor of Moscow last spring on a wave of democratic euphoria, is running into hard times. His city of nine million is short of food and money, its streets are filthy, its politics are in disarray, and his own popularity is sinking fast.
Now, on the eve of a dramatic increase in prices, something bound to further inflame the public mood, Mr. Popov has said he cannot take it anymore and has offered to resign -- again. But even his resignation threats are being shrugged off by a bitter electorate, which has found life under a democrat worse than under the now-departed Communists. 
 The deterioration of the economy, especially the long lines to buy food, are not generally attributed to Mr. Popov, who is well known as an advocate of radical reforms that have still not come to pass. But Muscovites do hold him responsible for squabbling that has paralyzed city politics, for widespread corruption, and for an overlapping bureaucracy that seems to have expanded rather than shrunk.
His critics accuse him of using the mayoralty to set himself up for the future. "The Mayor is one of the better-off people in Moscow," said Yuri A. Vingradov, a member of the Moscow City Council. "I don't think he has wasted his time."
Mr. Popov, a 53-year-old former professor who almost never wears a tie, has taken on extra functions -- like chairman of the Center for American-Russian Business, chairman of the Center for Baseball and Softball, and head of a still-nebulous international university.
Mr. Popov and his supporters say he is a victimized reformer whose way has been blocked from above and below. His plans to privatize apartments and small stores in Moscow, they say, have been snarled in a quarrel with the City Council and clouded by questions of whether the city can go ahead before the Russian republic adopts its own privatization plan.
 
Catalogue of Adversaries
 Last Sunday, in making his latest resignaton offer, Mr. Popov cited a lack of support by the Russian government, which has not approved his request that Moscow be given special status.
"I cannot work in conditions under which I am unable to carry out the obligations I made to the voters," he told Russian television news. In an interview tonight, he said the situation in Moscow -- where he says he is opposed by the old Communist apparatus, certain business circles and the "lumpen proletariat" -- is typical of other Russian cities.
Supporters concede that the Mayor has been unable to make much headway. "There is not a single serious problem to which the solution advanced by the Mayor's office was not blocked" by the City Council, Valery Vyzhutovich, a Moscow legislator, said in an article in the newspaper Izvestia.
But others see a flaw in Mr. Popov's argument, since he both complains that he needs more power and admits that he cannot manage the power he has.
Since taking office, Mr. Popov has created a system of nine Moscow prefectures, something intended to override the old Communist-dominated councils. The result, many complain, is an added layer of bureaucracy.
Yuri Sedykh-Bondarenko, deputy chairman of the City Council, or Mossoviet, assserted:
"If Gavriil Popov had not sat in City Hall for half a year and done nothing except reorganize administration, then the city would not be in the situation that it is. Now he sees the situation in the city, and that it is about to get more tense, so rather than take the responsibility, he puts it on Yeltsin and the Mossoviet."
Mr. Popov's threat to resign has gotten a cool reception from the chairman of the Russian Parliament. "We have done everything so that he could prove himself to be an innovator," said Ruslan Khasbulatov, as quoted by the independent news agency Interfax.
 
Problems Common to Liberals
 Mr. Vyzhutovich wrote that the Mayor's problems were typical of those of other democrats who have come to power in the last year.
"Having taken over the functions of power on a large scale, the democrats did not cope with management," he said. "To cope with it, one has to either refuse utopian attempts to manage everything, and give society a chance to regulate itself where possible, or cease to be democrats."
Even admirers concede that in the months since the August coup attempt failed, Mr. Popov has been a bit high-handed. He was the first to seize property belonging to the Communist Party, and in a particularly visible land grab took over a 32-floor tower on the banks of the Moscow River built by Comecon, the now-defunct Soviet-led trading bloc.
Mr. Popov's proposal was simple, his press secretary, Sergei Stupar, said. Since the city of Moscow had at one time parceled out the land for the project, a Mayor could simply offer to take it back and pay Comecon's former partners 100 million rubles. If the committee in charge of dissolving Comecon refused his idea, the Mayor's letter said, the city would simply take back the land and destroy the building.
Mr. Stupar said the panel has now accepted the offer, although he did not know when or how much would be paid for the building.
In the meantime, the Mayor's Department, a new layer of city government employing several hundred people, has occupied floors of the building. Most of the rest is available for lease, with prices for foreign companies starting at about $600 a square yard annually.

HEADLINE: J. Max Bond Sr., 89, an American Who Headed Liberian University

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
J. Max Bond Sr., a retired American educator who was president of the University of Liberia in the early 1950's, died on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.
The cause of his death was not immediately clear, but he had been suffering from prostate cancer, said a granddaughter, Ruth M. Bond. 
 Dr. Bond was born in Nashville, Tenn., the son of a Congregational minister. He was graduated from what later became Roosevelt College in Chicago, earned a master's degree from the University of Pittsburgh and a Ph.D. in sociology and economics in 1934 from the University of Southern California. While studying for his doctorate he worked as a waiter, a playground director and a physical training instructor.
He was director of an interracial commission in Kentucky from 1928 to 1931, a personnel and training official of the Tennessee Valley Authority from 1934 to 1938, dean at Dillard University in New Orleans from 1938 to 1940 and an administrator at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama from 1940 to 1944.
 
Worked With Haitian Schools
 From 1944 to 1947 he represented the Inter-American Educational Foundation in Haiti and also directed a commission working with the Haitian school system to improve its instruction in health and other fields.
He was then director of the School of Education at Atlanta University for three years, and was in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, from 1950 to 1954.
Dr. Bond's son George Clement Bond, who is director of the Institute of African Studies at Columbia University and a professor of anthropology at its Teachers College, said that as president of the University of Liberia, his father strove to maintain equality between teachers and students who were of indigenous African origin on the one hand and those who were Liberians descended from slaves in the United States.
The son said that after leaving the post in Monrovia, Dr. Bond was an offficial of the United States Agency for International Development from 1955 until his retirement in 1966. He served as an adviser in education and oversaw educational programs and had tours of duty in Afghanistan, Tunisia, Sierra Leone and Malawi.
In retirement in Washington he was active in local community affairs, particularly in the Capitol Hill neighborhood, where he lived.
He is survived by his wife, the former Ruth Clement; three children, Jane Emma and J. Max Jr., both of Manhattan, and George Clement of Teaneck, N.J., and six grandchildren.
Julian Bond, the civil rights figure and former Georgia state legislator, is his nephew. Julian Bond is currently teaching at American University in Washington.

HEADLINE: Limerick Journal;
An Irish City Bounces Back, in the Spirit of 1691

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMERICK, Ireland

 BODY:
People living here in Ireland's third-largest city, along the banks of what James Joyce described as "the dark mutinous Shannon waves," have long been accustomed to hearing their town bad-mouthed by the rest of the country.
To the smart alecks of Cork and Dublin, Limerick is "Stab City," where no one is safe on the streets. It has been a place to ridicule whether or not one has been there or knows very much about it. There is even doubt that the eponymous poetic form really started here. 
 In some ways, Limerick's problems reflect Ireland's: its unemployment rate is at the national average of 20 percent; it is ruefully watching young people emigrate to the Dublin area, Britain or America.
But in recent years the 1,000-year-old town on the Shannon River in western Ireland has been working hard, with some success, to improve not only its image and the physical look of the place but also the quality of life of its 76,000 people.
 
Foreign Companies Arrive
 An urban renewal program has cleaned out slums, refurbished the city hall area and attracted foreign companies to a clean, landscaped industrial park, providing hundreds of new jobs. As it finishes a year of celebrating its history, the city is arguing the merits of a renovation of its main medieval castle to attract more tourism.
The Mayor, Jim Kemmy, a 55-year-old stonemason, said: "Limerick has no more crime than any other place. The tabloids named us Stab City. The tabloids go for short words."
Indeed, none of Ireland's 17 murders in 1990 were committed in Limerick, and officials say there is no statistical proof that the city is worse than other places.
Mr. Kemmy said he hoped new industry could bring Limerick back to the prosperity it knew in the time of Peter Tate, who started selling shirts to sailors on the riverbank in the 1850's and became the town's leading employer with a factory that produced uniforms for the British Army and both the Union and Confederate armies in the American Civil War.
Limerick's modest renaissance has been enhanced by the emergence of a native as one of the most powerful national politicians, Desmond O'Malley. He is the head of the Progressive Democratic Party, which provides six crucial parliamentary votes in the coalition Government of Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey.
"Look out at the Shannon at low tide," Mr. O'Malley said, sitting in the lobby of the Ryan Limerick Hotel on a recent afternoon. "It is one of the superb sights in Ireland. There is a waterfall. It is the crossing point that controls the river for 60 miles east and west."
Eight hundred years ago, Mr. O'Malley's ancestors settled issues of river control and economy with axes, pikes and catapults that lofted diseased animals into the enemy throng. Now, he says, the success of the city and the area depends largely on regional planning and financing and on the creation of the Shannon Development Corporation.
In the old days, the problem was invasions by the Vikings and later the Normans. Now the enemy is Dublin, whose business executives and politicians want to end a longstanding arrangement intended to bring money to the west, the requirement that planes from North America land at nearby Shannon airport, with its huge duty-free shopping area. Some here favor reasonable argument and painful negotiations with the capital; others would seem to prefer the catapult.
King John's Castle in the center of the city was begun in 1210, lay ignored in recent centuries until the authorities had it refurbished for tourism, and it became the center of another battle.
The new facade, a network of connected pipes, resembles the Pompidou Center in Paris, the huge modern art museum whose exterior is also a set of crossing pipes and tubes. Some people call the castle "The Thing."
"Visually, the outside was not a success," Mr. O'Malley said. But inside, he said, are excellent displays of three eras, in archeological layers, of Limerick life -- the ancient Celts, topped by the Vikings, topped by the Normans who built the castle.
This year, the city celebrated its prime moment in history 300 years ago when it withstood a monthlong siege by the forces of William of Orange, the Protestant usurper of the English crown held by his father-in-law, the Catholic James II. The pro-James Catholic forces surrendered, but not before they won the Treaty of Limerick, which promised them religious freedom.
Some 12,000 Catholic troops were allowed safe passage to the Continent, and became known in Irish history as the Wild Geese, keeping national hopes and military tradition alive in exile. In succeeding centuries, Limerick kept slipping in national esteem, gaining a reputation for political radicalism.
But what happened to Limerick in 1691, a defeat that produced a kind of victory, is not unlike what is happening here now.
And so the people who created the commemoration celebration dug into the poetic history of the limerick. It may be that some of the Wild Geese soldiers learned a five-line satiric poem form in France and brought it back home, where it was used by poets writing in Gaelic to zing their English masters. There once was a Wild Goose from France . . . .

DINKINS RESCINDS SALARY CUTS

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
'Baby Bells' Are Accused of Overcharging

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The Consumer Federation of America, one of the nation's largest consumer groups, yesterday attacked the seven "Baby Bell" telephone companies for reportedly overcharging their customers by about $30 billion in the eight years since the January 1984 breakup of A.T.& T.
The Consumer Federation said the regional Bell holding companies had overcharged telephone ratepayers and had used the money to invest in lightly regulated businesses that have made little or no profit for the seven holding companies. The group said the money would have been better used to reduce customer bills. 
 The methodology underlying the Consumer Federation's charges is technical and arcane, and covers a wide variety of situations in 50 states. BellSouth, the largest Baby Bell, and the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, which represents state public service commissions, both declined to comment until they could study the group's charges and methodology.
Next month is the 10th anniversary of the Justice Department consent decree that led to the 1984 breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The Consumer Federation's asccusations come when recent court decisions have freed the Baby Bells to provide information services, like stock quotations, over telephone lines, a service that had been banned by the 1984 accord.
The Baby Bells' lightly regulated ventures include $2 billion in investments by Bell Atlantic and Ameritech in the New Zealand telephone company, and U S West's ownership of $1.6 billion worth of office buildings whose value has dropped sharply because of the recession.
Along with the GTE Corporation, the Baby Bells provide the bulk of local telephone service in the country and encounter little or no competition in providing that service to business and residential customers. Their revenues exceeded $100 billion in 1990.
The Consumer Federation, which claims 50 million members and represents 240 consumer groups, says that lightly regulated emerging businesses like information services would be open to pricing abuse. The group, based in Washington, is arguing that Congress should reimpose the ban on information services until the Baby Bells no longer enjoy a monopoly on local service.
Mark N. Cooper, the Consumer Federation's director of research, said the Baby Bells had received about $12 billion in "excess returns" since 1985. The figure is based on the Consumer Federation's assumption that the Baby Bells, which were virtual monopolies before divestiture, should have continued to earn the same rate of return after divestiture.
By the federation's calculations, Mr. Cooper said, the Baby Bells earned a nearly 1 percent higher return on equity, an important financial index, than all American manufacturers as a group.
 
'Excess Depreciation'
 Another $18 billion of the $30 billion in reported overcharges, Mr. Cooper said, comes from what he called "excess depreciation," which covers how a telephone company accounts for plant and equipment on its books. Such accelerated depreciation is intended to encourage a company to replace its outdated plant and equipment, by accounting for the depreciation as a higher cost of doing business.
But Mr. Cooper argued that the Bells' depreciation practices simply meant that the companies could keep more of their customers' money, rather than reduce telephone bills.

HEADLINE: Plan for Razing On Ellis Island Prompts Protest

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
A National Park Service proposal to demolish 12 buildings on Ellis Island, making way for the construction of an international conference center, drew sharply conflicting reactions at a hearing last night.
Proponents hailed the center, which would be privately built and owned, as a boost to the regional economy, while critics condemned the $145 million plan as a violation of the character of the island and the memory of millions of immigrants who passed through it. 
 Orin Lehman, New York State's historic preservation officer, appealed to the Park Service to abandon the project and instead stabilize and restore all 30 dilapidated buildings on the south half of the 25-acre island.
"Today's proposal is unnecessarily destructive of the physical and symbolic values which Ellis Island represents," Mr. Lehman said. "It tramples on the evocative nature of the island."
 
Destroy It to Save It?
 Another critic, Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan, also urged the Park Service to preserve all the buildings. "Must we destroy part of Ellis Island to save it?" he asked. "The partial destruction of a national shrine by an arm of Government should not be taken lightly."
But Representative Charles B. Rangel, another Democrat of Manhattan, argued in a statement read by an aide that the plan provided the "best, and perhaps only, hope for saving -- and using -- the greater proportion of historic buildings." Besides providing desperately needed jobs, Mr. Rangel's statement said, the center could be used for meetings of international, national, educational and scientific groups.
The Park Service approved the conference center idea in 1984. But until recently the service had insisted that the developer, William Hubbard, director of the Center for Housing Partnerships, a New York company that rehabilitates older buildings, create the center in existing structures without demolition. Mr. Hubbard was unable to raise financing for the project.
Last summer, a new partner, International Conference Resorts of America, offered financing if the 12 buildings were torn down.
Eighteen other buildings, most of them onetime hospital wards, would be rehabilitated to provide conference suites and hotel rooms. The new complex would include more hotel rooms and suites, a ballroom, banquet hall, restaurant and pool.
The 12 buildings that would be destroyed include a furnace room, laundry, crematory and five hospital wards.

HEADLINE: A Hardy Flu Bug and Long Lines for Shots

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 17

 BODY:
Before Peter Gianokos rolled up his sleeve yesterday for a nurse to inject him with a dose of influenza vaccine, the 74-year-old Stamford resident had not had a flu shot since he was in the Navy during World War II.
"I heard it's more severe this winter, and I know a lot of people who've had the flu pretty bad," he said, explaining his decision to show up at one of about 45 flu clinics held during the last two months by the Stamford Health Department. "They advertised it so much, and since it's a good precaution and it's free, I'd be foolish not to take it." 
 Mr. Gianokos is among a record number of people in Stamford and many other communities in the Northeast who have deluged clinics in recent weeks seeking flu shots. Public-health officials say that the rush to get shots stems from fears about the severity and duration of this year's flu season, reports of a vaccine shortage and even the recession.
"We've seen flu earlier this year than we usually do, as well as levels of flu among schoolchildren that we generally don't see until the peak of the flu season, between January and March," said Dr. Louisa Chapman, a medical epidemiologist and expert on influenza at the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta. "We don't know if it's just coming earlier this year or it's going to be a more long and drawn-out flu season."
 
Schools Closed
 In the agency's most recent weekly national survey, it found that 8 to 10 percent of doctor visits were for "flu-like symptoms," a percentage "typically associated with the season's peak," Dr. Chapman added.
Health officials throughout the region also say that this year's flu season has either peaked earlier or is threatening to be unusually severe. On Monday, 75 New Jersey schools reported absentee rates of at least 15 percent -- bringing to 138 the number of schools that have had such a high absentee rate since late November. Several schools have closed because of flu outbreaks, said Darlene Weiner, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Health Department. In New York State, 18 of 62 upstate counties reported widespread flu last week, William Fagel, a State Health Department spokesman, said.
Flu-vaccine campaigns are usually directed toward the elderly, who are the most at risk for getting the disease and dying from it, but this year, health-care professionals say, many younger people are coming to doctors and clinics for shots. In addition, rising health-care costs and layoffs appear to be drawing a broader swath of the population to public clinics for free care.
"Getting sick is so expensive, and my doctor retired," said Marie Rebb, 78, explaining why she had come to the Stamford clinic, where requests for $5 donations were going largely unheeded.
 
$65 vs. Free
 "My doctor wanted $65 for the office visit and the shot, which I thought was pretty rude and outrageous," said Al Vaikutis, 38, who works for a courier service in Stamford. "I heard this was free, and these are my tax dollars."
Peggy Hone, a nurse at the Stamford clinic, said: "I've never seen this kind of tremendous turnout. There are a lot of people in their 20's, 30's and 40's with chronic health problems like high blood pressure who wouldn't have come in years past."
Influenza is unpredictable because strains of the virus change from year to year, but during a relatively mild year it strikes from 10 to 20 percent of the American population and kills 10,000 people, Dr. Chapman said. In three of the last 34 years, more than 40,000 Americans have died, she said, and during the worldwide epidemic of 1918-19, 20 million people died, including a half million Americans. Most of the deaths occur among people older than 65 or those who have chronic lung and heart conditions.
While many clinics and hospitals have run out of vaccine in recent weeks, the problem has been more one of distribution than of supply, Dr. Chapman said. The shortages have principally affected state and local health departments, which account for only about 15 percent of vaccine orders, she added. Several vaccine manufacturers are "redistributing from areas of excess to ones of shortage," she said, and clinics have been scrambling to obtain additional doses to meet the heavy demand.
 
Wanting to Stay Well
 The Stamford Health Department had planned to provide vaccine for 4,000 of the town's 108,000 residents this fall -- triple the number of doses administered four years ago. With hundreds of people lining up for shots the supply was exhausted by early December, Ms. Ormond said.
"We had a run on the vaccine about two weeks ago," said Dr. Andrew McBride, Stamford's health director. "We called other health departments and hospitals, but we had a difficult time getting more vaccine."
The town was eventually able to purchase several hundred additional doses from a manufacturer for about $6 each -- nearly double what it had paid for the first batch of doses it had ordered, he said.
Trying to explain the heavy demand, Jeanne Ormond, the director of the Stamford Health Activities Program for the Elderly, added: "With the economy the way it is, people -- old and young -- are hurting and stressed out and want to stay well."

HEADLINE: Those Lights in Big Cities Get Brighter, Census Finds

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Census Bureau reported today that three in four Americans -- 20 million more than a decade ago -- live in cities or the suburbs around them, more than ever before.
Final calculations have yet to be made on the urban-suburban-rural population breakdown from the 1990 census, but Larry Long, a Census Bureau demographer, estimated today that 23 percent to 24 percent of the nation's population lives in rural areas, slightly more than 25 percent in central cities and the remaining 50 percent in suburban communities. 
 The phenomenon of metropolitan areas lapping outward into old farm land, combined with an influx of immigrants into core urban areas like Los Angeles and New York, has made the United States the newest and largest member of the small international fraternity of nations whose populations are more than 75 percent urban.
The other nations in that fraternity fall into four categories: countries built around a single city, like Hong Kong or Singapore; small nations like Israel, Belgium and the Netherlands; mountainous countries with limited amounts of habitable land, like Iceland or New Zealand, and the two highly industrialized economic powerhouses, Germany and Japan.
 
The Definition Varies
 Carl Haub, a spokesman for the Population Reference Bureau, a private research organization in Washington, cautioned that the definition of "urbanized population" can vary from one country to another.
The Census Bureau defines an urban resident as one who lives in a central city or its satellite suburban communities if the core city has a population of at least 50,000 and the suburban community is economically linked either to that urban core or its suburbs.
Thus, a city like Brewster, N.Y., and nearby communities can be considered urban and a part of the New York metropolitan area if its population density is greater than 1,000 people per square mile and most of its work force commutes to Manhattan or close-in suburbs like White Plains.
The latest census report indicated that the rate of urbanization was growing fastest in the Western. Virtually all of California's population increase of six million in the last decade consists of people who moved into urban areas, and 93 percent of the state's population of 29.9 million now lives in urban areas.
 
Top 10 States Listed
 New York, which until 1960 was, with Rhode Island, one of the two most urban states in the nation, is now tied with Massachusetts for 10th place in its percentage of urban population (84.3 percent), after California, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Hawaii, Utah, Arizona, Nevada, Illinois and Florida.
Over all, the population of the West is now 86.3 percent urbanized, while the population of the Northeast is 78.9 percent urbanized and that of the Midwest is 71.7 percent urbanized. About 68.6 percent of the South's population lives in urban areas, the lowest percentage of any region in the country.
But Vermont remains the nation's most rural state, with 67.8 percent of its population of 563,000 living in rural areas.

HEADLINE: Bush's Time to Act;
Passive Approach on the Recession Collides With Harsh Political Reality

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
At one extreme, President Bush is being urged to propose a rebate in income taxes due April 15. This might be good politics, but it is probably bad economics.
At the other extreme, Mr. Bush is being counseled to sit tight and ride out the recession. This could be good economics, but it is terrible politics. 
 By acknowledging today what voters have perceived and Democrats have harped on for weeks -- that the country is still hip-deep in economic misery -- the White House seemed to be saying that the President was inclined for the first time in his Presidency to act rather than let the economy take care of itself.
George Bush did not cause the recession. And probably nothing he does will be primarily responsible for getting the economy back on its feet. But the American system does not permit Presidents to run successfully for re-election if they do nothing while businesses fail and workers lose their jobs. The last President who tried, as Democrats keep pointing out, was Herbert Hoover.
 
Little Chance of Passage
 The best bet is that Mr. Bush will come down somewhere between the two extremes and propose tax measures that will satisfy his political needs but do little damage if any to the budget deficit. If so, his solutions will be mostly cosmetic.
He must decide what to do before the end of the year, when he leaves for a two-week trip to the Far East and his staff begins preparing his State of the Union Message and the crucial chapters of his budget.
Whatever course the President takes, this much is certain: His economic package will not be enacted in full and maybe not even in part. Republicans are simply too small a minority in Congress, and Democrats have too much of a stake in putting their partisan stamp on economic recovery measures.
The best Mr. Bush can hope for is that the final product will be the result of negotiations between the White House and Democratic Congressional leaders. From the President's perspective, that would put the Democrats on board. He could still take political credit if the economic ship catches wind and begins to sail. If it sinks, he would not go down alone.
 
'An Untenable Position'
 The Democrats in Congress are under as much pressure as the President to get something enacted. They, like the President, are incumbents. "You can't run for re-election having done nothing," said a Washington economist who has been in and out of the Government for more than 20 years, "because your opponent will say you brought this all on and then didn't do anything about it. It's an untenable position."
"In this town," the economist added, "incumbency always trumps ideology."
The idea of a rebate in 1991 income taxes is being pushed mainly by Republicans in the House of Representatives who have never seen a tax cut they did not like. The problem, as with any tax cut that is not offset by spending cuts or tax increases elsewhere, is that it would show an almost total disregard of budget discipline and might spook the financial markets.
 
Fears for Interest Rates
 The rise in interest rates resulting from the markets' fear of inflation could offset whatever stimulus might be gained from consumers' spending their new-found wealth. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told the Senate Finance Committee last week that one of the "guiding principles" of the Administration's policy was to do nothing that would raise interest rates.
On the other hand, in the position the President finds himself now, no politician can afford to sit on his hands and let the business cycle run its course.
That position might seem wise to economists who follow computer models more closely than election returns. In testimony today before the House Ways and Means Committee, prominent economists from across the political spectrum testified against an immediate cut in income taxes. The prevailing view was that any tax cut large enough to provide a quick kick to the economy would do serious long-term damage.
But with the Democrats almost uniformly backing one kind of tax cut or another for the middle class, silence by the President would allow his opponents to paint him as oblivious to the economic pain in the country. In its statements today, the White House went to lengths to demonstrate that Mr. Bush grasps the desperate shape some people are in.
So at the least, Mr. Bush will reintroduce his proposals for a capital gains tax cut and tax-free savings accounts. His advisers suggested he might offer some kind of tax credit for business investments in plants and machinery. And following the Democrats' lead, he will probably have to advance a tax break for middle-income taxpayers.
The big question is what the President will suggest to pay for this tax relief. Many Democrats want to raise the taxes of rich people, but the President's advisers say that is one step he will not take.
The President wants to be seen as acting decisively. But in frank moments, his advisers acknowledge that perception is more important than the reality.
 
Not Enough for a Movie
 Over a number of years, they say, a capital gains tax cut, an investment tax credit and incentives for savings would be good for the country. But they would have little effect, if any, on the immediate problem of a flagging economy. And a tax cut for the middle class of $300 a family, which is in the range being discussed, amounts to less than $6 a week for each family, not even enough for a good movie in most places.
For all the talk about their differences, there is precious little to choose from between the Republicans and Democrats on the matter of how to get out of the recession. In their debate on Sunday night, the Democratic Presidential candidates offered little in this regard.
Some suggested that taxing the rich more and the middle class less would induce more consumer spending, since the less affluent people are, the more likely they are to spend the money in their pockets. But economists, almost without exception, say the effect would be negligible. Redistributing the tax burden might be good social policy, but it would do little for the economy.
To make any real difference, a fiscal stimulus would probably have to exceed $50 billion, or about 1 percent of the nation's annual output. But the dominant view of economists is that a combination of tax cuts and spending increases that large when he budget deficit is already close to $400 billion would be irresponsible.
So however he tries to seize the political advantage next year in his budget and State of the Union Message, the President must mostly rely on the economy to cure itself. His Presidency may be riding on the outcome.

HEADLINE: Kerrey Concern Violates Laws On Child Labor

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Labor Department said today that on Friday it had assessed a $64,650 fine against a restaurant chain partly owned by Senator Bob Kerrey for violations of the child labor laws. The company, which is one-third owned by the Nebraska Senator, acknowledged the violations.
The Labor Department's regional office in Kansas City, Mo., said that in an unannounced sweep of businesses in four states, including Nebraska, it had found by far the most numerous violations at seven Grandmother's Inc. restaurants in Omaha and Lincoln that Mr. Kerrey, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, founded 19 years ago with his brother-in-law, Dean Rasmussen. 
 The department said it had found 116 young people working illegally long or late-night hours, or operating hazardous machinery illegally. The fine is more than 10 times the average assessed this year against companies found in violation of the child labor provisions of the Fair Labor Standard Act of 1938.
The citation of Grandmother's Inc. coincides with a pronounced decline in enforcement of the child labor laws from the record levels the Labor Department reached last year with several surprise inspections of businesses. Most were fast-food chains and retail stores, which make heavy use of teen-age workers who are paid the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour or slightly more.
But the number of teen-agers at Grandmother's Inc., amounting to 20 percent of the payroll, is also unusually high. Employers in Nebraska face greater temptation than most to resort to teen-age workers; the state's unemployment rate is only 2.2 percent, suggesting that employers have to dig deeper into the population for workers than most.
Senator Kerrey, who makes a point of his entrepreneurial experience in appealing for the support of business people, was campaigning in Texas today. He said: "I have been informed by my business partner that he has taken actions to correct possible violations of U.S. Department of Labor regulations. The restaurants are now in compliance."
He said that government regulations are the "most difficult" obstacle to starting a business but that be fully supported the child labor laws.
In an article last year, the Nation's Restaurant News called Mr. Kerrey "a loyal friend of the industry" and "an unequivocal proponent of free enterprise against government interference." It added that in the Senate Mr. Kerrey "is proving the fallacy of assuming that only Republicans can help free enterprise."
 
Assurance on Procedures

The Senator's campaign spokesman, Steve Jarding, said he doubted there was any political dimension to the Labor Department investigation. Steven Hofman, a spokesman for Labor Secretary Lynn Martin, said that on being informed Monday that a business partly owned by Mr. Kerrey would be cited Mrs. Martin sought assurance that normal investigatory procedures had been followed before allowing Grandmother's Inc. to be cited.
The Labor Department said the ownership of a business was not a consideration when inspectors conduct sweeps of the kind that ensnared Grandmother's Inc. along with 26 other businesses in Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri and Kansas. All the other businesses had fewer violations, it said. Mr. Rasmussen told The Washington Post, which reported the fine in today's editions, that he was "a very embarrassed businessman with egg all over his face."
Mr. Rasmussen, who is the husband of Senator Kerry's sister Jessie, runs the eight-store company of Grandmother's Skillet family-type restaurants and Don & Millie's hamburger and French-fry outlets. Mr. Jarding said Mr. Kerrey, who retains the title of chairman, owns 35 percent of the business, receives a $5,000-a-year director's fee and also receives an amount of the profits.
 
Too Late and too Long
 The Labor Department said most of the violations involved young people working too late or too long. With few exceptions, the law prohibits all paid work by children under the age of 14. For 14- and 15-year-olds, it allows three hours of work before or after school on school days, but not before 7 A.M. or after 7 P.M. On nonschool days, they can work up to 8 hours and up to 40 hours a week during vacations.
The law also prohibits young people from taking many jobs that can be hazardous. Those who are 16 and 17 are free to work whatever hours they wish, but they are excluded from certain jobs.
The Department said 112 of the 116 minors cited in the Grandmother's Inc. case were 14 and 15 year olds who were working too late at night or excessive hours. Among them, one 15-year-old was also working as a cook, the Labor Department said. The other four cases involved a 16-year-old and a 17-year-old operating meat-slicing machines and a 16-year-old and a 17-year-old operating baking machinery.
Last year, in response to growing evidence of widespread violations of the child labor laws, Mrs. Martin's predecessor, Elizabeth H. Dole, began four nationwide sweeps of businesses that tend to use teen-age workers. As a result, the number of youths found working in violation of the laws leaped to 39,790 in the fiscal year 1990 from 22,508 in 1989.
In the fiscal year 1991, which ended in September, enforcement showed signs of waning.

The fine stems from violations of child labor laws. Teen-agers make up 20 percent of the chain's payroll. This Grandmother's is in Omaha, Neb. (Associated Press)
