HEADLINE: Federal Panel Calls for National Standards and Tests for All Schoolchildren

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
In a major departure for American education, a major advisory panel is calling for voluntary national curriculum standards and national tests for American schoolchildren.
Such standards would spell out, for the first time on a national level, what children should be expected to learn and what level of achievement is good enough at different stages, according to the National Council on Education Standards and Testing, an advisory group of major political and educational leaders whose approval is crucial to the success of any such effort. The council, created by Congress last June, concluded its deliberations today. Its final report will be made public in mid-January. 
 The council asked Congress to provide money for a successor group to put the recommendations into effect. But council members said the movement was bound to proceed anyway because President Bush made these ideas the cornerstone of his strategy to revive American schools. Several groups are already working to develop national standards in specific subjects and prototypes of national tests.
 
Concern and Opposition
 But because the panel was charged only to consider the broad outlines of national standards and tests, many crucial details are yet to be worked out, prompting concern and opposition from some educators. They worry that setting standards without providing schools the resources to help meet them will end up discriminating against poor children who attend inadequate schools.
Also, excessively detailed standards could create a national curriculum, stifling teacher creativity, denying parents a voice and causing political battles over what children should learn, the educators say. And they fear that without considerable money and commitment to devise sophisticated tests, national tests could end up resembling the same widely reviled standardized tests that American children take now.
Despite such fears, which have been expressed even among some of its members, the council concluded that standards and tests were essential to reach the education goals that the President and the nation's governors have set for the year 2000. These include making American children the best in the world in mathematics and science achievement and insuring that they demonstrate competency in five core subjects: English, mathematics, science, history and geography.
National standards in these subjects and national tests, the council's draft report said, will help in these ways: "First, they can help us extend educational opportunity to all Americans. Second, they can strengthen our democratic institutions and values while enabling all of our citizens to participate effectively in the political process. Third, they can enhance our economic competitiveness."
Although such standards and tests would be voluntary, the council recommended incentives for states and local school districts to adopt them, like tying Federal scholarships to test results, or penalties for schools that have high failure rates.
But such incentives or sanctions were not spelled out in the report, reflecting sharp disagreements between those council members who see consequences as the only way to enforce high standards and those who fear they might discriminate against poor or minority students who score badly because they attend inadequate schools.
In either case, the very existence of national standards and tests would represent a radical departure from a longstanding American tradition of local control, which has led to a patchwork of curriculum requirements and tests. "It was a fairly historic session," Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado, the council's co-chairman, said of its work. The other co-chairman is Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina.
 
Some Ways to Set National Standards
 Governor Romer emphasized that setting national standards did not mean imposing a national curriculum. Instead, the council called for broad descriptions of core knowledge and skills -- saying, for example, that all children should learn certain principles of algebra and be able to use tables and graphs. In addition to such content standards, the council called for performance standards, or how to decide what achievement is good enough at certain stages.
The National Council of Teachers of Mathematics has already drawn up nationwide mathematics standards. The National Academy of Sciences, with the help of other groups, is working on science standards. The National Endowment for the Humanities today announced a $1.6 million grant to develop history standards. And California has drawn up curriculum outlines in several subjects.
The council proposed that its successor body examine such efforts and certify those that meet what they called "world-class standards." But many politically explosive issues remain unresolved.
While it is relatively easy in science and math to agree on what principles children should know, efforts in New York and California to do so in history and English have produced bruising battles. California's history guidelines and the textbooks based on them, while widely praised by many educators, have been bitterly fought by several ethnic groups who believe that their histories had been improperly told.
"Who sets these standards for schools and students, and by what right?" asked Theodore R. Sizer, an education expert at Brown University who heads the Coalition of Essential Schools, a network of nearly 200 schools working to improve academic performance. "Education is infused with values -- what texts will I choose? How do I teach evolution? I as the parent want to look into the eyes of people capable of changing that decision."
Reflecting the fears of many in the council that students in poor schools would be unfairly penalized, the council recommended setting standards to evaluate whether schools have enough money and equipment to help students meet high standards. But the council did not call for such standards to be nationwide, leaving open the possibility that states would still vary widely in the quality of their schools and how much money they give them.
"The council shares the concerns of those who fear that without other substantive reforms higher standards and richer assessments would be a cruel hoax," the draft report said.
This was one of the most divisive issues on the council, and even on the last day of deliberations tensions were evident.
 
National Tests: Can They Be Fair?
 There was even less agreement on exactly what a national system of tests should be. The council's 32 members agreed that such tests should be tied to the national standards and should check whether students were in fact achieving them. Tests would tell parents whether their children were doing well enough and how they compared with other students across the country.
They would also show whether teachers and schools were doing an adequate job. The council said schools and students should be rated on the basis of how much their test results improved to avoid favoring wealthy schools teaching privileged children.
Council members also agreed that the national tests should include portfolios of students' work and "performance-based assessments," which test students' analytical and problem-solving skills.
But the draft report was fuzzy on other details. The council agreed there should not be one national test, so that states together or separately could devise their own. It was unclear how results on different tests could be compared, although several testing groups are working on these technical issues.
The council did not estimate any cost for developing these tests, although most experts believe that they would be several times more expensive than conventional multiple choice tests.
Even more than the debate about standards, some council members and outside educators worry whether tests will be fair. Linda Darling-Hammond, a professor of education at Columbia University's Teachers College, said previous efforts had failed for lack of money or had ended up excluding children who scored low.
"How would we insure that this test would be any better?" she asked. "We will end up punishing the kids, schools and teachers least well-funded and least well-served. We will certify the inequality that exists in this country. There is no companion plan to equalize educational resources."
The draft report echoes many of these concerns and suggests that the council's successor body could help set standards to make sure tests were being used fairly. "The council recognizes concerns about poor, minority and disabled students who have not been well served by testing in the past," the draft report said.
 
How the Changes Would Take Effect
 But debate continued even today over what stakes should be tied to test results. Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said, "There is no evidence that telling people they are doing badly will do anything if there are no consequences."
Governor Romer replied, "We need to handle fairness before a number of people will buy into this."
The successor group the council envisions would be evenly divided among educators, state and local officials and the general public. It would issue a kind of "Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval" on standards and tests, subject to the approval of the National Education Goals Panel, created to oversee progress toward meeting the national education goals.
The council asked Congress to appropriate money for the successor body, and since the council includes four members of Congress, Governor Romer said he was optimistic. The four lawmakers are Senators Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, and Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, and Representatives Bill Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Dale E. Kildee, Democrat of Michigan.
The council also includes the leaders of the two national teachers' unions, Mr. Shanker of the American Federation of Teachers and Keith Geiger of the National Education Association, as well as school superintendents, educators, state legislators, Bush Administration officials and a business executive, Roger D. Semerad, a senior vice president of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation.
The council ended by approving the principles in the draft report, subject to several wording changes. The final report will go to Congress, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander and the National Education Goals Panel.
Chart: "Measuring Student's Progress: A Call for National Standards"
 New "performance standards" for American schoolchildren urged by the National Council on Education Standards and Testing would spell out what achievement levels children should reach at different stages of their education. This ia an example of standards for science.
 
Knows everyday science facts
 Students know some general scientific facts of the type that could be learned from everyday experinces.
 They can read simple graphs, match the disctinguishing characteristics of animals, and predict the operation of familiar apparatuses that work according to mechanical principles.
 
Understands simple scientific principles
 Students are developing some understanding of simple scientific principles, particularly in the life sciences. For example, they exhibit some rudimentary knowledge of the structured function of plants and animals.
 
Applies basic scientific information
 Students can interpret data from simple tables and make inferences about the outcomes of experimental procedures.
 They exhibit knowlegde of the life science, including a familiarity with aspects of animal behavior and ecological relationships.
 
Analyzes scientific procedures and data
 Students can evaluate the appropriateness of the design of an experiment.
 They have more detailed scientific knowledge, and the skill to apply their knowlegde in interpreting information from text and graphs.
 These students also exhibit a growing understanding of principles from the physical sciences.
 
Integrates specialized scientific information
 Students can infer relationships and draw conclusions using detailed scientific knowledge from the physical sciences, particularly chemistry.
 They can also apply basic principles of genetics and interpret the social implications of research in this field.

HEADLINE: Trinidad Party in Comeback

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Patrick Manning, a 45-year-old geologist, was elected Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago by a landslide in voting on Monday, and now faces the daunting task of finding the money to finance his campaign promises.
Mr. Manning led his People's National Movement to a comeback after five years in opposition and a past tainted with corruption scandals and allegations of incompetence and mismanagement. 
 His party won 21 of 36 seats in Parliament, inflicting a crushing defeat on Prime Minister A. N. R. Robinson's National Alliance for Reconstruction, which lost all but two of the 33 seats it had won in elections in 1986 that ended 30 years of uninterrupted rule by the People's National Movement.
The United National Congress of Basdeo Panday, a veteran left-of-center politician favored by the country's ethnic Indians, took 13 seats.
Even before the full results were known, political analysts began wondering where Mr. Manning would get the money to fulfill expectations his campaign raised among voters hurting from an economic austerity program that followed standard International Monetary Fund prescriptions.
Mr. Manning has promised to ease the hardships caused by the program.
Mr. Robinson's Government cut back public spending, dismissed thousands of civil servants, reduced Government wages, introduced a 15 percent value-added tax, and privatized major state-owned companies.
Against the background of these widely detested measures, Black Muslim militants last year staged a violent attempt to topple the Government.
The rebels stormed Parliament and the headquarters of the state-run television and took Mr. Robinson, half his Cabinet and almost 50 other people hostage. When Mr. Robinson refused to resign, they shot him in the leg; the ordeal ended after six days and he has since recovered.
While the austerity program provoked anger against the Government here. it won praise from international economists and the United States.
"What happened here shows a classic dilemma shared by many third world governments," a diplomat here said. "By the time I.M.F.-style programs take effect, a disaffected electorate votes its authors out of office."

HEADLINE: U.S. Eases Spending Rules In Presidential Primaries

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Newly adopted Federal regulations have greatly loosened restrictions on how much Presidential campaigns can spend in each state. The changes will allow candidates in the 1992 primary season to pump unusually large amounts of money into the early states.
The regulations, which took effect last month, are expected to end a 16-year tradition of political trickery in which candidates foiled the intent of Federal election laws by following an unwritten code of conduct: stretch the rules to pour as much money as possible into states with early contests. 
 The intent of the state limits, which were put in place with the first federally financed Presidential campaign in 1976, was to discourage campaigns from concentrating their money and resources into the largest states with the most votes.
"It was really the fear that the small states would be ignored in the process," said Frederick S. Eiland, a spokesman for the Federal Election Commission. "It's now gone in the other direction."
 
Dodging of Limits
 The drafters of the original regulations did not realize that the delegate-rich states were not always the most important politically. Rather than focus on the big states, most campaigns sought ways to channel as much as they could into Iowa and New Hampshire, which have among the lowest spending limits but hold the first two contests. The spending limits are tied to a state's voting-age population.
While the new rules, drafted by the Federal Election Commission, do not abolish the limits, they essentially legitimize the practice of dodging them by exempting certain advertising, travel and consulting costs that had been considered part of a campaign's spending in a state.
The 1992 campaigns, for instance, will no longer have to resort to practices like renting cars in Nebraska for use in Iowa or putting up campaign workers in Vermont for the primary next door in New Hampshire -- all to keep down spending in a state.
"There's going to be a lot less funny business, monkey business or whatever you might want to call it with state caps," said Tim Raftis, the Presidential campaign manager for Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa. "Everything's going to be on the table in full sunshine for the public."
The change was something of a compromise for the election commission, which had repeatedly called on Congress to abolish the limits, calling them cumbersome, difficult to monitor and unnecessary, since candidates who take Federal money already must adhere to a spending ceiling.
With Congress unwilling to tamper with the campaign finance system, the election commission proposed the rules change, which its officials say will halve the time its auditors spend monitoring whether campaigns broke the limits.
"These multimillion-dollar campaigns have budgets probably three times as large as the Federal Election Commission," said Scott E. Thomas, a Democratic commissioner. "We were basically running out of resources to sort out all the minutiae that was required."
 
Rise in Limits
 The limits, which will be raised for next year, permit $872,539 to be spent in Iowa and $530,000 in New Hampshire, although those figures will be adjusted for 1992.
No one can say exactly how much more spending the new rules would permit, although some experts estimate they could as much as double the amounts now allowed. Others predict spending could go far higher.
 
Advantage for Cuomo
 Since the campaigns of the Democratic candidates are not nearly as flush as they were four years ago, the new rules could be of greatest benefit to a candidate like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York who, if he decides to run, could amass large sums quickly to pour far more money into the early states than had been permitted.
"These campaigns in New Hampshire are strapped for resources," said George B. Burger, a Democratic political consultant. "But Cuomo could conceivably spend three or four million dollars there. It gives a candidate like Cuomo a tremendous advantage." The same could be said for other candidates who catch on and find they could raise large sums quickly.
Yet some strategists argue that the new rules may not greatly affect spending patterns, since many campaigns always maneuvered around the limits anyway. The election Commission is still auditing the 1988 Presidential campaigns but has already concluded that seven of them broke the limits in Iowa or New Hampshire. Although the case is still in dispute, Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, was found to have surpassed the Iowa limit by more than $900,000.
Another reason the rules change may not have as far-reaching an effect in 1992 is because most Democratic campaigns started late, and their fund raising has been hampered by the sluggish economy. Moreover, since Mr. Harkin is the favorite son in Iowa, many campaigns have decided not to wage strong efforts there.
But it is also true that not all campaigns dodged the spending caps, so some may be more inclined to spend more this time if they know they would not be bending the rules.
This much is also clear: campaigns and their lawyers no longer must devote much of their time finding ways to exploit loopholes in state-by-state spending. And the new rules will also eliminate the spending limits as a political issue: it is less likely that Presidential candidates will point the finger at one another for busting spending caps.
"This relieves some of the candidates' anxiety about the pressure of the limits," said Robert F. Bauer, a lawyer who advises Democratic candidates on election laws, "and some of the difficulty of the commission in trying to enforce them."
While the new regulations do not abolish the state caps, they offer campaigns several exemptions so they do not have to count all their spending against the limit.
 
Exemptions to Limits
 Among the expenditures campaigns can make that no longer have to apply to the state limits are these:
*Half of all advertising costs. Fees for placing television, radio or print advertisements would not apply to the state limits at all.
*Travel and expenses of the candidate and staff members.
*Staff salaries in the state.
*Fees for consultants in a state who are advising on national campaign strategy.
The new regulations also abolish the "five-day rule," which in effect kept candidates and their workers from spending money within a state for more than four consecutive days. If they did, their travel expenses within the state would count against the state cap.
Major expenses that will still count against the state limits include half of advertising fees within the state, statewide polling and telephone drives and overhead expenses for offices.
 
Uncertainty on Amounts
 Donald J. Simon, a lawyer who advises Democratic candidates, said: "The commission has, in effect, raised the state limits. People always spent what they wanted to spend and dealt with the commission after the election. There should be less of that this year."
Officials at the election commission and officials from Presidential campaigns said they had no idea exactly how much more spending would now be permitted.
"It's like trying to put smoke in a bag," said John W. McGarry, a Democrat who heads the commission. "I don't think there is a scientific answer or even a way to analyze that." He said the change was important, though, because "the state-by-state regulations were generating a massive disrespect for the law and for the commission. It was abominable."
While she favored revising the rules, another commissioner, Joan D. Aikens, said she was still concerned that the rules change might go too far in violating the spirit of the law. "Everybody wants to make it easier for the candidates to comply with the limits, so they don't have to jump through hoops," said Ms. Aikens, a Republican. "But I wanted us to be careful that we just don't blow them away."
Mr. Bauer said new rules or old rules, most campaigns were still going to go about their spending the way they always have. "Spending," he said, "will still be a product of panic and bad planning."

HEADLINE: Scaling Back Growth at Harvard's Kennedy School

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 12

 BODY:
The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, which takes pride in advising governments how to run better, is being overhauled itself after more than a decade of spectacular growth.
The task is delicate because the Kennedy School was the most cherished legacy of Derek C. Bok, Harvard's president for 20 years until he retired last June. Mr. Bok wanted it to create "a new profession" of public service, and he had sought to make it the equal of Harvard's gradudate schools of law, medicine and business. 
 But Mr. Bok's successor, Neil Rudenstine, in one of his first acts as president, appointed a new dean of the Kennedy School last month, Albert Carnesale, and charged him with restructuring the institution.
Foremost among Mr. Carnesale's tasks will be to end the school's madcap expansion, consolidate some of the school's myriad programs and find a new balance between its two often-quarrelsome factions. These two camps, whose rivalry often seems to leave the Kennedy School with an identity crisis, are the traditional scholars and the "practitioners," or former government officials and journalists, who have been brought in to teach about what is deemed the real world.
 
'Different Point in History'
 "Clearly the school is just at a different point in its history than it was 10 years ago," Mr. Rudenstine said. "There has been this tremendous growth that was wonderful, exciting and important. But it is perfectly clear that trajectory cannot be continued."
Instead, Mr. Rudenstine said, the Kennedy School "needs to be more selective, to have a sharpened vision and to make some tough choices."
One pressing reason for the shift is that while the Kennedy School's endowment has soared to $132 million from only $20 million in 1978, when it moved into its handsome new brick headquarters beside the Charles River, the institution is running a deficit. During that time its faculty climbed to 100 from 20 and its full-time graduate students increased to 700 from 200.
Mr. Carnesale, who had served for 10 years as the school's academic dean, insisted in a recent interview that he would not retreat from the grand vision outlined by Mr. Bok.
But at the same time he said the Kennedy School no longer believed it was "establishing a new profession," as Mr. Bok had called for, and that, unlike 10 year ago, the Kennedy School did not now "think of itself as analogous to the law school or the medical school."
"We are trying to improve the quality of public service, not establish a new profession," he said.
 
Leader for 3-Ring Circus
 By all accounts, Mr. Carnesale, an affable 55-year-old expert on nuclear arms control, was a popular choice to be the school's leader.
"He's what this three-ring circus needs, a good manager," said Dorothy Zinberg, a lecturer in public policy.
But there is already concern among some of the school's practitioners that Mr. Carnesale will try to answer criticism that the Kennedy School has more glitz than substance by imposing traditional scholarly requirements on them.
The critical issue is what Mr. Carnesale will decide to do about some of the practitioners who have long been out of government or journalism but who have not published scholarly books, as regular academics would be expected to do to win tenure at Harvard. These teachers, who work under limited contracts, are given the title of lecturer in public policy, not professor, and have no job security.
Some of these lecturers, like Robert B. Reich, the lawyer and economist whose most recent book is "The Work of Nations" (Knopf, 1991), are among the Kennedy School's most popular teachers and best known faculty members.
Mr. Carnesale must also cope with a budget deficit that Mr. Rudenstine said surprised him when he took over as Harvard's president last summer. The school's financial troubles stem from the era of expansion, when the then dean, Graham Allison, described by colleagues as a virtual genius at fund-raising, brought in vast quantities of money for new research centers and faculty chairs but not enough for operating expenses.
One school official said the Kennedy School got less of its income from its endowment than other parts of Harvard, only about 15 percent. Mr. Carnesale said the deficit last year was $300,000 on a budget of $42 million. The recession has also caused a sharp increase in requests for financial aid, he said.
Mr. Carnesale said he planned some consolidation of the school's curriculum and eight largely autonomous research centers. In line with a program for all of Harvard initiated by Mr. Rudenstine, he said the Kennedy School would concentrate on health-care issues, education policy and environmental questions. The school awards master's degrees in public policy and public administration.
The current retrenchment was actually begun two years ago by Mr. Bok when he appointed Robert Putnam, a respected political scientist, to succeed Mr. Allison, who remained on the faculty when he resigned as dean. Mr. Putnam said he was shocked to find "that we simply didn't know where we were financially." Last summer Mr. Putnam resigned unexpectedly, worn down, colleagues say, by his role as an accountant and by strong opposition from some of the practitioners who found him suspect because of his scholarly background.
The conflict between the two groups of faculty has continued under Mr. Carnesale, with each side expressing scorn for the other.
"It's impossible to have rigorous standards for practitioners," said one professor of economics, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "We only get the ones who are about to be out of office, and when they get here, they don't do research, which is half of the work."
Another frequent complaint by the scholars is that the practitioners were originally intended to stay for only a few years, bringing their fresh experience with them, and then return to new jobs in government or journalism. Instead, some of the former officials have stayed on at the Kennedy School for a decade or more.
On the other side, some practitioners believe that some scholars are simply jealous that they tend to appear more often on television or the Op-Ed pages of major newspapers. "You can never underestimate the power of envy," said a lecturer, who also spoke on the condition that his name not be used.
Mr. Carnesale insists that "the creative tensions in this school are inherent in the undertaking," since the Kennedy School was a professional school at an academic university. "The trick is to find the right balance between scholars and practitioners and to respect each other's contributions," he said.
But Mr. Carnesale acknowledged he believed that the Kennedy School now should "regularize" its guidelines on how long to keep practitioners and what standards to set for them. Last spring, in fact, Mr. Carnesale was chairman of a committee that recommended that practitioners be subject to the same eight-year deadline faced by scholars seeking tenure. At that time they would have to win a tenure-like appointment or move on.
Despite the bickering among the faculty, there is agreement among professors, administrators and students that the quality of the graduate students at the Kennedy School has sharply improved over the past decade, and now may rival those at Harvard's law and business schools. Still, a number of students say they would like to see more practitioners, not fewer.
"The school should balance its academically-bloated ranks with more professionals who have experience" in government, said Christopher Parker, who received a master's degree in public policy last June and now works as an analyst at the Office of Management and Budget in Washington. "I think the Kennedy School should be a training ground for professionals rather than a place where academic research dominates."
Lisa Duperier, a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Commerce in the Bush Administration who is in the mid-career graduate program, sees another weakness. "It wouldn't hurt to have one or two more conservative scholars on the faculty," she said. "A lot of Republicans don't know they can come to the Kennedy School, do research and receive high-quality professional support."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Bankruptcy Explanation By Maxwell

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
A main reason the board of the Maxwell Communication Corporation took the unusual step of seeking bankruptcy protection from creditors in the United States was to try to avoid a piecemeal selloff of its businesses by its bankers, the company's leaders said today.
This helps explain why bankers are furious that the heavily indebted British publishing company filed in New York for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code on Monday night. The filing came after a meeting between Maxwell Communication and the eight-member steering committee of the banks on Monday afternoon. At that meeting, according to both sides, the company's executives did not mention the possibility that they might file for Chapter 11. 
 "We are absolutely livid," an official at one bank on the steering committee said today, echoing what other bankers also said in interviews. The bankers met all day today in an attempt to explore various options, which reportedly included legally challenging Maxwell Communication's right to file for bankruptcy protection in the United States as opposed to Britain. They apparently did not reach a final decision.
Maxwell Communication today applied to a British court to place the company in administration, which is the British equivalent of bankruptcy protection. At a news conference today, Peter Laister, the company's chairman, and David Shaffer, the managing director, stressed that the action in Britain was taken to support the Chapter 11 filing and make it more difficult for someone to legally challenge it.
In other words, the request that an administrator be appointed was not an alternative to Chapter 11. And if Maxwell Communication's board gets what it wants, a court-appointed administrator would wield relatively little power over the company. Administrators in Britain typically control the company in bankruptcy and have considerable freedom to close or sell businesses and make other important decisions. But in the case of a Maxwell Communication operating in Chapter 11, the administrator would apparently only be able to express his position to the company's board and management, which they could ignore.
 
Bankers Want to Choose
 One indication of how angry the bankers are is that they asked the British court to appoint an administrator of their choice -- someone from Price Waterhouse -- rather than the administrator from another accounting firm, Touche Ross & Company, which Maxwell Communication requested. The judge took the petitions under advisement and issued a stay on the request for administration until Friday.
As far as many of Maxwell Communication's 43 banks had been concerned, the issue before Monday night was not whether or not to sell off Maxwell Communication's businesses one by one in an attempt to repay its debts. The issue was whether they should liquidate the company now or wait perhaps two or three years when the economy in the United States improved and the businesses would fetch a higher price.
The company now estimates that its debts to banks and bondholders total somewhere from 1.3 billion to more than 1.4 billion ($2.37 billion to $2.55 billion) and Mr. Shaffer said the company's liabilities "probably exceed" the value of its assets.
About 80 percent of the assets od Maxwell Communication are in North America. Its main businesses, which are based in the United States, include Macmillan Inc. book publishers, Official Airline Guides and half of Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing. The company's leaders cited this fact as a justification for the Chapter 11 filing, although none of the subsidiaries were included in the bankruptcy filing.
Mr. Shaffer also said he feared that the confidence of creditors, customers, suppliers and employees of the operations in the United States would have been shaken if the company had sought only British administration. That would have weakened the company and decreased its chances for emerging from bankruptcy largely intact.
And Mr. Laister and Mr. Shaffer -- both of whom have been in their jobs only two weeks -- insisted that they thought that all creditors and stakeholders would fare better in the end if most of the company were retained.
"The objective of Chapter 11 is in fact to see some reconstruction and come out at the far end," Mr. Laister said. "The process of administration perhaps results in that less often."
According to Mr. Laister and Mr. Shaffer, the tone of the Monday afternoon meeting with the bank steering committee, led by Credit Lyonnais and the Barclays Bank, played a major role in the decision to file for Chapter 11 protection. For about two weeks, the company had been seeking an agreement that would extend through March the time by which the banks would not take action on loans that would force the company into bankruptcy or receivership.
The banks had granted only an informal standstill, and that expires on Friday, and "a number of banks" had not even been willing to commit themselves to that, Mr. Laister said.
Mr. Laister also confirmed today that the private Maxwell companies had owned about 80 percent of Maxwell Communication's shares, much higher than the 68 percent stake previously disclosed. Investigators believe that one reason the shares were purchased was to help support the price of the stock -- which collateralized loans to other Maxwell private companies.

HEADLINE: Hudson Valley Reels Under Impact of I.B.M. Cuts

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 13

 BODY:
I.B.M. isn't merely a prime mover of the economy here in Dutchess County. With some 20,000 workers -- 10 times as many as the next largest private employer -- I.B.M. is the economy. And now that the International Business Machines Corporation is pulling in its reins, each tug seems to spread anxiety across the soft hills of this rural county at the edge of the suburbs.
"Every family must have at least one member who works for I.B.M.," said Ellen Grogan, who counts two nephews, a brother-in-law and a future son-in-law there. "Rumors plague the area. People are scared. The security is gone -- the sense that I.B.M. will support us." 
 The frisson of fear reverberates across the Hudson Valley as the troubled computer giant continues to whittle its workforce. I.B.M. is the largest private employer in three counties: Dutchess, which is home to two big plants producing semiconductors and mainframe computers that account for 16 percent of all jobs in the county; Westchester, where I.B.M. has its world headquarters, and Ulster, home to a major manufacturing and development center.
 
Effects Felt All Over
 Most everyone, from county officials to I.B.M. employees, acknowledges that consolidation is necessary for the company to remain competitive. And they add that I.B.M.'s no-layoff policy has taken the sting out of the cutbacks, which are to be achieved primarily through early retirements and financial incentives. Yet the pangs of retrenchment are being widely felt: in housing and commercial real estate, in retail sales, in support for charities.
In Dutchess, I.B.M. has eliminated 4,000 jobs since 1983, when the workforce there peaked at 24,700. In Westchester, where I.B.M. accounts for 2 percent of all jobs, the number of employees has fallen by 3,000, from 15,000 in 1985 to 12,000. And in Ulster, the number of jobs fell from 7,000 in 1985 to 5,700 in 1990, for a loss of 1,300.
Those cutbacks happened before I.B.M. announced that it planned to cut 20,000 jobs worldwide this year out of a workforce of 350,000. Another announcement recently indicated that I.B.M. would try to match that number next year.
"They are talking about cutting 20,000 next year, and we could lose 600 to 1,000 people," said Constance S. Freid, director of the Westchester County Office of Economic Development. "That could have a severe impact on the county. These people have mortgages to pay and children to send to school. We count on them to boost our retail sales."
In all three counties, the fallout is similar. The housing market has suffered since I.B.M. -- whose initials, employees used to say, stood for "I've Been Moved" -- has slowed the practice of rotating staff through the New York region, as have other big companies.
 
Driving Force in Real Estate
 "In the past, all the major Westchester corporations -- Nynex, I.B.M., Texaco, Pepsico -- took their most promising field managers and brought them to the corporate headquarters for a couple of years," said Joseph F. Dzaluk, a former employee relations adviser in personnel at I.B.M. headquarters in Armonk and now the executive director of the Westchester Housing Forum, a nonprofit group encouraging the creation of affordable housing. "That provided a cushion of well-paid people buying homes in the $300,000 to $400,000 range," he said. "But those companies are not doing that as much today."
Dolores Y. Newberry of W. J. Lavery Real Estate in LaGrange, who is regional vice president for the lower Hudson region of the New York State Association of Realtors, agreed. "You could always count on a lot of people being transferred into Dutchess County by I.B.M., and that kept the market active for sellers and buyers," she said. "I.B.M. is not moving people like they did."
The commercial office market has also been hurt by the company's efforts to move employees from buildings it leases to buildings it owns.
In the last five or six years, real estate experts and builders in Dutchess County say, I.B.M. has vacated 500,000 square feet of office space.
"Years ago, builders would put up offices on speculation, knowing that I.B.M. would eventually rent it," said Lucille P. Pattison, the Dutchess County Executive. "When a landlord had vacant space, he didn't worry. But you can no longer count on I.B.M. as the tenant of Dutchess County."
In Westchester, a major landlord was forced to seek protection under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy laws just before I.B.M. left a 212,000-square-foot building in Rye Brook in October. Two years ago, I.B.M. vacated a 400,000-square-foot building in downtown White Plains, and now the owner, who has filed for bankruptcy protection, is trying to stave off foreclosure.
 
Charities Affected
 The changes at I.B.M. are also hurting charities because donations are down, from individual I.B.M. employees -- since there are fewer of them -- and from the company. John J. Durkin, president of the United Way of Dutchess County, said that I.B.M.'s corporate donation has remained the same for the last three years, at $1.1 million. "Before, we were getting increases of 5, 8 and 10 percent a year."
"People are saying the good old days are over," Mr. Durkin said. "All through the 1970's and most of the 1980's, I.B.M. was extremely prosperous, and there was a mentality of prosperity here that people thought would reign forever."
I.B.M., however, says that it is not pulling the plug on the Hudson Valley, which stretches from Westchester County on the east side of the river north to Columbia and from Rockland County on the west side of the Hudson north to Ulster.
Jim Ruderman, a spokesman for I.B.M., said that this year the company expected a "small drop" in its Westchester workforce -- somewhere in the hundreds. "We're not going to be growing in the county," Mr. Ruderman said. "But we're also not planning to pull out of the county. We've been part of Westchester for quite a while, and we have some of our key operations there."
 
Commitment to Area
 Dutchess County should not expect any Draconian changes either, he said. "I see us being relatively stable there," Mr. Ruderman said. "The manufacturing work that we're doing in Dutchess is an integral part of our business."
I.B.M., in fact, recently invested $50 million in a state-of-the-art "clean room" for technological research in East Fishkill, where the company makes semiconductors.
Despite the thousands of positions cut from I.B.M.'s complexes in the Hudson Valley, unemployment rates there are still low, relative to the state and nation. While the jobless rate in New York State is 7 percent, Dutchess's is 4.8 percent and Westchester's and Ulster's are both 5.3 percent.
"The Hudson Valley was the No. 1 growth region of the state in the 1980's, and it's still holding up relatively well now," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York City.
 
'Nothing Is Stable'
 "Anything that happens to I.B.M. is going to swing things and going to have major impacts, but so far the way it hurts most is that the Hudson Valley is not getting the growth they had in the 1980's," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. "It's a shift. The lesson of this period is that no community is immune. Now, nothing is stable. All the insulation has worn away."
Mrs. Pattison, the Dutchess County Executive, echoed that view. "I believe this is the first time in modern history that Dutchess has ever felt a recession," she said. "In the early 1980's, we didn't feel a pinch because of I.B.M.'s growth. We always felt invulnerable to the economic pressures on the rest of the country, but that's no longer true."
I.B.M.'s contraction should be a wake-up call, business leaders in Dutchess say. "The positive side is that it might push the county to approach economic diversification," said Jerry McDonald, president of the Dutchess County Economic Development Corporation, a private, non-profit organization whose goal is to attract new businesses.
In Ulster County, elected officials are trying to focus on the ultimate and, ideally, positive consequences of I.B.M.'s cuts: that the company will become stronger in the long run. "In some ways, when I.B.M. sneezes, everyone gets a cold," said Richard B. Mathews, the Republican chairman of the Ulster County Legislature. "We have to do more with less. But in the long run we hope that I.B.M. will still be a major presence here."

HEADLINE: Bank C.D. Yields Off Again

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to decline through the week that ends today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, a publication based in North Palm Beach, Fla., that reports on interest rates.
"Because of more weak economic signals, such as a fall in housing starts, and with no inflation in the wind, look for the Federal Reserve to lower the disccount rate momentarily," Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. "That should trigger another decline in the banks' prime rate, especially since their cost of funds has fallen." 
 "It is a grim consumer earnings picture for an investor for at least six months or more because we have not yet seen the bottom of the numbers," Mr. Heady said.
The nationwide average yield on money market accounts dropped to 4.40 percent, off 7 basis points, and the six-month certificate yield declined 11 basis points, to 4.44 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The New York commercial banks averaged lower rates than those outside the area. On money market accounts, the yield averaged 4.11 percent, down 7 basis points since last week, and on the three-month certificates, the banks now offer 4.04 percent on average, down 12 basis points.
In the case of money market accounts, the largest cuts among New York commercial banks were made by Manufacturers Hanover and Chemical Banking, which each cut their yields 26 basis points. In addition, Manufacturers Hanover made the biggest cuts in three-month and six-month certificates lowering the yields by 41 points and 52 points, respectively.
At savings institutions in the New York area, yields for money market accounts were cut to an average 4.78 percent, down 5 basis points; for three-month certificates to an average of 4.72 percent, down 11 basis points, and for six-month certificates to an average of 4.90 percent, down 10 basis points.

HEADLINE: Panel Weighs Requirement For Free Anti-Smoking Ads

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The New York City Council held hearings yesterday on an anti-smoking bill that would require public service messages on billboards in subways and bus shelters to counter the seductive influence of cigarette advertisements on the young.
The measure would also outlaw smoking by anyone, adult or juvenile, in public schools during school hours and would require buyers of cigarettes to prove that they are older than 18 by showing a driver's license or state identification card. 
 The bill has the support of Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Mayor David N. Dinkins. Several legislators said they expected it to be passed in some form early next year, although there were many details to be ironed out, especially how the public service advertisements would be financed.
The most controversial provision of the bill, called the Tobacco Product Regulation Act, would require that for every three cigarette advertisements in buses, bus shelters, subways, telephone booths, baseball stadiums and other city-owned property similar space be provided for a free-of-charge anti-smoking advertisement. The bill does not say who would produce the advertisements.
The testimony at the hearing set the stage for an emotional battle over cigarette advertising in the city that will pit the interests of advertising and tobacco companies against those of anti-smoking groups.
On one side, proponents of the bill accused the tobacco industry yesterday of directing some advertisements at children, like the cartoonish Joe Camel series for Camel cigarettes. The supporters said children had a right to know the other side of the story.
"We should not be advertising poisons and things that promote death," Dr. Harold Freeman, a Harlem surgeon who is an adviser to President Bush on cancer, told the Council Health Committee. "This bill does at least give youth the opportunity to hear the truth."
But lobbyists for cigarette companies claimed the measure would run afoul of free speech protections under the United States Constitution. And business leaders said it was unclear who would end up picking up the tab for the public service messages during an economically difficult time when every advertising dollar counts.
 
Tobacco Institute View
 Adding to the complexities surrounding the bill, lawyers for the Dinkins administration also raised questions about whether the city had the legal authority to force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to accept the public service advertisements. In addition, franchise agreements with the New York Yankees and the New York Mets may make it difficult to enforce such regulations at the two baseball stadiums, said Andrea Cohen, an assistant corporation counsel.
David Reemes, a Washington lawyer representing the Tobacco Institute, said the bill would amount to "a de facto ban on cigarette ads" because agents selling outdoor space would not want to subsidize the public service advertisements. He also said the industry would challenge the bill on free-speech grounds if it were passed.
Testifying in favor of the bill, a 52-year-old former model, Linda Sackman, told of losing her larynx and nearly her life to throat cancer after smoking for almost 33 years. Ms. Sackman began her career at 17 as the glamourous model in the Lucky Strike cigarette advertisements.
She said she wished every child who considered smoking could trade places with her for a moment. "That would teach them very quickly."


GRAPHIC: Highlights of the Tobacco Product Regulation Act, sponsored by City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.
Chart: "Legislation: Clearing the Air"
 Age Limit: Everyone who buys or sells tobacco in the city would have to be at least 18 years old, and prove it with a driver's license, passport or state identification.
 Ban in School: Smoking would be banned in city schools during school hours.
 Advertising: One public health message about the hazards of smoking would be required for every three tobacco advertisements on subways, trains, buses, taxicabs, ferries, trams, bus shelters, city-owned property, or any property "to which a permit license or other authorization has been granted by the city of New York."
 Fines: $300 for a first violation of the law, $500 for the second violation and $1,000 for all later violations.

HEADLINE: Dow Rally Ends With A 16.77 Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks took modest losses in heavy trading yesterday, with some traders seeing disappointment at the Federal Reserve's failure to move quickly to lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 16.77 points to close at 2,902.28.
After opening higher, then surrendering those gains, stocks moved lower in choppy trading, as investors waited to see if the Fed, after its Open Market Committee meeting, would make another rate cut. 
 But by late morning, the Fed indicated that it had not eased credit by draining reserves from the banking system, and investors, after a four-day rally, began backing off.
 
Broader Gauges Lower
 The New York Stock Exchange composite index slipped 0.87 point, to 211.21, as volume reached 191.7 million shares, up from 172.5 million on Monday. Declining issues easily outpaced gaining ones, 1,139 to 594.
Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 1.72, to 382.74, while the American Stock Exchange index slipped 0.64, to 369.81. The Nasdaq index was down a sharp 4.03, to 539.70, while the Russell 2,000, which tracks smaller stocks, dropped 0.89, to 177.66.
Traders said the approaching expiration on Friday of options on individual stocks, indexes and futures contracts also limited the potential for yesterday's market to rise.
The release of weak housing-start numbers for November had little effect, traders said. But the absence of Fed intervention did hurt.
 
Union Carbide Off
 Elsewhere in the market, Union Carbide's intention to spin off its industrial gases business to shareholders, moved Standard & Poor's to change its rating to "negative," from "stable." The agency noted that all the publicly rated debt and commercial paper, which was guaranteed by Union Carbide's chemical and plastics unit, would be solely dependent on the chemical business. The stock fell 3/8 to finish at 19 1/4.
Tenneco also fell 3/8, to 29 1/8, as it said it would cut more than 6,000 jobs by the end of next year. The company said $50 million, beyond the $250 million previously announced, would be saved.
Traders said Shao Wang, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, cut his earnings forecast for Digital Equipment and repeated his "hold" rating on the stock. They said he cited continued weak demand and other factors. The stock was off 1/2, to 56 1/2.
 
Paper Sector Down
 The ecoonomy's gloomy outlook was one reason Chad E. Brown, a Merrill Lynch analyst, lowered his earnings estimates and ratings on several paper companies. He said that in talking to industry officials, he was getting confirmation that white paper, coated paper and newsprint prices were continuing to weaken.
Among the companies he mentioned were International Paper, which fell 1 1/8, to 63 3/4; Georgia-Pacific, which lost 2 5/8, to 48 7/8, and Boise Cascade, which was off 1, to 18 3/4.

HEADLINE: 9 Towns Spare No Effort to Snare New Plant

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 17

 BODY:
At a time when most regions have been battered by the recession and many manufacturing industries are shrinking, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation is offering a potential economic bonanza to some lucky community: a new aircraft plant that could ultimately create 10,000 or more jobs.
But as it examines nine competing sites from Alabama to Arizona, McDonnell Douglas is looking for a lot in return. In addition to 600 acres adjacent to an airport, the company is seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in financial aid from state and local governments, including tax breaks and worker-training programs. The company also wants to avoid the heavy regulation and high costs of doing business in the current home of its jetliner business, California, which it has ruled out as a site for the new plant. 
 The selection is extremely important to McDonnell Douglas, the nation's largest military contractor and the second-largest builder of commercial jetliners, after Boeing. The company needs to build a highly efficient plant at the lowest possible cost to produce a new long-range jumbo jetliner, the MD-12, which it is counting on to help it survive intense worldwide competition.
 The process also suggests the rewards -- and the considerable risks -- for cities and states as they battle one another to attract businesses and give their economies a lift. The nine cities wooing McDonnell Douglas are Fort Worth; Houston; Kansas City, Mo.; Mesa, Ariz.; Mobile, Ala.; Salt Lake City; Shreveport, La.; Tulsa, Okla., and Belleville, Ill., which is just across the Mississippi River from St. Louis, where McDonnell Douglas is based.
Attracting businesses has become a serious enterprise for many states and cities and has taken on added importance as the economy has slumped. Indianapolis recently won a heated competition for a United Airlines maintenance center by offering the company nearly $300 million in state and local financial assistance in return for a pledge to create 6,300 jobs.
But public officials, academics and private consultants say city and state governments frequently fail to take a hard look at whether the economic payoff will justify their investment of taxpayer money. In some cases, these people say, it may be decades before governments will be able to calculate whether an employer has created enough jobs and generated sufficient additional tax revenue to offset the financial incentives they granted.
In other instances, the community has been a clear loser. In Yonkers, north of New York City, the Otis Elevator Company shut a plant in the mid-1980's just a few years after the city and the state invested $14 million to help build it.
McDonnell Douglas could possibly create a similar problem, some analysts said. The company has been losing market share in jetliners and suffering from the decline in Pentagon spending. It recently agreed to sell 40 percent of its commercial aircraft business to the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation for $2 billion.
"Cities and states have been burned before," said Virginia Mayer, the manager of economic development for the National League of Cities. "They have to think harder about whether it's worth it, given the fiscal stress they are going through."
Larry Ledebur, the director of the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State University in Detroit, said that in many cases governments offered too much in incentives, not realizing that companies tend to make decisions primarily on criteria like access to markets, transportation and other costs.
"The first question you have to ask is whether it is necessary to give incentives to get the firm there," Professor Ledebur said. "But we are in a world where cities and states feel they have to offer a competitive incentive package."
 In McDonnell Douglas's case, each interested city has submitted a package of financial incentives to the company, which is expected to announce a decision early next year. The bids are sealed, but state and local officials said most or all of them appeared to offer incentives worth at least several hundred million dollars, primarily in the form of tax breaks, improvements to roads and other structures and worker-training programs.
The officials involved in putting together the incentive packages say they tried to tie the level of tax breaks and other support to the number of jobs created or other economic criteria. And there are signs of a reluctance to attract McDonnell Douglas at any cost: residents of Kansas City, for example, voted down a proposed $90 million property tax increase that would have helped to pay for improvements to the site McDonnell Douglas is considering.
"This is the biggest economic development package in this decade, and maybe in many decades," said Carl M. Koupal Jr., the director of Missouri's Department of Economic Development. "But there's some realization by all of us involved in these situations that you can't just roll in and start throwing money at these projects."
 
Fear of Bidding Wars
 Officials of the competing regions say they want to avoid bidding wars.
"If someone wants to give up the farm, I congratulate McDonnell Douglas on getting it, but they're not going to get it from us," said John Baricevic, chairman of the St. Clair County Board of Supervisors in Illinois, which is trying to bring the plant to the St. Louis area. "We've tried to be responsive to McDonnell Douglas's needs, but we have our other taxpayers to think about as well."
McDonnell Douglas originally announced that it would consider only four sites -- Kansas City, Salt Lake City, Shreveport and Tulsa -- then later said it would expand its search after being approached by the other localities.
In addition to evaluating the packages of financial incentives, McDonnell Douglas is assessing local wage rates, access to highways and rail lines, environmental regulations and the political support the company could expect.
 The attraction of the McDonnell Douglas plant is easy to see. The company estimates that it would need about 5,000 workers, many of them trained production workers making $15 an hour or more. Economists estimate that the plant would create another 5,000 jobs at everything from new restaurants nearby to suppliers that would be compelled to establish operations in the area.
Some estimates put the economic benefits much higher. One particularly rosy estimate was provided by the Mid-America Regional Council, a Kansas City research group that estimated that the plant would create 19,000 jobs and generate $505 million in additional after-tax income in the Kansas City area, based on what the researchers called a "conservative realistic scenario."
Likening financial incentives to an investment, the researchers calculated that the rate of return to Kansas City for a $500 million, 20-year package of incentives would be nearly 30 percent, using what they called extremely conservative assumptions.
 
Political Move in Utah
 The prospect of an economic jolt of that magnitude has communities eager to impress McDonnell Douglas with more than financial incentives.
In Utah, officials removed a potential political thorn from the company's side. The Republican-controlled State Legislature redrew the boundaries of a Congressional district in October to insure that Representative Wayne Owens, a Democrat who has clashed repeatedly in Washington with McDonnell Douglas over the need for one of its military aircraft, would no longer represent the area near the Salt Lake City airport where officials hope the company will build the factory.
"The Legislature was just making sure there wasn't a political reason to rule us out," said Russell G. Behrmann, a spokesman for the Utah Department of Community and Economic Development.
 Company executives have left no doubt that in selecting the site they are trying to avoid the kinds of troubles they have had in California.
Though based in St. Louis, the company has built its commercial jetliners in Long Beach, Calif., for decades. McDonnell Douglas says it cannot build the MD-12 in Long Beach because it does not have room at its site there.
But company executives have also made no secret of their displeasure with California's high labor costs, tight environmental regulations and what many executives say is a lack of support among the state's Congressional delegation. And the company is not considering alternative sites in California, including the Mojave Desert town of Palmdale, where there is plenty of land and a skilled work force that has helped to build aircraft like the Northrop Corporation's B-2 bomber.
 
Others Leave California
 California, in many ways, is the flip side of the rush among many states to attract manufacturing jobs. McDonnell Douglas is just one of a number of aerospace companies that are beginning to move from the state.
In a study released last month, the California Business Roundtable, a research and lobbying group financed by corporations, found that nearly a quarter of the companies surveyed planned to relocate some or all of their operations out of California and that a similar number planned to pursue expansion plans elsewhere.
It is little surprise, then, that other localities are rushing to assure McDonnell Douglas that it will face few or none of the problems it has in California. Shreveport, like other cities, has been telling the company that because its region's air meets Federal standards, there are almost no regulations regarding air pollution. That would leave McDonnell Douglas free to come in and operate in a way California would not allow.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A site near St. Louis is one of nine competing for a McDonnell Douglas commercial jetliner plant. (St. Clair County) (pg. Chart: "Vying for a New Factory"
 Nine cities are conpeting for a new McDonnell Douglas plant. The company is based in St. Louis and has major aircraft operations in Long Beach, Calif.
 1. Salt Lake City: The company already has a commercial aircraft parts plant near the airport. The state recently redrew a Congressional districtboundary so the proposed site would not be represented by a Congressional critic of McDonnell Douglas.
 2. Mesa: The Arizona city is home to the McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Company and would be convenient for the commercial aircraft division's esecutives, who are based in Southern California.
 3. Forth Worth: The city's bid is backed by H. Ross Perot, who owns land that could be the plant site. The region has thousands of trained aerospace workers laid off from General Dynamics.
 4. Houston: The company has a plant in the area that does work for NASA's space station, but the city is considered a long shot.
 5. Kansas City: Voters in Missouri rejected a $90 million property-tax increase to pay for site improvements, but city and state governments say their proposal is competitive.
 6. Tulsa: The area is already an aerospace center, with more than 350 aerospace companies there, including a large McDonnell Douglas operation.
 7. Belleville: A trained pool of labor, including many workers laid off from McDonnell Douglas's military programs, live in this Illinois town east of St. Louis.
 8. Shreveport: Economically depressed Louisiana is pushing hard for the plant. Economic development officials have received 80,000 pieces of mail from residents in support of efforts to attract the company.
 9. Mobile: The Alabama city has an expanding aerospace industry and a port to bring in large aircraft parts. (pg. D6)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Fed Appoints Chief Of Currency Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
William J. McDonough, a former vice chairman of the First Chicago Corporation, was named yesterday to direct the Federal Reserve's intervention operations in world currency markets.
The job puts him at one of the key pivots in the $600-billion-a-day foreign exchange market. 
 While a central bank like the Federal Reserve cannot determine the direction of the currency market, intervention by selling or buying dollars can often help slow or even stop a rally or a decline of the dollar. Intervention is also one of the key ways that the United States Government can send a distinct signal about its desire for the dollar and, indirectly, its feeling about other economic policy matters.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York does the actual intervention, which Mr. McDonough will run. The intevention is approved by the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve. Mr. McDonough was named to two jobs yesterday, one as an executive vice president of the New York bank and the other as manager of foreign operations for the Federal Reserve System.
The Fed's last major period of intervention was from May to October 1989, when is sold a record $17.8 billion of dollars in six months and helped turn a dollar rally.
Mr. McDonough's appointment, which was announced by E. Gerald Corrigan, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, is unusual because he comes from outside the Reserve Bank or the Treasury and has not been a player in these circles. He succedes Sam Y. Cross, who came to the Fed with a Treasury background 10 years ago. Mr. Cross retired this month.
Although he has never been a foreign exchange trader himself, Mr. McDonough supervised the foreign exchange and other trading operations for years while he was at First Chicago and its bank, the First National Bank of Chicago. For at least six years, he said, he spent at least 30 hours a week in the trading room.
When he retired from the bank at age 55 in 1989, he had no intention of sitting on the sidelines. Since then he has been an adivser to the World Bank and chairman of an Illinois commission studying ways to attract and keep highly qualified workers in state and local government.
His outside interests are in tennis, foreign affairs and the opera. "I am a tenor who sings at parties, hopefully only when asked," he said. He and his wife, plan to live in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Commerce Dept. Losing One More Top Official

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Michael R. Darby, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, announced his resignation today in the agency's latest high-level departure.
Mr. Darby, whose responsibilities included overseeing the 1990 Census, becomes the third of the Commerce Department's six under secretaries to take a new job this year. His announcement today that he would return to teaching to avoid losing a tenured faculty position coincides with speculation in Washington over who will replace Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher when he resigns to become chairman of President Bush's re-election campaign.
 
Work Done by Staff
 But the high turnover rate has had limited effect, because so much of the department's daily work is done by the staff. Mr. Mosbacher has concentrated this year on domestic political and economic policy making at the White House and on urging business leaders to export more, rather than on promoting the department's role in interagency decision making. The State and Defense Departments, for example, are increasingly influential in export control regulations. 
 Of the 10,000 employees at the Economics and Statistics Administration, which Mr. Darby heads, only a handful are political appointees.
No successor to Mr. Mosbacher is likely to be named until after he returns from a trip to Asia on Jan. 10 and resigns, probably the following week, to head up the Bush campaign.
Deputy Commerce Secretary Rockwell A. Schnabel will be the Acting Secretary during Mr. Mosbacher's absence and during the confirmation hearings of a successor. He is not expected to make any substantial changes.
 
To Depart Jan. 4
 Mr. Darby's departure, which is planned for Jan. 4, follows the resignation in May of Dennis Kloske, the Under Secretary for Export Administration, and the promotion of Mr. Schnabel from Under Secretary for Travel and Tourism.
Two widely mentioned candidates to succeed Mr. Mosbacher have been John B. Macomber, the chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, and Bill Frenzel, a former Minnesota Republican who served for 16 years on the House Ways and Means Committee and focused on trade issues.
But one official familiar with the selection process said today that Mr. Macomber's name had already been ruled out, because the White House was interested in nominating someone who could help the Administration more in an election year, like a woman, a member of a minority or someone with strong political connections in a key state.
"It won't be him; they need the political mileage on this appointment," said the official, who asked not to be named.
Mr. Macomber, who the official said did not actively seek the position, comes from New York, which may prove important in next year's elections, but as a former management consultant and chemical company executive who has never held elective office, he has little voter recognition.
 
No Call, Frenzel Says
 Mr. Frenzel said today that while he would not rule out accepting the job if pressed to take it, he had not been contacted by the White House.
Mr. Darby, who is 46 years old, was told that if he did not return to his tenured position at the John E. Anderson School of Business at the University of California at Los Angeles by the beginning of the year he would lose it automatically, Carol A. Scott, the faculty chairman, said today.
Mr. Darby, who spent nearly three years as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Economic Affairs before moving to the Commerce Department in May 1989, has received several extensions to his original leave of absence.

HEADLINE: Bam! Pow! Margins! Sales Mix!

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Will Marvel Entertainment Group's shareholder reports become collector's items?
Yesterday, the comic book publisher released its first quarterly report since Marvel became a public company in July. The report came out in the form of a four-page comic book, with Spider-Man and the Incredible Hulk, two of the company's comic characters, bragging to each other about just how wonderful a quarter it was. 
 But if the pictures were familiar to comic book readers, the words may have seemed a little on the formal side. "Gross margins increased due to the favorable sales mix of publications and higher licensing revenues," Incredible Hulk explains to Spider-Man at one point. "And interest expense declined due to lower interest rates and reduced indebtedness."
But if some comic fans find that kind of talk perplexing, they are likely to understand, though perhaps not appreciate, the Hulk's next comment: "And after the quarter ended, we announced a $0.25 retail price increase for most of our comic books in 1992."
The financial figures in the report had previously been released, showing that net income in the third quarter more than tripled, rising to $6.7 million, or 55 cents a share, from $2.1 million, or 18 cents a share. Revenues were up 59 percent, to $38.3 million.
The results, together with expectations that comic book fans will willingly pay the higher prices, have helped raise Marvel's share price from $16.50 when it went public in July, to $42.75 yesterday, down 62.5 cents for the day in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Dropped 2.1% in November

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Housing starts fell 2.1 percent in November, all but assuring home builders of their worst year since the end of World War II, the Commerce Department reported today. The report apparently contributed to a White House decision to acknowledge that the economy remained in recession.
The housing industry traditionally leads the economy out of recession, but after a spurt earlier this year it has slumped along with the rest of the economy despite continuing declines in interest rates. 
 Mirroring the suggestions of many analysts, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said, "For all practical purposes, the recession continues."
The Bush Administration and many private economists have urged the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates to help revive the faltering economy.
The Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank's policy-making arm, met privately today amid expectations of a further easing of credit, perhaps as early as this week. This morning, however, the Fed drained reserves from the banking system when the overnight interest rate subject to its direct control slipped below the current target of 4 1/2 percent. This action was aimed at steadying rates, though analysts did not rule out later action to cut them. [Page D14.]
The housing figures followed by a day a Federal Reserve report showing that industrial production also fell in November, by four-tenths of a percent, after posting virtually no growth for three months.
In the housing report, the Commerce Department said new construction of single-family homes and apartments totaled a seasonally adjusted 1.066 million last month, down from 1.089 million in October. The decline was entirely in apartments.
"We are now guaranteed the lowest total since World War II," said David F. Seiders, an economist at the National Association of Home Builders.
The housing weakness was widespread. Starts fell in both the Midwest and West and barely rose in the South. Only the Northeast posted a sizable gain.
Starts in the first 11 months of the year were 16.5 percent below the 1990 period, and analysts said the 1991 total would be less than the 1.015 million units built in 1946 as the nation began to recover from the war. There had been just 325,000 starts in 1945.
"If we get a number in December that doesn't fall off the cliff, we will come in about 1.004 million for '91," Mr. Seiders said. "Even in 1982, one of the deepest recessions in memory, we had 1.062 million starts."
The revised 7.1 percent jump in October was the biggest advance since a 17.1 percent gain in February, when the housing industry began emerging from its recession.
But the increase was not as big as the 7.3 percent advance initially reported last month. And the 3.7 percent drop in September was a bit deeper than the original 3.5 percent estimate.
John A. Tuccillo, an economist with the National Association of Realtors, attributed the weakness to "a lapse in consumer confidence, diminished demand and the ongoing financing struggle in the building industry."
Analysts said snow and cold temperatures in November also curbed construction in some areas, particularly the Midwest.
But applications for building permits -- often a barometer of future activity -- suggested continued weakness. They fell 2.9 percent, to a 998,000 annual rate, after rising 4.5 percent a month earlier.
Despite the bleak outlook for 1991, analysts said the housing industry should resume growth early next year. Richard Peach, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association, said there were already reports of more prospective buyers looking at homes. As sales pick up, builders usually resume construction.
