HEADLINE: A Base for Post-Apartheid Profits

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Among all the departures of American companies from South Africa, perhaps none has had such a spectacular aftermath as the disinvestment of the Mobil Oil Corporation in 1989. The facilities it left behind have provided the catalyst for one of the more remarkable success stories in Africa's petroleum industry.
Mobil's oil refining and marketing operation was purchased for a little more than $230 million, a fraction of its value, by Gencor Ltd., the mining and industrial conglomerate. Since the birth of the new subsidiary, Engen (an abbreviation of Energy Gencor), in July 1989, the oil operation has generated such profits that Gencor could recoup its investment before the end of 1992. 
 And though its success may be the most noteworthy, Engen is only one of several South African units that were sold off by United States companies because of apartheid and are now benefiting from that institution's dismantling. Countries that once shunned trading with South Africa are beginning to show a willingess to do business with the nation's companies.
 
The de Klerk Track
 Mobil announced its departure from South Africa in April 1989, only months before F. W. de Klerk became President and transformed the political climate. But as Rob J. Angel, Engen's managing director, observed: "Everybody's wonderful being a Monday morning quarterback. Nobody but nobody expected de Klerk to come in eight months later and start South Africa on the track on which it's essentially continued from that time on."
Many businesses that were sold when American corporations left seem likely to keep operating independently in a post-apartheid South Africa, despite the lifting of economic sanctions by the Bush Administration in July. General Motors, for example, is not expected to buy back its former subsidiary in Port Elizabeth, which manufactures Opel automobiles as a local corporation called Delta Motors. The effect of such disinvestment is to leave South Africa with a home-grown industrial base that needs foreign investment, but does not need the old parent corporations.
Gencor was known for its mining, industrial and financial activities. But it also had a cluster of service stations operating under the name Trek, an interest in another fuel distributor called Sonap and investments in natural gas exploration off Africa's southernmost coast -- interests that, together, justified creating an energy division.
"But the thing they saw lacking was that they really had no core to that critical mass," Mr. Angel recalled. "They concluded that the only way they were going to develop that was to make a major acquisition."
The Mobil operation in South Africa that Gencor bought for a little more than 650 million rand, currently about $232 million, included a chain of service stations -- Engen now has more than 1,500 -- an oil refinery and some lesser assets. The liabilities included more than $100 million in debts inherited from Mobil's capital restructuring before it left.
Gencor persuaded Mr. Angel, a 49-year-old Australian chemical engineer who ran Mobil's operation in southern Africa, to stay on as the new managing director of Engen. Gencor agreed to avoid laying off any Mobil employees for a year and has since expanded the work force by 10 percent, to 3,700 people.
 
Rewards for Loyalty
 To insure loyalty, the company offered employees new stock at less than $4 a share, a third of the initial price. And Gencor has continued the work of the Mobil Foundation -- renamed the Energos Foundation -- which was heavily involved in social and economic projects for black South Africans.
Although South Africa remains in a recession and is starved for foreign capital, Engen's net income jumped by more than 34 percent, to the equivalent of $103 million, in the fiscal year ended Aug. 30. Dividends on its shares rose 20 percent. With a total market capitalization of $2 billion, Engen has become the seventh-largest industrial company listed on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange.
Americans can buy shares in Engen or other South African stocks through any of the major United States brokerages that handle them.
Engen now exports petroleum products to 15 other African countries and island states in the Indian Ocean. This accounts for only 5 percent of its sales volume, but Engen is expanding Mobil's old refinery in Durban to meet projected demand. A new issue of 44 million shares last March was snapped up, raising more than $390 million in fresh capital.
Engen's best asset is probably the potential market in sub-Saharan Africa. South Africa has no exploitable oil reserves, although because of sanctions it does manufacture fuel from coal and natural gas.
The South African Government purchases its oil quietly from other countries, often through middlemen, and subsidizes the resale to local wholesalers like Engen. Mr. Angel declined to discuss the arrangement, which the Government keeps secret because it circumvents the oil embargo placed on South Africa by the United Nations.
 
'We Can Compete Successfully'
 Sanctions notwithstanding, Engen has found that it can profitably import crude oil to Durban for refining and then market the finished product to the neighboring African countries willing to trade with it.
"Crude oil has to be processed somewhere," said John Roberts, Engen's financial director. "I think we can compete successfully against the Persian Gulf and against Singapore."
Mr. Angel said that South Africa's competitive refining costs offset the higher initial costs of shipping the crude oil to Durban. "We've got a pretty strong competitive position with places that are effectively just on our doorstep," Mr. Angel said. "Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Zambia, Zaire are really just natural markets for us." Engen is expanding its market farther north into Kenya.
To service sub-Saharan Africa, Engen is expanding and upgrading its Durban refinery, which will eventually raise production capacity to 150,000 barrels a day. The first phase, costing $225 million, will increase capacity 30 percent by next August. The second phase should cost about $535 million.
South African refineries have generally not been as large as those overseas, Mr. Angel said, "but as regards sophistication, they're probably ahead of the vast bulk of refineries in Europe."
 
Looking at Broader Markets
 Though Mr. Roberts said that Engen is primarily a marketing and refining company, it is becoming a more active trader, buying and selling oil that never reaches South Africa and planning to set up an office in Switzerland to improve its trading position.
By now, Engen has developed an inside knowledge of the crude oil market. "When U.N. sanctions go, we will start developing direct links between ourselves and producers," Mr. Angel said. "We've then got a few cards in our hands. We will not be an insignificant producer of crude oil."
Engen hopes to produce half of its own oil by the end of the decade. It has joined consortiums exploring for oil in Namibia and West Africa. And it has bought 27 percent of Gencor's 8 percent interest in the vast Alba oilfield and Kilda gas field under the North Sea off northeast Scotland.
Engen executives seem comfortable operating independently of Mobil.
The purchase agreement has precluded Engen from sharing Mobil's technology since July 1989. Engen must devise its own lubricants, for example, to replace outdated Mobil formulas. But Mr. Roberts is undaunted.
"The vast majority of technology is commercially available," he said, including a broad variety unavailable from Mobil. "Sometimes when you're part of a family, you're locked out of another family's technology."
By July 1994, Engen must also drop the Mobil trademark for its products, but as Mr. Angel said, "A new name really doesn't worry me."
Engen has attained significant independence, not only from Mobil but even from Gencor, and Engen executives appreciate having a free hand.
 
'We Were Stagnating'
 "Under the Mobil Corporation banner, we were stagnating; things are a little different now," said Barry Hurt, Engen's director of corporate relations. "All the projects we wanted to get involved with, where funds weren't forthcoming, suddenly started happening."
Although Mobil usually sent in a team of outsiders to handle major changes in its South African operations, Mr. Angel and his managers now do it themselves.
The growth of Engen testifies to local business confidence as South Africa moves toward democratic majority rule. Mr. Angel observed that whatever government came to power would need a thriving oil industry.
"The road into the future has not been and will not be a smooth one," Mr. Angel said. "But I think being South African, we can take a broader view of the risks than perhaps a multinational."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends the Day Lower As Cut in Rates Is Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower yesterday in a session dominated by speculation over when the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates again.
Many economists expect the Fed to cut interest rates soon, perhaps by today, as part of its continuing campaign to arouse a languid economy. 
 Andrew Hodge, vice president at Bank Brussels Lambert, said the dollar fell slightly about noon after the Fed drained funds from the banking system. The move surprised economists, who were expecting the Fed to add reserves as a means to lower rates. Despite the Fed's action, economists still believe rates will move lower.
A country's currency generally declines when its central bank lowers interest rates, a move that generally makes the currency less valuable to foreign investors. Mr. Hodge said the Fed's next move was so widely expected that he doubted the dollar would be hurt.
So far this year, the Fed has cut the discount rate four times, shaving two percentage points off the fee on its loans to Fed member banks. The rate now stands at 4 1/2 percent.
Despite the expectations about the Fed's action, Hubert Pedroli of Credit Suisse said the economy's poor performance provided a weak backdrop for the dollar.
"I think the trend is kind of unchanged," said Mr. Pedroli, Credit Suisse's manager of corporate foreign exchange. "Whether the Fed does anything or doesn't do anything, the dollar will still be under pressure."
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.28 yen, down 0.17 yen from Monday's close. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at a higher rate of 128.30 yen. At closing in New York, the dollar was at 128.29 yen, down from 128.40 late Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8200, from $1.8210 late Monday. At closing in New York, sterling cost $1.8275, more expensive than $1.8245 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5703 German marks, down from 1.5750; 1.3885 Swiss francs, down from 1.3935; 5.3635 French francs, down from 5.3805; 1,187.00 Italian lire, down from 1,188.75, and 1.14615 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1428.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.5770 German marks, down from 1.5785; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3945; 5.3845 French francs, down from 5.3895; 1.7750 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7780; 1,190.00 Italian lire, down from 1,191.25, and 1.1451 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1429.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Dep to Withdraw Stock Offering

 BODY:
The Dep Corporation, a Los Angeles-based maker of hair and skin-care products, said yesterday that it planned to withdraw its registration statement involving an offering of 1.7 million common shares. Robert Berglass, the chairman and president, cited "poor market conditions and the current price of the company's stock" as the primary considerations in the company's decision. 
 Also yesterday, Don E. Marsh, the president and chief executive of Marsh Supermarkets Inc. in Indianapolis, said the company planned to withdraw its registration statement regarding 3.9 million class B common shares because of economic conditions. He said the company's post-Thanksgiving sales were lower than expected.

HEADLINE: As Costs of New Drugs Rise, Hospitals Stick by Old Ones

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
When the CIBA-Geigy Corporation came out with a new arthritis drug two years ago, it filled medical journals with advertisements, hired Mickey Mantle with his arthritic knees as a spokesman and deployed representatives across the nation to leave free samples of the drug, Voltaren, in hospital doctors' lounges.
But at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, the campaign fell flat. The hospital's pharmacy committee decided that older, less expensive drugs were just as effective. The hospital's pharmacy would not stock Voltaren, the committee decreed, and its doctors should not use it. The hospital prohibited company representatives from promoting the drug on hospital premises or even mentioning it. 
 In the last five years, the hospital has rejected or placed restrictions on dozens of drugs.
 
Drugs at $3,000 a Dose
 "I get some flak from doctors and drug companies, but there's generally less of a fight than I would predict," said Harold DeMonaco, the hospital's chief of pharmacy. "I put on my white coat as a clinician and say, 'what we have already is just as good.' Then I put on my suit as an administrator and say, 'and by the way, it's cheaper.' "
As drug costs rise as much as 10 percent a year for hospitals, and with some bioengineered drugs selling for as much as $3,000 a dose, many hospitals are buying expensive new wonder drugs judiciously and limiting the drugs to the patients who are most likely to be helped by them.
Some institutions have even begun aggressive counter-advertising campaigns: when a drug company hands out a mug promoting a new fourth-generation antibiotic, the hospital counters with note pads reminding doctors of cheaper alternatives.
But the hospitals are battling a formidable foe. According to a recent Senate report, the pharmaceutical industry spends $10 billion a year on marketing, more than the roughly $9 billion spent on research and development. Industry analysts say companies spend more than $5,000 per doctor per year on marketing activities.
"Pharmacy budgets keep going up and up and up, and we're under increasing pressure to keep down costs," said Dr. Arthur Atkinson, chief of the pharmacy committee at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. Medicare, Medicaid and, in many states, private insurance plans pay a lump sum to hospitals for each patient according to the diagnosis, so the real costs of drugs are not passed on by the hospital to the patient. Some drugs about to go on the market cost more than a hospital is paid for a patient's entire stay.
Used properly, even thousand-dollar drugs can be money savers if they reduce the need for long hospital stays, said Dr. Stephen Schondelmeyer, an economist at the University of Minnesota. But that is rarely the case. So the new cost-consciousness means that hospitalized patients are less likely to be given the latest drug if its added benefits seem slim compared to its added cost. "If we spend dollars unwisely on expensive new products, another patient may not get the medicine he needs," Dr. Schondelmeyer said.
At some hospitals, doctors are forbidden to prescribe drugs that are not accepted by the pharmacy as cost-effective; at others, the drugs are allowed only with special permission. In some cases, pharmacists monitor doctors' prescribing habits and challenge those who order drugs that could be replaced by effective but cheaper alternatives.
 
Reining in Companies
 Most often, the restrictions apply to drugs still covered by patents; with drugs on which the patents have expired, most hospitals long ago abandoned brand name products for their generic equivalents.
In addition, many hospitals now restrict the activities of the freewheeling drug company representatives, called detail men.
Kaiser Permanente, a health maintenance organization in California, changed an open-door policy for drug company representatives at its 15 hospitals in northern California when "we realized that by remaining passive we were supporting marketing interests that we didn't agree with," said Francis J. Crosson, the company's associate executive director.
Under the new policy, representatives wear identifying badges and may enter only by appointment; seven pharmaceutical companies have been banished for six months for offenses that included paying $100 to doctors to attend dinners sponsored by the companies and improperly filling out applications, usually completed by doctors, to get drugs adopted by hospital pharmacies.
Virtually all hospitals have combined their policing efforts with moves to educate doctors about cost-effective drug use. Three years ago, Kaiser began hiring "counter-detail men," or pharmacists who roam the hospitals drumming up support for older, less expensive drugs. Mimicking the drug company representatives, they give free lunches and have mugs, calendars and pens produced bearing inspirational messages.
Often doctors appreciate the advice.
"Nobody from the drug industry details the cheap stuff, they only detail the new and wondrous," said Mr. DeMonaco of Massachusetts General. "So young doctors have a paucity of information about old standards like ampicillin, and are hounded to use expensive new antibiotics."
Some industry analysts have predicted that drug costs, which now make up less than 10 percent of most hospital budgets, could rise to 30 percent of operating expenses over the next decade, largely because of costly new medicines, said Dr. R. A. Branch, head of the Center for Clinical Pharmacology at the University of Pittsburgh. Kaiser's drug budget, even with intensive cost-control measures, has doubled since 1985, and Massachusetts General's pharmacy costs are rising an average of 9 percent a year.
 
Budget-Consuming Drugs
 Already, hospitals have seen how the advent of a single new drug can quickly eat up a hefty chunk of the budget. Toradol, a non-narcotic painkiller introduced last year for use after surgery, alone accounts for about 6 percent of many hospitals' drug costs. And hospital administrators are quaking at the impending release of Centoxin, a bioengineered medicine that is used in tandem with antibiotics to treat a type of overwhelming infection of the blood called sepsis when it is caused by certain bacteria. In Europe, where Centoxin is already on the market, the drug is selling for $3,800 a dose.
For about 20 percent of patients, the drug may make the difference between life and death, but for the rest it offers little help. However, tests that show who will benefit take two days; if doctors wait, patients who might benefit may die. Hospitals around the country are developing guidelines for the use of the drug.
"If we give it to everyone with septic shock, we could consume about 30 percent of our budget for pharmaceuticals and couldn't purchase cancer drugs or antibiotics," said Dr. Michael Rie, an intensive-care specialist at the University of Kentucky.
In many cases, however, drugs that cost far more than the medicines they replace offer advantages that are almost imperceptible or simply cosmetic.
Although either ampicillin, the old standby, or Suprax, a new antibiotic, will treat the average sore throat or respiratory infection, the new drug has a somewhat better cure rate against the rare resistant germ and need only be taken once a day, as opposed to four times for the older antibiotic. But ampicillin costs 10 cents a pill, compared with $10 a pill for Suprax.
In intensive-care units, patients can be sedated using a combination of new drugs given intravenously, for $10,000 a week, or using older drugs, whose patents have expired, for several hundred dollars. The new combination is slightly less irritating to the veins and its effects can be reversed more quickly when the patient is ready to come off the breathing machine.
 
Deals on Some Drugs
 With some newer classes of drugs, all the alternatives are still covered by exclusive patents and hospitals frequently negotiate discounted prices by agreeing to limit prescriptions to one product.
For drug companies, each decision by a pharmacy can yield pay dirt or dust. And so, when Northwestern Memorial decided on the Merck drug, Smith-Kline complained to the hospital's president about the decision -- and was overruled.
Where not restricted, drug company representatives know how to let themselves into locked lounges and continue to lavish doctors with gifts. After a recent agreement between the pharmaceutical industry and the American Medical Association to halt the practice of providing large equipment and expensive vacations to doctors, smaller prizes remain acceptable.
Hospital pharmacies have to work hard to limit costly prescribing under this sort of pressure. At Massachusetts General the pharmacy committee decided to stock Toradol, the pain medicine, but allows its routine use in only a limited number of chest-surgery patients. Independent studies have shown that for most people who have had operations, morphine works just as well if not better in the day after surgery, Mr. DeMonaco said, and it costs 16 cents, instead of the $6 per dose for the other drug.
 
Not for Sore Throats
 Many hospitals, like Kaiser, have published guidelines to help doctors select the proper drug for a given condition and have monitored their adherence to the advice. "If people need to use very expensive antibiotics for life-threatening infections, that's fine, but we don't want them used for sore throats," Dr. Atkinson said.
Massachusetts General now has a pharmacist on every ward to review doctors' drug orders and to encourage cost-effective prescribing.
Hospitals that have invested heavily in controlling costs say their programs have worked. Dr. Tracie Paiva, a pharmacist at Kaiser, is proud of the note pads printed to look like decks of cards, reading "Lisinopril, Kaiser's ACE of Hearts," promoting a cost-effective blood-pressure drug. "Since we started our program, our prescribing patterns have become very different than most other hospitals," she said.

HEADLINE: Family Rituals Dickens Could Hardly Imagine

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:
MENTION Christmas in most American households and visions of seasonal rituals dance like sugarplums.
Decorating the home, last-minute gift shopping and creamy eggnog dusted with nutmeg top a long list of things associated with the Christmas season, that traditional time of homecoming and cheer for Christians and many non-Christians alike. 
But there are family rituals -- some new, some as old as Yule logs and mistletoe -- that are not always recognized as such. Social researchers say that structural changes in family life and the external culture's entry into the family circle in the form of television have exerted powerful influences on how Christmas is observed, despite what appears to be a common longing to preserve the traditional ways of celebrating. These are some examples:
* The shouting match is rarely cited as a holiday ritual, but in many families it wouldn't be Christmas without one.
* If voices of carolers drifting through a frosty night are the idealized sounds of Christmas, the voice of George Bailey cursing his bad fortune in the Frank Capra film "It's a Wonderful Life" on television is more often heard in American homes.
* While Christmas dinner for family and friends is celebrated as a unifying ritual, working women are finding it difficult to spend the hours preparing it.
* And the ritual debate on materialism that accompanies gift giving is played out this year against a gloomy economic backdrop that invites guilt for spending too much or too little.
The day itself, whether observed with religious piety or festive holiday spirit, touches emotional roots so deep that nearly everyone has adopted rituals associated with it. This is true even if, like Scrooge, the ritual for some is the effort to ignore Christmas.
When events like divorce and remarriage take place and Christmas-time rituals are forced to accommodate newcomers to a family setting, the changes can be very disturbing. But some authorities, like Dr. Steven J. Wolin, a Washington psychiatrist, think it is a good thing that the rituals don't remain static.
"An issue that keeps coming up in my clinical work is that people don't realize ritual involves both continuity and change," Dr. Wolin said. "They think it's all continuity. People feel if they are changing holiday rituals they must be doing it wrong. I tell them if they don't change, the rituals will become hollow and die."
Still, there can be fierce resistance.
Because of powerful childhood memories that haunt the back corridors of the mind, it is not unusual for grown-ups to become cross and pouty if prized Christmas rituals are challenged or usurped.
How many newly married couples find themselves disagreeing on ways to trim a Christmas tree, asked Dr. William J. Doherty, director of the marriage and family therapy program at the University of Minnesota. What if one grew up in a family that meticulously decorated each branch with tinsel, strand by silvery strand, and the other came from a long line of tinsel-tossers? What if he comes from a blue spruce family and she from a family of Douglas fir fanciers?
Something more than esthetics, Dr. Doherty proposed, is at work in such cases. The "correct way" in the mind of each spouse may be an emotionally potent link to a parent, dead or alive. Thus, breaking with childhood memories in the reverential glow of Christmas can invite anger or tears.
The list of possible conflicts is long: When to put up the tree and when to take it down? Are stockings hung even after the children have grown and moved away? How come mashed turnips are still served now that Uncle Harry is dead -- he's the only one who liked them?
"In our family, one of our biggest traditions is our annual Christmas Eve fight over who's not helping out," said Dr. Lee Combrinck-Graham, a family therapist and associate professor of psychiatry at the University of Illinois in Chicago. "It's useful to recognize that while the holidays are supposed to be fun, there's often a lot of tension building along with our expectations. Sometimes, these tensions need to be released before we can enjoy ourselves."
But many people dread Christmas because of the feelings of loneliness it awakens if family or friends are dead, estranged or live far away.
Even when families get together, who sits around the dinner table may be dictated more by a custody settlement in a divorce than by choice. Like in-laws, stepparents and stepchildren have to tiptoe a minefield of misunderstandings, and the atmosphere can turn explosive if competing notions on Christmas ritual collide.
"One of the great rituals of Christmas is lying," Dr. Doherty said. "Saying you love the gift you really hate is one lie. Saying the turkey is delicious even when it's dry and overdone is what loving families do.
"But a 15-year old stepdaughter at her stepmother's table may have no incentive to fake it. Instead you get a turning up of the nose and, 'This isn't the way Mom makes the stuffing!' "
Women, sociologists agree, are most often the keepers of family rituals, more likely than men to perpetuate them. Yet as women have moved into the work force, the effort and time needed to prepare a traditional Christmas dinner depresses those who feel they can't keep up with the demands made on them.
"Trying to pull off a big Christmas dinner today requires incredible changes on everyone's part, but unfortunately the job is approached as though it's still women's work," said Dr. Evan Imber-Black, professor of psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx.
Fran Sevcik, director of public relations for Kloster Cruise Ltd. of Miami, said she had tired herself out trying to celebrate both Hanukkah and Christmas with her husband and two young children.
"You try to rush home on Christmas Eve and do everything and you get frazzled," she said. This year, she said, the family decided to spend Christmas at Disney World.
Television, which has its own rituals, can be another intrusion.
Viewers may be warmed and heartened by watching, year after year, the wringing emotional experience of "It's a Wonderful Life," in which a man learns the value of his life at Christmas, or by watching football games, but many families get together so infrequently these days that turning on the television can nullify the ritual of storytelling that keeps family histories alive.
Francine Hermelin, a University of Michigan student, recalled that last year, she spent Thanksgiving at her grandmother's home, talking for hours after the meal with older relatives about family history.
"That was a very important experience for me and I looked forward to doing it again this Thanksgiving," she said. "But it was crazy. 'E.T.' was on television and we all ran to watch it before we were quite through eating. We hardly spoke all night."
Suzanne Mercure of Boston, a business manager who is divorced, plans to spend Christmas Eve with her parents but said she would not stay overnight. Instead, she said she would spend Christmas day with casual friends "who can't get back to where they come from to be with their families," the bands of single and divorced, orphaned and emotionally distant, who inhabit all the cities of America.
Ms. Mercure says she has adopted two new Christmas rituals.
"I telephone around the country to friends I haven't been in touch with all year," she explained. She said Christmas cards and postage now amount to $1 for each card and she finds a greater emotional resonance in hearing a friend's voice.
The other takes place on Christmas night at home, alone, when she plays a videotape of her favorite movie, "The Velveteen Rabbit."
"It's a story about a child who thinks toys are not real," Ms. Mercure said. "He learns if you are loved, you are real."

LENGTH: 1140 words

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
DEPRESSION has long been considered primarily a women's disease. The rate for women being treated and in community surveys, in fact, is two to six times as high asfor men.
Now it looks as if men could be starting to catch up. Economic and social pressures and a greater willingness by men and doctors to recognize and discuss emotional problems may eventually whittle away the statistical difference. Still, according to a recent analysis involving more than 23,000 patients and 500 medical practitioners, many more mistakes are made in recognizing depression in men than in women. 
 The study, published in the current issue of the journal Psychological Assessment, found that clinicians outside the mental health field failed to recognize symptoms of depression in two-thirds of the men as against half the women who were found to be suffering from it using standardized tests. Furthermore, the clinicians in the study were more likely to diagnose depression in women when in fact they were not suffering from it, according to the test results.
 
Differences by Sex
 Historically, it has been considered "unmanly" to admit to suffering from emotional problems. Rather than seek medical help for depression or even acknowledge that they may have such a problem, many men have traditionally handled their feelings by drinking too much alcohol, taking mood-altering drugs, being cranky and irritable or falsely cheerful, abusing their wives or children, becoming workaholics or exercise addicts or, with little or no warning, committing suicide.
On top of this, many doctors have been reluctant to delve into the emotions with their male patients or even to ask "embarrassing" questions that might reveal alcohol or drug abuse. Another obstacle to detecting depression in men is that men are only half as likely as women to visit a doctor.
Women, on the other hand, see doctors far more regularly. Facing less social stigma about emotional problems, women generally feel more comfortable than men in talking about their bad feelings and are more inclined to confront them rather than to try to drown them in pills and alcohol. Doctors, too, have been less reluctant to quiz female patients about their emotional health and more likely to conclude that women with certain hallmark symptoms are in fact depressed.
To be sure, even when diagnostic errors are taken into account, depression is still considered to be a more common affliction among women. Dr. Myrna M. Weissman, professor of epidemiology in psychiatry at Columbia University, and her husband, Dr. Gerald L. Klerman, professor of psychiatry at Cornell University Medical Center, have analyzed scores of studies in the United States and many other countries. They find that while depression affects young boys and girls with equal frequency, after puberty girls and women are about twice as susceptible.
 
Shifting Causes
 The distribution is probably related, in part, to hormonal factors; for example premenstrual and postpartum depression are common and well recognized. But it may also reflect social pressures that affect men and women differently. For example, Dr. Klerman said, while the women's movement may have succeeded in raising social awareness about the need for men to participate more in household chores and child-rearing, in most households women with outside jobs still do the lion's share.
"There has been a distinct rise in depression among young women, and a main reason for it is that the promises to women have not been fulfilled," Dr. Klerman said.
For both men and women, Dr. Weissman said, feeling powerful and in control is a potent antidote to depression. "Maybe different things make men and women feel powerful and in control, though that is likely to be less so as women's and men's roles become more similar," she said.
Rates of depression have been increasing worldwide in both men and women born after World War II. If indeed there has been a disproportionate increase in depression among men, Dr. Klerman suggested socioeconomic factors as a prominent cause. Many men can no longer reinforce their social dominance by holding "macho" jobs. Instead, more men today hold unisex jobs and are forced to compete with women.
In the last few years, extensive layoffs and forced retirements have compounded the problem. A disproportionate number of men are out of work, suffering from lost status and battered self-esteem on top of often severe economic pressures, a perfect formula for depression.
Dr. Harold M. Visotsky, director of the Center for the Study of Depressive Disorders at Northwestern University, noted that "as women get more involved in male roles and move up career ladders, they are beginning to be more susceptible to anxiety and depression as a result of job stress."
 
Recognizing Signs
 Many people, especially men, suppress their emotional symptoms and instead express their depression through their bodies. They may suffer often from headaches, vague abdominal pains, muscle aches and pains, fatigue or gastrointestinal disturbances. Others try to self-medicate their bad feelings with alcohol or drugs like nicotine and cocaine.
Manifestations of depression can vary widely from individual to individual, but certain signs and symptoms are common. They include a loss of interest in formerly pleasurable activities and a generalized inertia, an inability to help oneself or accept help from others. Some people thwart the efforts of others to help by becoming touchy, curt or sarcastic. Indeed, many depressed people believe that nothing can help them or that they do not deserve to be helped. Others feel ashamed or inappropriately guilty, thinking that they should be able to snap out of it.
Loss of appetite and sleep disturbances -- insomnia (especially early-morning awakening) or excessive sleepiness -- are common signs of depression. Also common is a general slowing down of mental and physical activities, a phenomenon called psychomotor retardation. Depressed people often have difficulty concentrating and thinking clearly and doing work they once did easily.
 
Getting Help
 Even when the causes of depression are obvious, like loss of employment, divorce or death of a loved one, professional counseling, group therapy and sometimes treatment with antidepressant medication can help greatly to relieve the anguish. Pastoral counseling or at community mental health centers can help those without enough money or insurance.
If nothing else, try joining a self-help group. There are now many men's groups as well as women's groups in urban areas. Participation in regular physical activity is another valuable antidote to depression.
Above all, do not wait until the demons of depression result in alcohol or drug abuse, spouse or child abuse or, worst of all, suicide.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bankers Trust Raises Dividend

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation has raised its quarterly dividend by 10 percent because it did better than expected in the recession. The New York-based bank group said the quarterly dividend would be raised to 70 cents a share from 63.5 cents a share. 
 Bankers Trust said it expected fourth-quarter profits to equal those of a year ago, when the company recorded quarterly earnings of $123 million, or $1.40 a share. It earned $665 million, or $7.80 a share, for all of 1990. The higher dividend is payable on Jan. 25 for all stockholders of record as of Jan. 2. Bankers Trust stock fell $2.50 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $61.125. Analysts said they had expected the fourth-quarter results to be higher than those of a year ago.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Fans Paying the Price

 BODY:
Inside a parka and under a frozen sky, the man slid through the line and strode up to Window 4 at Shea Stadium yesterday. "Hey, hey, you can't cut the line," cried some of the people standing on line, their breath visible, their anger real. "Wait your turn."
The man in the parka turned around and Jeff Torborg smiled. The voices went silent for a second as the new manager of the Mets addressed his accusers. There was surprise but not embarrassment. 
 "Hey, you got the best seat in the place already," one person croaked.
Tickets for most of the rest of the seats at Shea Stadium for the 1992 season went on sale yesterday, and a line of 300 was present for the 9 A.M. start. By 6 P.M., the Mets had sold 51,000 seats, up from the roughly 40,000 the club sold on the first day of sales a year ago.
"We can't separate ourselves from the rest of the city with respect to the economy, and it's a tough economy," said General Manager Al Harazin. "We have been perceived as disappointing and plainly not interesting lately. I wanted to improve that perception. We're in the entertainment business."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Jays-Red Sox Rivalry: Bids for Top Pitchers

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
This will be a critical day in the immediate future of two pitchers who between them have pitched 366 victories, 807 games and 5,629 innings. Jack Morris and Frank Viola, veteran free agents both, are the dual targets of a dual pursuit, and at least one decision could clarify the pursuit at least in part today.
The Toronto Blue Jays and the Boston Red Sox, who have fought each other for the American League East championship several times in recent years, are both trying to sign Morris or Viola. Morris is scheduled to visit Toronto today and will very likely accept what one baseball official familiar with the Blue Jays' plans said was an offer of more than $10 million for two years. 
 "The intent is to sign one or the other, not both," Gord Ash, the assistant general manager, said by telephone from Toronto. He acknowledged that the club had made offers to both pitchers, adding, "We left it that the first one to come forward and accept would have a deal."
Was there any chance the Blue Jays would sign both? "It would be a slim chance," Ash said.
 
2 for Morris, 1 for Viola
 The baseball person who spoke of the offer to Morris said it was a two-year contract with an option for a third year. He said the Blue Jays had offered Viola a one-year deal that would enable him to be a free agent again next year.
The Red Sox, who also seek an established starting pitcher, have talked to agents for both pitchers. The Red Sox, in fact, hope that Morris's visit to Toronto is a failure because if he doesn't reach agreement with the Blue Jays, he plans to visit Boston tomorrow.
But there seemed to be a strong chance that Morris would accept the Blue Jays' offer, which was said to be one that would put him on the economic level of Roger Clemens and Dwight Gooden. They are baseball's highest-paid pitchers with contracts averaging more than $5 million a year.
Neither Richard Moss, Morris's lawyer, nor Craig Fenech, Viola's agent, returned telephone calls seeking comment on their clients' plans.
 
Three-Year Pact Rejected
 Viola would have to decide whether or not he wants to accept a one-year contract with Toronto. Last April, he rejected the Mets' three-year offer for $13 million, and no one has admitted to having made him as good an offer since he became a free agent last month.
By tomorrow's midnight deadline, he could accept the Mets' offer of salary arbitration and thus retain his right to be a free agent again a year from now. But a recent development has opened the door for players to be in position to sign with a team other than their previous team and not be restricted by the five-year waiting period for a second free agency.
That's how Morris became a free agent again this year after just one season with the Twins. Once he did not exercise the option for 1992 in his contract with Minnesota, he became a free agent because the Twins did not offer him salary arbitration.
The Blue Jays could agree not to offer Viola arbitration next year, thus allowing him to go free for 1993. Then he could sign with any team, including the expansion teams, the Colorado Rockies and the Florida Marlins, who will be in business by then.
 
Second-Half Slump
 Although Fenech has been noncommunicative about his negotiations for Viola, officials of various teams have questioned whether or not he has had attractive multiyear offers. The 31-year-old Viola, a left-hander who has never missed a start because of injury, has apparently had the market for him hurt by his performance in the second half of the season.
After he compiled an 11-5 record in his first 19 starts with the Mets in 1991, Viola slumped badly and won only 2 games while losing 10 in his last 17 starts.
He attributed his collapse to problems he had with two fingers on his pitching hand. The problems have since dissipated or been corrected. Word circulated throughout baseball immediately after the season that Viola had elbow problems, too, but Fenech sent medical reports to all of the teams showing that the pitcher had no such problems.
The Blue Jays have two starters whose status could have a question mark attached next season. One is left-hander Jimmy Key, who broke an ankle on Sunday and will be in a cast for the next four weeks. The other is right-hander Dave Stieb, who was limited to nine starts last season because of shoulder and back ailments. The Blue Jays have no guarantee he will be sound at the start of the season.
Another starter, Tom Candiotti, who joined the rotation after being acquired from Cleveland on June 27, signed with the Los Angeles Dodgers as a free agent, leaving Todd Stottlemyre, Juan Guzman and David Wells as the Blue Jays' starters.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 BOB KIPPER, a 27-year-old free-agent reliever, agreed yesterday to a $1 million, one-year contract with the Minnesota Twins. Kipper was 2-2 with a 4.65 earned run average in 52 relief appearances for Pittsburgh last season, when he earned $900,000. He gets a $100,000 signing bonus and $900,000 in 1992. The Twins have an option for 1993 at $1 million, which becomes guaranteed if Kipper pitches in 40 games next season. . . . The San Diego Padres dropped out of the bidding for the free-agent outfielder DANNY TARTABULL, saying they couldn't afford his request for a five-year contract at more than $4 million per season.

HEADLINE: Brutalizing the Helpless;
State Senate Republicans Target the Poor

 BODY:
The budget battle between Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and the State Legislature is more partisan than usual this year. Senate Republicans seem to be using the impasse to tarnish Mr. Cuomo's credibility as a possible Democratic Presidential contender.
The struggle is over where to impose the harshest cuts -- on welfare and Medicaid recipients or on schoolchildren. That's a false and destructive choice. Fairness dictates careful cuts both in school aid and Medicaid and welfare. 
 Like other states in the Northeast, New York has been hit hard by the recession. Mr. Cuomo and the legislators must close an $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget and a projected $4 billion gap next year.
Considering the furious backlash against tax increases in New Jersey and Connecticut, raising taxes is not politically realistic. That means going after health, education and service programs, which make up close to 75 percent of the budget. The two big spending targets are social services, like welfare and Medicaid, and aid to local school districts.
Senate Republicans would impose almost all the cuts on social services. They propose to save $1.8 billion over 15 months by limiting Medicaid services and curtailing eligibility for welfare. They would reduce welfare grants to poor, unemployed single adults by 20 percent, stringently limit their Medicaid benefits and eliminate emergency assistance for the homeless.
By imposing such severe cuts, the Republicans aim to eliminate the need for cuts in aid to education, one of the plums that legislators take back home. It's true that most school districts suffered budget cuts last December and July. And many have growing enrollments. That's a powerful reason to make school aid cuts judiciously, not to exempt schools altogether.
Gov. Cuomo would spread the pain more fairly than the Republicans. He proposes cutting $1.2 billion from social programs and $840 million from the schools. Mr. Cuomo would limit not only Medicaid benefits for inner-city clients, but also nursing home and long-term care benefits that are used by the middle class.
In cutting school aid, the Governor would use a formula that takes into account each school district's relative wealth, thus easing the burden on poorer districts. That ought to offer some protection to New York City, which already receives less than its fair share of school aid while educating a disproportionate share of students with special needs.
In these tough times, Mr. Cuomo offers a better way to spread the pain than the Senate Republicans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Putting the Unemployed Back to Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Unemployment is at its highest in a decade. Many corporations are still cutting back their staffs and becoming overcautious about plans that involve expansion and rehiring. 
 What can Government do to get the economy moving forward again? Most suggested solutions would do more harm than good. They would either reduce Government revenues by cutting taxes or increase Government spending with new pump-priming programs. With our budget deficit, we simply can't afford that. Other suggested solutions are aimed at stimulating consumer spending, ignoring the underlying problem that spending is already too high and savings are too low.
Here's an idea that will not cut Government revenues, increase expenditures or stimulate spending at the expense of savings, but will reduce unemployment, encourage business to move forward with plans for expansion and all at no cost to the taxpayer: Enact legislation to permit corporations to deduct from their corporate income taxes for the next three years an amount exactly equal to what they withhold for income taxes from those they newly employ in calendar year 1992, who have been unemployed for more than four months. Companies would only be eligible if their total employment increased during the year by at least the number of new employees.
Such a plan would reduce the unemployment rolls by making it less expensive for corporations to hire new people. This would stimulate corporations to move forward with new products and new services, and, best of all, it would not cost the Treasury anything nor violate the budget agreement, since lower revenues from corporate income taxes would be exactly offset by higher revenues from individual income taxes of the newly re-employed.
Too good to be true? Maybe. What really happens is that the Government forgoes for three years the income taxes it otherwise would receive from the new employment. But since there are not likely to be any new income taxes without some new incentive, it looks like a reasonable trade-off.
 
JOHN C. WHITEHEAD
New York, Dec. 16, 1991
 
The writer is former head of Goldman, Sachs and a former Deputy Secretary of State.

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Market Place;
T. J. Maxx Parent Set to Branch Out

BYLINE: By Glenn Rifkin

 BODY:
BERNARD CAMMARATA, president and chief executive of the TJX Companies in Framingham, Mass., the parent of T. J. Maxx, the star of the $10 billion off-price retail apparel industry, is banking that its success will carry over to two new satellite ventures.
At an analysts' meeting today in New York, Mr. Cammarata plans to announce plans for some former Zayre properties that the company took over in a complex series of transactions with the bankrupt Ames Department Stores. 
 In the spring, TJX plans to open three units to offer home fashions at a sharp discount in warehouse-like settings of 50,000 square feet. The second concept, known as Value Mart, will be an indoor marketplace housing a collection of booths occupied by small, independent retailers. Four sites in Florida are scheduled to open soon.
Analysts credit Mr. Cammarata for engineering the company's success. He created T. J. Maxx for the Zayre Corporation in 1976 and has overseen T. J. Maxx's steady growth since then without a money-losing year. With 438 stores, the nationwide chain now accounts for 80 percent of TJX's revenues. It offers family-oriented, name-brand apparel at discounts of 20 percent to 60 percent and has brought in nearly $2 billion in revenues and operating profits estimated at $180 million this year.
"He pioneered the concept of an off-price apparel location where a woman can shop for the whole family," Richard Baum, a retail analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said. "They have offered outstanding value on merchandise and been very consistent about it."
Mr. Cammarata said the chain recently opened its first downtown location --in Chicago -- with "extremely" good results, and this year entered the Long Island market, where it plans to accelerate openings in the next few years.
Despite this success, however, most financial analysts cannot ignore the continuing disappointment with TJX's Hit or Miss division, which has dragged down profits and is to be downsized in 1992. Mr. Baum calculates that Hit or Miss lost $13 million through the first three quarters this year, and he expects a $20 million loss for the full year. And he does not expect the chain to break even next year. Revenues dropped from $385 million last year to some $370 million this year, according to Mr. Baum, and he expects flat growth next year.
"Hit or Miss had a very disappointing year," Mr. Cammarata said. "We've tried to transition this business in a very difficult economy for retailers."
The Hit or Miss small apparel shops for women -- the average store is 3,000 square feet -- are designed for strip malls. The division tried to gain momentum this year by shifting its focus to career-oriented merchandise for professional women. The timing could not have been worse, Mr. Baum said. "They beefed up their career apparel in a year when a lot of people are worrying about whether they have a career," Mr. Baum said.
Mr. Cammarata recently brought in Herbert Yalof, former president of Macy's northeast division, to serve as Hit or Miss's president, and earlier this year he recruited Michele Fortune, former chief executive of Ann Taylor, to head the chain's merchandising. He said the mix of casual and career clothes would move from 65-35 in favor of career wear to a 50-50 mix.
More importantly, TJX will trim the Hit or Miss chain, closing 70 of the 525 stores next year and opening some 20 for a net reduction of about 50.
"The turnaround is under way," said Skip Wells of Adams, Harkness & Hill in Boston. "But whether it succeeds won't be clear until 1992."
Mr. Baum said TJX stock, despite the Hit or Miss problems, was undervalued. The stock closed yesterday in New York Stock Exchange trading down 25 cents, to $15.375.
"The majority of the company is T. J. Maxx and that is quite healthy," Mr. Baum said. "I think the problems are overstated." He said T. J. Maxx was rapidly closing the gap on its larger competitor, Marshalls, and he estimated revenue growth of 12 percent, up to $2.15 billion this year, from $1.94 billion last year. "I think it can grow at that rate for several more years," Mr. Baum said.
Not all analysts are as bullish, given the Hit or Miss situation and the burden of the former Zayre properties. When Zayre was the parent of T. J. Maxx it negotiated a complex deal with Ames in which TJX was spun off as a separate company and Ames got the former Zayre properties. But, under the deal, TJX assumed responsibility for 119 former Zayre properties when Ames filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in 1990. That resulted in a $185 million write-off for TJX in 1990.
Mr. Cammarata says TJX has negotiated settlements or arranged alternative uses for 76 of the properties, leaving 43, and some of those will be used in the new ventures.
"TJX is handicapped by the extra 50-pound burden of Hit or Miss and the Ames situation," said Margo McGlade, an analyst with Paine Webber. "The question for investors is do they want to bet on T. J. Maxx and wait out the problems with Hit or Miss and Ames?"

HEADLINE: GENERAL MOTORS TO CUT 70,000 JOBS; 21 PLANTS TO SHUT

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation, which has dominated the world automotive industry for generations, acknowledged today that it would probably never regain the huge share of the market that it enjoyed more than a decade ago.
In a wide retrenchment, G.M. said that it would close 21 of its 125 assembly and parts-making plants in North America over the next few years and eliminate more than 70,000 jobs, or nearly 18 percent of its employees in the United States and Canada. 
 G.M.'s steps, which the company signaled with a brief announcement last week, effectively pares 22 percent of the No. 1 auto maker's capacity to make cars and light trucks in North America.
 
Struggle Against Competition
 Ever since the late 1970's, when oil prices climbed and small foreign cars surged in popularity, G.M. has been struggling to halt the erosion of its share of the American car market, with little success. Quality problems plagued some of its early redesigned cars, which only fueled the sales of foreign manufacturers, many of which started selling larger cars and setting up plants in the United States.
While G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation all closed plants and reduced their workforces during the 1980's, G.M.'s steps, while painful to thousands who lost their jobs, were considered modest by automotive experts, given the magnitude of the company's problems.
 
Excess Capacity
 G.M. closed 11 older plants in 1986 and trimmed eight more assembly plants in October 1990. Still, it continued to have the plants and workers to build far more cars than the market wanted. Such excess capacity in a depressed sales year like 1991 gave the company losses on the order of $500 million a month.
Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, said that the immediate goal of the cutbacks was to restore profitability in North America, where G.M. faces an estimated $6 billion to $8 billion loss this year, its largest ever. But financial analysts said the changes would not help G.M. turn a profit before 1993.
By not specifying today which of the 21 plants would be closed, Mr. Stempel put the lives of thousands of workers in limbo. [Page D1.]
But he put some plants in a competition for survival against others that make identical products. For example, the plant in Arlington, Tex., near Fort Worth, that makes big Chevrolets, Buicks and Cadillacs, could be closed in favor of a plant that makes most of the same cars in Ypsilanti, Mich., near Ann Arbor. Mr. Stempel said a decision would not be made for months.
The nation's biggest auto maker becomes the latest American corporation to be forced to scale back its operations because of the recession and a fundamental restructuring of industries like transporation, computers and financial services.
In G.M.'s case, the recession aggravated the unpleasant consequences of an inefficient organization that uses more workers to make a car than any other auto maker.
"As I told our stockholders, we cannot blame our problems totally on the war, the plunge in consumer confidence, or the recession," Mr. Stempel said. "Rather, we must make fundamental changes in the way G.M. does business if we are to improve our performance."
He spoke over G.M.'s closed-circuit television network to approximately 400,000 workers in the United States and Canada. Afterward, a news conference was broadcast over the radio in some cities where G.M. has plants.
 
Skepticism From Union
 In Detroit, the United Automobile Workers union, which represents most of G.M.'s production workers, expressed skepticism at the urgency of the auto maker's travails, which it attributed to G.M. executives running scared of Wall Street.
Owen Bieber, the U.A.W. president, said, "The proper answer to the insatiable demands of the Ebenezer Scrooge types who run Wall Street is not a snappy 'Yes, sir!' salute."
He said G.M., by cutting capacity, had chosen a "self-defeating path." Mr. Bieber rejected the idea of granting G.M. concessions, and a spokesman said G.M. had not asked to reopen the three-year labor agreement, which expires in the fall of 1993.
On the New York Stock Exchange, G.M.'s common stock closed at $27.75 a share today, down 12.5 cents a share.
In coming months, Wall Street credit rating agencies will decide whether to lower their grade on G.M.'s debt securities, thereby raising G.M.'s costs of borrowing. Last s warned that they might issue G.M. a lower grade.
(nt questioning at today's news conference, Mr. Stempel said that G.M. must be profitable at whatever number of cars it is selling. By making the cutbacks, he said, the company aims to be able to make a profit with a market share "in the low 30" percent of the domestic vehicle market. In October, G.M.'s share was about 35 percent, down from 44.1 percent a decade ago, and 46 percent in 1978, just before oil prices jumped.
On the employment front, Mr. Stempel said the salaried work force, which stands now at 91,000 in North America, would be reduced to 71,000 by the mid-1990's, or approximately half the size it was in 1985. Likewise, the hourly work force, which stands at 304,000, will fall to about 250,000, also half the 1985 level.
 
Some Bonuses Eliminated
 Mr. Stempel said G.M. would not distribute an annual $600 bonus next year to salaried workers, except to some in foreign posts, the second consecutive year that the payment will not be paid in the United States.
Also, the stock-incentive program will be canceled for the year, Mr. Stempel said, and G.M.'s contribution to an employee savings plan will drop to 25 percent from 50 percent of the employee's annual deposit.
G.M. said it would try to cut staff through attrition, buyouts and early retirements. But Mr. Stempel said that he would not rule out a white- collar layoff. Hiring will be frozen in 1992, except for technical specialists. As the cuts take place, Mr. Stempel promised, "G.M. will become a much different corporation."
 
An Analyst's View
 But Ron Glantz, an automotive analyst with Dean Witter in San Francisco, said G.M.'s top executives were remiss in failing to cut or restructure their own ranks. "I think names should be taken," he said. The comment echoed the sentiment of many: that tens of thousands of G.M. workers, but few executives, pay a steep penalty for G.M.'s slide.
Individuals close to G.M.'s non-employee directors have asked Mr. Stempel to think about realigning top management. But Mr. Stempel, prefacing his news conference with the comment that top management "remains in place," later noted that the number of G.M. executives had dropped by one-third in recent years.
Today, G.M. disclosed the location of two plants whose workers already had received the bad news: Two plants in Lansing, Mich. that produce six-cylinder engines will be closed. G.M. has excess capacity at engine plants in Flint, Mich. and Tonawanda, N.Y., which could absorb additional production.
 
Parity in Productivity
 At one time, G.M. selected plants for closing based on their productivity or quality records. Mr. Stempel said the quality levels at most G.M. plants had improved to the point where they do not differ much now, so the company will consider how the closings will affect the employment of states and local communities before deciding which plants to close.
G.M. is expected to press plants for labor concessions in order to keep them open and save jobs. It has already been trying to negotiate adding a third work shift at some plants, in order to have almost non-stop assembly, for three crews of workers, Monday through Saturday. Only a few hours a day would be devoted to maintenance and repairs. G.M. has tried this plan in Europe and has found it successful.
Beyond operating more s efficiently, a big question is whether new G.M. car and truck models are meeting the expectations of their owners. Some models, like the redesigned 1992 Cadillac Seville, have shown signs of winning back younger, more affluent buyers that defected to imported brands. The Saturn models have attracted a high proportion of "import intenders," people who would have otherwise bought a foreign car
 
A Buick Cools
 Other models, like the full-size, rear-wheel-drive Chevrolet Caprice, seem better suited to another day and age, even though they were redesigned a few years ago. The Buick Park Avenue, a full-sized luxury sedan that won initial raves and strong sales, has cooled lately because Buick introduced a similar model, the LeSabre, that sells for far less money.
The cost of developing new models is soaring, and G.M. will have less money to spend. Mr. Stempel said capital spending for next year is being reduced by $1.1 billion, to $6.6 billion, or 14 percent. He said engineering budgets would be curtailed and operations consolidated.
Lloyd Reuss, G.M.'s president, who is in charge of the North American automotive business, said G.M. was finding ways "to get more for dollars spent."
 
Money-Saving Idea
 Mr. Stempel also took a step toward a money-saving idea that was first raised during last year's labor negotiations, and is used at Ford and Chrysler. He announced that a two-week shutdown of North American operations would occur in 1992 during the weeks of July 20 and 27.
He wants all employees to take vacations during those weeks; that time would be used at most plants to change tools for the new model year.
Previously, assembly workers who were laid off during tool changes collected unemployment benefits and could take vacation at other times.

Charts: "Recent History at General Motors
1979: Thousands of workers were laid off after a decade marked by declining sales, a recession, the Arab oil embrago and gains by Japanese automakers.
1980: Roger B. Smith was named chairman.
1981: G.M., with 741,000 workers worlwide, consoliated its truck, bus and van operations.
1983: G.M. and the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan formed a joint venture to build cars at a G.M. plant in Fremont, Calif. Mr. Smith announced the Saturn project to build new car to offset the growing Japanese cars in U.S. market.
1985: The company opened a high-tech, robot filled plant in Hamtramck, Mich.
1986: G.M. announced plans to close 11 U.S. assembly and stamping plants in United States.
1987: G.M. and United Automobile Workers reached a national labor contract prohibiting the closing of a plant unless its product sales fall.
1988: Company idled three assembly plants.
1990: G.M. and Saab-Scania AB of Sweden form 50-50 joint venture to make cars in Europe. Mr. Smith retired as chairman, and was succeeded by Robert C. Stempel. As auto sales plummeted, G.M. took a $2.1 billion charge to pay for four plant closings. Profits fell to $102 million.
Oct, 22, 1991: The company announced a third-quarter loss of $1.1 billion, bringing its nine-month loss to $2.2 billion.
Yesterday: Mr. Stempel announced that G.M. would close 21 plants over the next few years and would eliminate 9,000 salaried and 15,000 hourly jobs in 1992 through retirement and attrition, in addition to the layoffs at the shuttered plants (Source: Associated Press) (pg. D4)
 
"Highlights of the G.M. Plan"
Here are the major points of a plan to restructure the North American operations of General Motors Corp.:
 
PLANT CLOSINGS
The company said it will close six vehicle assembly plants, four powertrain plants and 11 component plants over the next few years.
Few details were released. G.M. said the assembly of large, rear-wheel-drive cars now done at plants in Arlington, Texas, and Ypsilanti, Mich., would be consolidated into one plant, but did not say which one.
One of its five plants that make midsize, front-wheel-drive cars also will be eliminated. The plants are in Oklahoma City; Oshawa, Ontario; Doraville, Ga.; Kansas City, Kan.; and Ramos Arizpe, Mexico.
Both consolidations will start next year.
 
JOB CUTS
G.M. will accelerate a white-collar job reduction program that began this year. It said 9,000 salaried jobs will be cut in 1992 through attrition and a new early-retirement program. Another 11,000 could be cut through consolidation in 1993 and 1994. The company plans no hiring in 1992 except for special situtions.
 
BONUSES AND OTHER COMPENSATION
G.M. will eliminate the $600 holiday bonus for salaried employees in 1992 for the second will eliminate stock-incentive compensation, except for some in international divisions. No U.S. profit-sharing payments will be made to employees.
 
CAPITAL SPENDING
Capital spending for next year will be reduced to $6.6 billion, down $1.1 billion from previous plans.
 
TOTAL SAVINGS
G.M. said it expects the plan will result in savings of $2 billion in 1992 and $5 billion a year by 1995. (Source: Associated Press) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: U.S. AND ITS ALLIES TO MOVE ON LIBYA OVER AIR BOMBINGS

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The United States, Britain and France have agreed to begin a campaign to win international support for sanctions against Libya for the part they say it played in the bombings of a Pan American World Airways plane over Scotland and of a French airliner in Africa, in which a total of 440 people were killed, officials of the three countries said today.
The three countries are considering a Security Council resolution that would at a minimum ban all international flights in and out of Libya, the sale of commercial planes and spare parts, and the delivery of any airline-related services. 
 "You'd have to take a bus to Cairo or a ferry to Malta to get out of Libya," one Administration official said. "The punishment would fit the crime."
 
Stricter Sanctions Discussed
 But the countries are also discussing more stringent sanctions, ranging from a ban on the sale of military equipment and civilian technology that could have military uses to a ban on Libyan oil exports.
The intention of the sanctions would be to force Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to comply with specific demands made by the three countries, officials said. The demands include an American and British request for extradition of two Libyan intelligence agents who have been indicted in connection with the bombing of Pan Am's Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland three years ago Saturday and compensation for that attack. A total of 259 passengers on board the plane and 11 people on the ground were killed in the Pan Am bombing. French courts have also accused Libyan agents of the bombing of a Union de Transports Aeriens plane over Niger in September 1989 in which 170 people were killed.
International air-related sanctions would be more bothersome than economically crippling for Libya. Traffic in and out of Libya would have to go by either land or sea, and Libya would presumably have a difficult time maintaining its commercial aircraft. Libya has been the target of a variety of United States and European Community sanctions for years, and it is doubtful that new economic sanctions would change Colonel Qaddafi's behavior.
Officials of the three Governments said that while they have not ruled out military action against Libya as a last resort, their current strategy does not include any attempt to gain international support for a military strike.
The United States has already laid the groundwork for sanctions through its embassies. Immediately after the indictments of two Libyan intelligence agents by a Federal grand jury and by Britain on Nov. 14, the United States ordered ambassadors in every capital to present the evidence compiled for the indictments and make a general argument for punishing the regime of Colonel Qaddafi. Libya has since announced that the two men named in the indictment are under investigation and will be tried in Libya.
But American and British officials acknowledge the difficulty they face in trying to win sanctions against Libya, adding that they have not completely agreed on a joint strategy for accomplishing their goals.
One Administration official said that when the United States discussed the matter at "a very high level" with other permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, which include Britain and France along with China and the Soviet Union, there was "general agreement of a need to take action." But a Western diplomat involved in the discussions said that convincing China to go along with sanctions would be "an uphill battle."
The three Governments appear to be moving toward a step by step approach that mirrors the strategy used against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. British officials said today that they expect to circulate a draft document at the United Nations before Christmas that echoes public demands made of Libya on Nov. 27, officials said.
In a joint statement on that day, the United States and Britain demanded that Libya promptly hand over the agents accused of taking part in the bombings, accept official responsibility for their actions, pay compensation for the bombing and furnish witnesses and evidence for the case. France joined its allies in a separate statement that did not list specific demands, but simply called on Libya to "comply with all these demands" and cease its support for international terrorism.
If there is sufficient support for a resolution, the three countries will present a formal resolution to the Security Council in January, after the expiration of the two-year term of Cuba and Yemen, two Council members likely to oppose any punitive measures against Libya. If Libya does not comply, a follow-up resolution seeking sanctions would be submitted.
The three countries may also seek sanctions through either the European Community or the Group of Seven industrialized countries, particularly if there is substantial resistance to the sanctions strategy in the Security Council. Although one Administration official called a mandatory Security Council resolution "the preferred course," Washington believes that both of the other groups may be more willing than certain Security Council members to impose stringent sanctions. The stricter sanctions could include a limit on diplomatic representation, a ban on oil sales and and a freeze on Libyan assets in foreign banks.
Although France has issued arrest warrants for suspects in the U.T.A. bombing, it has not asked for their extradition or for compensation.
To stave off the sanctions, Libya has proposed a number of concessions, including an offer to sever ties with all terrorist organizations and the creation of an international fact-finding tribunal to investigate the bombings. One Administration official called the overtures "hokey," but other officials said Libya's willingness to address the issue may persuade some Arab governments to oppose punitive measures.
