HEADLINE: Connecticut to Sponsor Nursing-Home Insurance

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Early next year an insurance company in Connecticut will sell the first long-term nursing-home insurance policy to be co-sponsored by a state government. The moment will push both the insurance industry and the state -- old allies in Connecticut and now full partners -- into a new frontier in the national policy debate over health care for the elderly. 
 State officials say the policies, which may be available in other states later next year based on the Connecticut model, will be far cheaper than existing private long-term-care insurance. In addition, policyholders will no longer have to go broke before Medicaid will pick up their bills.
But the initiative, which moved forward today when Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. announced the names of the first three companies signed to carry the new product, is also not without its critics. The powerful American Association of Retired Persons has blasted the plan as both wrong-headed policy and bad for consumers.
The hope is that by encouraging people to buy private insurance to pay for nursing home care -- care that now costs an average of about $50,000 a year in Connecticut -- the state can reduce over time the number of residents who need Medicaid, a joint state-Federal program that this year will drain nearly 9 percent of the entire state budget into the nursing home system.
Officials say the plan is aimed directly at middle-class residents who are too wealthy to qualify for Medicaid but too poor to pay their own way.
And it will help sell insurance, a fact that has not been overlooked by either critics or supporters here in what is unquestionably the closest thing to the nation's insurance capital. Giants like Aetna Life and Casualty, The Travelers Corporation, Phoenix Mutual and The Hartford dominate much of the local economy. In 1989, according to the most recent figures, the industry accounted for 14 percent of all nonfarm employment in Connecticut and 18 percent of the state's nonfarm gross product.
The originators of the partnership idea, the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, a private philanthropic group, said that when the first seed grants were issued in 1987, Connecticut was the only place in the country where the insurance business was already a major participant in statewide public policy planning.
That pre-existing relationship meant that Connecticut got the first grants, the first Federal approval from the Medicaid administration last summer and that its insurance regulators were also the first to write consumer guidelines that are now being duplicated more or less intact in Indiana and California. Both those states plan to begin selling state-sanctioned long-term care insurance next year, said Stephen A. Somers, an associate vice president at the Johnson Foundation.
 
'Marketing Advantage'
 But whether it follows that what is good for insurance and good for Connecticut is also good for the nation's health care policy is still not completely answered.
"The insurance companies are pushing it because it gives them a marketing advantage," said Phyllis Torda, director of health and social policy for Families U.S.A., a Washington-based health care advocacy group that has been highly critical of the Connecticut partnership plan. "The state got sucked in."
Ms. Torda, whose group favors a national health care solution, said that state-by-state partnerships of the public and industry could inhibit the momentum toward a national overhaul and that by focusing attention on the middle class, the truly needy people for whom Medicaid was set up might ultimately suffer, especially in the majority of states that allow nursing homes to give preference to non-Medicaid patients.
The American Association of Retired Persons, one of the nation's most powerful lobbying groups, says the Connecticut plan may simply be a bad deal for consumers.
With state budgets under severe stress in Connecticut and elsewhere, and a debate starting in Washington about the need for a large-scale overhaul, the association of retired people argues that a policy purchased today by a 65-year-old retiree may be worthless in 15 or 20 years when nursing home care is needed because the care system under which the policy was set up may no longer exist.
 
New York Proposal
 But the proposal, whatever its flaws, also addresses a number of needs. By allowing nursing home patients a way to avoid the humiliation of complete impoverishment -- either by transferring all their assets to their children or simply by paying the nursing home until one's life savings are gone -- supporters say that more people can grow old with their dignity intact.
And state officials here and elsewhere say that some way must be found to rein in nursing home costs in the 1990's. New York, for example, has applied for Federal authorization to allow an insurance plan under which a patient would buy nursing home coverage for a set period, say three years. After that time elapsed, the policyholder would automatically be eligible for Medicaid coverage, regardless of how much wealth he had.
Under the Connecticut plan, by contrast, a person could buy a set amount of insurance, say $50,000 worth. That policy would do two things: upon entering a nursing home, the policy would then begin paying out and would cover all expenses up to $50,000. After that, it would protect $50,000 of assets owned by the patient.
The insurance companies participating in the program are the Travelers, Blue Cross-Blue Shield of Connecticut and the Amax Life Assurance Company.
If the policyholder had greater wealth than $50,000, he would have to start paying for nursing-home care, but only to the point that his assets are reduced to $50,000, at which time Medicaid would take over.
The terms of the policies vary among the companies, but in general a $50,000 policy would cost about $80 a month for a healthy 65-year-old. The premiums would be lower for a younger person and would rise with age. Policies would not be sold to anyone with a pre-existing debilitating condition.
 
Subsidy Plan Dropped
 People over the age of 84 would also have difficulty buying coverage. The policies would be sold by insurance agents, not the state.
Advocates for the elderly say they fear that poor people will be afraid they need the insurance and that the state and the insurers will not be diligent enough in saying no, given the budget pressures from rising Medicaid costs.
"It's not clear where the line will be," said Judith Stein Hulin, co-director of the Center for Medicare Advocacy, a nonprofit legal advice and counseling center. "People who have clearly in their mind the worry of a nursing home stay are quick to plan for the future and to do without," she said. "If you're living on a low budget now, the added cost of a long-term-care policy could add to your impoverishment."


GRAPHIC: Cost: A 65-year-old person pays about $960 a year for a long term care policy covering $50,000 of nursing home expenses, about one year's worth on average in Connecticut.

 Extended Care: If expenses exceed the amount of coverage, the policy would shelter $50,000 of the patient's assets from the Federal Medicaid rules that otherwise require a person to be impoverished in order to get aid. A patient with more than $50,000 in assets would have to pay privately for nursing care, but only until $50,000 was left of his savings. (pg. B14)

HEADLINE: Joseph R. Smallwood Dies at 90; Led Newfoundland Into Canada

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Joseph R. Smallwood, the politician credited by Canadians with leading Newfoundland and Labrador into the Canadian confederation in 1949, died on Tuesday night at his home outside St. John's, the Newfoundland capital. He was 90 years old.
He had been suffering from several ailments, including recurrent pneumonia, for several years. 
 Mr. Smallwood, known as Joey, was a salty figure who both infuriated and delighted Canadians with his efforts during 22 years as Newfoundland's Premier to extend the province's influence across the country.
Newfoundland, which with Labrador was a British colony, decided to join the Canadian confederation in a 1948 referendum by a narrow 7,000 vote margin. Mr. Smallwood led the campaign for joining Canada against opponents who favored an economic union with the United States or that Newfoundland declare its independence.
 
Known for Bluntness
 Rarely one to offer smooth comforts when blunt words would do, Mr. Smallwood made his mark by telling voters before the referendum that a rugged self-assurance born of centuries of hard-scrabble existence, mostly from fishing the rough seas of the Grand Banks, did not qualify them for independence.
"We are not a nation," he told the Newfoundlanders, many of whom are of Scottish and Irish descent. "We are a medium-sized municipality left far behind the march of time." Asked years later what would have become of Newfoundland if it had not joined Canada, Mr. Smallwood replied, "We'd be bankrupt and destitute."
The referendum ended nearly 400 years of British rule over the island of Newfoundland and the adjacent mainland territory of Labrador, which together became Canada's 10th and poorest province.
A diminutive figure with an unflagging energy and outspokenness, Mr. Smallwood blustered and pestered his way into the national consciousness, winning a share of Canada's bounty in federal projects and payments to Newfoundland that were often the envy of other provinces.
 
Legendary Stature
 Mr. Smallwood savored his designation as Canada's only living "father of Confederation," a label given to political leaders who founded Canada from four British colonies in 1867. But in tributes across Canada today, he was equally remembered for his dogged outspokenness and canny politics.
Those qualities gave him a legendary stature on "the Rock," as Newfoundlanders call the craggy, windswept island of 575,000 people that is North America's easternmost outpost.
One such tribute came from John Crosbie, Canada's Fisheries Minister, who was a political ally before leading a revolt inside Newfoundland's Liberal Party against what many regarded as Mr. Smallwood's idiosyncratic decision-making and taste for political intrigue. The rebellion led to Mr. Smallwood's ouster as the Newfoundland premier in 1972.
"I would say he would occupy the same place in our history as Sir John A. Macdonald," Mr. Crosbie said. referring to Canada's first Prime Minister. "He was a real one-man political band. It wasn't a question of dialogue or debate."
 
Began as Journalist
 Joseph Roberts Smallwood was born at Gambo, Newfoundland, on Dec. 24, 1900, the son of a sawmill owner. As a young man, he worked as a journalist in Newfoundland, reporting on the early trans-Atlantic flights for which Newfoundland was a staging post.
In the 1920's, he worked in New York for leftist newspapers and for the Progressive Party. Returning to Newfoundland, he worked as a union organizer and a broadcaster. During World War II, he became a pig farmer and supplied the Gander Air Force Base, a stopover point for American aircraft and troops being ferried to Europe.
As Newfoundland's Premier, he often described himself as a socialist and said that unfettered free enterprise resulted in "sheer, ghastly chaos." But his management of Newfoundland's financial affairs, including an early program of subsidized industrialization that led to widespread bankruptcies, was sharply criticized. But he was widely credited with being the moving force behind the giant Churchill Falls hydroelectric project in Labrador, one of Newfoundland's biggest sources of revenue.
In his last years he accumulated heavy personal debt with a project to write and publish a four-volume encyclopedia of Newfoundland, two volumes of which were completed in 1981 and 1984. A campaign was begun across Canada that raised money to help pay off the debts.
Surviving are his wife, Clara, two sons and a daughter.

HEADLINE: Control Board Assails Dinkins 4-Year Fiscal Plan

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Expanding on its earlier complaints, the State Financial Control Board issued a sharply critical report yesterday on Mayor David N. Dinkins long-term plan to balance the city's books, saying the administration's predictions about future tax revenues, debt and demands on welfare and the schools were unrealistic.
The City Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, insisted that the city's economic assumptions were sound. But he said the administration would take many of the board's criticisms to heart while revising the plan. 
 The report takes on special significance because the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, led by Felix G. Rohatyn, has said it will not provide $1 billion in crucial aid unless the Dinkins administration can satisfy the board that it has a feasible plan to permanently shrink the government.
The Mayor and his deputies are to submit a revised four-year plan to the board in mid-January that they have vowed will meet the tests that Mr. Rohatyn and the board members have set forth. A heightened sense of expectation has surrounded the January plan because state fiscal monitors and bond-rating agencies have repeatedly questioned Mr. Dinkins's ability to bring the city's spending in line with its revenues.
 
Different Projections
 Promising that his January plan would allay the fears raised in the board's report, Mayor Dinkins said yesterday, "I'm confident we'll be able to satisfy all analysts and observers of our four-year plan."
The executive director of the control board, Allen J. Proctor, said state analysts believed the city would face larger budget shortfalls over the next five years than city analysts have projected. That is largely because state analysts do not believe the nation will crawl out of the recession as quickly as the city believes, nor that the recovery, when it comes, will ease the burden on the welfare system as much as city planners have hoped.
As a result, he said, the city is expected to face additional budget shortfalls of $333 million this year, $505 million next year and $694 million in fiscal 1994. In the two years after that, he said, the shortfalls are likely to be $913 million and $1.1 billion more than in the Mayor's plan.
Public-interest groups and bond-rating experts said the control board report would increase the already intense pressure on the Dinkins administration to draft a bolder plan before the January meeting.
"It illuminates what many people have been saying for several months," said Hyman C. Grossman, a managing director of Standard & Poor's. "That is that we need to see a plan that is a little more realistic than what we've seen so far."
"It's a gentle way of giving them some guidelines," Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog organization, said of the report.
Mayoral aides said Mr. Dinkins would be shown today the plans his agency heads have been drafting to flesh out the sketchy four-year plan the adminstration unveiled on Nov. 6, which was criticized by fiscal monitors for lacking specifics.
"I hardly think there is anything in the control board report that will be a fatal flaw to the plan we're working on," First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said yesterday evening. "We believe these are essentially technical difficulties."

HEADLINE: Squeezed Networks Plan Radical Changes in Covering '92 Race

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Facing sharply reduced budgets and acknowledging that they made serious mistakes in 1988, the four national television news organizations, ABC, CBS, NBC and CNN, are planning radical changes in their coverage of the 1992 Presidential election campaign.
"You are going to see a zero-based approach to the coverage," said Tom Hannon, the political director of the Cable News Network. "Everything will be looked at in a brand new light." 
 The financial picture is so bleak at the four organizations that ABC and CBS may have their main newscaster stay home during the Republican National Convention, to be held in Houston from Aug. 17 to 20. It would be the first time since networks began broadcasting the event in 1948 that a network's main newscaster would not be at a political convention.
 
Flaws in '88 Coverage
 But the news executives said the changes were also a result of unhappiness with the quality of television coverage in the 1988 campaign.
"It's an interesting question as to whether the economic necessities are dovetailing with the lessons we may or may not have learned from 1988," Mr. Hannon said.
Specifically, he said: "There was way too much manipulation of television news in 1988. There was a far too narrow discussion of the issues, and television certainly played a major role in bringing that about."
Tim Russert, senior vice president of NBC News, said that four years ago, politicians felt: "Television is covering style not substance, so we'll deliver style. If they're not going to cover the campaign seriously, why should we be serious?"
Each television news organization says it hashas drawn up plans for more serious coverage of the 1992 campaign, including a new format for debates, more analytical reporting on issues and regular scrutiny of political commercials.
But, as Mr. Russert acknowledged, "scaling back costs" is at the heart of many of the revisions.
 
Fitting Plans to Budgets
 But the political director of ABC News said the emphasis on how cost-consciousness would affect the campaign coverage might be overstated. "We're all very aware of budgets and we certainly aren't going to waste any money," said Hal Bruno, the ABC official. "But there will not be one single thing we want to do that we won't be able to do."
A number of plans are specifically tied to reduced political news budgets.
For instance, the Republican National Convention may have to go gavel to gavel without the presence of Peter Jennings from ABC and Dan Rather from CBS. "We don't believe an anchorman has to be there to cover a coronation ceremony," said Joe Peyronnin, vice president of CBS News.
If they do not go to Houston, Mr. Jennings and Mr. Rather would anchor the coverage from New York. "I'm not going to say this wouldn't cost us less," Mr. Peyronnin said. "But we have been overwhelmingly overstaffed at previous conventions." The two newscasters will be at the Democratic National Convention, however, because the Democrats have a contest for the nomination and the gathering will be in New York, from July 13 to 17.
Tom Brokaw, NBC's main newscaster, will attend both conventions. He will appear on NBC as well as the Public Broadcasting System, which has made a deal to share convention coverage with NBC.
Because of increased competition and low ratings for the conventions, the three networks plan much more limited live coverage of convention activities than ever before. Unless something unexpected happens, each network will be cutting back on the number of hours of prime time that will be pre-empted for money-losing convention coverage and will devote more time to money-making entertainment programming. CNN and the public affairs cable channel C-SPAN will cover the conventions gavel to gavel.
But even before the first piece of bunting goes up at the convention sites, the networks plan to scale back coverage of the primaries.
 
Pooling of Information
 For instance, the networks for the first time plan to pool voter information on primary nights. A new organization called Voter Research and Surveys will supply to all four national television news organizations information gleaned from questions asked of voters leaving the polls. Until 1990, ABC, CBS and NBC did their own questioning of voters as well as offering projections of results. "We'll each save millions this year because of V.R.S.," Mr. Bruno said.
This move will cost CNN money, however, because it did not question voters leaving the polls in 1988. CNN, which spent only about $750,000 on election results in 1988, will pay about $4.5 million for the service next year.
Because of the high cost of travel, "star correspondents," as Mr. Russert called them, will rarely go on the campaign trail during the primaries. Instead, the networks will mainly have young producers or researchers follow the candidates every day. Both ABC and CBS experimented with this system in 1988 and said it worked well.
Network camera crews will supply almost none of the daily video footage of primary campaigning. Instead of the expensive four-person crews that used to travel with candidates, the networks may try to put together what Mr. Peyronnin called "ad hoc pool arrangements," in which the networks designate one crew to supply coverage for all four news organizations.
In addition, the networks plan to rely far more on crews and even reporters supplied by local affiliated stations, who Mr. Russert said "have gotten quite good in the major cities."
"I would trust those guys," he said.
C-SPAN is likely to become a bigger supplier for the networks. The channel covers the major daily activities of the candidates in its "video verite" style, with no reporter, just a video record of what the candidate does and says.
In the past, network news departments have made arrangements with C-SPAN to provide daily political coverage when they did not have crews at the scene. The network simply runs the tape and adds its own reporter's comments. Calling C-SPAN "God's gift to campaign coverage," Mr. Russert said, "The networks used to be the video record of the campaign; now C-SPAN has taken that role."
Steve Scully, the political editor of C-SPAN, said for the 1992 campaign the channel had doubled its 1988 political budget to $2 million.
Another possibility for replacing the expensive daily process of trailing after candidates is a proposed organization called the Election Satellite Network. Financed by a subscription fee charged to each network, it would provide crews and producers to cover every activity by every candidate
 
Networks' 'Insurance Policy'
 The service's executive producer, Jerry Lamprecht, called it "an insurance policy" for the news organizations if news broke and they were not there.
One lingering concern the networks have about cutting back on the candidates' movements is an event like the attempted assassination of George C. Wallace in 1972, which was captured by a CBS crew, the only one on the scene.
"This is the kind of thing they just can't afford to do anymore," Mr. Lamprecht said. The networks have yet to commit to Mr. Lamprecht's service but all said they were considering it.
One aspect of the coverage that would certainly not save the networks money is the new plan for four debates among the major candidates. The news organizations proposed the plan, which commits them to carrying three Presidential debates and one Vice Presidential debates, each one 90 minutes in prime time and without commercials .
The plan, which is still evolving, has the nominees meeting with a single moderator in an empty television studio. So far, it has not been endorsed by either party.
To supplant the ritual documentation of the candidates' campaign day, the networks say they will provide in-depth analytical reporting on the candidates and the issues. Mr. Hannon said CNN planned "investigative biographies" on each candidate.
Mr. Bruno of ABC said, "We're not going to let them get away again with just trying to declare who's the bigger patriot."
The networks now dismiss carefully chosen, scenic campaign appearances, which they can no longer afford to cover anyway, as meaningless "photo opportunities" and "video news releases." Mr. Russert said, "In 1988, by the time George Bush went to his third flag factory, we should have known something was up."
By staying in the studio, using limited videotape of the appearances and more well-researched information on the candidates' positions, the network executives said, the viewer will be better served -- at a much lower price.
Each news organization also said it has a plan to examine the claims made in political commercials. Mr. Bruno said: "We're all determined to hold the candidates responsible for what is said and promised in their names in those 30-second ads. You could call it a truth squad."
Sig Rogich, now assistant to the President and the director of advertising for President Bush's 1988 campaign, said he doubted that the coverage would substantially change in 1992, despite all the revised plans.
"You won't see that big a change ultimately," Mr. Rogich said. "The public still wants to see the candidates in the field, reacting to people. There is only so much analytical reporting you can do before the viewers start turning to another channel. One network is going to realize that and go out on the road with the candidates."
Over all, Mr. Peyronnin said, the number of hours of coverage of the campaign on CBS will probably be greater this year than in 1988, although many of those hours may come outside prime time.
Although Mr. Hannon of CNN suggested that the cutbacks in the coverage by the broadcast networks might be more noticeable than those executives were now willing to admit, he said: "There is a strong conviction on the part of news people to redress some of the problems we saw in 1988. It is a good thing to get away from the daily utterances of these guys at the flag factories. But nothing ever happens in a vacuum. Partly what you have here is a white-hat rationale for spending less on coverage."
Still, he added: "For a lot of reasons this is going to be a radically different political year. It may be better. We just have to wait and see."

HEADLINE: Seoul Says It Now Has No Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 18

 BODY:
In a move intended to increase pressure on North Korea to halt its nuclear weapons program, President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea announced on national television tonight that there were not now any nuclear weapons in his country.
"As I speak, there do not exist any nuclear weapons whatsoever, anywhere in the Republic of Korea," Mr. Roh said. 
 It was the first time in nearly four decades that a South Korean President could have made that statement. Although it has never been officially confirmed, the United States has kept more than 100 nuclear weapons at American bases in South Korea as part of its commitment to defend the Seoul Government.
 
Decision to Withdraw Weapons
 But after Western intelligence officials began reporting this year that North Korea is possibly only a year away from completing its first atomic bomb, South Korea and the United States decided to withdraw all American nuclear weapons. The decision, which was announced last month by Mr. Roh, satisfied one of North Korea's conditions for allowing international inspection of its nuclear research complex at Yongbyon, just north of Pyongyang.
Mr. Roh said that with his announcement tonight, and an earlier offer with the United States to permit North Korea to inspect any civilian or military site in the South in return for reciprocal rights in the North, the Communist Government in Pyongyang no longer had any reason to resist an agreement to halt its nuclear weapons program.
"North Korea must forthwith conclude and ratify a nuclear safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency, shut down all nuclear reprocessing and enrichment facilities and submit unconditionally to international inspection," Mr. Roh said.
But Pyongyang has also demanded that the Seoul Government renounce the protection of the United States nuclear umbrella, which can still be extended over South Korea from American bases elsewhere in the Pacific. The South has made no such commitment, and there was no immediate reaction from the North to Mr. Roh's comments tonight.
Mr. Roh's speech is the latest in a series of moves intended to bring the Koreas closer together, including an agreement last week pledging each nation not to attack the other and providing for economic exchanges, the re-establishment of communications links and the reuniting of families separated since the Korean War began in 1950. The nonaggression pact was the first step toward a full peace treaty since an armistice was signed 38 years ago.
But Mr. Roh warned today that none of the recently agreed upon steps could proceed until the North stopped trying to build a nuclear bomb.
"Obviously, we cannot successfully build peace and national reconciliation without first resolving the nuclear question," Mr. Roh said, according to a copy of his speech made available by the South Korean Government.
 
Soviet Subsidies Halted
 North Korea is believed to be eager to carry out the trade clauses of last week's accord. The Soviet Union has halted its subsidized deliveries of a range of goods, including oil, and because of its increasing diplomatic and economic isolation, North Korea has almost no hard currency with which to conduct normal trade or to purchase the raw materials and finished goods it needs to keep its economy afloat.
The South Koreans have dangled the prospect of a sharp increase in trade on easy terms as an inducement to North Korea to join international agreements.
In addition, the Japanese Government has said that if North Korea abandons its nuclear weapons ambitions, Tokyo may be willing to offer substantial financial aid and trade opportunities on concessionary terms.
The two Koreas have agreed to meet before the end of the year to begin negotiating a joint pledge to insure the Korean Peninsula will remain nuclear free.
What will happen if Pyongyang still resists is unclear. The United States has indicated it may take the matter up at the United Nations, and South Korean generals have periodically made remarks suggesting they would consider military strikes to destroy the nuclear facilities.

HEADLINE: Motor-Vehicle Employees Charged in Fake-ID Ring

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
About 40 employees of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles have been arrested and charged with selling at least 700 fake driver's licenses and other documents, many of them to illegal aliens, Federal authorities in Manhattan said yesterday.
The United States Attorney, Otto G. Obermaier, said that an 18-month investigation had smashed a loosely organized ring of state workers and others. In all, 57 people were charged with fraud, bribery and trafficking in false documents, including driver's licenses, registrations, learner's permits and other Department of Motor Vehicle documents. 
 Law-enforcement officials said the arrests constituted one of the biggest roundups of public employees on corruption charges in recent memory.
 
Raids and Searches
 In a series of raids, city police officers and investigators from the United States Attorney's office, the Bronx District Attorney's office, and the office of the Inspector General of the Department of Motor Vehicles descended on four motor vehicle offices in the city -- two in Manhattan, one in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn. At the same time, several suspects' homes or businesses were searched.
At the state motor vehicle branch office at 2265 East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx early yesterday morning, about 100 patrons were startled and some ducked for cover when nearly 20 law-enforcement officers wearing bulletproof vests and carrying shotguns swooped in and arrested eight employees.
All of the suspects were to be arraigned later before United States magistrate judges.
At a news conference, Mr. Obermaier said the investigation uncovered a large underground market in the city for false motor vehicle ID's. He said the network was based on the cooperation of corrupt motor vehicle employees and others in a loose-knit gang that "engaged in a systematic pattern of corrupt transactions."
Each ring member had a specific role. For instance, he said, some were "runners" who funneled bribes to state employees.
 
Cost: Up to $1,000
 Mr. Obermaier said individual ID's cost anywhere from $250 to $1,000. The purchasers included illegal aliens, scofflaws cited for motor-vehicle violations, convicted criminals seeking to change their identities, and others who could not get the documents legally.
The heavy demand for the ID's stemmed, he said, from the wide acceptance given to them by the police, department stores, banks, credit card companies and other institutions.
For example, the police rely on driver's licenses to determine identity, residence and criminal histories, while government agencies use them to trace public benefit payments.
The conspiracy, law-enforcement officials said, relied on motor vehicle employees who had access to computers, ID supplies, official documents and validating stamps. They said the employees also had to know how to circumvent internal controls and security measures.
Mr. Obermaier said the investigation involved the use of undercover police officers, informers, and videotape and audio surveillance.
 
Widespread Thefts
 Although Mr. Obermaier did not disclose what set off the investigation, other officials said it was in response to widespread thefts in every motor vehicle office in the city.
For example, a number of document-validating machines were stolen, and officials said false documents recovered by the police were traced to the stolen machines.
Thousands of blank driver's licenses and other documents were also stolen from the offices. Mr. Obermaier said more than 1,200 vehicle registrations were stolen from the Harlem branch in a single theft, and 232 blank driver's licenses were stolen from the Bronx.
In July 1990, the authorities said, about 900 vehicle registrations were stolen from the department office at 40 Centre Street in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Debating Park Service Plan To Raze Ellis I. Buildings

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
The buildings were there when the immigrants poured into Ellis Island in the early 1900's: the morgue and the crematory, the contagious-disease wards, the furnace and laundry. But do they have enough historic merit to save them from the wrecker's ball?
That was the dominant question at a 3 1/2-hour hearing Tuesday night on the National Park Service's plan to demolish 12 buildings to make room for a privately owned, $145 million conference center with 325 rooms for overnight guests. 
 Gerald Patten, the service's regional director, said 99.5 percent of the 12 million immigrants who passed through Ellis Island never saw these buildings on the southern half of the island. He argued that the crumbling structures account for only 10 percent of the building space on the island and are not critical to a full appreciation of its past. The past, he said, is best remembered in the exhibits in the island's refurbished Great Hall, the site of Tuesday's hearing.
"This building is substantial enough to tell all the stories of Ellis Island," Mr. Patten said. Speaking of the plan, he said, "I think care has been taken to minimize the impact on the island's historic fabric."
 
Site of the Nightmare
 The most poignant rejoinder came from Ken Fitch, a Manhattan writer, who said the joy most immigrants felt on Ellis Island was mixed with the dread felt by ailing immigrants that they would be deported.
"The southern half of the island -- unknown, unseen and hidden -- is the physicalization of that fear," Mr. Fitch said. "It is the place where the nightmare dwells. We cannot underestimate the power of a place to teach." Destroying the buildings destroys the memory of Ellis's most wretched residents, Mr. Fitch said.
About 40 people spoke at the hearing, and they were evenly divided on the plan.
Preservationists argued to save the 12 buildings, calling them critical to the full educational value of the island and a true interpretation of its past. A commercial venture, most of them said, was not appropriate in what they called a shrine to the nation's immigrant history and ethnic diversity.
Supporters called the conference center plan a boon to tourism and an opportunity to create new jobs and tax revenues. They said it would be ideal for international summit meetings and would bring new bustle to New York Harbor. In addition, they said, the island's 18 other decaying buildings would be rebuilt, their facades intact, as part of the conference center. And scientific and academic groups and the general public would be able to use the center on weekends and holidays and on summer days when corporate conferences ebb.
The Park Service's allies included two Democratic Congressmen, Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan and Frank Guarini of Jersey City; leaders of several labor unions, the American Institute of Architects, and various business groups, including the New York Hotel and Motel Trades Council and the Association for a Better New York.
In a statement read by an aide, Mr. Rangel said that he regretted the loss of the crematory, morgue and hospital wards, which he said "should not be denigrated."
"However," he added, "neither should they be so revered as to prevent rational, responsible, preservation-minded development that serves the public and national interests from moving forward."
A critic, J. Jackson Walter, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, said the ancestors of 40 percent of Americans came through Ellis Island. He questioned whether a private conference center conveyed the true significance of the island and whether Americans would be proud of it 50 years from today.
"Economics simply can't be what Ellis Island is all about," Mr. Walter said. "This place is authentic. That reality needs to be preserved." Mr. Walter called for a national debate on the issue.
Another critic, Clark Strickland, president of the Preservation League of New York State, appealed to Congress and the public to provide funds to preserve all 30 decaying buildings.
Mr. Patten, the Park Service official, said the agency has a $200 million capital budget, a backlog of $2 billion in rehabilitation and repair work at its parks and landmarks and, consequently, no money for Ellis Island.
For years, the service had insisted on using existing buildings for a conference center. But its developer, William Hubbard of New York City, was unable to raise the financing until International Conference Resorts of America of Scottsdale, Ariz., offered to put up the money if the 12 buildings were demolished.
After the hearing, Michael Adlerstein, the park service's regional chief of urban projects, said officials would meet with the historic preservation officers of New York State and New Jersey and the Advisory Council on Historic Preservation, which advises President Bush and Congress on proposed changes to national landmark property.
"We'll try to find an acceptable plan within the concept of an international conference center that satisfies concerns the public raised," Mr. Adlerstein said.
During the hearing, New York State's preservation officer, Orin Lehman, said the proposal "tramples on the evocative nature of the island." New Jersey, however, softened its past criticism of the plan. James Hall, New Jersey's deputy preservation officer, called it "reasonable" and urged that more hearings be held.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A crowd waited outside a hearing room in the Great Hall at Ellis Island before entering a meeting held by the National Park Service. The service plans to demolish 12 buildings to make room for a $145 million conference center. Preservationists argued against the move. (F. N. Kinney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 34.7 Million Lack Health Insurance, Studies Say; Number Is Highest Since '65

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans without any health insurance rose last year by 1.3 million, bringing the total number of uninsured to 34.7 million, the highest since the creation of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965, several health policy researchers reported today.
The increase occurred before the recent surge in layoffs because of the slumping economy, the researchers said, suggesting that the problem reflected long-term changes in the nation's health-care system. The recession and the sharp rise in unemployment in recent months have almost certainly contributed to a further rise in the number of uninsured Americans because many people lose health insurance when they lose their jobs. 
 The number of unemployed has risen by 1.9 million since June 1990, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Last month 8.5 million Americans were unemployed, the bureau said.
The new study, a tabulation and analysis of Census Bureau data from the March 1991 Current Population Survey, was done by the Center for National Health Program Studies at Harvard Medical School. The bureau has not published a report on health insurance this year. But in response to questions, Census Bureau economists confirmed today that the number of people reporting they had no health insurance rose by 1.3 million last year.
 
Reasons for the Increase
 Dr. David U. Himmelstein, a co-author of the Harvard report, suggested two reasons for the increase in the uninsured: health insurance premiums have risen sharply, making private coverage less affordable, and many private insurers now decline to write policies for individuals and groups f deemed to pose a high risk because of pre-existing medical problems.
The Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group for commercial health insurers, said today that the average monthly premium for a family increased to $318 in 1990, from $210 in 1987. Donald B. White, a spokesman for the group, said employers paid more than 70 percent of such premiums.
Many people who joined the ranks of the uninsured last year were relatively affluent. Families with annual incomes of $50,000 or more accounted for nearly one-third of the increase in the number of people with no health insurance, the Harvard researchers said. The number of such uninsured families with incomes of $50,000 or more rose by 431,000, to a total of 5.3 million in 1990.
Families with annual incomes of $25,000 or more accounted for nearly three-fourths of the increase in the number of uninsured, the study said.
 
A Salient Political Issue
 Data in the report suggest why health care has become a salient political issue. Democrats and Republicans alike say their middle-income constituents have expressed growing concern about the cost and availability of health care and health insurance. Private businesses in diverse industries and the American Medical Association have joined labor unions in prodding President Bush and Congress to take action.
Last month, in an election to fill the seat of the late Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, voters in that state rejected the Republican candidate, former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, in favor of a Democrat, Harris Wofford, who supported national health insurance. Alarmed at those results, Mr. Bush said recently that he would offer comprehensive health-care proposals in his State of the Union Message next month.
The study issued today was written by Dr. Himmelstein, an associate professor of medicine at Harvard; Dr. Steffie Woolhandler, an assistant professor of medicine at Harvard, and Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, a consumer organization. All three support a national health insurance program to provide medical coverage to all Americans.
The number of people with private health insurance declined by 1.3 million last year, to 177 million, the study said.
Using data from other sources, Carl J. Schramm, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, estimated that the number of people with private health insurance protection declined by 5 million from 1980 to 1988. The nation's total population increased on the average by more than 2.2 million people a year in the 1980's.
"Health-care premiums reflect the price of health care, which has gone up at double-digit rates in recent years," Mr. Schramm said in an interview. "The rising cost of health care drives up premiums, so fewer and fewer businesses can afford health insurance. That's the primary reason five million people fell out of the private health insurance net. It's outrageous to blame health insurance companies for that development. We have to adjust our prices to reflect the underlying risk, the underlying cost of health care."
The number of people without any health insurance rose last year even though there was a big expansion of Medicaid, resulting from a new law that made benefits available to many pregnant women and children in low-income families. The number of people enrolled in Medicaid rose last year by 3.1 million, to 24.3 million, Dr. Himmelstein said.
The Harvard researchers used Census Bureau data to estimate the number of uninsured people in each state. The states with the lowest proportion of their populations uninsured were North Dakota, Wisconsin, Connecticut, Hawaii and Iowa. In each of those states, 6 percent to 8 percent of the people reported having no health insurance.
New Mexico, Texas, Mississippi, Louisiana and California had the highest proportions of their populations uninsured. In each of those states, 19 percent to 22 percent of the people said they had no health insurance.
Dr. Himmelstein said the number of uninsured people would have been much higher last year if the Medicaid program had not been expanded. "Without the expansion of Medicaid, the ranks of Americans without health insurance would have swelled by 4.4 million last year," he said.

HEADLINE: Bush Signs Transit Bill In Texas And Touts Jobs

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EULESS, Tex., Dec. 18

 BODY:
President Bush traveled 1,430 miles today to a muddy road-building site near Dallas in his latest effort to dramatize his eagerness to ease the "tough times" he now says the nation faces.
With television cameras rolling through a gray drizzle, Mr. Bush signed a $151 billion highways bill that he said would create or sustain 600,000 jobs in the current fiscal year. 
 The President watched approvingly as a roadworker, Arnold Martinez, introduced him with comments about layoffs in the industry and the "sometimes scary and financially difficult" nature of his work. Later, Mr. Bush donned a flag-emblazoned hard hat for a 20-minute inspection of earthmoving and paving machines.
 
Chicken-Fried Steak for Lunch
 Then the President loaded Mr. Martinez and six other workers picked out by the White House into his mud-spattered limousine and a van and the group was driven off to a roadside diner for a lunch of chicken-fried steak.
But at the same time, the fate of 3,800 jobs at a General Motors plant in nearby Arlington was thrown into question by an announcement that the company would consolidate operations there with those at a plant in Ypsilanti, Mich., and that one of the factories would be closed.
Today's appearance by Mr. Bush was the first since the White House abandoned its insistence that the economy was in a sluggish recovery and conceded that the recession that began in 1990 was continuing. Mr. Bush emphasized his anxiety about that whenever he found himself before a microphone or camera.
"Yes, there are layoffs and many families are having a rough go of it, and the American people want action," Mr. Bush said at the bill-signing ceremony. "And action is what they'll get. And I want every American to know that getting the economy back on track is my No. 1 priority."
Mr. Bush said twice today that his domestic priorities could be summed up in three words: "jobs, jobs, jobs."
Beyond today's roads bill, however, he offered no hint of other programs that he might favor to create those jobs or to otherwise spur the economy. Pressed to describe the growth package he plans to offer Congress next year, he said only: "We're going to have a big one."
The lunches, hard-hat tours and expressions of concern today reflect a recently mounted effort to depict Mr. Bush as someone who cares about the average American and his economic woes. The effort took shape about the time Mr. Bush replaced his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, with Samuel K. Skinner.
 
A New Strategy at Work
 Mr. Skinner, who helped run Mr. Bush's past presidential campaigns in Illinois, has said he plans to take the President outside Washington more often to see and hear the problems of ordinary Americans. He accompanied the President to today's ceremony, held beneath a largely finished expressway overpass near the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.
When the highways legislation that Mr. Bush applauded today was introduced in Congress, it was attacked by some of the President's his domestic policy advisers as "social engineering." Some conservatives oppose provisions that would channel more money to mass transit and high-technology projects like magnetically levitated trains, arguing that such systems often fail to support themselves.
But with the recovery from recession losing ground and unemployment growing by 240,000 workers last month alone, the highways bill has quickly become the tangible symbol of the Administration's economic policy.
In an afternoon speech at the airport to the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials, the President said the 600,000 jobs that the highways bill would support this fiscal year is "just the start."
"Private projects funded with this money will generate even more work for Americans," he said. "A good transportation network will support jobs that wouldn't exist otherwise. That's the biggest benefit of this law."
The Administration estimates that $11 billion of the $151 billion authorized by the bill will be given to the states and spent immediately, creating or saving 600,000 jobs in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
Economists say the legislation should sustain about 900,000 jobs annually over its six-year life. That includes workers who are currently employed on highway jobs but who are facing layoffs, and workers who were recently left jobless when spending on Government projects trailed off at the end of the last fiscal year.
The bill funnels $21 billion in construction and repair money over six years to a new "national highway system" melded from the Federal Interstate network and a patchwork of other heavily traveled roads.
According to Marion Anderson of Employment Research Associates, a Lansing, Mich., consultant, every billion dollars spent on mass transit creates about 7,000 construction jobs and another 20,000 other jobs, like steelmaking, government work and operation of lunch wagons that feed workers.

HEADLINE: States Slashed Aid to Poor in 1991, Report Says

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Drastically paring emergency cash assistance and programs intended to avert homelessness, states slashed programs for the poor more sharply this year than in any year since the recession of the early 1980's, according to a study issued today.
In what they called the first comprehensive report on the subject, the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Center for the Study of the States said 40 states froze or cut benefits under the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program. 
 Of the 30 state general assistance programs, intended primarily for poor single people and childless couples, 14 were cut, affecting nearly a half-million people, or about a third of all recipients.
These cuts "are especially biting because they came during a recession when jobs are scarce and poor and unskilled people cannot easily find work," said Isaac Shapiro, a senior researcher with the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington policy research organization. The other author of the study, the Center for the Study of the States, is affiliated with the State University of New York at Albany.
The budget cuts together with the recession will result in increased homelessness in the nation, the report said. Compounding problems, many states combined cuts in assistance programs with increases in sales and other taxes that disproportionately affect the poor, it said.
Eleven states cut emergency payments intended to avert homelessness, and nine cut programs to help those already homeless, the report said. Four states cut benefits for the low-income elderly, blind or disabled, and 20 others froze the benefits. Over all, state programs to make housing more affordable were slashed 22 percent.
"These cuts concentrated on the poorest of the poor, in contrast to the cuts made in the beginning of the Reagan Administration, which targeted the working poor who had other means of income," said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, at a news conference.
The study said governors and legislatures relied too heavily on spending cuts and not enough on increasing income taxes, noting that programs for the poor in most states constitute 6 percent of the state budget.
Molly Hering, legislative director for the American Legislative Exchange Council, a bipartisan organization of state legislators, said, "In very recessionary, tough times, taxpayers are finding it extremely difficult to justify why they are paying for able-bodied single men and women to remain on benefits." She asserted that the cuts helped the poor by providing incentives to become self-reliant.
Ray Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors' Association, said cuts were made across the board and not just in programs for the poor.
 
More Cuts Are Seen
 States dealt with a combined $30 billion in budget deficits for the 1992 fiscal year, and with budget problems continuing, the poor could face a new round of deep cuts next year, the report said.
Michigan and Massachusetts made the deepest cuts, it said. Michigan, for example, halted general assistance and cut basic benefits in the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, payments to the elderly, drug subsidies, food aid and emergency money when people are about to lose electricity or heat. Others that made deep cuts were California, the District of Columbia, Illinois, Maine, Maryland and Ohio.
This report is one of several released this week detailing what their authors characterized as governmental assaults on the poor. A report issued Monday by the United States Conference of Mayors on a survey of 28 cities said the demand for emergency food increased 26 percent and the demand for emergency shelter grew 13 percent this year. A report Tuesday by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty examined what it called "the recent spate of anti-homeless ordinances."

HEADLINE: Trump and USAir Deal Seen Near

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
USAir is close to signing an agreement to take over the running of the Trump shuttle, with an option to buy it after five years, two executives close to the talks said yesterday. In return, Donald J. Trump would no longer be held personally responsible for more than $300 million of the shuttle's debt.
But the executives, who insisted on anonymity, differed on the timing, with one saying it could be a matter of days and the other saying the move could occur in a week or more. 
 One executive said the banks, which have been trying to come to terms with Mr. Trump on his various debts, agreed to the deal because they felt USAir would pay more for the shuttle at the end of five years than the $360 million Mr. Trump paid Eastern Airlines to acquire it in 1989.
Representatives of USAir could not be reached for comment.
 
No Letter, Banker Says
 The banks, led by Citicorp, have suspended the shuttle's interest payments.
One executive, a banker, said last night that no letter of intent had been signed but that USAir was in talks about a deal. The banker said Mr. Trump would no longer be liable for $100 million of the shuttle's debts, though he would still owe $35 million.
It could not be determined yesterday why the executives differed so widely on the extent of Mr. Trump's personal debt in the deal.
The New York developer borrowed the money to buy the shuttle on the basis of his ability to repay the bank loans. At that time, his financial empire was still doing well.
One executive said that other airlines, including American and United, were interested in acquiring the Trump shuttle but that USAir had been the most aggressive.
 
Antitrust Concerns
 For USAir, the advantage of not buying the shuttle outright is that it does not have to put up a lot of cash immediately and that it may be in a better position to overcome antitrust concerns by arguing that it now holds only a minority stake.
USAir, based in Arlington, Va., is a leading carrier at La Guardia Airport in New York, National Airport in Washington and Logan International Airport in Boston, all of which are linked by the shuttle's hourly flights.
Thus the purchase, which is subject to approval by the Transportation Department, could raise antitrust questions, although the agency has approved several takeovers that have been opposed by the Justice Department as anti-competitive.
Under the agreement, for five years USAir would operate the shuttle with a small owernship stake. The carrier is likely to buy the shuttle afterward, since the landing slots the shuttle controls at La Guardia and at other airports are difficult to get.
Large airlines have often been hampered in expanding at these airports because they cannot get landing and takeoff slots at peak periods. The Trump shuttle would also help feed USAir's flights, which are heavily concentrated on the East Coast.
When Mr. Trump bought the shuttle from Eastern in July 1989, he called it the addition of another jewel to his empire, equaling it to his acquisition of the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. But a bitter strike at Eastern had cut the shuttle's market share to less than 20 percent, and Mr. Trump and his managers had a tough time winning travelers back from the Pan Am Shuttle, which has since been bought by Delta Air Lines.
 
Fighting to Regain Share
 Eventually, the Trump shuttle, helped by a refurbishment of its old fleet of Boeing 727's, as well as its terminals, fought back to about achieve a 50 percent share, but it has been unable to attain the more than the 60 percent share that produced high profits in the Eastern days.
Under Mr. Trump, the shuttle lost money most of the time, and its losses deepened during the Persian Gulf war, when fuel prices doubled and traffic plummeted.
Mr. Trump said in a recent interview that the shuttle had since recovered and was producing an operating profit. But airline analysts have held that two shuttles operating in the same market were too much and that neither could show solid profits until one succumbed.
Unlike for Mr. Trump, who has no other airline operations, the shuttle will be important for USAir, beyond being an asset that produces profits. It would be a strategic acquisition that would greatly strenghten the troubled carrier in some of the nation's largest and lucrative markets.
USAir has had heavy operating losses because of the traffic drop from the recession and high labor costs. The carrier has also been hampered by having too many fights in similar markets after it acquired Piedmont Airlines in 1987.
Delta, based in Atlanta, has a reputation for emphasizing service, so the competitive pressure on the Trump shuttle is expected to increase.
 
New Managers Expected
 On Oct. 1, Mr. Trump appointed a new president of the shuttle, Terry Hallcom, who had been the director of flight operations and an Eastern pilot for 22 years.
USAir is expected to named its own management team.
It could not be determined yesterday whether Mr. Trump lost money on the transaction, but the other executive close to the talks said yesterday that neither the banks nor Mr. Trump would lose money if USAir bought the shuttle.

HEADLINE: Stocks Prices Mixed as Dow Gains 5.81

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed yesterday as blue-chip issues rallied after some early weakness to finish slightly higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.81 points, to 2,908.09, while some indexes posted small losses.
Investor concern over the economy continued to hound the market, as well as disappointment with the Federal Reserve's delay in lowering interest rates. Some traders said the General Motors Corporation's announced restructuring could be interpreted as good news, while others said it simply underlined the economy's weakness. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 193.5 million shares, up from 191.7 million on Tuesday. Losing issues led gainers at 891 to 740.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.74 points, to 383.48, while the Big Board composite moved up 0.23 points, to 211.44. Trading on the American Stock Exchange pushed that index down 1.09 points, to 368.72.
The Nasdaq composite rose 0.14 points, to 593.84, while the Russell 2,000, a barometer of smaller stocks, slipped 0.29 points, to end at 177.37.
Blue-chip issues fell at the opening over disappointment in the Fed's delay in moving toward another rate cut. The decline also reflected some followthrough from Tuesday's late selloff. In addition, a soft bond market and some selling by investors closing portfolios for the year also exerted pressure on stocks.
Weighing on the market was the testimony by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the House Ways and Means Committee, where he said the United States business upturn "clearly has faltered."
Gene J. Seagle, research director at Gruntal & Company, said, "Greenspan's statement to the House Ways and Means Committee and soon-to-be-released Administration plan to stimulate a laggard economy have both buyers and sellers waiting to see which way the ax will fall."
But, he added: "History tells us to expect a year-end rally. Since World War II, the average gain from that rally has run to almost 10 percent."
Mr. Seagle said he sees an increased amount of cash on the sidelines that has been building up, with an unusually large accumulation in money funds, almost $500 billion that is receiving low rates of return.
In the market yesterday, BET Holdings, parent company for the cable network Black Entertainment Television, requested that trading be halted in its stock at about 1 P.M. so the company could clarify an "apparent misunderstanding" on subscriber levels. The stock, which last traded at 15 7/8, off 3, did not resume trading for the remainder of the day. The misunderstanding stems from a difference between the number of subscribers the company says it has and the number A. C. Nielsen says it has.
Based on the stock price appreciation of International Flavors and Fragrances, an analyst at Paine Webber, Kimberly Ritrievi, lowered her rating to "attractive" from "buy." She said, "I think there's a 20 percent upside, but it's not the screaming buy it was." The stock rose 1/4, to 96 5/8.
Another company whose rating was changed because of its stock price was Advanced Micro Devices, as analyst Thomas Kurlak of Merrill Lynch downgraded the company's intermediate term rating to "neutral" from "above average," traders said. The stock fell as much as 7/8, closing down 1/2, to 15 yesterday.
Digital Equipment said yesterday that it sees a second-quarter operating loss because of a weak worldwide economy. It also said competitive pressures had resulted in reduced demand for larger computer systems and, in addition, several new products have not yet been shipped. The stock, down as much as 6 1/8 early in the day, closed off 4 3/4, to 51 3/4.
Following a secondary offering of 2 million shares at $42 a share, Office Depot, which sells office supplies, fell 1 1/2, to finish the day at 42 1/2.

HEADLINE: Record Year In Bond Issues

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
American companies issued a record $464.4 billion in corporate bonds this year, encouraged by falling interest rates to raise fresh capital, IDD Information Services said yesterday.
The total far exceeds last year's record of $283.7 billion, said IDD, an economic research firm. 
 The leading underwriter for corporate bonds in 1991 was Merrill Lynch & Company, which managed 952 new deals worth $77 billion. Following Merrill were Goldman, Sachs & Company and Lehman Brothers, which each managed $55 billion in deals.
Merrill also ranked first among underwriters of new equity, including stock, with 1,067 deals worth $93.2 billion.
IDD said that each deal, on average, generated a fee of $1.1 million, or 0.24 percent of the total value.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Bleak About Economy But Warns Against a 'Quick Fix'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave Congress a bleak assessment of the economy today, but he suggested that the bad times would be over by Election Day and cautioned against a "quick fix" like a tax cut.
"The economy is struggling," Mr. Greenspan said, because the nation is feeling the hangover from rampant speculation and increased debt in the 1980's. He said he was especially struck by a deep-seated concern among Americans that they will not live as well as previous generations. 
But this "does not necessarily mean that a prolonged period of economic weakness is inevitable," he told the House Ways and Means Committee. Responding to questions from panel members, he said the kinds of tax cuts now being considered by the White House and Congress would probably be counterproductive.
Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that he might have underestimated the intractability of the recession earlier this year, but his basic advice now to Congress was to sit tight.
Mr. Greenspan ended three hours of testimony by saying, "I would be very doubtful that any short-term fiscal stimulus which could engender significant consumption at this stage would be sufficiently long-lasting to put us on a new long-term growth path."
 
Danger From the Deficit
 Mr. Greenspan's comments today repeatedly emphasized the danger of tax cuts or spending increases that might magnify the deficit. In other recent comments, the Federal Reserve chairman has said fiscal measures of some sort may help revive the economy, although he stressed that any such steps would have to avoid enlarging the deficit. Without giving particulars, he had said such a package was conceivable.
The financial markets are expecting the Federal Reserve to cut key interest rates again any day now, and today's testimony did not seem to have much effect on trading. Although Mr. Greenspan would not tip his hand, he said nothing to counter the expectation that additional easing of rates was in the offing. In answer to a question from the committee chairman, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, Mr. Greenspan said, "Obviously, we are looking at the situation exceptionally closely, and should in our judgment further action be required, you can expect us to do so."
The Federal Reserve chairman is highly respected in Congress, even among Democrats, and if he had recommended a fiscal stimulus, enactment would have been a foregone conclusion. But his advice against a tax cut that would increase the budget deficit might not have been sufficient to dissuade the politicians, who are under severe pressure at the outset of an election year to try to give the economy a quick jolt.
 
Relief for the Middle Class
 The White House is considering a variety of tax proposals, including one that would give taxpayers a rebate of up to some $300 on their taxes due April 15. Dozens of measures have been introduced in Congress, many of them to provide tax relief to middle-income taxpayers.
Mr. Rostenkowski, the dominant voice in Congress on tax matters, described the conflict in which the lawmakers find themselves: "We are being asked by our constituents to solve their economic problems, and we are being told by many experts that we should promote the long-run health of our economy."
Because the Federal Reserve has considerable control over short-term interest rates, Mr. Greenspan has more influence over the economy and bears more responsibility for its state than any other public official.
For the first time publicly, he suggested today that he might have miscalculated the nature of the recession earlier this year and implied that perhaps the Fed should have reduced rates last spring and summer when it was holding the line.
 
Rare Opportunity for Questions
 Unlike most other important officials, Mr. Greenspan rarely holds on-the-record interviews or answers questions from audiences after his speeches. So almost the only time he is subjected to public questioning is when he testifies before Congress.
His most recent previous testimony, in July, was unusually optimistic. "We are well on the path," he said then, "of actually achieving the type of goals which we've set out to achieve: a solid economic recovery with the unemployment rate moving down to its lowest sustainable, long-term rate, with growth at or close to its maximum long-term sustainable pace."
In line with that assessment, the Fed, which had been cutting interest rates more or less regularly since the summer of 1989 to try to thwart a serious recession, held rates constant from April to August of this year.
In retrospect now, he said, it is clear that as a result of the corporate mergers and buyouts, the overbuilding of commercial real estate and the household spending boom of the 1980's, much of it financed by debt, "the nation's balance sheet has been severely stretched."
 
Deciding to Trim Debts
 "By late summer," he continued, "the growing propensity of households to pare debt and businesses to reduce leverage was a signal that the balance sheet restraints, feared by many for a long time, had indeed taken hold, working against the normal forces of economic growth."
That is as close as Mr. Greenspan ever comes to admitting an error of judgment, although he said later in the hearing, "I am not sure there is any way that I know of analytically that we could have forecast that in advance."
Mr. Greenspan's economic assessment was not all gloomy. "There is a healing process going on," he told one questioner. "My best judgment at this stage is that what we are looking at is a pause, a different type of pause than we've seen in past recoveries, but a pause, nevertheless, in an economy which over all is in the process of recovering."
Asked then how long the process might take, he said, "This is a far shorter problem than a year."
 
Only One Tax to Cut
 Mr. Greenspan reiterated his long-standing support for a reduction in the capital gains tax and said other tax cuts to generate more business investment might be worthwhile as long as taxes were increased elsewhere or spending was cut to prevent adding to the deficit.
The Government's only policy position that would truly make a difference in economic growth, he said, was a reduction in the deficit. "It's only by removing the drain of Treasury borrowings from the capital market that the advantages of expanded savings and investment can be truly achieved," he declared.
Representative J. J. Pickle, a Texas Democrat, replied: "That's a statement of principle, but that's not likely to be achieved right now with respect to our immediate problems. In the land of the Wizard of Oz, that might come about, but not now."

HEADLINE: Tug-of-War Over G.M. Plant Closing

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Tex., Dec. 18

 BODY:
By not announcing which of two big-car assembly plants here and in Ypsilanti, Mich., it would close, the General Motors Corporation today put the lives of 3,400 workers here in limbo.
In saying only that the company intends to close in the next few years 21 assembly, engine and parts plants, Robert C. Stempel, chairman and chief executive of the No. 1 auto maker, set off a likely tug-of-war between the company, the union and local politicians as a decision is reached on which plants should be closed. 
 "That work is still ahead of us," Mr. Stemple said, predicting that the transition would occur next year.
But one thing is clear in this suburban city east of Fort Worth: Only one plant -- either the one here or the Ypsilanti plant, known as Willow Run, near Ann Arbor -- will be closed in the biggest retrenchment ever for General Motors.
At the Arlington plant, some workers challenged Mr. Stempel's promise that the plants would not be played off against each another to force the deepest possible concessions. But most workers boasted of their productivity.
"Dealers will tell you they'd rather have an Arlington car than a Willow Run car," said Annette Morrow, a seat builder and trimmer who has worked 15 years for G.M. "Willow Run labor is too militant and they have more salaried people there than we do," she said, referring to the Michigan plant.
Both plants build big cars, like the Chevrolet Caprice and the Buick Roadmaster. The decision on which to close will come down to which plant can make a better case for cutting costs and improving G.M.'s poor efficiency record so that the maker's cars can be priced more competitively.
The Michigan plant has lower costs for parts shipments, especially heavy engines and transmissions, compared with the Texas site because of its location near the heart of America's auto-making nerve center and G.M.'s North American supplier network. Yet the Texas plant is closer to suppliers of smaller parts, like wiring harnesses, door assemblies and body trim made in northern Mexico.
Arlington workers and executives once bragged that the quality of their work was one of the highest of any plant in the G.M. empire, but Mr. Stempel said today that that was no longer an issue. "The differences are so slight" now in quality levels among all G.M. plants, he said.
Workers at the G.M. plant here were told last week by their manager, Art Hester, and a senior union official, Mike Seiler, not to expect a decision today from Mr. Stempel. Many were stunned and angered by a report today in The Detroit Free Press that the decision to close the Arlington plant had already been made.
But after Mr. Stempel's remarks to reporters, many renewed their hopes that their plant would prevail in a competition with Willow Run.
 
Action by Union
 G.M.'s announcement today came as members of United Automobile Workers union Local 276 here voted to give their leaders a virtual blank check to bargain for whatever terms are needed to keep the Arlington plant in business.
"We need a good vote on this to give us the teeth to go in and negotiate," said Dave Perdue, president of the U.A.W. local. "I feel like we'll win."
One proposal outlined by the union was to add a third shift at the plant by moving to a four-day workweek of 10-hour shifts for its members. Current shifts are eight hours, five days a week. The change could open jobs for workers transferred from the Michigan plant, Mr. Perdue said.
Mr. Perdue said the union was not pressured into the concession by Mr. Hester. "He just lays the situation out on the table, and it's up to us to make some decisions," he said.
Walter Mays, 45, said the schedule change would help overcome the Arlington plant's smaller production capacity and higher freight costs compared with Willow Run's.
 
Making a Case
 The workers were told last week that Arlington managers would make their case before G.M. executives in Detroit during the week of Jan. 8, with Willow Run to follow a week later. A decision is expected before Feb. 1.
Mr. Mays was among those who were skeptical about Mr. Stempel's promise that the two plants were not being "whipsawed," as he put it.
"I've seen this before," Mr. Mays said of the schedule changes that his union leaders had endorsed. "Six years ago, we were told to vote in the team concept, or the plant would close," he said, referring to a way of reorganizing the work force. "We did, by 86 percent. Willow Run didn't, but they stayed open. I think it's another game to see what they can get. Their decision, whatever it is, has already been made."
 
Another Blow
 A shutdown of the sprawling, 38-year-old plant here would be yet another blow for the economy of the Fort Worth region, which, with one-third the population of Dallas, has been battered by plant closings and job cutbacks all year.
Just over a year ago, the Fort Worth area had one of the lowest jobless rates in Texas, at 4.4 percent. But jarring cutbacks in Pentagon budgets, which had an impact on a General Dynamics plant here; a slumping local economy, and rising manufacturing layoffs pushed unemployment to 7.2 percent in October.
The Pentagon canceled development of the Navy A-12 attack plane in January. And last summer it said that 7,000 jobs would be lost when the nearby Carswell Air Force Base, home to aging B-52 bombers, would be closed.
Those cutbacks knocked nearly 5 percent from the Fort Worth-Arlington economic base, and the loss of the G.M. plant "would blow away another point and a half," said Don C. Reynolds, a Fort Worth economist and former head of the county's economic development commission.
Bernard L. Weinstein, another local economist, said the General Motors plant, with a 1990 payroll of $121.5 million and hourly wages ranging between $15 and $25, contributes between $400 million and $500 million in purchasing power to the local economy.

GRAPHIC: Photo:Robert C. Stempel, chairman of General Motors, announcing yesterday in Detroit that G.M. would close six assembly and 15 components plants in North America and trim more than 70,000 jobs in the next few years. (Associated Press) (pg. D1)
 
Map of Texas showing location of Arlington. (pg. D4)
