HEADLINE: Excerpts From Fed Chief's Testimony

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the testimony of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday.
The upturn in business activity that began earlier this year clearly has faltered. It is apparent that the economy is struggling and that there have been some strong forces working against moderate cyclical revival. 
 Now that we are well past the period of gyrations associated with the crisis in the Persian Gulf, we can better gauge the strength of the underlying disinflationary forces that were active well before the economy tilted into recession in the autumn of 1990.
During the 1980's, large stocks of physical assets were amassed in a number of sectors, largely financed by huge increases in indebtedness.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The bottom line . . . is that the national balance sheet has been severely stretched. While most analysts of course were aware of the increasingly disturbing trends of rising debt and elevated corporate leverage, it was not clear that these burdens had as yet reached a magnitude that would restrain the American economy from a moderate cyclical recovery in 1991.

 	 	 		. . .	 	By late summer, however, with half the recession losses recovered, it became clear that the cumulative upward momentum that characterized previous recoveries was absent. The growing propensity of households to pare debt and businesses to reduce leverage was a signal that the balance sheet restraints feared by many for a long time had indeed taken hold, working against the normal forces of economic growth.
These events do not necessarily mean that a prolonged period of economic weakness is inevitable, but they do mean that policy makers must consider these unusual forces when shaping their response in the current situation.
It is essential that the direction of public policy be well targeted to the nature of the problem it is seeking to ameliorate. . . . But only in the context of prudent, noninflationary expansion of money and credit are such improvements likely to be lasting.
In concept, private balance sheet liquification also could be facilitated by tax cuts for individuals or corporations if they are largely saved by the recipients. In effect, public debt would displace private debt on our nation's balance sheet.
But if the markets were to perceive such policy initiatives as undermining long-term fiscal discipline, long-term interest rates would rise and debt service burdens again would mount. . . . Congress should approach with great caution any proposal that would expand the structural budget deficit. At a minimum, care should be taken to insure that any short-run stimulative action does not imply a widening of the deficit over the longer term. 

 	 	 		. ..	 	Consumers appear to be more apprehensive than one might expect given the broad macroeconomic circumstances. For example, the level of employment and particularly the layoff rate are well below those experienced in periods of economic weakness. This would not seem to square with the deep concerns expressed in surveys about perceived labor market conditions.
It is true that homeowners sense some contraction, however small, in the market value of their most important asset, the equity in their homes. But it is surely no worse a concern today than it was in the spring. If anything, the data on home prices suggests it should be less so.
I suspect that what concerns consumers and indeed everyone is that the current pause may be underscoring a retardation in long-term growth and living standards. So long as the recovery proceeded, this latent concern did not surface. But as balance sheet constraints held the recovery in check, earlier worries about whether the current generation will live as well as previous ones resurfaced.
Such anticipation certainly need not be realized if we follow appropriate policies, and this suggests strongly that any current policy initiatives should focus on some key fundamentals. Indeed, firm reliance on policies directed toward longer-term stability and incentives are likely to do as much or more for short-term economic expansion as a so-called quick fix.
. . . the essential shortcomings of this economy is the lack of saving and investment. It's here that our major policy focus should rest. Investment is the key to enhanced productivity and higher living standards. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	As I have argued previously before this committee, a reduction in the capital gains tax would be quite helpful. It is especially important considering our current difficulties with weak real estate property values. A capital gains tax cut would buoy property values, which would alleviate, in part, the collateral shortfalls that plague our financial institutions. . . . How far and how fast we can move towards a tax structure more conducive to capital formation is ultimately a political decision. 

 	 	 		. . .	 	Traditional fiscal stimulus might provide a temporary boost to aggregate demand, but if you accept the view that it is the concern of the American people for our long-term future that is at the root of our current problem, then other instruments of policy might well be more effective.
Market forces are already addressing our stretched balance sheets. Record issuance of equity in our capital markets recently is contributing to de-leveraging, and large bond issues are funding short-term debt, and removing some of that strain.
Finally, lower interest rates, as I indicated earlier, are lowering the debt-service burden. Mr. Chairman, we have made a good deal of progress in the balance-sheet adjustment process, and the payoff in the form of an easing of unusual restraint should begin to become evident in the reasonably near future.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Business Plans to Raise Capital Outlays by 5.4%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Businesses, after cutting plant and equipment spending in 1991 for the first time in five years, plan to increase investments by 5.4 percent next year, the Government said today.
Still, the increase would be less than half of the double-digit advances posted before the recession, and analysts said the report reflected anxiety over whether the economy could manage a sustained recovery. 
 "Normally in a recovery period, capital spending can be extremely brisk," said Gilbert Benz, an economist at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. The spending plans reported today are "a reflection that people are not expecting any real robust turnaround, even in late '92."
A Commerce Department survey in October and November found that businesses plan to spend $558.6 billion, which would be a record, for expansion and modernization in 1992, up from $530 billion projected for this year.
 
First Cut Since 1986
 But the survey found businesses were reducing their investments this year by five-tenths of 1 percent, the first decline since a 2.6 percent cut in 1986.
"The drop in '91 reflects what's now commonly thought to be an absence of any growth in the second half of the year," Mr. Benz said.
The new survey reversed a finding last summer, after the economy perked up a bit, that companies planned to increase spending by five-tenths of 1 percent this year. Spending in 1991 had been projected to rise 2.7 percent in a spring survey, 2.5 percent last winter and 2.4 percent a year ago.
The record for capital spending is $532.6 billion in 1990, although that reflected just a 5 percent increase as the economy entered the recession. Capital spending had advanced 11.4 percent in 1989 and 11 percent in 1988.
 
After Adjustment for Inflation
 The figures are not adjusted for inflation. When adjusted, 1992 spending plans rose 5.7 percent, to $521 billion. That compares with a decrease of 1.1 percent, to $492.8 billion, planned for 1991.
Slack demand has curbed much of the need for new plants and equipment. In fact, the Federal Reserve has said the nation's factories, mines and utilities used only 79.1 percent of their capacity in November.
At the same time, the recession has depleted the funds that businesses have for investment. The Commerce Department reported earlier that current-production cash flow -- the funds available for investment -- fell six-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter after inching up just three-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter.
The survey found utilities and companies engaged in mining, transportation and other nonmanufacturing businesses planned an 8.4 percent increase in capital spending to $374.5 billion.
Manufacturing companies, however, projected a one-tenth of 1 percent reduction to $184.1 billion.
The projection includes a 3 percent increase for industries making durable goods -- items like motor vehicles and machinery that are expected to last at least three years. But that was offset by a 2.4 percent decline in the production of nondurables, like food and clothing.

HEADLINE: Digital Forecasts Quarterly Operating Loss

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The Digital Equipment Corporation told analysts today that it was facing a probable operating loss for its second fiscal quarter ending Dec. 28. After the announcement, the computer company's stock plunged $4.75 to close at $51.75 on the Big Board.
While Digital did not say how much it expected to lose, analysts' estimates ranged from $18 million to $75 million. 
 Mark A. Steinkrauss, a Digital spokesman, said the loss resulted principally from reduced demand for larger computer systems like Digital's VAX 6000 and VAX 9000 lines because of the weak economy and competitive pressures. The loss would mark the first quarterly loss not related to a restructuring charge in Digital's 34-year history.
 
'Just Not Buying'
 Mr. Steinkrauss said the downturn was being felt in all Digital's global markets. "We're not losing business to other vendors," he said. "People are just not buying." Mr. Steinkrauss said that the company was considering more layoffs and plant closings but added that nothing would be announced until Jan. 16, when the quarterly numbers are handed out.
Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., has laid off 1,500 employees this quarter and plans to lay off 4,000 to 5,000 more in the second half of its fiscal year.
Marc Schulman, an analyst with UBS Securities, attributed the expected loss to the combined effect of the poor economy, a significant product-cycle transition for Digital and rumors that an impending investment tax credit would go into effect on Jan. 1.
"A customer has nothing to lose by waiting until Jan. 1 to buy new computers," Mr. Schulman said. "If you can get an investment tax credit that reduces the cost considerably, it is worth waiting." Mr. Schulman is now estimating the quarterly loss will be equal to 60 cents a share.
Digital has revamped nearly its entire product line and announced a large number of new computers since Oct. 30. The new products, which met with favorable reaction from customers and analysts, have not been shipped in volume as Digital gears up its manufacturing process. Mr. Steinkrauss said the new computers would be shipped in volume by March, as planned.
John B. Jones Jr. an analyst with Montgomery Securities, said the anticipated operating loss, which excludes interest earned from Digital's $2 billion in cash reserves, was not unexpected. He said he had forecast net earnings of 25 cents to 30 cents a share for the quarter, but a number of analysts had Digital's net at a break-even point, which would have pointed to a loss from operations.
For the comparable quarter a year ago, Digital reported a net profit of $155.4 million, or $1.25 a share, on sales of $3.18 billion.
"I think the market reaction is a bit overdone," Mr. Jones said. "But the mood on the Street for technology is definitely bearish right now. In the current economy, people are using every excuse they can find not to buy."
Mr. Schulman and Mr. Jones both said Digital's long-term strategy was fundamentally sound, and they were still bullish on the company's prospects, though not all analysts share that view.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Money Market Yields Rise

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt money market funds reversed course in the last week and strengthened a little, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors the funds and issues The Money Fund Report. The taxable funds continued their steady downward progress.
Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue's, said the tax-exempt yields rose "partly because of the recent large supply of municipal issues coming to market and a diminished appetite among investors for short-term securities at current low yields." 
 He pointed out that total assets of the tax-exempts dropped for the week by $720 million, to $92.7 billion. The average days to maturity of the tax-free funds' portfolio holdings rose by a day, to 59 days.
The seven-day compound average yield for the tax-exempts rose by 5 basis points, from 3.75 percent a week ago to 3.80 percent. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempt funds also rose 5 basis points, to 3.73 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
The 30-day compound yield was unchanged from the previous week at 3.77 percent, while the 30-day simple yield was also unchanged at 3.70.
Among tax-exempt funds investing in individual state securities, the top New York Fund was once again Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 4.48 percent, up a notch from 4.47 percent a week ago.
In Connecticut, the top-yielding fund this week was Dreyfus Conn. Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.14 percent, compared with the leader's yield last week of 4.04 percent.
New Jersey's leading fund for yields was again Calvert Tax Free Reserve New Jersey with a seven-day compound yield of 4.30 percent, compared with 4.24 percent a week ago.
Nationwide, among those funds with $100 million or more assets, the highest-yield performance for the week was once again turned in by the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.80 percent. compared with 4.74 percent a week ago.
 
Public Went Elsewhere
 Turning to the taxable funds, Mr. Frank said their total assets showed a sizable decline of $3 billion, to $475.1 billion, and most of the selling -- $2.6 billion -- came from individuals.
"The public was seeking higher yields elsewhere," Mr. Frank said. "Taxable money fund yields will continue to decline although in the weeks before the year-end we will be seeing some window dressing, or making the balance sheet look better, which traditionally raises money fund yields at year-end."
The average days to maturity of the portfolio holdings dropped by a day, to 61 days.
The seven-day compound yield on the taxable funds was 4.70 percent, down from 4.73 percent, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds was 4.59 percent, down from 4.63 percent.
The average compound 30-day yield dropped was 4.77 percent, down 4 basis points, and the 30-day simple yield was also down 4 basis points, to 4.66 percent. Among the taxables, the top-yielding fund for the week was the Twentieth Century Cash Reserve Fund, Kansas City, Mo., with a surprising yield of 17.76 percent, attributable to its taking capital gains.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a main competitor of money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.51, compared with 4.59 percent last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher; No Action on Rates Is Seen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday amid hints that interest rates in the United States would hold at present levels, at least for the short term.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $359 an ounce, up $1.70 from Tuesday. Later, the Republic National Bank said gold gained $1.30, to a late bid price of $358.80. 
 The dollar initially declined as traders sold the currency in anticipation that the Federal Reserve would move swiftly to cut interest rates. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less attractive to investors.
But the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicated in testimony before Congress that the central bank, while prepared to cut rates to help revive the economy, was not inclined to take immediate action.
"Traders took that to mean that interest rate differentials would be a bit better than expected, so the dollar was bid up," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Traders were also awaiting a news briefing scheduled for today by Germany's Bundesbank. The market is divided on whether the Bundesbank will announce a rate increase, which would hurt the dollar because investors may shift funds to capture higher yields on German fixed-income securities.
Activity was particularly light. "There is no corporate interest whatsoever," said Kevin Lawrie, chief dealer at the Bank of Boston. "One sizable order could knock the market one way or another."
He predicted the dollar would remain in a tight range until the new year. "People either made or lost their money and are quitting for the year," he said.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 128.42 Japanese yen, from 128.28 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London, it fell to 128.40 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 128.35 yen, up from 128.29 yen on Tuesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8253, from $1.8200 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.8290 to buy one pound, more expensive than Tuesday's $1.8275.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5715 German marks, up from 1.5703; 1.3925 Swiss francs, up from 1.3885; 5.3700 French francs, up from 5.3635; 1,187.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1470 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1461.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Blue Jays Make Morris Baseball's Richest Pitcher

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
For the fourth time in the last six winters, Jack Morris signed a contract as a free agent yesterday, and this time he became the highest-paid pitcher on baseball's ever-escalating salary scale. The Toronto Blue Jays, who have always had difficulty luring major free agents to Canada, captured Morris with a contract that guarantees him $10.85 million for two years.
The Boston Red Sox, who also had sought Morris's services, were on the verge of reaching agreement with their alternate choice, Frank Viola, on a three-year contract for about $14 million. Viola rejected the Mets' three-year, $13 million offer last April. 
 Morris's average of $5,425,000 a year sent the World Series hero leapfrogging past Roger Clemens's average annual value of $5,380,250 and Dwight Gooden's $5.15 million and placed him No. 2 on the overall list behind outfielder Bobby Bonilla's $5.8 million.
Morris, 36 years old, parlayed his 10-inning, 1-0 seventh-game victory over Atlanta 52 days ago and an unusual clause in his Minnesota contract into a new package that will pay him a $1.85 million signing bonus and salaries of $3.5 million and $4.5 million. The Blue Jays have an option for a third year with a $5.15 million salary, or they will pay him $1 million if they do not exercise the option.
Morris, who earned $3.7 million this year, became a free agent for the fourth time because he did not exercise the option he had in the contract he signed with the Twins as a free agent last February. The option would have paid him $3.65 million in 1992.
 
Significance Beyond Economics
 The new agreement, which was reached in approximately five hours of meetings club officials had in Toronto with the pitcher and his lawyer, Richard Moss, offered significance beyond economics. The Blue Jays have been one of baseball's most successful expansion teams, but they have never reached the World Series in their 15-year history.
"He has that competitive fire," Gord Ash, the assistant general manager, said in Toronto, explaining the club's willingness to pay such a high price. "He always wants to win. You would realize his competitiveness if you had been privileged to sit in on the negotiations."
Morris beat the Blue Jays in the first and fourth games of the American League pennant playoff, then won the first and seventh games of the World Series. He produced a remarkable performance in the seventh game, working with three days' rest instead of the customary four, rejecting efforts by Manager Tom Kelly to remove him from the game and escaping one difficult circumstance after another until the Twins finally scored a run in the 10th.
The veteran right-hander, a native of St. Paul, Minn., was thrilled to sign with the Twins last winter after spending his first 13 major league years with the Detroit Tigers. He said he preferred staying at home, but the Twins stopped short of offering him a contract that would put him in the Clemens-Goodens economic class.
"It was a tough decision," Morris told reporters in Toronto. "I have mixed emotions about what happened in Minnesota, but I think that can happen here, too. I enjoyed the year. It was one of the greatest of my career. I love Minnesota. I always have. But I like this team, and I like pitching in the dome."
Morris, who had an 18-12 record last season, initially wanted a guaranteed three-year contract, but no one was offering one. The Red Sox indicated they would, but Morris preferred pitching in the Skydome to Fenway Park. The Blue Jays offered him a two-year deal last week guaranteeing $10.75 million with the same option provisions for the third year.
In the negotiations yesterday, the Blue Jays added $100,000 to the total package and agreed to give Morris a chunk of the first-year salary as part of a larger signing bonus. The adjustments were made to cover the higher taxes Canada extracts from players' salaries. The Blue Jays also agreed to pay large chunks of the salaries on April 1 each year, $750,000 the first year and $1 million the second.
Morris will move into a starting rotation with Jimmy Key and Dave Stieb, if they are healthy, plus Todd Stottlemyre and Juan Guzman.
When Viola completes his agreement with the Red Sox, which was expected to be no later than today, he will join Clemens in the Boston rotation. The Red Sox were desperate to find an established starter who could fit in behind Clemens, generally considered the best pitcher in the majors.
Viola could have accepted the Mets' offer of salary arbitration before tonight's midnight deadline and become a free agent again next year, but the Red Sox have given him good reason not to take that step.
 
INSIDE PITCH
 MITCH WILLIAMS, a free-agent relief pitcher, re-signed with the Philadelphia Phillies for three years and $9.2 million. A year ago that deal would have been impressive. Now it's almost routine.

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 553 words

HEADLINE: The Economy: Go Fast, and Slow

 BODY:
The economy suffers from two ailments. For 20 years incomes have stagnated, leaving the middle class little better off than it was in the 1970's. Apart from that stagnation, the economy started sliding into recession in 1990, a slide that has now accelerated -- as witness the deep cuts announced yesterday by General Motors.
The remedy for the first problem is less consumption and more investment. The remedy for the second is more consumption. By confusing the two ailments, Congress is tying itself in knots. 
 The first need is to separate the problems and, for now, deal only with the recession. And the best way to do that is for Congress, immediately on its return in January, to pass a quick-hitting combination of temporary tax cuts and spending increases. The key word is temporary.
To reverse stagnation, Congress will need to write a savings-oriented tax code. But that intricate task can't be done quickly, especially not in an election year. It would be best left to an expert commission that reports back after the election.
Robert Solow of M.I.T. and Francis Bator of Harvard offer an ideal plan to fight recession. They propose a one-year, $80 billion cut in Federal income and payroll taxes. At the same time they would increase for one year all Federal grants to state and local governments by 10 percent. The idea is to raise spending immediately, focusing on mothballed projects that could be rapidly reopened.
The fiscal stimulus would be almost five times larger than that proposed by House Democratic leaders and three times the rebate of $300 per taxpayer that is under review in the White House. That would be big enough to matter but not to destabilize the economy if recovery begins soon.
The most important feature of the Solow-Bator plan is summed up in the word temporary. Because the tax cut and spending increases would expire in a year, they wouldn't raise the long-term deficit and thus would not jeopardize long-term savings.
What about proposals to subsidize business investment and personal savings? They wouldn't shorten the recession and would not, in many cases, even make sense within existing tax law.
For example, several economists call for stimulating investment by allowing businesses immediately to deduct the entire cost of long-lived investments, a practice known as expensing. But as Prof. Robert Hall of Stanford shrewdly observes, expensing makes little sense with tax laws that also permit tax-free contributions to pension funds.
With expensing, businesses would be able to borrow at tax-subsidized rates from pension funds and then use the money for tax-subsidized investments. That would amount to a double subsidy, inviting wasteful investment.
The tax code cannot be fixed hastily. Revision has to include a comprehensive plan for promoting saving, but without penalizing the poor who ordinarily save little. That job could be left to a bipartisan commission, with a post-election deadline that offers insulation from special pleading and election-year politics.
Without such insulation, Congress would be tempted to act rashly. That's why the Solow-Bator plan makes good political as well as economic sense. Come January, Congress can act boldly to give the slumping economy a temporary jolt. The key word is temporary.

HEADLINE: Russia Deserves The Soviet Seat

BYLINE: By Richard N. Gardner and Toby Trister Gati; Richard N. Gardner, former U.S. Ambassador to Italy, is professor of international law at Columbia. Toby Trister Gati is senior vice president of the United Nations Association.

 BODY:
The new commonwealth and the independent republics that will replace the Soviet Union are confronting the international community with potentially explosive legal and political conundrums. Some may be resolved when the republics meet in Kazakhstan on Saturday to address commonwealth issues. 
 Who will take over the Soviet seat in the U.N. General Assembly and Security Council, inheriting the veto? Will Russia take the Council seat, as President Boris Yeltsin wants? Will all the republics join the U.N., in addition to Byelorussia and Ukraine, which are members? Who should be admitted to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank?
Commonwealth members do not agree on who should take the Council seat. Ukraine would support Russia's taking it over. President Nursultan Nazarbayev made it clear to Secretary of State James Baker this week that Kazakhstan and the other Central Asian republics will not automatically cede the seat to Russia.
If the Commonwealth of Independent States wanted to occupy the Soviet Union's Council and General Assembly seats while the republics were also Assembly members, this would be bad politics and bad international law: bad law because the Charter permits only "states" -- countries -- to be members.
To qualify as a state, an entity must have a government capable of exercising executive and legislative authority over a population, and the capacity to carry out an independent foreign policy. Without such powers, an entity could not carry out U.N. decisions. A loose commonwealth whose only purpose is to coordinate the domestic and foreign policies of independent republics would qualify as an international organization, but would not be a state.
Seating a loose commonwealth in the Council with a right of veto would put at risk the excellent cooperation that the five permanent members established during and after the Persian Gulf crisis. The Islamic republics would likely use their influence to block the commonwealth from supporting military action against another Middle East aggressor like Saddam Hussein.
The best legal and political solution would be to give Russia the Soviet seat and admit the other nine republics as new members. Giving the Council seat to a Russia whose leaders are Western-oriented, dedicated to democracy and human rights and committed to developing a market economy would be the best assurance that Moscow's exceptional cooperation in recent years would continue. (Surely a condition should be that Russia would take over a suitable portion of the Soviet Union's financial contributions -- with the other republics picking up the rest -- and pay up the Soviet Union's arrears.)
It would also avoid a constitutional crisis that could paralyze the U.N. if the Council seat were left vacant or if other members pressed for other changes in the Council.
Washington should support early membership in the I.M.F. and World Bank for Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan in place of the Soviet Union's associate status. These republics have the best chance of developing market economies that can be integrated into the world economy. Membership would make them eligible to get financial aid and have their politically difficult transitions to market economies reinforced by internationally monitored programs.
Early U.N. membership for the republics would also serve global interests. Except for Russia, the republics are governed by leaders with little experience in international relations and an uncertain commitment to established international norms. Membership in the U.N. could school them for world citizenship.
It makes sense for Russia to assume the Soviet Union's rights and obligations at the U.N., since Russia exercises authority over 150 million people and controls some 75 percent of the land mass and valuable resources of the Soviet Union. And that goes out of business New Year's Eve. Unless the commonwealth resolves the problem satisfactorily by then, on Jan. 1 the Soviet Union will exist only at the U.N.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
After The Storm

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER; William Safire is on vacation.

 BODY:
Can anyone recall a disappearance more precipitous than that of the national celebration of Desert Storm, last winter's great victory in the Persian Gulf -- the war whose fighting men and women, unlike those of Vietnam, were to be honored and remembered?
The honors, like yellow ribbons, quickly came and went. The remembrance of the war, as evidenced by polls and public statements, has been equally short-lived, and soured by the survival of Saddam Hussein in Iraq. 
 President Bush's popularity, meanwhile, has gone south just as swiftly. The astronomical approval ratings he registered during and after the war -- around 90 percent in some cases -- have slipped to as low as 47 percent in a recent ABC News/Washington Post Poll. He's back to roughly the level of approval he had in 1989, in the midst of that year's "budget crisis," before the war made him look briefly Churchillian.
The best evidence of Mr. Bush's decline in public esteem may be his plaintive remarks the other day about the "filth and indecent material coming in through the airwaves and through these trials into people's homes." The obvious reference to the Palm Beach rape case might have been taken as merely a political slap at the Kennedy family, had the President not also criticized New York City's program to counter AIDS with free condoms for young people and clean needles for drug addicts.
AIDS, Mr. Bush chirped, "is a disease that for the most part can be controlled by individual behavior."
That's the Bushspeak equivalent of Nancy Reagan's "just say no" campaign, which didn't work either. Mr. Bush seemed to be turning to a tried-and-true, if threadbare, political remedy -- attacking a straw man, in this case indecency, to deflect attention from his lack of a coherent economic program and from foreign policies that look less effective every day.
Social concerns -- flag-burning, the Pledge of Allegiance, "family values," the fear of crime -- have been highly effective for him and for other Republicans in the past; remember the Mapplethorpe flap? Maybe this time preaching against "smut and filth" can do the trick for Mr. Bush.
Or maybe not. The economy is in bad shape and Republicans, as well as too many Democrats, have locked themselves into the nearly theological position that nothing can be done if it increases the budget deficit -- though the likelihood is that nothing effective can be done if it doesn't increase the budget deficit. More than at any time in the past quarter-century, the so-called "pocketbook issue" may be helping the Democrats -- assuming they find a presentable candidate for President.
But the economy alone is not responsible for Mr. Bush's tumble from grace. His response to political and economic chaos in the former Soviet Union may be properly restrained, but to much of the public it looks like indecisive hand-wringing about one of the signal developments of the 20th century. Nor does the Administration appear to know how to be helpful on the economic and other problems of Eastern Europe -- for instance, street crime, the redheaded stepchild of capitalism. It's up fivefold in Prague since Communism's collapse.
Japan and Western Europe go their ways, Washington notwithstanding. The nasty war in Yugoslavia is a bad advertisement for the "new world order" Mr. Bush proclaimed last winter; but there's little he can do about it, since the use of U.S. military power there would be unpopular among Americans. In all these cases, in fact, the power at Mr. Bush's disposal is mostly military; but in none would that power be appropriate or feasible.
Force might be both in Iraq, where Saddam Hussein's nuclear designs seem clear and his brutal control appears unaffected by what the world thought was catastrophic defeat. But it would be an admission of an early and mistaken end to the war, hence a smudge on his most acclaimed achievement, were Mr. Bush to order troops back to the gulf to finish the job. Nor is it clear that this time he'd have worldwide support.
Both at home and abroad, therefore, challenge and change are demanding more of George Bush -- vision, bold leadership, intuitive understanding -- than he seems able to give. Nearly a year after Desert Storm, his moment of glory seems far in the past, and irrelevant to a future in which standing tall will rarely be sufficient.

HEADLINE: In Nicaragua, Free Enterprise Never Left

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Nicaraguans, your headline states, "Are Back in Business" ("Managua Journal," Nov. 22). You see vendors on street corners peddling their wares to passing cars as an indication that the people are "rebuilding a market economy." Those of us who have known Nicaragua over the last decade see no surprise in this miniature example of private business in Managua or other parts of the country. It is an old characteristic of the peoples of poor countries, like paperboys, push-cart vendors and kids selling in buses or from door to door goodies made in mom's kitchen. 
 The streets of Managua have always been lined with stalls selling soft drinks, food or trinkets and kiosks for books or newspapers. Many turn their front windowsills into mini-minimarkets for the sale of candy or cookies. In smaller towns and cities there are no stores, and people do their shopping in the homes of neighbors. Signs are posted saying "Meat today" or "Nacatamales," but most people just know where to buy their eggs, bread, newspapers or clothing.
This kind of "free market" is not new in Nicaragua. Nor does it mean the country is "back in business." There has always been business, large and small, in the country. The Sandinistas still boast of a "mixed economy" that sponsored three types of economic structures: private agricultural and industrial enterprises; private cooperatives, and state properties established where the Somoza dictators had built their fortunes.
The Sandinistas recognized that the poor majority of the people can develop farms or industries on their own if given the chance. Unfortunately these plans were misinterpreted in some parts of the industrialized world, and the United States economic embargo and support for the contras eventually made it impossible for these plans to reach development.
Now is the time for the completion of these designs for a mixed economy and also for the political pluralism called for by the Sandinistas. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose husband was murdered by the Somoza dictatorship, seems to understand the value of the private cooperatives developed by the Sandinistas to help the vast majority raise themselves out of dire poverty.
There are lessons to be learned from the Nicaraguan experience as newly liberated lands try to build their future.
 
LOUISA D. KIRCHNER
Stamford, Conn., Dec. 1, 1991
 
The writer is a consultant, Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies, U. of Connecticut.

HEADLINE: We Need Both Big Science and Little Science;
Slide Rule Pork Barrel

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Gregg Easterbrook's "Big Science on Easy Street" (Op-Ed, Nov. 29) is exactly on target, but his argument can be extended. 
 Federal big-science spending has been guided by a politics of display, a taste for the heroic media event, since the space race of the 1960's. Teeing off on the moon provided the United States and several administrations with propaganda mileage that has yet to be rediscovered. It was a mask to cover urban riots and a divisive war. Despite the ostensible technical virtuosity of a space station or supercollider, these projects make few compelling photo opportunities, so the Government won't even achieve its unstated goals with them.
One suspects sectional politics in all of this. Just as the massive military budgets of the last half-century and the savings and loan institution and bank bailouts of recent years have transferred billions of dollars from the North to the Sunbelt, so, too, do most big-science projects. The supercollider is more pork for Texas, just as the space station is welfare for Sunbelt military contractors facing the end of cold war spending.
Big science projects only thinly conceal that the United States has no coherent direction in its science programs. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has managed to maintain funding momentum, though it has lacked any clear program goals since 1969 beyond low-grade shuttle stunts and highly cost-effective unmanned probes. Physicists get their supercollider largely because of the cultural momentum developed in the public mind by Einstein's generation of scientists.
Such funds could be better spent. Small science, particularly through the National Science Foundation, has generated a much higher rate of economic benefits for the public funds invested in it.
Also, the Government was willing to build a new National Archives facility, yet refuses it the few millions necessary to turn it into the service provider the nation desperately needs. As public and private universities face deep cutbacks, more and more students are denied financial access and the quality of higher education is in ever-greater jeopardy. Meanwhile, the professoriate is but a few years away from massive retirements, and there are neither graduate students to replace them nor funds available to train the students.
The politics of scientific and technological display and the pork barreling associated with it need to be replaced by a coherent plan for the careful programming that will revive American scientific and academic leadership.
 
ROBERT L. FROST
Asst. Prof. of History
State University of New York
Albany, Dec. 3, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 203 words

HEADLINE: Cures May Be Worse Than Economic Ills

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a result of the profligate Reagan years the traditional tools of financial management, monetary and fiscal policy, are no longer available to bring the economy out of recession. Fiscal policy has been rendered unusable by the size of the debt, monetary policy by the near destruction of the banking system and the financial integration of the world economy. 
 The route out of recession in the 1930's was to let the economy deflate, with massive unemployment and bankruptcies, followed by reflation in the 1940's and 50's. Today, such an approach is politically unacceptable.
There seems to be tacit agreement in both political camps that to end the recession the real burden of the debt must be destroyed by inflating the economy. And the politically acceptable way of doing this is through wide-scale "middle class" tax cuts.
It is not clear to me that this cure will not be more disastrous than the disease. The public may be best served by Government inaction, by a policy of "Just stand there." One way or another, the cost of the 1980's must be borne.
 
ROBERT FREEDMAN
Brookline, Mass., Dec. 8, 1991
 
The writer retired as Russell Colgate Professor of Economics, Colgate U.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 3567 words

HEADLINE: Street-Wise Impresario;
Sharpton Calls the Tunes, and Players Take Their Cues

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB with DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
When Richard Earl Luke died in the custody of the housing police on a balmy evening in May 1989, it did not take long for rumors and anger to race through the Queensbridge public housing project where he lived. His mother, Patricia Garcia, recalls that by morning her phone was ringing nonstop. Friends offered condolences. Family members checked in. In one instance, she remembers, she even received a call from someone she had never heard of -- the Rev. Al Sharpton.
Mrs. Garcia remembers that the reverend extended sympathy and offered assistance. Within an hour, she said, he was in her apartment with a handful of aides, reciting a prayer, pledging to cover funeral costs and suggesting the legal services of his brother in arms, Alton H. Maddox Jr. In the next few days, Mr. Sharpton led marches through her neighborhood while tensions roiled.
 
Projecting an Image
 The demonstrations soon died down, and a few months later, Mr. Sharpton moved on after what he describes as a falling-out with Mrs. Garcia, whose family still argues about him. Now, when she watches Mr. Sharpton on television, Mrs. Garcia says, she sometimes muses that he might have simply forsaken her for higher-profile cases. 
 "I often wonder about that," she said. Still, she says, she is a Sharpton supporter, because without him, "my son would have just been another black boy killed by the police."
In a score of cases over a half-decade, from Atlantic Beach, L.I., to Hillside, N.J., this most improbable protest leader has played the same role, often with the same ambiguous results. Through these cases, lacking a congregation, a balanced bank account or even a large corps of followers, he has projected himself as the pre-eminent leader of disaffected blacks in New York City.
And in many respects, he has become what he said he was.
Despite a history of associations with organized crime figures and an affinity for outrageous rhetoric and dubious charges, Mr. Sharpton, more than anyone, has come to dictate the times and terms under which one of the nation's most sensitive social issues -- race -- is dealt with in the New York region and often beyond.
 
A Master of Many Arts
 As impresario of an abrasive floating street theater involving demonstrations of rarely more than a few hundred people, Mr. Sharpton has managed to grab headlines and jangle the public psyche like no one else. But he is more than a master media manipulator and a man who capitalized on a void in black leadership in New York City.
An examination of Mr. Sharpton's rise also shows how his ever-precarious career has fed on alliances of the moment, alliances that raise questions about his motives, judgment and the extent of his following.
Today, his most important and least well-known connection is with the New Alliance Party, a political splinter group that has been accused of operating like a cult, engaging in anti-Semitism and disrupting other liberal and left-wing groups. New Alliance and its affiliates have virtually adopted Mr. Sharpton, providing a fourth of his modest income, legal and public-relations help, and, its leader says, as many as half the people at some of his marches.
Earlier, Mr. Sharpton had become enmeshed with organized-crime figures in the entertainment world. And law-enforcement officials have said he entered into another odd alliance -- with them. Offering fresh details of his role as an informant, they say he provided information that helped in the conviction of the boss of the Genovese crime family in Rockland County and much of Westchester.
 
'He Knows How to Manipulate'
 Much of the reason for his public prominence goes unacknowledged, lost in the infuriated responses to his often incendiary statements, which critics say not only inflame already painful situations but keep different racial and economic groups from finding common goals.
Beyond his sound bites and tabloid television word jousts, the 37-year-old Mr. Sharpton is a powerful, often mesmerizing speaker. One on one, he can be so engaging and witty that even investigators who have probed his finances and mob connections admit an odd fondness toward him. He is a quick study, a factory of oratory who digests and sometimes bends facts in split seconds and converts them into rhetoric. And, in a media-driven age, he has crafted a public image that has sucked up the air around it, along with a few forests worth of newsprint.
"You know who made him a leader?" asked Hazel Dukes, president of the New York State chapter of the N.A.A.C.P. "The media. The rest of us do things, and you just pass it off. He knows how to manipulate you."
Mr. Sharpton puts it differently.
"I created Al Sharpton," he explained recently, his brown processed curls bobbing with the emphasis. "I wore my hair like this. I dressed like this. I talked like this. I weighed this much. That was my persona. The media just covered it."
This persona, Mr. Sharpton says, has allowed him to fulfill the traditional role of the lightning-rod cleric who verbalizes the feelings of disfranchised blacks. He defends New Alliance as an important organization on the left, and says his involvements with organized-crime figures were unwitting ones, regrettable episodes in a life he has engineered so that the chapter titles are written in headline type.
 
The Persona
A Rise to Fame On a Shoestring
 For many prominent blacks in New York, such as Mayor David N. Dinkins and Ms. Dukes, Mr. Sharpton's rise has been baffling. The organizations they have been associated with have dues-paying memberships in the hundreds and thousands and often maintain large-scale social service operations.
Mr. Sharpton's nonprofit organization, the National Action Network, had $16.43 in its account at the Amalgamated Bank of New York at the end of September, according to documents he supplied. After bouncing five checks in a month, Mr. Sharpton's private promotional company, Raw Talent, had a negative balance of $189.75. After being acquitted at a state charity fraud trial, he is still under indictment for not filing state tax statements for several years.
Mr. Sharpton's staff is composed of three people: Jennifer Joseph, whom he met at the payola trial of the disk jockey Frankie Crocker more than a decade ago; Carl Redding, a 27-year-old linebacker-size Man Friday, and Anthony Charles, who volunteers for Mr. Sharpton after work at the Postal Service Express Mail depot in Brooklyn. None of his staff people earns more than $300 a week, he says.
His base of followers is modest. The turnout at a recent weekly meeting of what he calls his "nut group," meaning his core group, for example, reached 84 at its height. Yet it was at this meeting, broadcast over WWRL-AM from a three-quarters empty public school auditorium in Harlem, that many of Mr. Sharpton's strengths became apparent.
The audience was made up of black New Yorkers young and old, middle class and struggling. It included women like Bertha C. Richardson, who turned to Mr. Sharpton after her sister Mary Mitchell was killed by the police during a domestic dispute last year; younger men like Stevie D., a rap singer who lives a privately run shelter and considers Mr. Sharpton "the most courageous brother of our times," and Lenora Fulani, the perennial Presidential and gubernatorial candidate of the New Alliance Party.
 
Speaking in Black and White
 Mr. Sharpton slowly entered from the rear as an aide, Roslyn Bacon, in a slow, silken voice, implored the audience to "welcome our cleric, our corpulent cleric, the one and only Rev. Alfred C. Sharpton!"
As usual before a speech, a wary impassiveness deadened his features. But as he bellowed his trademark chant -- "No Justice, No Peace!" -- he seemed to wake up. Then in rocking cadence and raspy voice, he unleashed his populist news commentary.
He referred to Mayor Dinkins as "weak-kneed," to 82-year-old Dr. James Dumpson, an elder statesman to many black New Yorkers and the head of the city's besieged hospital system, as "old, senile James Dumpson," to the choice of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, whom he supported for re-election in 1986, and his possible Democratic opponents as one among "some recycled white trash."
Why was Dr. Leonard Jeffries threatened with the loss of his job at City College while former Mayor Edward I. Koch could get away with referring to Ronald V. Dellums, the black congressman from California, as a "Zulu warrior"? Why had Mr. Sharpton himself been charged with fraud in a 67-count indictment while the Rev. Bruce Ritter was left unprosecuted after allegations of sexual and financial improprieties?
Mr. Sharpton's parallels may be debatable, but for him, the answers were black and white. "I consider this double-standard something I will fight all of my life," he concluded.
If 84 people can create thunderous applause, they did so that day.
 
The Informant
Surrogate Father And Family Ties
 Mr. Sharpton was preaching from Brooklyn pulpits at age 4, and at 10 was ordained by the Rev. F. D. Washington, a Pentecostal minister with prodigious political connections.
That same year, Mr. Sharpton says, his father, Alfred Sr., who ran a construction company and owned 15 rental properties, deserted the family, which was forced to move from its two-family home in Hollis, Queens, to an apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. His mother, a seamstress, went on welfare.
Mr. Sharpton remains angry at his father, who he says contacted him for the first time in nearly 25 years after he was stabbed in an assassination attempt this year. He says friends had to talk him into taking the call. In the absence of his own father, he began a search for surrogates that led him, at 13, to the soul-singing legend James Brown, who took him under his wing and brought him into the music world.
It was there, while developing political and civil-rights connections elsewhere, that Mr. Sharpton met mobsters.
For a time, Mr. Sharpton's base organization, the National Youth Movement, made use of the offices of Spring Records, owned by a close associate of Mr. Brown's, Julie Rifkind. Though Mr. Rifkind denies it, Mr. Sharpton said Mr. Rifkind introduced him to several people who turned out to be organized-crime figures. Among them were Michael Franzese, a former Colombo family capo, and Daniel Pagano, who with his father, Joseph, reportedly ran Genovese family operations in Westchester and Rockland Counties. They figured dramatically in an event that would cloud Mr. Sharpton's reputation.
 
The Disputed Bluff

The outline has been widely reported. In 1983, Mr. Franzese told Mr. Sharpton that an associate, who later turned out to be an undercover F.B.I. agent, wanted to sponsor boxing matches and was looking for an introduction to the promoter Don King. A meeting was held in a high-rent Lincoln Square apartment, where the agent turned the subject from boxing to drug deals.
"He said he had some guys who needed to move some stuff if we knew anybody," Mr. Sharpton recalled. "We told him we didn't know people like that."
Law enforcement officials say Mr. Sharpton did nothing illegal, and that the agent did most of the talking. Nonetheless, they said they later confronted Mr. Sharpton and bluffed him into thinking they had a case. He became an informant, they said, but what he actually provided is murky.
A review of previously undisclosed court documents and interviews with several law enforcement officials indicates that Mr. Sharpton provided information in a successful investigation of Daniel Pagano.
The state had been investigating the Paganos, but it lacked a first-hand source who could confirm suspicions that the family's most sensitive meetings were held in Joseph Pagano's basement. Without such confirmation, a judge would never allow an electronic bug to be planted there.
 
F.B.I.'s 'Confidential Source'
 On Jan. 31, 1986, however, the officials told a judge in Rockland County that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had given them a "confidential source" who said he had been involved in some of the discussions, and who offered a detailed description of the basement. Their source, the officials now say, was Mr. Sharpton.
The bug was approved, and the recordings provided evidence against Joseph Pagano, who died before he could be indicted, and his son, who is serving a prison term of 1 1/3 to 4 years.
Mr. Sharpton denies providing the information. He said he was friendly with Daniel Pagano but did not know he was a mobster. He said that he may have met Joseph Pagano in passing and that he visited one of the Pagano houses but it was Daniel's.
"I never gave anyone a description of either house, no one asked me," he said.
Mr. Sharpton said he did help in drug and organized-crime investigations, but did so voluntarily after being threatened by a mobster in the record industry.
The early stories about Mr. Sharpton and law enforcement all but destroyed his already tenuous relationship with some black radical groups.
Meanwhile, other events isolated Mr. Sharpton from the public and from many civil-rights leaders. Even as he and his closest allies -- Mr. Maddox and C. Vernon Mason -- won supporters for championing the causes of black victims, their credibility was severely damaged by a series of rash, unsupported allegations in several cases, including the killing of Michael Griffith in Howard Beach and the allegations of rape made by Tawana Brawley, an incident Mr. Sharpton says he still believes took place.
During rallies at the Slave Theater in Brooklyn -- inaccessible to many whites -- the oratory grew still hotter and more divisive. Mr. Sharpton derided whites of all ethnicities, repeatedly used the word "faggots," and continually characterized black people who disagreed with him as "cocktail-sip Negroes," "yellow niggers" and "Negro militants" who carried "that German cracker's books under their arms."
That German cracker was Karl Marx.
Mr. Sharpton now says he regrets such language, but his critics say the damage has been done.
Jim Sleeper, an editorial writer at Newsday and author of "The Closest of Strangers," a book about race in New York City, sees Mr. Sharpton as "re-enacting an historically powerful truth" -- the injustice toward blacks by the police and the courts -- even in situations where it does not apply. The result, says Mr. Sleeper, gives voice to a deep-seated pain, but also divides Mr. Sharpton's followers from others.
Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, a veteran of black political wars in the city who is also critical of Mr. Sharpton, says he has only become such a public figure because of the press's attraction to his flamboyance and a gap in black leadership.
"What he's been able to do is fill a void out there in the wrong way, and that's what has to be looked at," Mr. Lynch said. "Our leaders have to be criticized."
 
The Spokesman
Victims' Friend Is Sometimes Foe
 Mr. Sharpton receives no greater testimonials than those of the families who feel he has helped them.
"When the reverend came, things started happening," says Sharon Mayse, whose 16-year-old daughter, Tasha, was killed in Hillside, N.J., in June when the police fired into a stolen church van in which the teen-ager was a passenger. "When I was under so much pressure he came down and gave me money to go away for the weekend. He helped me pay for my phone bill. I talk with him all the time on the phone. It's like he's a telephone call away."
In some instances, such as the 1989 slaying of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst, a distraught family member will reach out to Mr. Sharpton. In others, such as the beating of Alfred Jermaine Ewell in June by white teen-agers in Atlantic Beach, L.I., a neighborhood clergyman friendly with Mr. Sharpton will suggest that a hesitant family see him.
Sometimes, as at the wake of Phillip C. Pannell, the Teaneck, N.J., youth who was fatally shot by a police officer in April 1990, Mr. Sharpton will get the cold shoulder, although in this case he was later welcomed by the family and now advises Phillip's mother.
 
The Inevitable March

 Often he will offer families money for expenses. In the case of Jermaine Ewell's mother, Mr. Sharpton visited the hospital, peeled a $100 bill off a roll of money and gave it to her to help cover expenses, said a family spokesman. In others, he has offered to pay for funerals, Christmas presents and rent.
Once his help is accepted, Mr. Sharpton limits press access to the family, a strategy that he says protects grieving relatives, but one that also turns him into a spokesman. He remembers reporters' names, continues to speak to them when they write critically and promises exclusive interviews that sometimes don't occur.
"Most public relations people wish they were as good as he is," said Dominick Carter, a reporter for WLIB radio. "He knows how to manipulate the press. I mean that as a compliment."
A key part of the Sharpton strategy is the inevitable march. In Bensonhurst, Mr. Sharpton ordered more than 30.
But 30 marches, even if many involved fewer than 100 people, required a standing army that could be called upon week after week. New Alliance gave him this and more.
 
New Alliance Connection
 For more than 20 years, the party's founder, Fred Newman, has attempted to establish the movement as the nation's pre-eminent force in left-wing politics, much to the consternation of other organizations, which have accused it of disruptive, divisive and even conspiratorial tactics. The saga of Mr. Newman and his followers includes a flirtation with the political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and a large psychotherapy practice that critics say is little more than a mass-production line for new party members.
"It creates tremendous peer pressure within the group for obedience to its guru, Fred Newman," said Chip Berlet, a researcher for Political Research Associates, a nonprofit organization in Boston that investigates authoritarian groups.
Mr. Newman dismisses the criticisms as absurd and usually the product of jealousies on the left. He said most therapy clients don't involve themselves in the political party.
Mr. Newman says New Alliance is dedicated to challenging the political system and fighting for the rights of black, Hispanic gay and other minority group members. He said the organization's spinoff groups raise millions of dollars a year through the psychotherapy practice, a lobbying and fund-raising network and street solicitations for numerous political campaigns that attract public matching funds. The party and its members have spawned a law firm, a theater group, a public relations and booking company, a publishing arm, a telemarketing concern and a primary school in Harlem.
 
$20,000 for Speeches
 Mr. Newman said that since last year, when their relationship matured, New Alliance has provided between 30 and 50 percent of the troops at Mr. Sharpton's demonstrations.
It has done even more for his personal finances, much of which Mr. Sharpton says he funnels into his organization. This year, the party's lecture and media booking company, Castillo International, began lining up national speaking engagements for Mr. Sharpton. He has earned roughly $20,000 for at least 20 speeches at universities and churches, many of them booked by Castillo, which keeps 30 percent of the proceeds, but does his public relations without compensation.
Mr. Newman also made Mr. Sharpton a 50-percent partner in his private company that runs a nationwide teen-age talent competition. According to records provided by Mr. Sharpton, he received at least $12,000 this year from the enterprise. Not counting lecture work, Mr. Sharpton's ties to New Alliance and Mr. Newman accounted for about 25 percent of his income, which he estimated to be about $50,000 this year, according to records supplied by his accountant, P. Daniel Faustin.
Mr. Sharpton, who lives with his wife, Cathy Lee Jordan, and two young daughters in a $1,200-a-month garden apartment in Englewood, N.J., and also shares an apartment in Crown Heights with an aide, works out of a small office in a West 57th Street suite filled with New Alliance affiliates, for which he said he pays $600 a month for rent. He uses party-related lawyers without paying a fee.
 
Different Tactics
 Mr. Sharpton says he does not agree with all New Alliance stands for, like its emphasis on third-party politics, but was attracted by admiration for Ms. Fulani. He says he views his relationship with the group as an opportunity to broaden his base.
Thanks to Ms. Fulani, he said, he is working to tone down his language, particularly the word "faggot," which he said he uses to refer not to homosexuals but to "people without backbones." Although he has been accused of courting anti-Semitic sentiments during racial disturbances this summer in Crown Heights, he argued that he acted as a moderator, meeting with Mayor Dinkins when others in the streets were opposed and telling youths that they could not shout statements like "Heil Hitler!" at demonstrations.
But has he really changed?
In reflecting on some of his past comments, he said, "I think a lot of that rhetoric was things I had to grow out of." Then he paused and added, "In a lot of ways, I have a lot of the same sentiments, but I would express them in a different way."

HEADLINE: Federal Auditors Report Rise In Abuses in Medical Billing

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
At a time when Medicare and private health insurers are struggling to control medical bills, many doctors and hospitals are increasing their income by improperly manipulating the numerical codes used to describe their services on insurance claims and billing forms, Federal investigators say.
Federal auditors say the techniques are often illegal and clearly violate the intent of Federal rules for the payment of doctors' services under Medicare. 
 The Government has collected millions of dollars in civil penalties and restitution from doctors and hospitals, including a $1.5 million recovery announced just today in Pennsylvania.
The Government and private insurers say that doctors' creative billing techniques now add at least several billion dollars a year to the nation's health-care costs.
Alarmed at what they say is a growing pattern of abuse, Federal officials and private insurers have stepped up enforcement efforts, using computers to audit claims in an effort to crack down on doctors and hospitals submitting fraudulent and inflated bills.
Questionable bills, officials say, have most commonly been submitted by surgeons and other specialists who perform diagnostic and other procedures. These specialists, who tend to be the most highly paid members of the medical profession, face cuts in payments for their services under a new Medicare fee schedule that will take effect next month.
 
Fragmentation of a Bill
 With the help of a small army of consultants, doctors and their billing clerks have become adept at selecting codes that increase reimbursement. In one of the more common abuses, clearly forbidden by Federal rules, a doctor bills separately for two or more services that are performed on the same patient at the same time and that are supposed to be reported as a single comprehensive procedure.
For example, instead of a single fee for a total hysterectomy, the doctor might bill separately for four or five procedures. And auditors have found that some doctors charge twice for one of those procedures, removing the fallopian tubes and ovaries -- once on the left side and once on the right side. Fragmentation of a bill in this manner is clearly forbidden and can add $1,000 or $2,000 to the cost of a $3,300 hysterectomy, doctors and insurers say.
Hospitals, struggling to squeeze money out of insured patients to help finance care for the uninsured, have also begun to bill separately for many services once regarded as a single package, especially in the emergency room. The Government has accused many hospitals of filing inaccurate claims for lab tests and X-rays.
To challenge such practices, auditors must penetrate the arcane world of medical coding and billing, and also have deep expertise in medical procedures and terminology. Experts on reimbursement say that amid the vast flow of medical paperwork, it is often difficult to spot abusive billing practices, so most go undetected.
While insurance companies have always worried about the manipulation of billing codes, the Government has only recently begun to combat the problem, amid fresh evidence that more doctors and hospitals are improperly using such techniques to offset cuts in reimbursement under Medicare, Medicaid and private health plans.
A recent Federal investigation in Pennsylvania found improper "unbundling" of medical procedures and similar problems in bills submitted by 20 percent of the 8,000 doctors who filed Medicare claims for surgery. Based on that study, Richard P. Kusserow, inspector general at the Department of Health and Human Services, concluded that "a relatively high percentage of physicians" were improperly manipulating procedure codes for personal profit. He and his staff are now investigating similar practices in 14 other states, including California, Florida, Illinois, Michigan, New York and Ohio.
Thomas R. Owens, president of GMIS, a small company in Malvern, Pa., that audits claims for private insurers and helped conduct the Pennsylvania Medicare study for the Federal Government, said illegitimate practices like fragmentation of bills were adding $5 billion to $6 billion a year to the nation's health-care bill, which came to $666 billion in 1990.
 
A Problem Linked To Economic Law
 Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, agreed that billing manipulation was a growing problem, but said he did not know how much was legal or illegal.
"The manipulation of procedure codes is purely and simply a method to get adequate reimbursement for what physicians do," he said, adding that it is a law of economics that when reimbursement goes down, such manipulation will increase.
For every service, from a simple office visit to a heart transplant, there is a standard five-digit code, set by the A.M.A. or the Federal Government. The codes listed on an insurance claim affect the amount of money that doctors get from Medicare, Medicaid, Blue Cross and Blue Shield and commercial health insurers.
While the Medicare law does not prescribe a specific method of coding, Federal investigators and Government lawyers say that doctors who bill separately for services provided as a package violate the law because they knew or should have known that Medicare does not allow the practice.
Under Federal law, anyone who submits a false claim under Medicare or Medicaid is subject to a civil penalty of $10,000, plus three times the amount of any damages sustained. The maximum criminal penalty is five years in prison and a fine of $250,000.
 
A Redistribution Of Doctors' Incomes
 The intensifying scrutiny of doctors' billing practices comes after a bitter battle between the Government and the American Medical Association over the new Medicare fee schedule for doctors. A major purpose of the fee schedule is to shift income from specialists like surgeons, radiologists and others who perform highly paid procedures to family doctors and general practitioners who provide basic health care. The unbundling of charges has been observed most often in claims filed by specialists who tended to be the harshest critics of the fee schedule.
Most of the doctors with annual incomes of more than $250,000 are surgeons. Data collected by the medical association show that median income rose 11 percent last year for surgeons, to $200,000, and only 3 percent for family doctors and general practitioners, to $93,000.
The Government estimates that Americans are spending $148 billion on doctors' services this year, including $34 billion through Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled people, and nearly $8 billion through Medicaid, the health-care program for low-income people.
Dr. P. William Curreri, a surgeon in Mobile, Ala., said insurance companies had shown him "terrible examples" of doctors' improperly unbundling procedures to obtain additional payment. But he said there were "large gray areas" in the rules, so the distinction between fraud, innocent error and shrewd business practice was sometimes unclear.
Dr. Curreri is a member of the Physician Payment Review Commission, created by Congress in 1986 to advise lawmakers on payment of doctors under Medicare.
Mr. Kusserow, the inspector general, said the Government's current screening techniques could detect "only 1 percent of the potential overpayments" that occur because of unbundling. In Pennsylvania, he estimated, "this 'gaming' of codes has resulted in potential overpayments to physicians of $12.2 million in Medicare funds and nearly $700,000 in Medicaid funds annually."
Dr. Robert N. Moyers, president of the Pennsylvania Medical Society, expressed outrage at Mr. Kusserow's report, saying it contains "totally unsubstantiated and invalid allegations."
 
On Consultants And Their Roles
 William S. Tate, a spokesman for Medicode Inc., a Salt Lake City company that advises doctors and insurers on reimbursement, said: "There are a number of consultants running around the country teaching physicians how to game the system, how to jack up their reimbursement through abusive practices. But there are also responsible companies like our own, which show doctors how they can legally obtain more complete and accurate payment for their services."
Some consultants also say doctors sometimes get less money than they are entitled to because they leave the preparation of insurance claims to billing clerks who are inadequately trained.
"Additional reimbursement is warranted in about half the claims we examine closely," said J. Eric Sandhusen, president of Review Associates, a Medicare reimbursement consulting firm in Chicago.
Mr. Sandhusen said his firm works "on a straight commission basis," charging 25 percent of any additional amount that Medicare approves. In its brochure the firm promises to "get maximum payment from Medicare," and it tells doctors, "If we can't get you more money from Medicare, our fee is nothing."
C. Nancy Noonan, vice president of Berman & Associates, a consulting concern in Dayton, Ohio, that advises doctors on reimbursement, said, "There is truly, as in all professions, a small percentage of physicians who are bent on deceiving the system."
But she contended that "less than 5 percent" were intentionally fraudulent, and added: "Many more doctors are accidentally fraudulent. They do not know how to bill for their services. They do not know how to use procedural codes to their advantage, and they pay only $4 to $5 an hour for their billing clerks."

HEADLINE: Job Losses in New York Region Erode 80's Growth

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Job losses have been so severe over the last two years in Manhattan that they have completely erased all the private-sector growth of the booming 1980's, according to an annual year-end review by the region's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
There are now fewer private-sector jobs in Manhattan than there were in 1980, with the total back to its 1979 level, according to the figures released by Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the bureau. 
 Regionally, the picture is not much prettier. Since employment peaked in early 1989, the loss of 460,000 jobs in the five boroughs and 18 suburban counties in New York and northeastern New Jersey have erased 40 percent of the employment growth that took place in the 1980's. And in some places -- in Brooklyn and in Essex, Union and Passaic Counties in New Jersey -- those losses exceeded the 80's gains.
The region's experience has been far more serious than that of the rest of the country. The 3.6 percent decline in jobs for the 12 months ending in October stands in sharp contrast to the eight-tenths of 1 percent decline nationwide.
"This is the most severe downturn the region has experienced since World War II," said Mr. Ehrenhalt, a longtime observer of the economic scene. "It's clearly not your ordinary, run-of-the-mill recession."
 
Calls for Action
 Employment, particularly, is a closely watched indicator, because for every job that is lost, a second is believed to be wiped out by the spinoff effects of fewer people spending their wages in restaurants and stores in the region.
Mr. Ehrenhalt's gloomy assessment came on a day when an estimated 50,000-plus construction workers marched on City Hall, demanding that the Federal, state and local governments initiate public works projects to help revitalize the dead-in-the-water economy. And it led to renewed calls from political, labor and business leaders for more government investment, though few of those interviewed could agree on the appropriate remedy.
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, called some of Mr. Ehrenhalt's findings "shocking," but insisted there were some bright spots on the horizon that should also be noted. Wall Street has recovered its profitability and is hiring again, she said. Investors have spent large sums renovating everything from Madison Square Garden to the St. Regis Hotel, and new retailers are taking advantage of cheap rents to establish new beachheads in the city.
"The situation is not universally dismal," she concluded.
Despite his disheartening statistics, even Mr. Ehrenhalt agreed that all is not lost for the city. He noted that the pace of job losses slowed slightly in the second half of the year. And unlike other regions of the country, he said, payroll earnings in the Northeast grew at a slightly faster rate than last year.
He also argued that the layoffs that are now devastating many families represent the necessary reorganizing of industries that will soon return to the forefront of the international economy. "I wouldn't write off New York's ability to come back," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Still, there was little else about his year-end review to cheer about. Unlike the economic crunch of the mid-70's, when job losses were heavily concentrated in manufacturing, job losses in this recession have struck all sectors of the economy. Local jobs in government, which increased by an average of 13,400 from 1982 to 1987, declined by 6,000 in the first 10 months of this year.
And even the services industries, which have been among the few to continue to expand, lost jobs this year for the first time in the 16 years that the bureau began collecting comparable data on them. And the only category that has been showing any increase -- health and social services -- is now growing at a much slower pace than previously.
The downturn in Manhattan is particularly serious, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, because it has 28 percent of all the jobs in the New York-northeastern New Jersey region. And those jobs are much higher-paying, generating 37 percent of the region's payroll earnings.
Given Manhattan's prime role as an engine for the regional economy, it is not surprising that the suburbs have suffered so badly in this recession. When the last downturn hit in 1981, Long Island and the New York City suburbs continued to grow despite the city's setbacks.
But this time around, Long Island is having its worst job losses in four decades, thanks in large part to layoffs in the defense industry. Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange Counties have also suffered losses over the last two years, compared with the slight growth in employment they managed to eke out from the fall of 1981 to early 1983. And northern New Jersey has been particularly hard hit in this recession, with almost half the region's losses in manufacturing taking place in that area.
In Connecticut, jobs are down 8.7 percent in Fairfield County, 8.6 percent in New Haven County and 5.7 percent in Litchfield County.
The severity of the region's downturn, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, is not captured by the unemployment rate, which, at 6.9 percent is still lower than during any of the last three economic slumps. He explained this seeming inconsistency by noting that the labor force is shrinking because of long-term demographic changes.
Fewer women and young people are entering the work force, in addition to the many people who have simply given up looking for jobs. In the last year the regional work force has declined by about 100,000. Some of that shrinkage may reflect those people simply leaving the region, a trend that the bureau of labor statistics does not keep track of. But a recent New York Times Poll found that 50 percent of city residents who were interviewed indicated that they were making plans to leave the area eventually.
