HEADLINE: U.S. Urges Focus on Hard-Core Drug Users

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
With cocaine and heroin use rising again, Federal officials said today that more effort in the drug war must be focused on such hard-core users as high school dropouts and the unemployed.
But they said they did not foresee a major shift by the Bush Administration from its current policy of spending 70 percent of its anti-drug budget on law enforcement. 
 "When we have asked for money from Congress for more treatment we have not gotten it," Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in at a news conference with other officials at his headquarters.
He referred to a request for $150 million in treatment and education for the inner cities, an extremely small addition to the $11.6 billion anti-drug budget the Administration requested and Congress endorsed this year.
The increases in the use of cocaine and heroin shown in a national survey and a compilation of hospital reports that were made public today and Wednesday represented the first setback in several years of declining drug use. But Administration officials said that even with these increases, drug use in America was still lower now than in 1989. The biggest gains, the new reports show, have been in the middle class.
"As drug use goes down," said Bob Martinez, director of National Drug Control Policy, "it becomes harder to make progress because what is left are those who are most resistent to anti-drug messages."
The Administration takes credit for the middle-class improvement, but many drug experts say that much of the decline has resulted from people seeing first hand what damage drugs can do and from a national trend toward healthier living.
Administration officials said people without jobs were among the heaviest drug users. But they insisted that the ailing economy should not be blamed for increasing casualties in the war against drugs.
"I don't believe that unemployment causes drug use," said Bruce M. Carnes, an aide to Mr. Martinez. "I do think that people who use drugs can't keep their jobs."
The officials said indications that drug use among teen-agers was continuing to decline, though at a slower pace than previously, reassured them that the anti-drug message was getting across. But the surveys also suggested that something was going wrong with anti-drug education because the percentage of people who think taking drugs is risky or harmful has been falling. Three years ago, 84.9 percent of the population thought taking drugs was dangerous. This year the percentage had dropped to 80.6.
Mr. Martinez, the chief White House official in the effort to curb drug abuse, said the survey and the hospital reports indicated that the drug problem was increasingly centered in the inner cities and among minorities. He called this "the hard-core front," but said the hard core also included many Americans who are now 35 years of age or over and who have been using drugs for years.
 
Statistics on Cocaine Use
 According to the survey by the National Institute on Drug Abuse, which critics say tends to understate the extent of the drug problem, 1.9 million Americans acknowledged using cocaine this year, compared with 1.6 million last year and 2.9 million in 1988. Cocaine use grew in the over-35 group but remained about the same for the younger group, with the exception of teen-agers and young adults, among whom drug use declined slightly.
The reports from the hospitals, which are recorded quarterly, showed a sharp increase in the number of people seeking help in emergency rooms for reactions to cocaine in the first and second quarters of this year, after holding steady for the previous three quarters. The number seeking help after taking heroin also increased in the first half of this year after declining in the last three months of 1990.
"Students have heard and responded to our message to stop using drugs," Dr. Sullivan said, "but the tougher job of reaching dropouts, the unemployed and other special populations remains."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
B.C.C.I. has agreed to plead guilty to Federal and state criminal charges and will forfeit $550 million in the largest single criminal forfeiture ever obtained by the Government. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Leader of North Korea Denies Atom Arms Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PYONGYANG, North Korea, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Despite Western reports that his nation is only a year away from making an atomic bomb, the North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung, denied anew today that the country intended to make nuclear weapons and proposed conditions for allowing inspection of North Korea's nuclear research center.
In a conversation with a visiting American Congressman, Mr. Kim was reported to have said: 
 "We understand very well that we don't have nuclear weapons. And we are not intending to produce nuclear weapons. We have no capacity to produce nuclear weapons, nor do we have money for that purpose.
"And if we produce some nuclear weapons, they would be useless as far as we are concerned."
Mr. Kim's remarks were relayed by Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on East Asian and Pacific Affairs. He had met with Mr. Kim and other North Korean officials to discuss the nuclear issues, which have become a topic of increasing concern in recent months with Western intelligence reports that the Pyongyang Government is as little as a year away from building an atomic bomb.
 
Solarz Not Reassured
 Mr. Solarz said he was far from assured by Mr. Kim's denials, given what he called "incontrovertible" Western intelligence about North Korea's activities.
In the talks, the North Korean side offered to sign an agreement allowing inspection of its nuclear installations once it gets firm assurances that American nuclear weapons are being withdrawn from South Korea, Mr. Solarz said.
The Pyongyang leaders were reported to have insisted that the North Korean inspections occur simultaneously with inspections of South Korean military bases where American nuclear weapons had been kept. The South Korean President, Roh Tae Woo, announced this week that his country was now nuclear-free, meaning that all American atomic weapons had been withdrawn.
North Korea was also said to have demanded that talks over carrying out the inspections in South Korea be discussed primarily with the United States, not the Government in Seoul, which it has long refused to recognize as legitimate.
Both the United States and South Korea are considered likely to reject such a demand.
 
Threats of Attack
 The United States has said North Korea's seeming plans to become a nuclear power constituted the region's biggest threat to stability, and tensions have risen over threats in South Korea of a pre-emptive strike against the North Korean nuclear plant and counter-threats in Pyongyang that this would lead to war.
A breakthrough seemed to occur last week when North and South Korea signed a treaty of reconciliation and non-aggression, saying they would halt their mutual vilification and try to establish economic ties, communication lines and other links.
But the treaty did not address the nuclear issue, and most experts say that unless progress is made on that, the two sides are unlikely to carry out their other pledges in a significant way. Mr. Solarz's visit to the North Korean capital, which is normally barred to Americans, marked the first time an American official had held formal discussions with North Korea since the furor over the nuclear program arose in recent months.
It was also the first time anyone from the West had discussed the nuclear matter with Mr. Kim.
 
Inspections Had Been Promised
 Until now, the nuclear issue had been raised by Japan and South Korea, which have tried to persuade Pyongyang to fulfill an earlier pledge to sign an agreement allowing inspections of its nuclear installations by the International Atomic Energy Agency.
That signing was scheduled to occur in Brussels in September, but at the last minute North Korea backed away, saying the United States would first have to remove its nuclear weapons from South Korea.
Subsequently, American officials indicated that such a step would be taken, and President Roh announced on Wednesday that it had been completed.
All along, the North Koreans had maintained that their country was not producing a nuclear bomb. Indeed, Mr. Solarz said Mr. Kim and others repeated the contention here while agreeing to discuss the issue of inspection and verification.
Mr. Solarz said Mr. Kim had spoken vigorously and looked healthy. There had been some reports that he has been ailing.
The Congressman said he was far from assured by North Korean statements, adding that the United States had "incontrovertible" evidence from satellite photographs that North Korea was developing a bomb.

HEADLINE: BUSH ASSERTS TRIP IS SEARCH FOR JOBS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
President Bush sought today to portray an impending trip to Japan and the Pacific as a crusade to boost American exports and the economy, saying he intended during the 12-day tour to "relentlessly pursue our mission to create jobs and restore prosperity."
The remarks, similar to previous statements, were widely seen as a political response to criticism of his handling of the economy. But they took on added significance amid reports that Japanese leaders were dismayed by the White House's depiction of the visit as a campaign to pressure Japan into lowering trade barriers. 
 Shortly after meeting with American executives who will accompany him to Asia, Mr. Bush told journalists he would insist while overseas "that our trading partners provide U.S. companies with the same kind of opportunities that their firms enjoy here."
The Japanese leaders' unhappiness centers on Mr. Bush's decision to bring more than 20 American business executives on the trip, including the chiefs of Detroit's three major automakers, as a symbol of American insistence on freer access to Asian markets. Some Japanese officials were said to believe the executives' presence would generate a backlash among Japanese citizens, who increasingly regard the United States as a declining power whose complaints are rooted in envy of Tokyo's economic might.
 
Acknowledging 'Concern'
 Japan's embassy today acknowledged "a general concern" among officials that the American executives will turn what was a state visit into "a business mission," but did not specifically oppose the plan.
"The basic position is that it is up to the President whom he brings," Hiroshi Hirabayashi, the embassy's deputy chief of mission, said in an interview. Japan hopes that the visit will lead to a better understanding of trade frictions between the two nations, he said.
Those frictions have prompted Congressional anger over the American trade deficit with Japan, which has stayed at nearly $50 billion a year even as deficits with other countries have shrunk. Democrats plan to announce on Friday a measure that would restrict Japanese car imports unless the trade deficit with Japan narrows.
 
Shielding Markets?
 In an interview today, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said any Japanese reluctance over a visit by American executives appeared to reflect Tokyo's desire to shield its domestic markets from competition.
"I don't blame them," he said. "Why would they want to change something that's working so well for them?"
Mr. Mosbacher, who first suggested that the executives accompany the President on the trip, said he hoped the "more thoughtful" critics in Japan would "realize that they have a system that's different -- not a free and open trading system -- and if they want to join the rest of the world, they have to change."
One of the executives who met with Mr. Bush today, the Chrysler Corporation chairman Lee A. Iacocca, expressed a similar view.
"All we're doing is trying to sit down, government-to-government now, and business-to-business, and say, 'There's something basically unfair,' " he said. "We have to discuss what are the fundamental structural issues keeping us from getting a fair shake."
 
History of Trade Battles
 Washington and Tokyo have sparred in diplomatic circles over trade since the late 1970's, when Japan's successes in critical exports like steel, automobiles and electronics began to make a serious dent in the American trade balance. Japan's refusal to lower barriers to imports has touched off several diplomatic tiffs over trade.
But Mr. Bush has now raised the political stakes in the dispute another notch by making American businessmen unofficial envoys to Tokyo, and including some persistent critics of Japan, like Mr. Iacocca.
The tour of Asia, which will begin on Dec. 30 and include trips to Korea, Singapore and Australia as well as Japan, is the first in which American executives have traveled as a group with the President. That many of them are among the titans of American industry underlines the symbolic importance that the White House has placed on their participation.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Fell Slightly In October

BYLINE: By Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Record exports brought a slight drop in the United States' trade deficit in October, the Government said today, a rare bright spot in an otherwise dark economic outlook.
But further reductions in the trade gap remain a White House priority, and President Bush vowed today to press Japan and other trading partners to open their markets to more United States goods. 
 The Commerce Department said the October deficit fell 2.9 percent, to $6.7 billion, from $6.9 billion in September -- nearly guaranteeing that the shortfall between imports and exports for all of this year will drop to the lowest annual level since 1983.
 
Agenda for Bush's Trip
 Mr. Bush said at a news conference that on his Asian trip in a few weeks he would press Japan and other nations to open their markets to more American exports. The trip, from Dec. 30 to Jan. 10, will take him to Japan, Singapore, Australia and South Korea.
He said the United States has long been one of the world's most open markets, "but our friends and allies have benefited greatly from this and must share the responsibility for an open trading system."
The unexpected improvement in the trade deficit for October virtually insures that the 1991 trade deficit will be the smallest in eight years, the Commerce Secretary, Robert A. Mosbacher, said.
 
One Bright Spot
 The trade report was an unusual piece of good news for an economy suffering increasing layoffs and stagnating production. But the improvement owes much to a decrease in imports by Americans who are curbing their spending as they worry about the economy.
The trade deficit, which measures the excess of imports over exports, was less in October than economists expected.
Exports rose by 3.9 percent to a record $36.7 billion as imports increased 2.8 percent to $43.5 billion, the department said.
But Robert McGee, an economist with Tokai Bank in New York, said the rise in imports at the beginning of the fourth quarter was mainly a result of late orders by merchandisers who held off as long as possible on ordering Christmas merchandise.
 
Goods Piling Up
 "A lot of retailers were ordering more on the assumption of an economic rebound, but we now know that a lot of that just piled up in inventories in subsequent months," Mr. McGee said. "In the next few months, imports will taper off quite a bit."
Mr. Mosbacher said it was now virtually certain the 1991 trade deficit would drop below $70 billion and be the lowest since the $52.4 billion of 1983.
But the trade deficit with Japan has been worsening. It rose to $4.6 billion in October from $4.2 billion in September. The October deficit was the biggest monthly gap since February 1989.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

PUTTING THE 80's TO REST, STATISTICALLY
The recession has hit private industry in Manhattan so hard that it has erased all the job growth of the 1980's boom years, the Federal Government announced. Throughout the New York region, the picture is not much prettier. Since employment peaked in early 1989, 40 percent of the 80's job growth has been lost. Underlining the grim news, 50,000 angry construction workers took to the streets, marching across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall, where they protested delays in New York City's rebuilding projects that they said have cost them jobs. A1 and B2.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
KEY RULING ON EVIDENCE
In two notorious cases, one an act of arson in which six firefighters were killed, the other the shooting of police officers by black radicals in the 1970's, the State Court of Appeals broke new legal ground, ruling that a defendant seeking a new trial because the prosecution withheld evidence must demonstrate a reasonable possibility that this failure contributed to the conviction. B3.
 
N.Y.U. MEDICAL CENTER UNDER FIRE
In yet another criticism of the relationship between the city's public hospitals and the private institutions paid to staff them, the State Comptroller cited a variety of instances in which New York University Medical Center failed to comply with the terms of its contract to provide doctors to Bellevue Hospital. B2.
 
BEHOLD, A LIBRARY
At Public School 94 in the north Bronx, English classes are taught in the hallway, the science lab is in an old shower room and the guidance counselor has more than 1,000 students to worry about. But the school did reopen its library this week, nine years after it was closed to make space for a classroom. And that is a major event in a city where most public elementary schools lost their librarians years ago. B3.
 
HEART PACEMAKER FOR KOCH
Former Mayor Koch, who collapsed Wednesday at his health club, had a pacemaker implanted in his heart. B2.
 
The Post gets help in covering its debts. B3.

$500,000 BAIL IN NANNY CASE
A Westchester County judge set bail at $500,000 for a Swiss au pair accused of arson and murder in the death of a 3-month-old baby in her care. Her lawyer said it was unlikely that the defendant's family could raise that amount. B4.
 
TAX REPEAL MOVES AHEAD
The New Jersey Senate approved legislation to repeal Governor Florio's $2.8 billion tax package, which created a voter backlash that cost the Democrats control of the Legislature. B5.
 
NEW INDICTMENT IN JERSEY CITY

HEADLINE: Dow Climbs 6.27 Points in Volatile Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks ended a choppy and volatile session yesterday with blue chips modestly higher and secondary issues lower, as investors expressed wariness over the economy and disappointment at the Federal Reserve's delay in lowering interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.27 points to finish at 2,914.36.
Some traders said the erratic trading resulted from buying and selling ahead of today's "triple witching hour," when options on individual stocks, indexes and futures contracts expire. 
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 199.3 million shares, up from 194.5 million on Wednesday. The Big Board composite declined 0.53, to 210.91, as losers outpaced gaining issues by 1,026 to 693.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 0.96, to 382.52, while the American Stock Exchange composite fell 2.12, to 366.60. Trading on the Nasdaq was active as the composite fell 5.31, or nearly a full percentage point, to 534.53, while the Russell 2,000 fell 1.17, to 176.20.
Robert C. Walberg, equity analyst for MMS International, said yesterday's market was pretty much a standard "pre triple-witch" session.
"Most of the weakness displayed yesterday was primarily in the secondary market, with blue-chip issues performing a little better," he said. "The market is showing some strength, in that it has resisted falling sharply on bad news. For example, you had a 3 percent drop in the Tokyo market, weakness in the London market and a larger than expected weekly jobless claim figure."
"Once we get past today, the market should rally through year-end," Mr. Walberg added.
Prices started the day lower as investors continued to worry about the economy, with still no sign that the Fed was planning to lower rates. A bigger than expected rise in the weekly jobless claims and some sell program trading kept the pressure on. Analysts at MMS International said declines in overeseas markets and the lingering effects of General Motors' announced restructuring also dampened sentiment.
Elsewhere in the market, Diagnostics Products, a medical biotechnology company, said yesterday that it expects 1991 earnings to be 5 percent to 7 percent below analysts' estimates. The stock's opening was delayed 50 minutes, and it closed down 14 1/2, to 36 3/8.
Genentech, another biotechnology company, said some analysts were likely to lower their 1992 earnings estimates after the company told them it plans to increase research and development money in 1992, and that in the eyes of some analysts may mean lower earnings, as the stock fell 1 3/4, to 29 3/4.
Boeing stock rose 1/2, to 42 1/2, on news that the company had received $3.1 billion in firm orders for 34 jets.
Time Warner stock, which has lost ground steadily since it was disclosed that its co-chief executive, Steven Ross, was being treated for prostate cancer, was unchanged at 80. Traders said many investors consider Mr. Ross and the company as one, and rumors about his condition have taken a toll. According to analysts, the company sent a memorandum to its employees yesterday indicating that his condition has not deteriorated and that Mr. Ross had completed the first phase of treatment, with doctors encouraged by his progress.
In active trading, Advanced Micro Device hit a new high of 17 1/4, before closing up 1 3/4, to 16 3/4, as several analysts raised their earnings estimates or repeated buy ratings after the company said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter results are expected to be above Wall Street expectations.
Traders said Intel shares fell 2 3/8, to 42 1/2, as Goldman, Sachs lowered its earnings estimate on the company.
Nike shares were down in price, as the company expressed optimism that a recent ruling on a trademark dispute with Sideout Sport could be overturned. Nike shares were off 1 1/8 yesterday, finishing at 62 3/4.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Stores See 11th-Hour Slowdown

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
With only five days left before Christmas, retailers' gloomy assessment of their latest sales results has forced them to scale back their already meager expectations for the critical selling season. While merchants are hoping for a last-minute flurry of shoppers, many are now conceding that sales will be even worse than they feared.
"Time is running out," said Kenneth A. Macke, chairman and chief executive of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the Minneapolis department and discount store chain. Mr. Macke said he still expected a burst of activity this weekend, but added, "The big question is whether there will be a big enough pickup to make up for the disappointment of the first couple of weeks" of the season. 
 The answer already seems disheartening because in some instances sales have slowed rather than picked up since Thanksgiving. Retailers attribute the 11th-hour slowdown to the unrelenting stream of grim economic news, most recently the announcement by General Motors on Tuesday that it plans to close 21 plants and eliminate more than 70,000 jobs.
 
Elation 'Short-Lived'
 W. R. Howell, chairman and chief executive of the J. C. Penney Company, said he had been upbeat after a good November and brisk business over the Thanksgiving weekend. "Our elation was short-lived," he said. "We have scaled down our expectations." He, too, said December would be slower than most retailers had planned for.
Dayton Hudson, parent company of Target Stores, also said sales had been slower than expected. Mr. Macke said sales at the company's Mervyn's stores in the West dropped surprisingly sharply last weekend, compared with a year earlier. Sales at stores in California, Nevada and Arizona fell more than 10 percent.
"We had forecast softness, but not to that degree," Mr. Macke said.
Some merchants, scrutinizing the latest dismal results from the field, are trying last-minute tinkering, hoping to spur sales. To compete with a rash of bargain-priced videotapes at video stores and fast-food restaurants, Sears, Roebuck & Company recently cut the price of its "E.T." videotape to $9.99 from $14.99.
 
New Macy Promotion
 R. H. Macy, which earlier this week said Christmas sales were weaker than expected, ran newspaper advertisements complete with clip-out coupons offering an extra 10 or 15 percent off jewelry, housewares and clothing -- many of which are already on sale for half price.
A&S, a Federated Department Stores unit, kept its stores open until midnight for a sale this week.
Bargains remain a high priority for shoppers. Myles Jacob, the owner of two clothing stores in Minneapolis, said shoppers seemed more interested in getting a good price than in finding a specific gift. "People buy Christmas presents like they buy a stock," he said. "They buy it when they think it is a good deal."
Still, as is the case every Christmas, there are a few hot-selling items, including a $179.99 combination pool, table-tennis and glide hockey Tournament Table by Fisher Price, which has sold out at most toy retailers.
"For the last two months, I have spent most of my time talking to manufacturers trying to get more merchandise," said W. John Devine, chairman and chief executive of Children's Palace/Child World Inc., a discount toy retailer. "We could have done 10 percent more business if we had more product." Manufacturers, expecting reduced sales, produced a lot less this year, he said.
 
Inventory in Warehouses
 But Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson and other retailers say lack of inventory is not the problem, and outside retail experts agree. Isaac Lagnado, president of Tactical Retail Solutions, a retail consulting firm in New York, said suppliers' warehouses were filled with goods ready to be shipped.
But for the most part, retailers said there was little they could do but wait and hope that customers begin spending.
"We're hoping the last four or five days will pull us out," said James D. Gundell, general manager of the Bloomingdale's flagship store on Lexington Avenue at 59th Street. But, he added, in a common refrain, "We're running somewhat behind plan."
Many retailers count on Christmas sales for up to half of their profits.
Retailers and some industry experts still expect a burst of shoppers this weekend as consumers stop holding out for further price cuts. "A lot of people have been playing chicken with retailers and the retailer has blinked," Mr. Lagnado said. "Now it's the 12th round and the customers will blink."
For the most part, practical gifts like quilts, tools and kitchen appliances are selling well.
"Who would have thought about towels as a big gift item," Mr. Howell of J. C. Penney said.
 
Other Strong Sellers
 Mr. Lagnado said other strong sellers included the Little Mermaid dolls, Sega video games, Nerf Bow and Arrows and two hardy perennials, Barbie dolls and the Monopoly game.
"It's a lot of basic-type merchandise," said Jane Arend, a spokeswoman for Wal-Mart Stores Inc.
The problem does not seem to be that people are staying at home. For instance, Sears said that more than 300,000 children had had their picture taken with a poster of "E.T."
Not all retailers had bleak reports. Louis Connelly, a spokeswoman for the K Mart Corporation, said that sales were "running nicely ahead of last year."
Wal-Mart Stores has continued to outstrip the competition, and some specialty stores with distinct images, like the Gap and Crate & Barrel, have also stood out.
Gordon Segal, president of Crate & Barrel, a chain of home furnishing stores based in Chicago, said business had picked up this week, after a slow November. Last weekend, people were waiting in line to get into the company's store on Michigan Avenue, Chicago's main shopping street.
Some retail consultants are concerned that if the last-minute sales burst does materialize, stores that have been stingy hiring extra sales help will not be able to cope.
Mr. Lagnado, the retail consultant, said some retailers had made a mistake by skimping on hiring. "People are going to walk away" if they are forced to wait for help, he said.

HEADLINE: CENSUS REFLECTS RESTLESS NATION

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Nearly half of the population of the United States, historically one of the world's most restless nations, moved from one home to another from 1985 to 1989, with about 18 percent of the nation's households pulling up stakes in 1989 alone, according to the most recent data from the Federal Census Bureau.
In nearly three decades from 1960 to 1989, more than 91 percent of the nation's households had moved, the new report said. 
 But the long-term trends indicate that mobility in American society, which has fluctuated over the years along with economic factors like housing costs and interest rates, has slowly declined in the four decades since 1948, when slightly more than 20 percent of Americans moved annually.
Demographers said they expected the steady downturn in mobility rates to continue, at least in the short run, thanks in part to the current recession and in part to the fact that the percentage of Americans in their 20's and 30's -- the age group most likely to move -- is smaller than at any time since the Census Bureau began keeping statistics on mobility in 1948.
"We are moving considerably less in the 1950's," said Larry Long, a Census Bureau demographer.
"Our moving rates were consistently high in the 1950's, then they drifted downward and reached a low point in the early 1980's, when interest rates were so high and mobility rates fell below 17 percent," Mr. Long said. At the end of the recessions of the early 1980's, he said, pent-up desires produced a sudden rush to the moving vans, and the annual mobility rate shot up to 20 percent in 1985.
Since then, the annual moving rates have continued their slow long-term decline.
The West, with its rapidly expanding population, remained the most mobile section of the country, with about one-quarter of its population leaving one dwelling for another in 1989. But in the West, as elsewhere in the country, the vast majority of moves were made within a community or metropolitan area.
The South, where 19.8 percent of all housing units were occupied by new movers in 1989, the year of the survey, was the second most restless area of the country. In the Midwest, movers represented 16.2 percent of all householders; in the Northeast, only about 12 percent of households had moved in 1989.
The restlessness of the American people was noted as early as 1840 by the French historian Alexis de Tocqueville, who wrote, "An American will build a house in which to pass his old age and sell it before the roof is on; he will plant a garden and rent it just as the trees are coming into bearing."
In the United States today, "the population seems to have divided itself into movers and stayers," said Julie Davanzo, a senior economist at RAND, a research organization in Santa Monica, Calif. "Once you've moved once, you're more likely to move again.
"Migration is so much higher in the West because a lot of people have moved to the West and because people who have moved before are more likely to move again -- they are an inherently more mobile group."
Nationwide, renters, who tend to be younger families, were more than four times as likely to have moved in 1989 than homeowners. Nationally, 36.4 percent of renters had moved within the year, compared to 7.7 percent of homeowners.
Since blacks and Hispanic people, who have lower average incomes than the population at large, are disproportionately represented among renters, they are also more likely than white families to be on the move, the Census Bureau report said.
"Where people are more likely to rent, they are more inclined to move," said Jeanne M. Woodward, the author of the report. "Higher mobility rates of blacks reflect the fact they more commonly rent their housing units." About 57 percent of black households live in rented quarters, compared to 33 percent of white households; about 22 percent of black households moved in the survey year, compared to 17 percent of white households.
The survey, which was based on a smaple of 49,400 housing units in 878 counties and cities around the country, also found that among homeowners, the more educated and more affluent were the most likely to move frequently.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
In Praise of G.M., If Not of Its Stock

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
MOST automotive analysts agree that the sweeping retrenchment announced by the General Motors Corporation on Wednesday was long overdue, a necessary move to streamline the company's unwieldy operations to match its diminished share of the vehicle market.
But the analysts are divided on G.M.'s common stock, which is trading around its four-year low. Some advise selling the stock, out of fear that among other things the dividend may be cut again. Others urge investors to buy G.M. shares, predicting that the stock is unlikely to drop much more. 
 The announcement had little impact on the stock's price on Wednesday, because Wall Street had largely taken the restructuring into account earlier. A week before, G.M. officials had signaled that cutbacks were coming, giving credence to the rumors that had been sweeping Wall Street and pushing down the price. "The market had a week to digest," said Maryann N. Keller, an automotive analyst with Furman Selz in New York.
Although the stock was actively traded on Wednesday, prices fluctuated little after Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman, announced the changes at a news conference. But G.M.'s common shares fell again yesterday, reaching a new recent low of $26.875, down 87.5 cents.
With the question about potential cutbacks now answered -- 21 plants to be closed and more than 70,000 jobs to be eliminated over the next few years -- other questions remain that cloud the near-term outlook for G.M..
For one, it is unclear whether the company will lower its quarterly dividend of 40 cents a share again in the new year. After slicing the payout last February, from 75 cents, Mr. Stempel said the world's largest auto maker would not cut its dividend again before considering other actions.
 But Ronald A. Glantz, a Dean Witter analyst in San Francisco, said the United Automobile Workers union would want G.M. investors to share in the sacrifices, along with G.M. hourly workers, before the round of contract bargaining scheduled for 1993.
Mr. Stempel said G.M. would cut capital spending, but Mr. Glantz suggested that it might be prudent to cut the dividend for roughly 18 months to signal to the work force and to investors that the company "is not going to slash capital spending in an effort to appease Wall Street." Because a dividend cut would likely depress the stock, Mr. Glantz is maintaining his "sell" recommendation.
In coming months, credit rating agencies will also decide whether to lower the rating on G.M. debt securities, which would raise G.M.'s borrowing costs. Ms. Keller said the threat of such action would "put a lid on the stock." She declined to predict whether G.M.'s reduction plans were sufficient to stave off a downgrade. She is maintaining her "hold" recommendation on the stock.
 Another school of thought holds that the bad news about G.M. is over, and that the stock represents a buying opportunity. "The bad news is all out," said Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst with Paine Webber in New York, who has upgraded his recommendation to attractive, from neutral.
With G.M. removing more than 15 percent of its capacity, the industry as a whole will be operating, when consumer demand returns, at capacity levels not seen since the late 1970's. Mr. Girsky said many investors he spoke with yesterday were skeptical about investing in G.M.; some were doubtful that G.M. would follow through on its plans, and others thought American auto sales would never return to their previous levels.
Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody in New York, said that because expectations were so low, there was little risk in buying the stock now, which he is recommending. He says he thinks that the price will go no lower than $25 a share and that it may rise to $40 in a year.
"When the sun comes out, G.M. is going to be an inherently more profitable enterprise," he said. Mr. Kirnan also thinks that Americans may start linking their political views to their shopping lists, and will start test-driving more American cars than they have in recent years.
Jean-Claude Gruet of UBS Securities in New York is also recommending the stock. He noted that although consumer confidence was dismal -- a problem that will likely be made worse by G.M.'s cutbacks -- positive year-to-year auto sales comparisons may soon emerge, given the slump earlier this year. G.M.'s retrenching, combined with gains in market share for some of its new models, are behind his "buy" recommendation, for investors who have the patience to wait for the auto industry to turn up. When it does, he said, the stock will respond quickly.
Scott F. Merlis of Morgan Stanley likened the stock's future course to a bungee jump, saying it would snap back strongly once auto sales start to improve. Mr. Merlis recommends that investors hold the stock for the short-term, but considers it an attractive long-term investment.
"Although we are very concerned about the new downshift in the economy, and vehicle sales, G.M.'s ongoing effort to go lean will mean a lot of upside when the consumer comes back," he said.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Surged At Start of December

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
In a sign of deepening job-market distress, first-time claims for state unemployment insurance leaped 79,000 in the week ended Dec. 7 to match the highest level since March, the Labor Department reported today.
The increase, to 493,000, was markedly greater than most analysts had expected and tended to support predictions that the December jobless rate, to be reported on Jan. 3, will hit 7 percent after standing at 6.8 percent in October and November. 
 "Things are deteriorating," declared Alan C. Lerner, a senior economist at the Bankers Trust Company, also noting that the number of people collecting benefits under state programs jumped 763,100 in the week ended Nov. 30, to 3,546,100.
 
Holidays Are a Factor
 Before seasonal adjustment, initial claims totaled 613,500 for the Dec. 7 week, up 176,800 from the preceding week, when the Thanksgiving holiday closed unemployment offices and cut applications.
While the initial-claims figure is widely watched as a sign of what is to come -- it is one of the 11 components of the Government's index of leading indicators -- it is prone to erratic week-to-week swings, particularly around holidays. This has caused analysts to favor a four-week average in evaluating claims figures.
On this basis, the latest reading is 449,000, the same as in the preceding period. This was because the Dec. 7 level of 493,000 was exactly the same as reported for the week ended Nov. 9, which happened to be the highest since the recessionary depths of last March. In March, claims briefly soared to 540,000, the most in more than eight years.
Separately, the October trade figures from the Commerce Department provided a rare bit of upbeat economic news, showing that American companies exported a record $36.7 billion of merchandise that month, $1.4 billion more than in September. Imports rose a sizable $1.2 billion, which some analysts said was more likely a sign of delayed ordering of holiday goods than an indication of a rebounding domestic economy. Over all, the trade deficit for October was $6.7 billion, down slightly from September's $6.9 billion. [Page D4.]
 
Worries About Jobs
 The jobless-claims figures, which gauge the number of newly unemployed, had been expected to rise after their drop of 61,000 in the Thanksgiving week. But the increase of 79,000 was roughly twice as much as the consensus forecast. Besides pointing to a rise in the December unemployment rate, which is based on a survey conducted during the week ended Dec. 14, the data add to evidence that the economy may be contracting in the fourth quarter.
Yet the Federal Reserve continued to refrain from beginning another round of interest-rate cuts, puzzling many specialists.
"The numbers are pretty per suasive," said Michael W. Keran, chief economist for the Prudential Insurance Company. But he also noted that while consumers, politicians and many business people were decidedly pessimistic about the economy, the financial markets seemed more confident. Mr. Keran noted, for example, that not only was the stock market holding up, but also junk bonds were performing well and the spreads were narrowing between returns on investment-grade securities of differing qualities.
Yesterday, partly in response to the jobless numbers, long-term interest rates fell to their lowest level in more than four years.
These developments argue against those who foresee an extended deterioration of the economy that would seriously impair prospects for profits and debt coverage.
 
California Tops List
 The claims report showed that the states with the biggest increases for the Dec. 7 week were California, with 30,863 who had lost jobs, followed by North Carolina (19,714), Illinois (19,317) and Pennsylvania (16,018). The biggest decline was Wisconsin's, at 8,828, with Texas a distant second, down 2,840.
New York and New Jersey each had claims rise by about 7,250, with New Jersey citing big layoffs in air-conditioning factories and casinos.
Today's report also showed that 635,000 people filed claims during the Nov. 30 week for extended benefits under the recently enacted emergency compensation program, which provides up to 20 weeks of additional benefits to those who have already exhausted 26 weeks of benefits.
 
A Jobless Rate Is Up
 The seasonally adjusted rate of insured unemployment rose to 3.3 percent from 2.9 percent in the Nov. 30 week. This reflected 3,477,000 people collecting benefits, 419,000 higher than in the preceding week's seasonally adjusted revised level of 3,058,000.
The 10 states with the highest insured unemployment rates were Alaska, Vermont, Oregon, California, Rhode Island, Washington, Maine, Idaho, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. Puerto Rico's was 7.6 percent, slightly higher than Alaska's 7.5 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
New Camel Agency Defends 'Smooth Character' Image

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE advertising industry's two most-talked-about executives are finally talking about their new account.
In October, John L. Mezzina and William G. Brown Jr. stunned their colleagues. The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company unexpectedly moved the creative portion of its $40 million Camel cigarette account from Young & Rubicam New York, which the two men had left two months earlier, to Mezzina/Brown Inc., their small start-up agency. 
 With the account's transition almost completed, the men agreed to an interview, their first since landing the account, at their office on Manhattan's new Madison Avenue, Park Avenue South. The other day, as workers painted and remodeled the 18,000 square feet of space being occupied by Mezzina/Brown's 40 employees -- including about a dozen who, like Mr. Mezzina and Mr. Brown had worked on Camel at Y.& R. -- the executives discussed the surprising events of recent weeks.
"We had hopes Reynolds would be interested in doing business with us when we were out on our own," Mr. Brown, the agency's president, said, sitting behind a desk in a still sparsely furnished office.
"Did we think it would be of the magnitude it turned out to be?" he asked. "Probably not."
Yet not only is the Camel account large, it is perhaps the most reviled advertising in America today. Attacks on the brand's "Smooth character" campaign, developed in 1988 -- a year before the account came to Y.& R. -- continue unabated.
Only last week, the Journal of the American Medical Association singled out the campaign, and its Joe Camel cartoon caricature, for blistering criticism. A coalition of antismoking and health groups, charging that the ads actually appeal more to children than adults, demanded they be banned.
Mr. Brown staunchly defended the campaign. It is "terrific," he said, "and it is working." Echoing Reynolds, he and Mr. Mezzina insisted the ads are aimed solely at adult smokers.
"We are not targeting kids," Mr. Mezzina, the agency's chairman and executive creative director, said as he smoked a Camel. "We are playing this according to Hoyle."
Mr. Brown added, "There are 50 million people out there who already smoke, and 48 million do not smoke Camel. We've got a huge market to target out there without bringing in under-age smokers."
Mezzina/Brown is producing Camel advertising, the executives said, though none of it has yet appeared. It will continue in the "Smooth character" vein, they added.
Mr. Brown compared Joe Camel to other "illustrious spokes-characters" like the Pink Panther, which appears in ads for Owens-Corning insulation, and the Jolly Green Giant.
"It's highly unlikely kids run out to buy vegetables because the Jolly Green Giant suggests their stuff is great," he said.
Working on a campaign "that's particularly high-profile makes your job more difficult, clearly," Mr. Mezzina said. "I hope people would not think we're tainted because we're associated with something controversial," he added.
That is of particular concern because Mezzina/Brown intends to seek additional clients "as soon as it's practical," Mr. Brown said. But because "Camel is so huge and multifaceted," he added, "it may be a few more months before we can get involved in pitching other accounts."
Reynolds's decision to shift the Camel account "was in no way a reflection on Y.& R.," said David N. Iauco, the company's senior vice president of marketing, because the giant agency "was doing a good job."
But, he added, after Mr. Mezzina and Mr. Brown left Young & Rubicam, "the opportunity to retain the leadership team on the brand was an attractive option."
Discussing their move, Mr. Brown said: "At some point in most people's advertising careers, you think about going out on your own. When you hit your early 40's" -- he is 43; Mr. Mezzina is 42 -- "it's time to take destiny into your own hands."
The executives disputed suggestions that Reynolds hired them simply because it is cheaper for a small agency to handle such a huge account.
"Certainly there are economic advantages" for Reynolds, Mr. Brown said. "But Camel is one of their flagship brands. No matter what the financial advantages are, there's no way in the world they would put it into the hands of those who couldn't meet the tough marketing challenge."
And that "is easier for a small agency," Mr. Mezzina said, "because what tends to happen in any large organization is that the falcon can't hear the falconer."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Bad Year, Good Decade for the Rich

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Representative Thomas J. Downey has done as much as anyone in recent years to advance the Democrats' case that the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. So eyebrows were raised today when the Long Island Democrat released a study that seemed to weaken part of his case.
The very richest Americans were the ones who seemed to get poorer in 1989, losing almost 10 percent of their income, the study showed, while the incomes of most other Americans stayed the same and the poor showed a modest gain. 
 Mr. Downey was quick to note that the trend affected only the top 1 percent of Americans -- movie stars and corporate chiefs -- and to argue that the findings signaled no real reversal in what he called the trend toward greater income inequality.
He almost dared Republicans to make an issue out of it. "There's an interesting dilemma for them," he said. "To recognize this drop in the incomes of the very rich, they'd have to recognize the huge past gains."
While Mr. Downey's critics did not seize the moment to call for bailouts of Donald Trump, some did suggest that there just may have been some grandstanding in the Democrats' past statements about windfalls for the very wealthy. Since sample sizes of this group are always small, the critics say, they give way to large statistical fluctuations.
"Probably earlier impressions were exaggerated," said Marvin Kosters, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington research group, in a reference to the bandwagon the Democrats tried to get rolling on the tables in last year's Green Book, a House Ways and Means Committee compilation of social welfare statistics.
Last year's tables showed that from 1977-1988, the incomes of the richest 1 percent rose by 96 percent. Today's updated figures downgrade that rise, though they still show a hefty 78 percent gain from 1977 to 1989.
Economists were puzzled over the numbers, which were computed by the Congressional Budget Office and made public by the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, which Mr. Downey heads. They cover 1988 to 1989, the period before the recession's official arrival.
Perhaps they show the recession hit the richest first. Perhaps they reflect the downturn in real estate and banking. Perhaps they involve some kind of delayed reaction to 1986 tax changes. Perhaps the budget office made a mathematical error.
"I haven't a clue," said Henry Aaron, an economist at the Brookings Institution, another research center.
The figures showed that in 1989 the pre-tax incomes for the top 1 percent of American families fell by about $57,000 -- to $560,000 from $617,000. The change was adjusted for inflation and expressed in projected 1992 dollars.
After-tax incomes for those families also fell at similar rates, dropping to $410,000, down from $451,000 a year earlier.
Information from the budget office, not contained in the Ways and Means report, indicated that the 1989 reductions for the very richest came mostly because of drops in salaries and other earned income. Rough approximations showed that 60 percent of the drop was from labor income and 40 percent from reduced capital income.
But no one challenged Mr. Downey's assertion that the past decade's trend has been toward greater income inequality. From 1977 to 1989, today's study showed, the poorest fifth of American families saw their incomes drop by more than 10 percent, to $8,391, while the incomes of the richest fifth grew by more than 25 percent, to $109,424.
"I agree there's been greater income inequality for individuals over that period, and for families," said Mr. Kosters. But he said he thought that some Democrats had exaggerated its extent, and its causes. Part of the reason for the growing inequality is demographic rather than economic, he argued. Richer Americans often belong to families in which both the husband and wife work, he said, while poorer American families are increasingly headed by a single woman.
Further, Mr. Kosters argues, the trend may reverse itself. Seeing the economic benefits of a good education, he said, more poor people may seek one, and seeing the low costs of unskilled workers, more employers might seek them out and train them.
But he cautioned that today's data did nothing either to support or contradict that theory. Statistically, not politically speaking, "the evidence is too weak to say, one way or the other," he said.

HEADLINE: Idle, Angry Hard Hats Tell Off City Hall

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Fifty thousand angry construction workers took to the streets yesterday, marching across the Brooklyn Bridge to City Hall, where they protested delays in the city's rebuilding projects that they said have cost them jobs.
Waving American flags and chanting "Prime the pump!" the union members called on city, state, and Federal officials to increase capital spending programs to help revive their ailing industry. 
 Industry and union officials who spoke at the City Hall Park rally that followed said more than half of the city's 90,000 construction workers are currently unemployed, and cited 10 major capital spending projects stalled by bureaucratic delays in recent years that could have generated at least 15,000 jobs.
"We came together to send a message that this region is close to a depression and that it's time to stop planning projects which have been stalled for years, and actually start building them," said Louis Colleti, president and chief executive of the New York Building Congress, an umbrella group representing contractors and labor unions.
 
Hard Hats and Boots
 The officials said that the rally had closed down virtually all construction projects involving union workers in New York City yesterday because all union workers had agreed to give up a day's pay to draw attention to the construction industry's problems.
The police estimated that 50,000 people, many clad in hard hats and boots, attended the rally. In a rare alliance, representatives from management, engineering, design and civic groups also took part in the rally.
As speakers addressed the rally, the construction workers, many carrying signs reading "Rebuild America," often broke into chants of "We want jobs! We want jobs!" that were followed by screams, yells and clapping.
The protesters closed the westbound lane of the Brooklyn Bridge and Broadway and Chambers Streets for several hours yesterday, but the police said that there was no disorderly conduct.
Among the stalled rebuilding projects the speakers cited were the relocation of the old Miller Highway south of 56th Street, where Westway was supposed to go, a new West Side waterfront park from Battery Park to midtown, full financing of the Metropolitan Transit Authority's capital plan, a third water tunnel, the Ellis Island International Conference Center and a new headquarters for the Commodities Exchange, at the World Trade Center.
 
Delays in Awarding Contracts
 Last year, the city's Environmental Protection Department failed to let more than $600 million in budgeted contracts to repair sewers and water mains, delays that the department attributed to a shift in offices, changes in procurement rules and holdups in supporting services by other city agencies. Construction officials and other aides to Mayor David N. Dinkins said the slow progress would cost the city both millions of dollars in extra work and a chance to stimulate the sluggish local economy.
Vincent DiLuci, an unemployed electrician from Brooklyn who marched in the rally, said that he had been without work for 10 months and had recently applied for public assistance to feed his wife and three children. "I'm doing all I can to find work, and now I learn that there's work available but the city won't award contracts," Mr. DeLuci said. "Now that's depressing."
John Cardinal O'Connor, whose civic and charitable activities the construction industry has long supported financially, told the protesters that he had come to the rally to express his "personal support and belief in organized labor." Referring to political leaders, the Cardinal said: "We need their help and support to get people working again. We need a plan, and we need a plan now, and we need it put into action now."
Responding to the protesters outside his office windows yesterday, Mayor Dinkins said in a statement that he shared their frustration, and he called on the President to finance an "anti-recessionary" agenda to put people back to work. "Obviously a single Mayor in a single city cannot jump-start the nation's economy," Mr. Dinkins said.
Mr. Coletti of the building congress agreed with Mr. Dinkins and called for the establishment of a national infrastructure fund that would finance the rebuilding of the nation's roads, bridges, highways and schools.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Another Top Manager Is Leaving Salomon

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The stream of departures continued at Salomon Brothers yesterday, as the firm announced that Jay F. Higgins, a vice chairman and one of the only remaining members of Salomon's prior senior management, would resign at the end of the year.
The departure of Mr. Higgins, who founded the firm's mergers and acquisitions department and served as the head of investment banking, had been expected. But his decision marks the highest-level defection since November, when Stanley B. Shopkorn, the head of the equities division and one of Salomon's most aggressive traders, said he would leave at the end of the year. 
 Salomon has been struggling to keep its executives since the Treasuries market scandal began to unfold in August. Since then, virtually all of the firm's former management, including John H. Gutfreund, the chairman, were either asked to resign or chose to leave as the changes at the firm made their future roles less certain.
Rumors of Mr. Higgins's departure began to circulate last month after the announcement of a large management shake-up. Deryck C. Maughan, who was named chief operating officer in August, recast the firm's management structure, eliminating the executive committee that had run the firm and replacing it with his own new committee of managers. Mr. Higgins, who was named to the executive committee during Mr. Gutfreund's tenure, was not appointed to the new committee.
In an interview Mr. Higgins, 47 years old, said he had long planned to leave, even before the Treasuries market scandal began to rock the firm. "I have been thinking for a while that I would be doing something else in 1992," Mr. Higgins said, adding that he had no specific plans. "I wish these guys nothing but the best. They are doing a difficult job, and I think they are doing a spectacular job."
Salomon executives have been wary of possible departures after the end of the year, when executives will have their bonuses and all participants in a three-year, $120 million deferred compensation plan will receive their share of the pool.
Mr. Higgins has played an important role in the firm since the Treasuries market scandal began to unfold. After the World Bank, the bluest of Salomon's blue-chip clients, suspended business with the firm, Mr. Higgins maintained contact with the bank and worked aggressively at preserving the firm's relationship with the international lending agency, as well as at regaining its business.
Mr. Higgins joined the firm's corporate finance department in 1969, after receiving his undergraduate degree from Princeton University and his master's degree in business administration from the University of Chicago. In 1978, he founded the mergers and acquisitions department, and he was named a general partner one year later. In 1986, he was named the head of corporate finance, and and he became head of investment banking in 1987. He assumed his latest job in 1988.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Germany's Rate Increases Cause Losses for the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Battered by a rise in German interest rates, the dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday.
Gold prices were mixed, falling in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the dollar fell $1.80, closing at $357.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $357.50, off $1.30. 
 The German mark, strengthened by a half-percentage point increase in two important interest rates, was the standout on the foreign exchange markets.
Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, raised its discount rate to a record 8 percent and also increased the Lombard rate, the interest charge to banks using securities as collateral, to 9.75 percent.
An increase in German rates supports the mark -- and in turn undermines other currencies, including the dollar -- because higher yields make German investments more attractive.
The dollar tumbled more than 2 pfennigs, falling to 1.5575 marks in New York, from 1.5715 late Wednesday. In earlier German trading, the dollar fell to 1.5595 marks from 1.5730, and the mark also rose against other currencies.
John McCarthy, chief foreign exchange dealer with ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in New York, said comments by German officials in support of a stronger mark also weakened the dollar.
The dollar was also hurt by expectations of a further decrease in United States interest rates. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to push the discount rate below its current level of 4 1/2 percent in hopes of reviving the economy.
Another drop in American rates will make United States investments even less competitive in the face of higher yields overseas.
Mr. McCarthy predicted the dollar would continue to decline.
"Pressure looks to be on the dollar in the very short term," he said.
The dollar fell to 128.15 yen, from 128.35 in late New York trading Wednesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.28 yen to close at 128.70 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.8365 from $1.8290. In London, the pound rose to $1.8330 from $1.8253.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included 1.3805 Swiss francs, down from 1.3925; 5.3255 French francs, down from 5.3700; 1,180.25 Italian lire, down from 1,187.00, and 1.1565 Canadian dollars, up from 1.14695.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Prices for Heating Oil Drop To Lowest Level in 6 Months

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil traders ignored freezing temperatures yesterday and pushed home heating oil futures to the lowest price since June.
"You'd think people were frolicking on the beach, the prices we're seeing," said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. 
 Heating oil for January delivery settled at 53.46 cents a gallon, down 1.26 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil for next-month delivery has not been that low since June 13, when the final price was 53.44 cents a gallon.
 
Crude Oil, Gasoline Off, Too
 Light, sweet crude oil for January settled at $19.13 a barrel, down 26 cents. Unleaded gasoline for January settled at 53.57 cents a gallon, down 0.65 cent.
Even though oil prices had been falling lately, traders were surprised by the sharpness of the plunge in heating oil.
"You're near the year's low on heating oil, and you're in a cold spell in the Northeast," said Victor Yu, vice president of futures for the Nikkhah Energy Group. "It does not say much about the rallying strength of this market."
Heating oil supplies are greater than demand, analysts said, largely because the weather in the Northeast has been mild for much of the fall.
"There's just a lot of inventories that need to be worked off," Mr. Yu said. The American Petroleum Institute reported this week that the nation's ample supply of heating oil was rising.
The rest of the energy futures were sold off in the afternoon, despite a rally in the morning on the news that the United States, Britain and France might seek to boycott Libyan oil in retaliation for the terrorist bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The Western nations contend that Libyan agents were responsible for the bombing.
Reports of a Texas refinery fire kept gasoline futures from falling as far as the crude oil and heating oil contracts, Mr. Yu said.
Natural gas prices for January took another tumble, falling 5.7 cents to settle at $1.708 for 1,000 cubic feet. Natural gas has fallen 16.5 cents in five straight losing sessions.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Will Recession Revive Unions?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WILL this stubborn recession, which the White House now concedes is continuing, further weaken the American labor movement? Or will the slump revive it?
History does not provide an answer. On the contrary, it shows that hard times can have a double, and contradictory, effect on organized labor. On one side, falling sales and profits, plant closings, business failures, layoffs and the fear of unemployment undermine labor's bargaining power and ability to organize. But, on the other side, a serious and prolonged slump also provides a challenge to attack problems of poverty and unemployment, and may revive the spirit and drive of the unions -- as happened in the 1930's Depression. 
 The election of Ron Carey, the crusading head of a United Parcel Service local in Queens, as president of the teamsters' union indicates that the spirit of union democracy and the struggle for the best interests of rank-and-file workers are indeed reviving in a union known for the corruption and violence of its leadership.
But one such victory -- and one that is far from complete -- does not mean that the war is won. It will be a continuing struggle to re-establish organized labor as an effective check and balance to the powers of corporate management -- a point made by George P. Shultz and described last week in this column. Mr. Shultz, a former Secretary of State, Secretary of Labor and president of Bechtel Group Inc., sees a free labor movement as vital to a free and healthy society.
"The worst thing that can happen in a good labor-management relationship," Mr. Shultz recently told the National Planning Association, "is for people to start valuing it too highly and elevate its importance above getting problems resolved." When either management or labor is afraid to press the other on critical issues for fear of spoiling their relationship, he said, "the relationship is inevitably going to go down hill because it isn't serving the interests of the people."
But how can organized labor regain its vigor and its role as an effective check and balance to management?
In response to that question, Owen Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, expressed optimism: "While we've taken our lumps, we haven't lost our vision or our vigor. Nor are we without resources. We have a job to do. I share with my colleagues in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- including, I might add, teamster president Ron Carey -- a genuine enthusiasm for doing that job."
Mr. Bieber reformulated the question as, "What's needed to insure that our contribution continues?"
And then he answered it this way: "We need changes in American labor laws, which have been tilted against the very working people they were written to protect. We need to restrain the buccaneer employers who employ permanent strikebreakers. Why? Because they severely tilt the bargaining and organizing process in favor of the least responsible employers. And we need to revisit the issue of overall labor law reform in the 1990's to insure a neutral climate for organizing."
The aim of overhauling the labor laws to clear the way for union organizing goes back to the New Deal. The rapid growth of unions in the Depression took place under the protective arm of the Federal Government and the Supreme Court, which found the National Labor Relations Act to be constitutional. The act affirmed the right of labor to organize and bargain collectively with employers.
"We've had just about every imaginable obstacle thrown at us in the last decade or so," Mr. Bieber said.
But that could reverse. If the present recession continues or worsens in the months before the November 1992 election, there could be a radical improvement in the political climate for labor organizing, as there was when Franklin D. Roosvelt defeated Herbert Hoover in 1932.
However, the growth of union membership during the Depression was not just because of political forces; it was also spurred by the newly formed Congress of Industrial Organizations and by the hot competition between the C.I.O. and the American Federation of Labor for members. A. H. Raskin, who for many years was the chief labor correspondent of The New York Times, feels that the most important requirement for a revival of the labor movement today is "commitment" -- the commitment of labor leaders to rank-and-file members and to the jobless, poor and unorganized. "Everything would stem from that commitment," Mr. Raskin said.
Changes in technology and the skill requirements of workers, the shift from goods to services, the changing demography of the labor force, intensifying global competition and the failures of the unions to adapt to these changes -- all these help to explain the linked trends of declining union membership, stagnating wages and declining productivity growth. Labor and management both need to take a new look at their relationship and their common objectives, with the focus on how to get productivity growing again.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
From Silver Boom Town to Celebrity Playground

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

Whiteout
Lost in Aspen
By Ted Conover
269 pages. Random House. $20.
Having previously explored the precarious worlds of railroad hobos ("Rolling Nowhere") and illegal aliens from Mexico ("Coyotes"), the journalist Ted Conover now turns to the other end of the social spectrum in his latest book, "Whiteout: Lost in Aspen." His subject is Aspen, the glittering ski resort and celebrity enclave in the Rocky Mountains of Colorado. The underlying theme, however, is similar to that explored in his earlier books: the promise and betrayal of the American Dream. 
 As Mr. Conover writes, Aspen was originally a quiet valley where the Ute Indians spent their summers. The discovery of silver there quickly transformed it into a boom town in the 1880's; the boom ended abruptly in 1893, when the price of silver plummeted on world markets, and the town's economy collapsed. By the late 1930's, as the skiing industry was just getting started in the United States, Aspen boasted a meager population of 600 or 700.
Among the new visitors to Aspen at this time was the American businessman Walter Paepcke. He belonged to the Chicago world of high-thinking idealists who included the philosopher Mortimer Adler; Robert M. Hutchins, the University of Chicago president, and the Bauhaus designer Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, and he came up with a visionary plan for turning Aspen into a sort of high-culture resort. After helping to stage the Goethe Bicentennial Festival in Aspen in 1949, Paepcke and his wife, Elizabeth, set about institutionalizing what they had achieved. The result was the think tank known as the Aspen Institute.
"One of the strange ironies of Aspen," Mr. Conover writes, "is that even among those who continue to love the town, there is a constant discussion of when Aspen began to go downhill and whether it now is ruined. This discussion usually takes as a narrative model the Book of Genesis, with Paradise created fresh in the late 40's and 50's and Innocence lost gradually ever since. Walter and Elizabeth Paepcke are like Adam and Eve, the first in the Garden, and greedheads from the outside world play the Serpent. It is a battle of good and evil for the soul of Aspen."
According to Mr. Conover, some older Aspenites date the decline of their town to the paving of Independence Pass, a mountain road, which allowed easier access. Others point to the legalization of condominium ownership, which opened the way for more buildings and more people. Later arrivals in town cite the opening of a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in 1973, and the construction of the Ritz Carlton Hotel, started in 1988.
In any case, Aspen's "Paepckeinspired air of utopian possibility" became a magnet in the 1960's and 70's for hippies, counterculture types and people intent on shedding their pasts and reinventing themselves. "It was a young place, sufficiently in flux to have a sense of alternatives about it," Mr. Conover writes. "It was in the mountains, far from cities and repressive childhoods, but close to nature. Commerce seemed something the town was not about -- Babbitt lived far away. Small was beautiful, Aspen was both, and the young flocked to it."
As Mr. Conover sees it, different aspects of Aspen's appeal were summed up by two of its most famous citizens: while Hunter S. Thompson, the gonzo journalist, became a kind of "unpaid advertisement for bohemian Aspen, a call for freaks and rebels," the presence of John Denver "seemed to pave the way for seekers, for nature lovers, for spiritualists, for flower children." Other celebrities -- including Jill St. John, Jimmy Buffett, George Hamilton, Jack Nicholson, Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell, Robert Wagner, and Sally Field -- took houses in the town as well. By the 80's, says Mr. Conover, Aspen had become "a great celebrity laboratory."
From his vantage point as a cabdriver and later as a reporter for the local paper, The Aspen Times, Mr. Conover gives the reader a selection of entertaining anecdotes about famous and not-so-famous Aspenites. He introduces Jon, owner of the local "disco cab" -- a taxi equipped with a mirrored ball, black light, a fog machine and two musical keyboards; Cynthia, a self-proclaimed U.F.O. abductee, who says things like, "We've hugged in a previous life, am I right?," and a new-age guru named Diamond, who asserts that illness "is not accidental," that "there are no accidents." In addition, he recounts his own comical attempts to crash Don Johnson's Christmas party, survive a new-age retreat weekend and make it through Barbi Benton's annual pajama party.
This lively book leaves the reader amused and a little disgusted with the excesses of Aspen. Mr. Conover seems to have focused on the town's more colorful and more outrageous aspects, and Aspen comes across as a collection of weirdos, nuts, conspicuous consumers, self-indulgent partygoers and aging narcissists. It's the sort of place where people of both sexes wear full-length fur coats and Day-Glo bodysuits, the sort of place where the average house costs more than $1 million and the average worker is forced to commute.
Mr. Conover grew up in Colorado (though far away from the glitter of Aspen), and by making himself a character in his story -- much the way he did in "Coyotes" -- he avoids appearing as a judgmental outsider. Much of this book, in fact, chronicles his own seduction by Aspen: in the course of two years, we see him go from being an impoverished cabdriver, scrambling to make ends meet, to being an Aspen insider, impatient with the unhip world that lies beyond the town. Indeed, his own loss of innocence becomes a kind of metaphor for Aspen's own precipitous tumble from grace.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER

 BODY:

A Star at Raphael
Some enticing Provencal food is being stirred up at Restaurant Raphael, 33 West 54th Street in Manhattan. The new chef is Jean-Michel Bergougnoux, who ran the kitchen at the three-star Le Cygne until it closed last summer. His dinner menu carries beguilements like a wonderful combination of salmon glazed with periwinkle juice and dill ($20), loin of rabbit with bacon and braised endive ($22) and sirloin steak with a red wine sauce and bone marrow, and a gratin of salsify, fava beans and prosciutto ($24). 
 A recent lunch started with a harmonious confit of sliced eggplant layered with slices of warm lamb and goat cheese ($8.50). Also alluring was a salad of perfectly sauteed skate with capers ($8).
Among main courses, an earthy assembly is the pan-seared cod fillet with cabbage and a sesame oil vinaigrette ($17). When the weather is cold, a highly recommended dish is braised aiguillette of beef, a sinewy but extremely flavorful cut, served with its juices and a confit of carrots ($19). Finally there is the Provencal specialty brandade de morue, to which Mr. Bergougnoux gives rough texture and splendid flavor by blending pieces of cod with potatoes and serving with a dark beefy sauce ($7.50).
Restaurant Raphael serves lunch noon to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday, dinner 6 to 10 P.M. Monday to Friday, until 11 P.M. Saturday. All major credit cards accepted. Telephone: (212) 582-8993.
 
The Changing Scene
 CLOSED: Harvey's Chelsea House, the 102-year-old restaurant at 108 West 18th Street in Manhattan, but perhaps temporarily. Dick Harvey, the owner for 16 years, said that taxes, insurance and utility costs, compounded by the bad economy, had forced him to close.
He is considering seeking investors or a partner. "If I can't come up with something soon, I'll have to sell or declare bankruptcy," he said.
