SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3434 words

HEADLINE: How to Win Friends and Influence Culture

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
"MEMBERSHIP was the foam on the wave of enthusiasm for the arts," says Jan E. Adlmann, assistant director for external affairs at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. "And the wave has subsided."
Mr. Adlmann's fanciful metaphor underscored some tough facts. Faced with spending cuts by city, state and Federal governments and by recession-pinched corporations, New York City's cultural institutions are running hard just to stay in place. Increasingly, they are turning to their grass-roots base: the thousands of members who, year in and year out, contribute $25, $1,000 or $250,000 to help keep the doors open at institutions ranging from the Bronx Zoo to Fraunces Tavern, from powerhouses like the Metropolitan Opera to boutique-size operations like the New York City Fire Museum. 
 "All membership people are much more under the gun than in the mid-80's," Mr. Adlmann said. "In the 90's, American museums across the board will see a greater enlargement of development staff, which includes membership, than any other department."
Membership directors tend to use words like "family" and "love" when speaking of their supporters. In a cold economic climate, they thrive on the heartwarming gesture, the unanticipated donation, the membership upgrade. And no season cheers quite like Christmas, when, says Marilyn Shapiro, head of marketing and development for the Metropolitan Opera, "people generally take stock of their giving."
The city's cultural institutions usually give excellent value for money. Nearly all of them offer benefits packages geared to particular levels of monetary support, usually starting with a basic membership in the $25-to-$75 range (with discounts for students and the elderly) and moving up to big-bucks categories with honorific designations like patron, special friend, star and angel.
Typically, a basic membership includes free admission, a discount at the museum store, a monthly events calendar and fliers about special events. At the Museum of Modern Art, for example, a basic individual membership buys unlimited free admission to the museum (normally $7), as well as a 10 percent discount at the museum's three stores.
And all over town, there's evidence of fancy footwork at the base-membership level. The Museo del Barrio offers free admission to the art museum in Ponce, Puerto Rico. The Asia Society gives discounts at selected Asian restaurants in New York, while the New York Botanical Garden offers discounts at selected nurseries and garden centers. The Museum of American Folk Art offers a limited $15 "Quilt Connection" category for people interested solely in quilts. The International Center of Photography, with a truly shrewd eye, promises members that an expert will review their portfolios.
The greater the contribution, the greater the privileges. A few hundred dollars at a blue-chip museum buys invitations to special viewings or rehearsals, special classes and seminars, and free guest admissions. At institutions in Manhattan off Museum Mile, or in other boroughs, the donor's dollar goes further: $500 can buy a listing in programs or the annual report; at the Brooklyn Museum, $5,000 lands a private tea and personal exhibition tour with the director.
At $1,000, which development officers regard as the benchmark of serious philanthropy, the benefits come showering down, usually in the form of recognition (one's name printed in the annual report or on programs, for example), invitations to black-tie galas and special previews, and access to the curatorial staff, performers and artists. More money brings entry into brass-plaque territory. Top-level donors ($1,000 and up) at the Whitney Museum of American Art can borrow a work of art from the museum's permanent collection to hang in their homes for the length of their membership.
Gradations can be as finely tuned as the seating plan for dinner at Versailles. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, $500 a year buys your name on a plaque plate affixed to a mezzanine seat in the academy's Opera House; $1,000 moves you into the orchestra seats. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, "we reserve access to curators for the upper, upper level, starting at $2,000," said Barbara Dougherty, membership manager.
 
Selling the Institution
 Most membership directors insist that they're selling the institution, not benefits. Nevertheless, "members of a certain category are very aware of their benefits and complain when they don't get them," Ms. Dougherty said. And the benefit just out of reach can rankle. Hell hath no fury like a sustaining member who finds that $300 does not buy a drink at the Temple of Dendur.
The care and feeding of members is an unrelenting obsession. "We surveyed our membership in September, found out some interesting things and are revising our benefits mix accordingly," said William Y. Fellenberg, director of membership at the Museum of Modern Art. "They expressed a growing interest in behind-the-scenes activities related to exhibitions. In response to this, the membership department conducts a variety of talks led by artists and curators."
The Metropolitan Museum found that its members objected to crowded previews (which have since been increased in number to thin out the crowds) and wanted a clearer presentation of information in the monthly calendar. (It was redesigned, and members were surveyed for their reactions.)
The challenge for development officers is to persuade one-year members to renew and basic members to trade up to more expensive membership categories, each with a tempting inducement. The mutual benefit increases geometrically at higher levels, where institutions can offer prestige and recognition at low cost. That means more money for the institution and a bigger tax deduction for the donor, since taxpayers cannot write off the market value of benefits.
"You structure those special events throughout the year as you see fit," said Jerome A. Kleinman, director of development for the New York Philharmonic. He added that while he cannot promise members "a cup of coffee with Maestro Masur," he can deliver members of the orchestra in small gatherings.
Part of the science of membership development is deciding how to price the product. "You're going to raise your fees every couple of years," said Ms. Dougherty of the Metropolitan Museum. "We did it on July 1, 1990, from 14 to 33 percent, depending on the category. Membership dropped off 6 percent, but income grew 8 percent." The Guggenheim Museum, which is preparing to open its doors again in May after a two-year renovation program, will raise its fees dramatically on Jan. 1 but is offering its members a chance to renew or upgrade at the old prices before the New Year.
 
Satisfied Customers
 Worrying about numbers is endemic to the trade. Four times a year, New York's Membership Group for Cultural Institutions meets to discuss topics like the tax deductibility of membership, the pros and cons of direct mail, and effective lobbying for more lenient post-office regulations. The spirit of cooperation carries over into the real world, it seems, since the Brooklyn Botanic Garden shares its mailing lists with the New York Botanical Garden, for the obvious reason: "Exchanging is cheaper than renting a list," says Bella Podesta, director of membership at the Bronx garden.
The pressure is on to keep members happy but not spend money, to keep the cost of membership overhead at 30 percent of donations. More and more, organizations are offering members the option of waiving certain benefits, like free museum publications, if they would prefer to see the cost of the benefit go directly to the institution. The Metropolitan Museum, for example, asks members in the $300-and-up categories if they would like to pick up their publications themselves, thereby saving the museum the cost of postage.
Without members, of course, none of the frantic cost-cutting will make any difference. After steady growth in the early and mid-80's, cultural institutions have faced two years of flat membership, even as prices have risen. The crunch has come, and development officers who contend that they are not losing members do so with a note of triumph.
By the way, Richard Gere, the Jacques Marchais Center of Tibetan Art on Staten Island has a message for you: your membership has lapsed; please renew.
 
HERE'S WHERE TO GIVE AND WHAT YOU'LL GET
 Here is a sampling of cultural institutions in New York City with membership programs, giving mailing addresses and highlights. Most institutions offer students and the elderly a discount on the base membership price. All of them gratefully accept contributions of any amount from nonmembers. Another way to help is to buy gifts at museum shops, some of which offer extra discounts during the holidays.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
Making The Best Of Slim Pickings

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
Curious habit: The closer television gets to Christmas, the stingier it gets with original programming. Most weekly series have segued into repeats, and an inordinate number of holiday specials are, ahem, "classics" from decades past. Finding something requires an effort, but persistence can be rewarded, however modestly. These are this weekend's more promising entries:
"THE YEAR IN ROCK: 1991"(MTV), tonight at 9). The predictable blitz of fleeting images, overseen by the hosts Tabitha Soren and Kurt Loder, is used to catalogue a year that, on the whole, was troubling. With the recession trickling down to the music industry, sales of recordings and concert tickets were off considerably, leaving a good many top names playing before embarrassingly empty halls and stadiums. MTV was clearly less impressed than George Bush with the Persian Gulf War, obviously preferring the "Give Peace a Chance" protesters. Performers from Paula Abdul to Rick James got entangled in unseemly legal situations. But, gamely optimistic, MTV also looks at some brighter sides. Hot new artists: Nirvana, Marky Mark, Seal, Color Me Badd, Naughty by Nature. Breakthroughs: Metallica, the Black Crowes, Extreme, Chris Isaak. Most encouraging pop-culture development: more film releases by black film makers than in the previous five years combined. Short on analysis, this MTV image collection, punctuated with brief blasts of music, is almost dizzyingly comprehensive. 
 "THE WISH THAT CHANGED CHRISTMAS" (CBS, tonight at 8:30). Based on the Rumer Godden book "The Story of Holly and Ivy," this animated program was produced for McDonald's -- officially it's a "Ronald McDonald Family Theater" presentation -- by a Children's Television Workshop subsidiary and Colossal Pictures. Little Ivy, an orphan, spends Christmas Eve looking for a grandmother and a Christmas doll. Far be it from me to reveal the outcome. Providing a couple of the more prominent voices are Paul Winfield and Jonathan Winters. The animation is creaky and the story is treacly (under 9's would seem to be the targeted audience) but, at the breaks, Ronald the clown spiritedly encourages his young viewers to explore the range of books available to them at libraries. That effort is admirable, assuming the libraries still haven't been closed because of budget cutbacks.
"TRIBUTE TO ELTON JOHN AND BERNIE TAUPIN" (ABC, tomorrow at 9 P.M.). With Sylvester Stallone introducing them, performers honoring the songwriting team will include Sting, Tina Turner, George Michael, Sinead O'Connor, Phil Collins, the Who, the Beach Boys and Eric Clapton. Mr. John himself joins Mr. Michael for "Don't Let the Sun Go Down on Me." A collage of Mr. John singing "Your Song" down through the years provides a nifty fashion review of his unfailingly eye-catching hats.
"AMAZING GRACE" (Channel 13, tonight at 9). If you insist on picking one rerun this weekend, this should be it. Produced by Bill Moyers, the 90-minute program traces the story of "Amazing Grace" since it was written in the 18th century by an English minister named John Newton. Truly amazing has been the hymn's extraordinary impact on singers and listeners. Renditions are offered here by, among others, Jessye Norman, Judy Collins, Johnny Cash and the gospel singer Marion Williams, who notes simply that "it's a song that gets to the heart of men." How sweet it is, indeed.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Visit to Gorbachev

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Mikhail Gorbachev is talking in his Kremlin chambers talking courteously, gracefully and forcefully for an hour about himself and his country, mustering the strength to act as if his life, power and nation were not shattering around him.
He also acts as if he does not know that he has bitter enemies who are waiting for him to leave the Kremlin's protection, some of them waiting in prison. But of course he must know. 
 He says important things that he has not said before except to his intimates. He says he has accepted the verdict of the people and the republics that a commonwealth -- not a state, not a nation, but a concept -- will replace the country he ruled.
But he wants a role in it; he says he can help. He says he does not believe dark dictatorship will return. But then, he says calmly that authoritarianism may be necessary to prevent destabilization.
As he talks he knows what his visitors do not -- that within a few hours he will sit down with the man who wants to drive him from that suite of offices forever. Boris Yeltsin is coming. It turns out Mr. Yeltsin's message is that all that remains for him is a pension.
Sitting around his table are about 25 Russians, other Europeans, and Americans attending a conference on "The Anatomy of Hatred" -- a title that encompasses xenophobia, racism, anti-Semitism, religious fanaticism. It has been organized by the much-respected magazine Ogonyok and one of the few men for whom Mr. Gorbachev and other holders of high office find time -- Elie Wiesel, Nobel Peace Prize laureate.
Listening to Mr. Gorbachev, I think of somebody not there, a former K.G.B. general who had unexpectedly appeared at the conference. Maj. Gen. Oleg Kalugin gave a little talk on fighting hatred, which coming from any top officer of the K.G.B., present or former or perhaps in between, did not move me, except to slight nausea.
In September the general appeared on the "MacNeil/Lehrer" program. He said something so important that I took a transcript with me to Moscow. There he suddenly was, so I read out a passage in which he said he had "certain reasons" to believe that the K.G.B. "may have something about Mr. Gorbachev, which we do not know yet exactly what" but that might make him "dependent" on the K.G.B. or "vulnerable" to it. The general said one day it might be used against Mr. Gorbachev by the K.G.B. -- particularly by its former chairman, Vladimir Kryuchkov, in a cell awaiting trial as a member of the three-day coup. The general said Mr. Kryuchkov did know exactly what.
The democracy-loving general said he still thought that would happen. His tone was, just wait and see. In any case, the assumption here is that the coup makers, all appointed by Mr. Gorbachev, will not go quietly to life imprisonment without trying to take him along.
Also -- talk is around about Mr. Gorbachev being summoned to testify about scores of billions of dollars in foreign loans or credit that have disappeared. That is not just a threat but a justified legal step that could be blocked only by former Communist politicians of the commonwealth who might not want to be asked too many questions themselves.
But in Mr. Gorbachev's private meeting room -- two nail holes in the wall brocade show where Marx and Lenin recently looked down -- I thought mostly of how warm and courageous he was and how historically important was his decision to try to save the Communist system by opening its windows to a large measure of freedom.
But then, every time I hear myself think that I also hear what political prisoners of the Soviet system say on release -- glad, not grateful. Neither they nor, as it developed, the people ever would be grateful to that suffocating system or to a leader trying to preserve as much of it as he could.
The people felt they had the right to more freedom, and to bread too -- even sausage once in a while. He could not do that within the system and would not abandon it. That is why he is now a pebble in the shoe.
Mr. Gorbachev talked of terrible economic crisis, of growing destabilization. But he talked as if somehow he had nothing to do with it all. His enemies know he did, and are waiting. His friends know that too, but they will try to help him, when he is out of office, at least as long as they can.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: No Mysticism in Oz, Just the Populist Credo

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report on "The Wizard of Oz as a Secular Myth of America," a paper delivered by Paul Nathanson at the convention of the American Academy of Religion in Kansas City (news article, Nov. 28). Dr. Nathanson, a researcher at McGill University's Center for Medicine, Ethics and Law in Montreal, apparently views "The Wizard of Oz" as a mild blend of religion and mysticism. In fact, the book is a secular political tract firmly based in history and ideology. 
 In 1896, L. Frank Baum was a supporter of the populist William Jennings Bryan in the Presidential campaign against the eventual winner, the Republican William McKinley. The chief issue in that election was the gold standard (tight money, high interest rates) with McKinley for and Bryan opposed since it kept farmers and workers in debt, and made capital scarce for small business.
In his parable, Baum had the Scarecrow (farmer), the Woodsman (worker) and the Cowardly Lion (Bryan) join Dorothy (Everyman) in the trip to Oz, the abbreviation for ounce, the standard measure for gold. Their travel to the Emerald City to free the land of Oz involved passage along the yellow brick road (gold again) and battle with the Wicked Witch (the Eastern banking establishment).
The Emerald City is unmasked as a facade of papier-mache, not a "modern technological metropolis," and the Wizard confesses himself a common man making believe.
Unlike the 1896 election, Baum's tale has a happy ending from his point of view. Dorothy's companions gain character, defeat the Wicked Witch and free Munchkin Village, which is not "an idyllic Midwestern town," but the nation.
But then, Baum would have cheerfully left religious themes to those who seek them.
 
SAUL ROSEN
New York, Dec. 4, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: New Yorkers Don't Live in Ecological Vacuum

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"What to Do About Water" (editorial, Nov. 19) makes a commendable call for sensible, everyday water conservation measures in New York City. On Nov. 29 you report a major drought is feared as reservoirs hit lows and indirectly show that this call for conservation -- and the city's recent sequence of watch, warning and emergency -- are part of a pattern of response that arrives too little and too late for the watershed region. 
 A chart accompanying the Nov. 29 article shows a documented trend of insufficient rainfall stretching back to the beginning of 1991. Drought conditions were noted in the upstate watershed area early last summer, with many streams and wells running low or dry. Yet the official New York City response to that shortfall was delayed until late September, when the city initiated a drought watch.
This lag comes because downstate drought response is geared to reservoir levels, not natural conditions. Months of intense drought can pass while city officials wait for the prescribed reservoir levels to do anything. The result is that a Catskill resident has long stopped watering his lawn by the time a New Yorker is advised to take shorter showers.
Another result is that upstate residents watch fish kills in the heated waters of lowered reservoirs and see critical downstream water flows curtailed, while urbanites continue regularly to water golf courses and wash cars.
It is difficult for a city to be attuned to an environment that sustains it when that environment is 125 miles away. However, that difficulty is no excuse. Conservation should have begun in New York City months ago. It is both enlightened self-interest and an obligation for New Yorkers to be much more mindful of the impact that their behavior has upon the ecology and economy of their watershed regions.
 
MIKE WELSH
Assistant Director for Programs
Catskill Center for
Conservation and Development
Arkville, N.Y., Dec. 4, 1991

HEADLINE: Cuomo Says He Will Not Run for President in '92

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 20

 BODY:
After 10 weeks of tortuous public deliberation that seemed to take him to the brink of candidacy, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo stepped back today and announced that he would not run for President in 1992.
Only two months before the New Hampshire primary, his announcement gave final form to a Democratic field that had been largely overshadowed by Mr. Cuomo's potential entry. Less than 90 minutes before the 5 P.M. filing deadline for the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Cuomo told a crowded news conference in the Capitol that he could not run because of the lack of progress in negotiating a solution to the state's severe fiscal problems. 
 "It seems to me I cannot turn my attention to New Hampshire while this threat hangs over the head of the New Yorkers that I've sworn to put first," said the 59-year-old Governor as his aides looked on grimly.
 
Kept Country Guessing
 Today's announcement by Mr. Cuomo, who spent most of the day closeted in the Executive Mansion, culminated a surreal political odyssey in which the Governor abandoned his claim to have "no plans and no plans to make plans" to run and then kept the country guessing about whether he would.
The scene on the second floor of the State Capitol, where a crush of reporters waited for white smoke from the Executive Mansion, provided a fitting conclusion.
Because Mr. Cuomo acted more and more like a candidate -- he distributed economic position papers and granted extensive interviews while his aides searched for office space and plotted a fund-raising strategy -- most political strategists assumed that he was running. Still, he continued to insist that his major obstacle was a budget solution, even though a solution grew ever more unlikely as the New Hampshire filing deadline approached.
In his four-minute statement and in a lengthy question-and-answer session afterward, Mr. Cuomo said the Republicans who control the State Senate had made it impossible for him to run by stonewalling the budget talks "for their own purposes."
 
Gave G.O.P. a Veto
 Whether the budget really was the only factor blocking Mr. Cuomo's candidacy, the Governor's announcement left many people wondering why he had created a situation in which he seemed to hand the Republicans, through their role in the budget process, a veto over his Presidential ambitions as well.
The state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, said Mr. Cuomo was using the Senate Republicans as scapegoats. "After months of fence-straddling, Cuomo looked in the mirror and realized that he wasn't up to the job of running the country," Mr. Powers said.
Mr. Cuomo said today that he realized he could have skipped the New Hampshire primary, forged a budget solution and then announced for the Presidency. But he said he would follow the request of the Democratic National Committee Chairman, Ronald H. Brown, that he not do so.
"Theoretically, at a point in the future when our gap has been closed and our budget process restored to reasonableness, I could then enter the remaining primaries and still be a contender for the Presidency," said Mr. Cuomo, who is serving his third term as Governor.
"But I accept the judgment of the national chairman of our party that it would be in the best interest of the Democratic Party that I abandon any such effort now so as to avoid whatever inconvenience and disruption to the process is created by the uncertain possibility of another candidacy."
 
'You Don't Get Drafted'
 While Mr. Cuomo did not specifically rule out a potential draft, he said: "You don't get drafted for the Presidency. Whoever wins the primary ought to be the candidate."
Although Mr. Cuomo seemed impassive during his hour-long news conference, he said he regretted not having the chance to run for President. He said there were "a number of excellent candidates" in the Democratic field. And even in announcing that he would not join it, he delivered a vibrant stump speech promoting Democratic alternatives to the Bush Administration's domestic policy.
Mr. Cuomo's announcement seemed to cement the Democratic field at six major candidates -- former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts and Gov. Douglas Wilder of Virginia.
All lack the stature and name recognition enjoyed by Mr. Cuomo. But the Governor's decision to withdraw from consideration opened an important new phase of the Democratic campaign, in which one or two of the contenders can escape from Mr. Cuomo's shadow and try to break from the pack in the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 18.
Mr. Cuomo's announcement represented something of a political epiphany, not only for the the Governor, but also for the Democratic Party. It means that the Democrats enter the race against a suddenly vulnerable President Bush without two of their most dynamic leaders -- Mr. Cuomo and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.
A Cuomo race against Mr. Bush would have been problematic in many ways, and Republican strategists had boasted that the Governor's vulnerabilities would be easy to exploit. But Mr. Cuomo's formidable political assets, including his intellect and his eloquence, had convinced many Democrats that he was the party's best hope, despite the burdens of his uneven record in New York and his complex and mercurial personality.
 
Kept Family in Suspense
 Mr. Cuomo kept his family, his aides and reporters in suspense until virtually the last possible moment today. Much of the crowd jammed into Room 250 of the State Capitol had no idea what Mr. Cuomo would say when he walked to the lectern at 3:37 P.M., took a long sip of water, slipped on his metal-rimmed glasses, folded his hands and started reading his statement.
The Governor spent the day speaking with political advisers and making a last-ditch effort to negotiate a deal that would close the nearly $5 billion budget gap facing the state in the next 15 months. Cuomo aides said the Governor began to write his statement at about 2 P.M. after his chief of staff, Andrew J. Zambelli, was informed by aides to the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., that the latest round of discussions would not produce an agreement.
Mr. Cuomo's political aides had been making preparations for a campaign for weeks, including plans to meet today's filing deadline. Two chartered planes were sitting on the tarmac at Albany County Airport to shuttle Mr. Cuomo and his press corps to Concord, N.H., where he would have paid his $1,000 filing fee and announced his candidacy in front of the New Hampshire Statehouse.
In the event that Mr. Cuomo decided to run but could not make the trip himself because of timing or bad weather, a Cuomo supporter had been sent to Concord in advance with a copy of filing papers that Mr. Cuomo had already signed.
At least temporarily, Mr. Cuomo's announcement ended a political journey that began in 1984, when Mr. Cuomo's stirring keynote speech to the Democratic National Convention transformed him instantly into a potential Presidential candidate.
Even as Mr. Cuomo was passing up his second Presidential race in four years, he was asked whether he would consider running in 1996. "My mother has a wonderful expression -- between now and then a Pope will be born," he said. "It means that everything happens. Ninety-six is an eon away, at least one eon, possibly an eon and a quarter."
Mr. Cuomo was implored to run in the 1988 race by Democratic leaders and gave the race brief consideration before announcing on a radio call-in show in February 1987 that he would not be a candidate. Until a year later, when he definitely ruled out the possibility of a draft, talk continued of a host of "Mario scenarios."
By his own admission, Mr. Cuomo's decision-making process this year was far more complex. He announced somewhat casually at an Oct. 11 meeting of his fund-raising committee that he would "think about" the 1992 race, but then told reporters he had said "absolutely nothing" new.
 
Thinking, Not Acting
 Before long, Mr. Cuomo made it clear he was giving the race serious thought and was being treated as an unannounced candidate.
But Mr. Cuomo insisted from the beginning that he did not feel he could run if he could not craft a resolution to the state's worsening budget problems, although his language varied on what form the solution had to take.
He continued today to resist accusing the Republicans who control the State Senate of deliberately sabotaging his Presidential plans by refusing to reach a budget agreement.
"I'm not going to assume that anybody had perverse motivation," he said. "I'll leave that to God and their conscience."
But he made it clear that he felt the Republicans were obstructing the budget process. "The Republicans have responded to every reasonable offer of compromise with new and predictably unacceptable demands, making it apparent that they believe at least for the moment that their own purposes are best served by pushing the state closer to the brink of disaster," Mr. Cuomo said.
The State Democratic Chairman, John A. Marino, who was directing the planning for a Cuomo campaign, threatened vengeance against the Republicans who, he said, had thwarted Mr. Cuomo. He placed the greatest blame on Ralph Marino, to whom he is not related, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Long Island Republican, who came to Albany this week to denigrate Mr. Cuomo's fiscal abilities. Mr. D'Amato and all legislators face re-election next year.
"I'm going to make sure next November that voters remember what the Republicans did this December," Mr. Marino said. "Al D'Amato will be history. Ralph Marino, a two-bit Republican politician from Nassau County who is Al D'Amato's puppet, and his friends are going to pay a price."
While disappointed New York Democrats sought solace in revenge, national Democratic figures said that Mr. Cuomo's second unconsummated flirtation with a Presidential campaign might leave a bitter political aftertaste.
"If he had wavered and run, people would not have remembered," said Geoffrey Garin, a Washington-based Democratic political consultant who is not aligned with any of his party's candidates. "The only thing people would have remembered would be the candidacy that followed the process. Now all they're left with is the process. And the process was unattractive."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Photographers standing in front of an unused lectern yesterday outside the Statehouse in Concord, N.H., where Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was expected to speak if he had arrived there to enter the New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
Doing Unto Others in Christmas Season

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
It will be a different kind of Christmas for the Cardall family of Salt Lake City. All this week, they have been down in the basement, sorting and packing clothes, shoes, kitchen utensils, blankets and toys donated by friends and neighbors for two orphanages in Mexico.
Today, 10 Cardalls will pile into the big Chevy Beauville van and a pickup truck and begin the 2,500-mile round trip to Chihuahua. 
 "We decided to spend the money we would normally spend for gifts and traditional trappings to pay for gas and motels and food," said Duane Cardall, a correspondent for KSL television news, the CBS affiliate in Salt Lake City. Mr. Cardall and his wife, Margaret, will be making the trip with seven of their eight children and a son-in-law.
Though nobody keeps figures, there are undoubtedly thousands of people like the Cardalls, determined to keep Christmas in their own way regardless of what the culture urges on them. But sure as God made Super Nintendos, such people remain a tiny minority.
Increasing their number is the aim of an organization called Alternatives, founded in 1973 as a protest against the commercialization of Christmas.
It produces videos, posters, Christmas play scripts, inserts for church bulletins, and a book, "To Celebrate," a kind of Whole Earth Catalogue of ideas about keeping holidays in ways that are simpler, serener, truer to their religious character and more concerned about reaching out to the poor and powerless than keeping a list of who is naughty or nice.
There is a danger here of becoming a politically correct Grinch, a Scrooge of altruism.
Alternatives recognizes it, and though it is occasionally guilty of venial earnestness, it steers clear of Puritanical hostility to holiday merriment. Indeed, the problem it assails is that "when Christmas does come, it often finds us spiritually, emotionally and financially exhausted," the joy of the season shadowed with "vague feelings of guilt about misspent energy and resources."
That is from "Whose Birthday Is It, Anyway?" an Aternatives brochure stuffed with family Advent services, small-scale suggestions about gift-giving and lists of charities and self-help crafts groups.
With three full-time and two part-time employees, Alternatives operates out of an old general store in Ellenwood, a hamlet 20 miles south of Atlanta. The nonprofit group was begun by a former civil rights worker, Bob Kochitsky, and now receives support from several Christian denominations.
The sagging economy has been bad for Christmas sales but good for Alternatives. Kathryn Munnell, the organization's director, said she had met a great many people who had wanted to change the commercial emphasis they put on Christmas but did not feel they could do it. "The hard times give them a practical reason," she said.
But what happens when good intentions confront the world of shopping malls, Ninja turtles, adolescent peer pressure and harried adults? Just start with a few telephone numbers of churches, religious orders and individuals who purchased Alternatives' materials. Very quickly one bumps into little dramas of quiet virtue, uncertainty, ambivalence, regret, everything but complacency.
 
'Taking in Strays'
 There is Patti Gatti, a Roman Catholic who teaches a morality course to juniors at Our Lady of Victory girls' high school in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Mrs. Gatti, who has been a lifetime member of a Bronx parish, steers her students into working for the homeless and has a weakness, her two children say, for "taking in strays" like an unmarried mother and a student struggling with a drug problem.
Does Mrs. Gatti manage a different kind of Christmas? "I can't honestly say that," she replies.
Richard Stanley is a volunteer, not just at Christmas-time but all year round, at the same Dobbs Ferry project where Mrs. Gatti's students often work, the Midnight Run, an effort by churches and synagogues throughout Westchester to collect food, clothing and blankets for the homeless and distribute them at about midnight three nights a week in New York City. His wife, Patricia, has overseen the packing for the Midnight Run for years, and their son Ben, now 10, has been doing his part since the age of 5.
"The commercial Christmas is not particularly appealing to me," said Mr. Stanley, an assistant chancellor at New York University and a member of St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, N.Y. He has talked to relatives "about trying to gear things down a bit" but met a poor reception. "People equate love and strong family feelings with the commercial efforts," he said.
 
Unease on the East Side
 At the Brick Presbyterian Church on Manhattan's East Side recently, a handful of youngsters from fifth to eighth grade intently watched an Alternatives video about Christmas. The video takes up many topics, from the nature of celebration to the impact of the Industrial Revolution and advertising on holidays.
What seized the attention of the students, all enrolled in some of Manhattan's most exclusive private schools, was a brief segment depicting the stress and demoralization that commercial Christmas can produce for poor children and their families.
"It's kind of depressing -- families who don't get anything," said Walter Masterson, an eighth grader. Laura Worth, a seventh grader, added, "I felt spoiled."
But Laura manages to articulate what was clear from the students' faces, that they also felt uneasy. "I know you shouldn't buy as many as we do, but presents are fun," she said. It's a jump from Manhattan's East Side to the old school house in a cornfield near Palmyra, Mich., where the Bertrams live. "The question goes deeper than celebrating an alterntive kind of Christmas," Mary Bertram said. "It's a question of a whole view of how you live."
 
Change After Volunteering
 The Bertrams found their way of living changed when they volunteered to work two years in Costa Rica building houses with Habitat for Humanity. Now Bob Bertram, who resigned from the Roman Catholic priesthood, manages housing loans as an officer of the Farmers Loan Admininstration.
The Bertrams have four children, ages 9, 11, 15 and 16. Gift-giving is important in their household, which combines her Mexican-American heritage with his German-American customs. But the gifts are small ones, often given throughout the 12 days of Christmas, from Dec. 25 to the Jan. 6 Feast of the Epiphany. They include coupons promising personal favors like washing dishes for someone.
The Bertrams' Christmas shopping list usually has around 25 people, relatives and godchildren, Ms. Bertram said, and a budget of about $200. Advent wreath ceremonies add to the liturgies the Bertrams hold weekly in their home all year round.
In October, after much discussion, the family bought a computer system for $1,900. "Was it a Christmas present or not?" Ms. Bertram wonders. She approves of the purchase but can not quite forget that it cost as much as two houses would in Central America.
Since 1986, Beverly Fawcett has been going home to Bethel, Conn., for Christmas from her volunteer work at the Holy Trinity School, run by Episcopalian sisters in Port au Prince, Haiti.
 
Gifts in Earlier Times
 In previous years she has arrived with a Santa's pack full of gifts from Haiti for her four sons and other relatives -- "beautiful things," she said in a tone that practically pulsed with enthusiasm for a troubled nation she has come to love deeply. The gifts were modest but this year, she said, they will not even be that.
Her Christmas expenditures will go instead to assure the graduation of a young woman from a Port au Prince nursing program. Ms. Fawcett's relatives will receive cards with a photograph of the aspiring nurse, Gladys Francois, who grew up in a Port au Prince orphanage and who, Ms. Fawcett said, "glows with happiness and is so thankful in the midst of nothing."
One might think that a 59-year-old woman who had given five years of her life to working in Haiti could assume she had certain prerogatives. "But you feel so guilty if you do anything different," Ms. Fawcett said. "I came home thinking, 'Oh my God, all I've got is these cards.'
"I found myself going to the mall, and then I said, 'Oh nuts, if people are not satisfied with this, that's not my problem.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We decided to spend the money we would normally spend for gifts and traditional trappings to pay for gas and motels and food," said Duane Cardall, center, who leaves today with his wife, Margaret, and other family members in Salt Lake City to take clothes and other items to orphanages in Mexico. (Ravell Call for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FED CUTS KEY RATE IT CHARGES BANKS TO A 27-YEAR LOW

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
In a bold move to revive the slumping economy, the Federal Reserve chopped its bedrock discount rate today by a full point, to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest level since 1964.
The surprisingly big cut was seen as part of a broad effort to stimulate borrowing and perk up an economy whose signs of recovery from recession have all but vanished. The discount rate is what the Federal Reserve charges on loans to banks but its significance is in the message it carries to the financial markets and businesses and consumers. 
 In addition to cutting the discount rate, the Federal Reserve also signaled today that it had cut a second key interest rate, the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other on overnight loans. That rate also fell more than expected, by one-half percentage point, to 4 percent, instead of an anticipated one-quarter point.
Taking the cue, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company quickly slashed its prime lending rate to 6 1/2 percent from 7 1/2 percent, and many other big banks followed, including Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Chemical, Manufacturers Hanover and First National Bank of Chicago.
Because the prime rate is used as a benchmark for many kinds of borrowing, including home-equity loans and other adjustable rate mortgages, such cuts benefit both consumers and businesses, which widely hailed today's moves.
 
Cheaper Mortgage Expected
 The rate cut is also expected to put some downward pressure on rates for conventional mortgages. If mortgage rates were to drop a quarter point, for example, this would mean the monthly payment on a $200,000 loan would fall by $36. Since January 1991, rates for fixed-rate mortgages have fallen from 10 percent to what John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, predicts will be 8 percent by next month, a saving of $288 a month. For an adjustable-rate mortgage, which he expects will fall to 6 percent from 8 1/2 percent over the same period, a borrower would save $338 a month.
Savers, however, will be hurt by today's cut in rates, as banks within days further shrink the interest rates they pay on new certificates of deposit, and yields fall similarly for money market funds.
The bond and stock markets surged today, but the dollar fell in world currency markets as lower interest rates made American investments relatively less attractive.
Describing the discount rate cut, the Fed stated: "The reduction was made on the basis of cumulating evidence, notably monetary and credit conditions, as well as current economic conditions, that point to a receding of inflationary pressures." It said this move, "together with the cumulative effects already in train from previous actions, should provide the basis for a resumption of sustained economic expansion."
The White House has repeatedly urged the Fed to relax monetary policy, and President Bush, whose standing in public opinions has been plummeting over his handling of the economy, called the discount-rate cut "a significant step" that will help to create jobs. "I commend this latest Federal Reserve Board action, which will significantly help our efforts to turn the economy around and get America back to work," he said in a statement.
Democrats in Congress generally welcomed the moves, but several chided the Fed for moving too slowly. "He should have done a point two months ago, three months ago," said Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, referring to the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan. Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, head of the Banking Committee, said the action "reflects their anxiety."
A Federal Reserve spokesman said the decision, approved by a 6-to-1 vote, was made at a meeting of the board of governors called on short notice for Thursday evening. One Wall Street specialist said that such sessions were highly unusual and that this one was particularly remarkable in that it came only two days after a meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's chief policy-making body.
The discount rate cut was the biggest since December 1981, when the rate dropped to 12 percent from 13 percent. The move carried the rate to a level exactly half that of the 7 percent at which it stood as recently as mid-December 1990.
Time and again over the last year the Fed has cut both its administered discount rate and the overnight private market rate over which it exerts substantial control. But its gradual approach has not succeeded in pulling the economy out of the recession that began in July 1990. Activity did pick up during the summer and early fall -- resulting in modest growth of gross domestic product for the second and third quarters.
The Commerce Department today published its second revision of American gross domestic product for the third quarter -- the total output within the nation's borders -- putting it at a negligibly higher 1.8 percent annual rate instead of the 1.7 percent announced Dec. 4.
But the fragile rebound seems to have crumbled in the last several weeks. Among other things, confidence has eroded, the job market has worsened and retail sales have stagnated.
While there had been talk earlier this month that the Fed might do something emphatic to jolt the economy to life, Mr. Greenspan left the impression in an appearance before the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday that he would continue a policy of gradualism.
 
Signaling the Fed's Intentions
 It was not entirely clear today whether the Fed made its decision to ease more aggressively at Tuesday's Open Market Committee meeting or whether the move was prompted by subsequent events, like the report on Thursday morning of a big jump in first-time claims for unemployment insurance and the unexpectedly sharp increases that German authorities posted for their discount and Lombard rates. The German anti-inflation move, which is expected to slow economic growth in that country, could lead to reduced demand for American exports, one of the few sources of strength.
The Fed governor Wayne D. Angell dissented from the discount-rate decision, which the Fed said was instigated by the regional banks in New York and Chicago. Mr. Angell's office said he would not comment on his rationale.
But a summary of policy actions of the Nov. 5 Open Market Committee meeting published today showed Mr. Angell to have been one of two members voting against an easier policy adopted at that time and confirmed in a discount rate cut the next day.
 
Dissent Among Fed Governors
 "Mr. Angell dissented because he was concerned about the impact of further easing on inflation expectations and consequently on long-term interest rates," the record for that meeting showed. "In his view, the prospect for a robust and long-lasting recovery is dependent on the completion of adjustments in business pricing practices, household savings and balance sheets more generally. Monetary policy actions that are perceived as a shift from a focus on price-level stability to one on short-term economic growth may well abort the needed adjustments."
The other dissenter on Nov. 5 was Edward W. Kelley Jr., who cited the still unseen effects of earlier stimulus and the "considerable risks" that further easing would fuel fears of higher inflation. Since then, however, inflation has continued at a subdued 3 to 3.5 percent pace and the economy has deteriorated further.
Today's action means various real short-term interest rates -- actual rate less inflation rate -- are barely positive. Analysts have noted that, while interest rates have come down across the entire spectrum this year, long-term yields in particular have remained fairly high in real terms. That is, 8 percent mortgages at a time of 3 percent to 3.5 percent inflation means real rates of 4.5 to 5 percent.
The discount rate cut, announced at 8:30 A.M. today and effective immediately, was the sixth in the past year. At 3 1/2 percent, the rate is the lowest since November 1964, when it was raised to 4 percent from 3 percent during the military buildup in Vietnam. No official records are kept of the Federal funds rate, but one Wall Street specialist said he believed it had not been as low as 4 percent since 1963.

HEADLINE: End to Cambodian Embargo Seems Near

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Bush Administration appears to be on the verge of lifting a United States embargo on Cambodia that has been in effect since 1975, when Americans fled the advancing Khmer Rouge and their brutal restructuring of the nation.
Members of Congress, who have been urging the Administration to end the embargo since a Cambodian peace accord was signed in Paris on Oct. 23, say an announcement may be made to coincide with President Bush's trip to Asia beginning Dec. 30. The State Department says only that action is expected "in the near future." 
 With the decision this week by the Treasury Department to relax a ban and allow American travel agents to arrange tours to Vietnam, lifting the embargo on trade with Cambodia would open the way for American business to return to Indochina for the first time since the end of the Vietnam War.
Trade restrictions against Vietnam, whose Government Washington does not yet formally recognize, are being discussed in a working group of United States and Vietnamese representatives. The United States has maintained diplomatic relations with Laos, but trade has been minimal.
 
Unease About Khmer Rouge
 In the House and Senate, there is disquiet among both Democrats and Republicans over what is described as an overly passive American policy on Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge, backed by China, remains the strongest of four Cambodian factions now linked in an interim governing council, and elections for a new government are not expected until 1993 at the earliest.
No efforts have yet been made to disarm the factions. A United Nations coordinator for all programs in Cambodia, including disarmament of the groups and resettlement of their civilian followers, has not been named.
Representative Chester G. Atkins, Democrat of Massachusetts, says the United States will bear great responsibility if the Khmer Rouge becomes a renewed threat, since Washington and the Chinese have insisted on a role for the faction in the peace process.
Mr. Atkins, who serves on the House Appropriations Committee, says that when Administration officials approach Congress in the new year with requests for millions of dollars to pay for American commitments to the rebuilding of Cambodia, they will be pressed for an unambiguous policy opposing a role for the Khmer Rouge under the faction's current leadership.
 
Lawmakers Write to Bush
 "One single clear and continuing theme in United States policy to Cambodia has been our insistence on the inclusion of the Khmer Rouge in the interim Government," Mr. Atkins said in an interview today. "That is really quite astonishing. It sent an enormous signal to the Cambodian people that the killing fields could very easily happen again."
Early this month, Mr. Atkins persuaded 56 Senators and 247 Representatives to sign a letter to President Bush asking that the Administration lend its weight to actions insuring that the Khmer Rouge cannot return to power in any part of Cambodia.
The letter also asks President Bush to support an international tribunal to try the Khmer Rouge leadership for genocide. More than one million Cambodians died during a reign of terror by the radical Communist movement from 1975 to late 1978.
"Every day's delay by President Bush in lifting the trade embargo on Cambodia benefits the Khmer Rouge," Senator Alan Cranston said in a statement issued today.
Vietnam and Cambodia, two of the world's poorest and least developed nations, say an end to American economic sanctions would be critical to their economic growth.
John Gunther Dean, the last American Ambassador to Cambodia before the Khmer Rouge takeover, said this week in an interview that the United States had a special responsibility to help the Cambodians rebuild in safety.
"A lot of people look at us and say, 'What's the U.S. going to do?' " he said. Mr. Dean was lobbying as an envoy of Unesco, which is seeking aid for educational and cultural projects and establishing Cambodia's's first free press.

LENGTH: 585 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Fed Rate Cut
In a bold move to revive the economy, the Fed chopped its discount rate by a full point, to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest level since 1964. The surprisingly big cut was seen as part of a broad effort to stimulate borrowing. The Fed also signaled that it had lowered the Federal funds rate by half a point. [Page 1.] 
 The Fed's striking action may have been a desperate attempt to wrest control of the economy back from the politicians. To many authorities, Greenspan was basically saying to the politicians: "I'm in command. Trust me." News Analysis. [1.]
From chief executives to car dealers, business people across the country welcomed the rate cut as a confidence-building gesture that should help revive the sluggish economy. [43.]
The Economy
The U.S. economy grew at a modest annual rate of 1.8 percent in the summer as consumer spending and the nation's trade performance showed slightly better gains than previously believed, the Government said. [43.]
The nation's travel industry is preparing for a bleak winter, as Americans plan fewer and shorter vacations. [7.]

Dow Corning Wright kept breast-implant data from the F.D.A. and the public, an F.D.A. panel member said. [8.]

Japanese mini-vans are being "dumped" in the U.S. market, the Commerce Dept. said in a preliminary ruling. But the agency said they were not being so underpriced as auto makers had contended. [33.]

A battle for control of Maxwell Communication erupted after an English court appointed three partners of Price Waterhouse to be administrators of the company. Also, the lawyer for many banks with loans to the company suggested that some current executives might have been involved in transferring assets. [33.]

Markets

Stocks closed broadly higher in the heaviest trading in nearly a year, as investors took the rate cut by the Fed as a signal that it was serious about jolting the economy to life. The Dow advanced to 2,934.48, up 20.12 for the day and the week. [36.]

HEADLINE: Winter Vacation Forecast: From Bleak to Cloudy

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
If "a sad tale's best for winter," as Shakespeare put it, the nation's travel industry is preparing to tell a bleak one.
In a sputtering economy, fewer Americans than usual are planning winter vacations. And for those lucky enough to get away, economic necessity is forcing many to stay closer to home and return sooner than they would have wanted. 
 Even with big discounts, fewer people than expected will be taking winter flights to Europe or Hawaii, or cruises to the Caribbean.
 
Splurging on Nothing
 In a recent survey of 200 American Express travel agents in major cities, nearly 70 percent said their clients were economizing on hotels and airfares, taking shorter vacations and traveling closer to home. Asked on what their clients planned to splurge, 42 percent of the agents replied, "Nothing."
"Even if the numbers of vacationers aren't down a lot," said Jerry Cheske, a spokesman for the American Automobile Association, "we're hearing they'll be spending less, cutting costs and looking to economize."
The prospect of a grim winter, the second in a row for the travel industry, spells trouble not only for the industry but also for the economy in general. Tourism is the leading industry in 13 states, according to the Travel and Tourism Government Affairs Council, and the second or third in 24 others.
Americans and foreign visitors spent more on travel and tourism in 1990 -- $327.3 billion -- than on anything but automobiles and food from the supermarket, the National Travel and Tourism Awareness Council, a coalition of 10 organizations from government and private industry, reported last week. With 5.9 million workers in everything from to amusement parks to car rental offices, the travel and tourism industry is the nation's third largest employer.
 
$2 Billion Loss Expected
 But at the moment, that employer is reeling. The nation's airlines said recently that they expected to lose almost $2 billion this year, on top of the record $4 billion they lost in 1990. And 60 percent of the nation's hotels are reporting a net operating loss, said Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm.
And travel agencies have been bludgeoned by the recession; Travel Agent magazine says 2,300 agencies closed or went bankrupt through the first nine months of this year, as against 1,600 for all of 1990.
When Americans were asked in a recent survey by the 20,000-member American Society of Travel Agents to list their favorite vacation destinations, 6 percent of the respondents listed "visiting relatives."
"It's the first time such a designation ever showed up in the poll," said Courtney Froemming, a spokeswoman for the organization, "and it appears directly related to the economy."
 
A Nontraveler's Lament
 David Kenney, a bookstore clerk in Northampton, Mass., went with his girlfriend to New Orleans for Mardi Gras last year, and the year before they visited San Francisco. Although still in the same job, "This winter I can't even afford a ski weekend in Vermont," he said. "Everything is just so much more expensive, especially in the Northeast."
What makes this winter's preliminary indications doubly disappointing, industry executives say, is that winter vacations have become more popular in recent years. Last year winter vacations accounted for 18 percent of all vacations by Americans, as against 60 percent in the summer.
This change is mostly because frequent short vacations are better suited to households in which both partners work. And having been battered last winter by the Persian Gulf war, the industry expected an explosion of pent-up demand this winter.
Unless there is a dramatic turnaround soon, that does not seem likely.
In Hawaii, despite a promotion drive and what travel agents say are some of the lowest air-land package deals in years, visitors from the mainland will fall below expectations.
"The first quarter of the year is always our best," said Clem Judd, president of the Hawaii Hotel Association. "But from what we can see this will not be a strong winter, because consumers on the mainland don't yet have confidence in the economy."
Similarly, the outlook is uncertain for some popular Florida tourist spots.
"Based on what I can see, we're looking at a sluggish winter season," said Stu Blumberg, the president of the Miami Beach Resort Hotel Association. "We'll probably come out about the same as in 1991, but that was not a great winter."
 
Lower Hotel Rates Likely
 In Orlando, which averages more than 13.6 million visitors a year, "the word 'recession' is on few lips," one hotelier said, "but on everybody's mind." That is because, with demand soft, rates for Orlando's 77,300 hotel rooms are expected to average $2 to $3 less this winter than last.
In part because attendance was down this year even at Walt Disney World, Disney -- to the surprise of some other Orlando merchants -- agreed to participate in Magicard, a promotion offering discounts of 10 to 50 percent for about 80 attractions, hotels and restaurants in the area.
"We made it available in mid-May via a '900' number that cost the caller $3, the price of printing, handling and mailing the card," said John Rutherford, the public relations director of the Orlando Convention and Visitors Bureau. "By the end of June we had to switch to a toll-free '800' number, because there was virtually no response. People wouldn't pay the three dollars. Since then we've distributed about a half-million cards."
The picture is no less discouraging out West.
"We think we're going to have a winter much like last year, flat to some extent," said Pat Tierney, director of the Tucson Convention and Visitors Bureau in Arizona.
 
Bets Are Off in Vegas
 And not even Las Vegas is immune.
"The recession may not have a heavy impact here, but it will have some impact because we're not recession-proof," said John Reible of the Las Vegas News Bureau, an arm of the Chamber of Commerce. "We probably won't get the occupancy rate we would otherwise, and some of the long-distance trippers probably won't come."
Even the fact that San Diego will be the host city for the 1992 America's Cup races, beginning next month, seems not to have had a major impact on tourism to that city.
"There appears to be an extremely high level of caution among travelers," said Tom Vincent, chairman of the San Diego Hotel and Motel Association. "People aren't booking rooms ahead of time like in the past. I can only guess a lot of people are concerned that if they take a vacation they won't have a job when they get back."
Inevitably, some parts of the travel industry are predicting a good winter. The North American cruise ship industry is projecting a 10 percent growth next year, said Jim Godsman, president of the Cruise Line International Association. But the increase is not as great as the industry expected, and the industry is small -- about four million passengers this year, as against the estimated 450 million people who will fly on domestic airlines this year. Moreover, its growth is being fueled in part by discounts as high as 50 percent.
 
Economizing at Ski Resorts
 Ski resorts in New Mexico and Colorado report higher bookings than last winter. But a larger percentage of visitors this winter will be from neighboring states, officials there say, and their stays will be shorter.
Colleen Murphy, the corporate communications director of the Book-of-the-Month Club in New York, said she and her husband, Ervin, are going to Utah for a week in March to ski. Even so, they will be watching expenses.
"We chose it because we got a good deal on it, and it was cheaper than going to the islands," she said. "But we have a kitchenette to avoid the added cost of eating at restaurants. In fact, we plan to take along a lot of Grape-Nuts."
Industry executives now say the industry is unlikely to pull out of the doldrums before next summer. Until then, they might take comfort in other words from Shakespeare in "The Winter's Tale":
I must be patient till the heavens look
With an aspect more favorable.

HEADLINE: Third-Quarter Growth Put at Revised 1.8% Rate

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The United States economy grew at a modest annual rate of 1.8 percent in the summer as consumer spending and the nation's trade performance showed slightly better gains than previously believed, the Government said today.
But analysts said the modest improvement in the gross domestic product did not change their view that the economic recovery stalled during the summer, raising the very real possibility that the economy has toppled back into recession in the current October-December quarter.
 
Ups and Downs
 The new G.D.P. report made a change of one-tenth of a percentage point in an estimate released two weeks ago, which put growth at an annual rate of 1.7 percent in the third quarter. 
 This followed growth of 1.4 percent in the April-June quarter, which in turn had followed two consecutive quarterly declines in G.D.P., reflecting the recession that began in July 1990.
The return to growth in the G.D.P. had caused the Bush Administration to declare the downturn at an end. But weak statistics in recent months have raised fears that the recovery has faltered and the recession has returned full force.
Today's revisions showed that the economic weakness has kept inflation well under control. A price index tied to the G.D.P. rose at an annual rate of just 2.1 percent in the third quarter, down from gains of 5 percent in the first quarter and 3.1 percent in the second quarter.
The new-found strength came primarily in consumer spending, where purchases of electricity and gas rose because of colder weather in the Midwest, and in the country's trade performance, where the growth of exports was revised slightly upward.
 
Debate Continues
 The small revision really offered no surprises and did little to settle the debate over what the economy will do in the current quarter.
Today's G.D.P. report was the second appearance of the Government's new measurement for the overall economy. After a half century, the G.D.P. is replacing the gross national product -- a move welcomed by most economists as providing a better barometer of how the domestic economy is doing.
The difference is that the G.D.P. measures output within the nation's borders while the G.N.P. includes profits earned by American companies on their overseas subsidiaries.
The new report said the G.D.P. was increasing at an annual rate of $22 billion in the third quarter, $1.7 billion higher than previously estimated.
While economists said the small gain in exports was heartening, they said consumer spending on discretionary purchases was revised downward and initial reports for the fourth quarter have shown further weakness.
