HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: Long Island - A special report;
After Decades of Prosperity, Long Island Confronts a Stagnant Economy

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHPAGE, L.I., Dec. 20

 BODY:
Long Island residents are beginning to learn that they just can't have it all.
The island, frequently listed in surveys in the 1980's as one of the country's most desirable spots, is struggling now, not just with the effects of the national recession that have battered states throughout the Northeast but also with stubborn home-grown problems that will make it harder to bounce back when the region's recovery begins. 
 "All of the ingredients that made Long Island such a success in the 1980's have petered out," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "All the key engines have stalled or gone into reverse, and as a result what you're left with is a lot of question marks."
Here in Bethpage, the Grumman Corporation, the center of a once-massive defense industry, has laid off 9,000 people, or a third of its Long Island workforce, since 1987. Around the Island, more than 90,000 people are out of work, so that in 1990 -- for the first time ever -- Nassau and Suffolk counties lost more jobs than they gained. Businesses are failing; unemployed workers are stuck with houses they can't sell, and the Island's young people are fleeing, looking for a better life someplace else.
"This happens to be the worst recession Long Island has experienced since the end of World War II," said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "Some of the reasons are beyond the scope of Long Island to solve, but there are plenty of locally induced reasons."
 
Residue of 80's Growth
 Many are direct results of the rapid growth in the 1980's: an overburdened, outmoded transportation system; burdensome taxes; energy, housing and garbage-disposal costs that are among the highest in the country; a Byzantine structure of overlapping, inefficient governments, and a growing rift between environmental and economic interests that tends to discourage business and stall development.
In the high-flying 1980's, residents and businesses were willing to overlook, or at least accept, these problems. Maybe costs were high, but so was employment, so were salaries, and so was that important suburban intangible: quality of life. Now the equation is out of balance, and planners say Long Islanders must lower their expectations about living the good life.
 
Unrealistic Aspirations
 "People aren't realistic about what it takes to sustain a culture," said John H. Marburger, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "People's aspirations about life style are too expensive to be sustained with what we have now in the economy."
Even as Long Island's economy suffers from New York City's white-collar layoffs, the employment numbers on the Island itself look bleak. In a place with an exceptionally skilled labor force, where the median family income was $46,475 in 1989, the unemployment rate climbed to 6.8 percent in September, compared to 4.1 percent a year earlier and 3.4 percent in September 1988. "A good part of that reflects the downsizing of the defense industry, but the recession has really touched all sectors of the economy," said Pearl S. Kamer, the chief economist for the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
Among the worst-off sectors are manufacturing, which lost 24,500 jobs between June 1989 and June 1991, construction, which lost 9,700 jobs, and trade, which lost 22,500 jobs. Things are so bad that Gary Huth, an associate economist at the New York State Labor Department's office in Hicksville, pointed to the Federal Government's decision to extend jobless benefits to the long-time unemployed as one of the few positive things that promise "to provide a substantial income shot into Long Island."
 
From Despair Comes Hope
 Of the 32,000 Island residents who have exhausted their jobless benefits since the end of February, about 22,400 are probably still out of work and eligible for an extension, Mr. Huth said. "It's not the same thing as having the situation changed by having jobs created, but it would add a healthy boost of about $50 million into the economy," he said.
The recession has all but halted building on Long Island. In the construction industry, which has been one of the mainstays of the Long Island economy, more than half the workforce of 60,000 is unemployed, said David Richardson, business manager of the Building and Construction Trades of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which represents 52 unions. He and other industry leaders say the problem is not just the banks' unwillingness to lend money for new construction, but also the Island's dauntingly tangled bureaucracy, which has discouraged growth even in good times.
"It has made the whole question of economic growth on Long Island an enormously complicated thing," said John V. N. Klein, a former Suffolk County Executive who is chairman of a group seeking ways to reduce the tax burden. Pointing out that the Island has some 660 different taxing jurisdictions, from counties to sewer districts, he said that in some places, one piece of real estate could be in 15 taxing districts at once -- each with its own zoning codes or permit requirements.
"The intricate processes of approval that the localities have built up over the years turns people off," he said. "Twenty years ago, it would have taken less than a month to get approval for, let's say, an industrial building. But now it may take a year to 18 months. It is the bureaucratic characteristics of the local governments that make it happen that way."
 
Environment
Battle to Preserve A Rural Character
 The Island's increasingly powerful environmentalists take a much different view. Worried about damage to the area's fragile underground water supply and concerned that Suffolk County will go the way of densely developed Nassau, they say that what ails Long Island is too much development, not too little. Combining forces with civic associations and other local groups, environmentalists have successfully delayed or helped cancel project after project, from a huge shopping mall in Brookhaven to a segment of the Long Island Expressway service road in Syosset that was planned by the state to help ease traffic congestion.
The environmentalists say they are not obstructionists and not zealots, but rather people who care about the Island's future. "The spate of new environmental regulations and environmental lawsuits is the result of the effect of overdevelopment taking its toll on Long Island, both environmentally and economically," said Richard A. Amper, executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, which is involved in a lawsuit seeking to block development in a large swath of Suffolk County.
Planners like Dr. Koppelman say that many environmentalists have legitimate concerns about untrammeled growth. But, Dr. Koppelman said, their agenda is increasingly set by a small group he describes as people "masquerading as environmentalists who really want to stop the world."
 
Battle Over Airport
 There is little common ground between many of the most active environmentalists and business leaders. Last month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came to the Island with a plan to boost the economy that included a study of the development of Calverton Airport in Suffolk County, a project that would allow Long Island businesses to ship cargo by air rather than using congested highways.
While business groups reacted positively to the announcement, the area's most prominent environmentalists said development of Calverton would poison one of the Island's most fragile areas.
"At a time when Mario Cuomo needs to demonstrate vision and leadership, his plans for the future of Long Island promise heavy debts to subsidize a clique of development interests," said Van Howell, a spokesman for the Earth Island Center of Long Island, in a news release denouncing the proposal.
 
Industry in Transition
Learning to Adapt Without Defense
 Even as the environmentalists and business leaders seem to grow further apart, the Island is painfully trying to find something to replace the dying defense industry, which fueled growth through most of the boom years. At its peak in the 1940's and the 1950's, defense accounted for about half the jobs on Long Island; in 1988, the figure was 25 percent and falling fast.
"We're seeing a change in the economic base, with a downsizing of the defense industry that's more than cyclical," said Pearl S. Kamercq, the planning board's chief economist.
Beyond the changes at Grumman, where the workforce has been reduced to 13,000 from a peak of 36,000 in the late 1960's, many of the Island's smaller companies and subcontractors have closed shop, moved away or tried to diversify into non-defense areas.
The results have been mixed so far. "We don't know yet whether the subcontractors or other companies will be successful in switching their work to civilian industries -- that's a big if," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Many business leaders point to the fledgling biotechnology industry as one hope for the future, calling it a natural match for the island's talented labor pool, good educational facilities and first-rate research centers like the State University of New York at Stony Brook and Brookhaven National Laboratory.
 
Housing
For the Young, Few Cheap Homes
 But experts on planning say that to attract and keep new industry, Long Island is going to have to do something about some stubborn basic problems.
One of the most pressing is the lack of affordable housing, which is driving away many of the Island's young people who would otherwise make up its future workforce. Dr. Koppelman estimates that by the end of the decade Long Island will need 100,000 units of affordable housing to meet the demand.
There is no lack of older, higher-priced homes on the Island. In the early 1980's, real estate prices rose so fast that from 1981 to 1985, many houses had doubled in value. There are now thousands of houses on the market on Long Island, many owned by people desperate to find a cheaper life someplace else. But at a median price of $165,900 in Suffolk County and $209,500 in Nassau, many of the homes are beyond the price range of workers in their mid-20's.
But instead of building cheaper houses, developers built office buildings, which by 1990 had a vacancy rate of 20.4 percent.
Businesses say they don't need new office space; they need new houses for their workers.
 
Barriers to Growth
 "Businesses have said time and time again that their reasons for locating somewhere else or not coming or not expanding are the high cost of home ownership, high real estate taxes and high utility costs," said Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, which works to develop affordable housing.
Mr. Morgo said that two things were stymying the construction of affordable housing: restrictive zoning laws and residents' own reluctance to accept clustered housing like rental homes or condominium developments -- a reluctance that have the effect of pricing their own children out of Long Island's housing market.
"Many people still have the Long Island mindset that they want houses on at least a quarter of an acre with a yard and a picket fence," he said. "And it's really shocking to see how many people can't afford to have that."
To Mr. Morgo, an attitudinal change is needed. "People have to know that increased density does not mean the urbanization of Long Island," he said.
 
Doing Business
Worry Over Taxes And Bureaucracy
 It is a given, by now, that Long Island is one of the country's most expensive places to live, because of the combination of state and local taxes, retail prices and energy, housing, and transportation costs. In the past, there was always enough business here to provide the tax base needed to sustain the high level of services in school districts and local governments. But now, the story is a sadly familiar one: even as Federal and state money dries up, the tax base is shrinking, government is making painful cuts, and taxes are rising. And businesses are moving out, having concluded that the equation that always showed Long Island was worth it has now tipped to the other side.
Many officials say there is a growing sense that the Island is anti-business. They cite the case of the Olympus Corporation Scientific Products Group, a subsidiary of a Japanese-owned company. Based in Lake Success for the last 24 years, Olympus, with about 600 workers on Long Island, has spent four years looking for a place to build a new $40 million headquarters on the Island -- a project that would create jobs and pump money into the economy and provide a badly needed lift to the sagging construction industry.
The company has considered some 25 sites in half a dozen communities, but none has panned out, said Richard Kester, a senior vice president. In some cases, civic groups raised objections about increased traffic and other environmental issues. In other cases, he said, it became clear that the zoning was so restrictive that it was useless to even try.
It's not that Olympus doesn't want to stay on Long Island -- it likes the highly skilled workforce and has longstanding ties here. But, Mr. Kester said, if the process drags on, the company will be forced to move away. It has already installed its manufacturing operations in Albuquerque. "They were extremely excited to get us, and they greased everything through the system," Mr. Kester said.
Environmentalists continue to argue that what makes Long Island great isn't business, but the shore, the air and the land. Tourism is one of the most important industries on the Island, they say, adding that for Long Island to thrive, it has to put even further restrictions on business and development.
"The solution lies in accommodation of the environment by otherwise self-serving interests," said Mr. Amper of the Pine Barrens Society. "We live on an island with finite resources, so an economy that's based on unrestricted building isn't going to be sustainable anyway, no matter what the environmental consequences."
But he is fighting with increasingly tough opponents from business and government, who say the answer is fewer restrictions, not more. "We need fundamental, radical change in the relationship between business and government," said Bruce Nyman, supervisor of the City of Long Beach in Nassau County. "We took the business community for granted all these years and kept responding to our constituents' wishes, and we forgot that without a strong business base we can't support our residents."
 
Need for Reorganization
 He and others who are studying Long Island say that it is has reached a crucial juncture. "They've got to reorganize," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at New York University. "For Long Island to succeed, there will have to be a massive reorganizing to reduce costs. There's going to have to be strategic decisions to put in high density at certain points."
The traffic problem has to be addressed, too, experts say, through a combination of road improvements, support for suburban bus lines and the encouragement of staggered work hours and carpooling. New development must take place, they say, but in a measured way, with a focus on rehabilitating the older structures built during the 1950's.
And, perhaps most important, planners say that a new and perhaps less selfish attitude has to emerge.
"There's still a recognition that this place is desirable," said Mr. Kunz of the Regional Planning Board. "And public opinion is turning around and saying, 'The economy isn't doing so well, so we're going to have to make some improvements.' You can't say no to everything."

HEADLINE: Diplomats Without a Country;
Life After the Fall: Representing Neither Soviet Nor Union

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

 BODY:
For Alexander Denisov, spokesman of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations, the rudest reflection of his country's disintegration came not from Washington, but at a discount electronics shop in Manhattan.
He went there a month ago to buy a stereo receiver, and was shocked when the salesman turned down the tax exemption card he carries as a diplomat. 
 "I cannot accept this card," the salesman said. "This country doesn't exist anymore."
"I didn't like the joke," Mr. Denisov recalled. "I said: 'Mind your own business. This card was good enough for the State Department; it's good enough for you.' " Even now, Mr. Denisov's face tightens at the memory.
Smart alecks aside, diplomats and other functionaries of the former Soviet Union say it has been disorienting, at times frightening, to see their country dissolve and redefine itself amid confusion and the threat of famine these last few months. In a scene probably mirrored in embassies and missions around the world, Moscow's envoys have endured unimagined humiliations and uncertainties as the Soviet Union's status has fallen from superpower to international basket case.
Yesterday, they were taken aback by the unilateral seizure by President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Kremlin and takeover of the Foreign Ministry in Moscow the day before. Yuri Chizhik, a press attache, said the mission would handle Mr. Yeltsin's orders as it had the failed putschists who grabbed power from the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in August.
"We refused then to pass on their decrees to the United Nations, and I think the same sort of thinking will guide us in this," Mr. Chizhik said.
Diplomats here wonder whether the Soviet Foreign Ministry will be replaced by a Russian Foreign Ministry, or a ministry of the coalition that may be created at today's meeting of leaders from the Kazakhstan meeting of European and Asian republics.
"Last week was different from today," Mr. Chizik said. "Yesterday was different, and next Monday will be dramatically different."
 
Life Without Certainty
 For now, the envoys dwell in hybrid worlds, speaking the language of democracy and the free market, but still living behind a steel fence at their compound in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and displaying the red flag inside their mission.
At the mission on 67th Street, the shelves in the visitors' waiting room still offer pamphlets dutifully reporting meetings of the Communist Party, now defunct. In vintage Cold War fashion, two surveillance cameras, one of them hidden, continue to record visitors. Yesterday morning a young Russian flashed an obscene gesture at one of them.
"K.G.B.," was his brief explanation.
Being a Soviet diplomat used to be easier, when a diplomat could confidently chart his Government's position opposite Washington's.
Now a kind of gallows humor appears to sustain morale at the mission, where the 150 employees -- diplomats, secretaries, drivers and maintenance workers -- count thousands of relatives back in the Soviet Union.
They are not even sure what to call their home country.
"Until the new entity is internationally accepted, we're still the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, although there is no union, no soviet, no socialism and no republics," Mr. Denisov said. "That's the paradox we live with today." He said that legally the republics of the Soviet Union are states.
 
Loyalty to Moscow
 He made sure a visitor noted that the lights were still burning and the heat turned on at the mission. Then, paraphrasing Mark Twain, he said, "The reports of our death are greatly exaggerated."
Day by day, Mr. Denisov and others have watched the underpinnings of their identities slip away.
"I came here as a representative of the Soviet Foreign Ministry, and that does not exist anymore," he said yesterday.
At the age of 54, he imagines he may well have to look for another job when he returns to Moscow later this year. But he cannot envision a job out of government.
"When I left my country there was no private sector," he said. "I just don't have any idea what it is."
Like Mr. Denisov, Yuri Romantsov, the new chief of the Tass bureau at Rockefeller Center, does not know what to call his home country -- so he tries to avoid sentences in which he would normally use its name.
In the temporary absence of a country, Soviets here said they think of home as Moscow, the city most of them left for New York. And those who are native Muscovites, like Mr. Romantsov, think of home as Russia.
The job of correspondents for Tass, faithful mouthpiece of the ruling Communist Party now turned news agency, has changed also. Yuri Kirilchenko, a 34-year-old correspondent in New York, said he no longer had to send classified reports on political and economic trends to high-ranking officials in Moscow. "Now we have declassified this information and made it available to everyone in the form of booklets," he said.
He worries about another kind of distortion in the rapid about-face going on in Moscow. Under the old system, his editors especially wanted stories about the depravity of capitalism, and so Mr. Kirilchenko offered a stream of articles about the homeless and hungry of New York.
But on a recent visit to Moscow, he spoke to a group of teen-agers who wanted to know what it was really like here. "I honestly told them about everything I saw, but when I tried to tell them I really saw homeless people by Radio City, their reaction was skeptical," Mr. Kirilchenko reported. "They said, 'Come on, do you really expect us to believe that crap? You're just giving us propaganda again.' "
He understood, all too well, the skepticism. For Mr. Kirilchenko, as for many of his compatriots in the former Soviet Union, yesterday's masters have become today's villains. Now the Tass reporter has a calendar hanging in the gray cubicle where he works. It is a reproduction of "The Return of the Prodigal Son," a nightmarish painting by the Russian nationalist artist Ilya Glazunov. It shows the great figures of Russian history -- Pushkin, Peter the Great, Catherine the Great -- sadly gazing at a Russia pillaged by 73 years of Communist rule, something that Mr. Kirilchenko played no small role in upholding.

HEADLINE: A Move to Break World Trade Deadlock

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, Dec. 20

 BODY:
After five tense years of negotiations over liberalizing world trade, the head of the world's principal trade organization sought to break the deadlock today with a proposed agreement that calls for cutting subsidies to farmers worldwide, phasing out import quotas on third-world textiles and giving more protection to patents and copyrights.
In piecing together the complex 500-page document, Arthur Dunkel, Director General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, sought to present, on a take-it-or-leave-it basis, a package of compromises that would set rules for world trade well into the 21st century. In effect, he cast himself as a binding arbitrator, hoping that GATT's 108 nations will go along, even though no nation would get everything it wanted.
 
Success Is Uncertain
 Mr. Dunkel is betting that the promised benefits of this complex agreement will be enough to persuade nations to ignore the intensive lobbying of the many special-interest groups that oppose certain provisions. But whether he will succeed is far from certain. Some negotiators said tonight that the continuing dispute over farm subsidies could torpedo the whole package. And on Thursday, even before Mr. Dunkel's plan was distributed, France's Agricultural Minister said his nation would seek to bury the Dunkel draft because he assumed it would go too far toward meeting Washington's demands to cut the subsidies. 
And the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, issued a statement shortly before release of the complete text that was markedly more cautious than her stance at the beginning of this week. "It is important to emphasize that the Director General's document is only a draft; it is not a finished legal text," she said.
Mrs. Hills had warned on Monday that while changes to Mr. Dunkel's proposals would be possible, "if one party tries to change one thing and there's a rush to change, you're going to have the agreement unravel."
Still, at GATT's headquarters in Geneva, many trade officials said today that Mr. Dunkel's plan stood a good chance of being approved by the nations involved in the talks.
Mr. Dunkel's draft agreement calls for creating a stronger mechanism to settle trade disputes and for granting banks and other financial service companies greater access to foreign markets. His plan would also make it harder for governments to grant subsidies to industry, which give companies in some countries an advantage over their competitors.
GATT officials say the accord would save consumers worldwide tens of billions of dollars a year. But farmers in Europe and textile workers in the United States are lobbying against the agreement, saying it threatens their livelihood. Some American drug companies complain that the accord does not give them enough protection against patent violations by third-world countries; banks in India and Singapore fear the agreement will make it too easy for big Western banks to enter their markets.
"Everyone will try to change the package, but all their efforts will neutralize each other," said Tran Van Thinh, the European Community's chief GATT negotiator.
Mr. Dunkel released his draft agreement hours after American and European Community officials broke off their talks, without agreement. The two sides have been unable to agree over how much to cut the $300 billion in subsidies that farmers receive each year worldwide. The United States, Canada, Argentina, Australia and other food-exporting nations have been pressing for sharp cuts.
The five-year talks, known as the Uruguay Round because they began in Punta del Este, Uruguay, were originally scheduled to end last December. But the impasse over farm subsidies blocked completion.
After considering Mr. Dunkel's draft, senior trade negotiators are supposed to return to Geneva on Jan. 13 to complete an agreement and hammer out the unresolved details.
GATT officials hope to schedule a final meeting in April, possibly in Morocco, where trade ministers would sign the trade agreement.
The draft accord would help developing countries by phasing out over 10 years the multifiber arrangement, which allows wealthy industrial countries to set strict limits on imports of third-world apparel. The Bush Administration had wanted a longer phase-out period, but third-world officials say restrictions on their textile exports have long held back their growth.
The plan also calls on the developing world to phase out over the next decade their violations of foreign copyrights and patents.
Mr. Dunkel's draft makes a nod to Japan by creating more specific rules for what a country must prove to find another country guilty of "dumping" -- the practice of selling goods below cost or below what they sell for in a domestic market. Japan has been accused by the United States and the European Community of dumping various goods, most recently mini-vans.
At the same time, the plan makes concessions to the United States and the European Community by establishing rules that allow them to crack down on factories that are said to circumvent dumping laws by bringing in low-cost parts and doing a bit of final assembly so the products are not considered imports.
Many economists and government officials say success in the GATT talks could provide some much-needed impetus to the world's languishing economy. They also say the talks are important for Eastern Europe and the developing world, whose economic crises can be alleviated if they obtain greater access to foreign markets.
 
Bush and Major Conferred
 In the last week President Bush has talked with Prime Minister John Major of Britain and other European leaders, trying to give the talks the impetus they need to succeed. In Brussels, the United States Secretary of Agriculture, Edward Madigan, discussed farm subsidies with the European Community's Farm Commissioner, Ray MacSharry of Ireland.
American officials say they are near agreement on how fast to cut farm subsidies: cuts of 30 to 35 percent over five or six years are being debated. But differences remain over what the base period should be, how much subsidized exports the community should be allowed to have and the community's demand to be allowed to reduce some farm imports to offset losses in exports it may suffer because of cuts in export subsidies.

HEADLINE: Newman Helps Make Neediest's Day

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Fueled by a generous contribution from Paul Newman's food company, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund soared past the $2 million mark in total contributions yesterday.
The $100,000 donation from Newman's Own Inc. combined with a $20 check from Arpy Kashmanian of Forest Hills, a $100 contribution from June Danielson of New Rochelle, N.Y., and hundreds of other gifts enabled the Neediest Cases to post its biggest day this year: $178,187.37. 
 But the 80th annual appeal is falling steadily behind last year's pace. Starting off on Thanksgiving Day with $16,000 less than the 1990 campaign, this year's drive now stands $115,000 behind last year's total as it enters its most critical period.
From Dec. 21 to Jan. 10 last year, the Neediest Cases received $1.52 million in contributions. Put another way, more than one-third of the $4.4 million contributed in the yearlong campaign, was recorded in that three-week period.
Many other charities are reporting similar difficulties. Donations are down 7 percent at The Children's Aid Society, while the Diocese of Brooklyn reports that unsolicited contributions have fallen 30 percent.
Although governments provide some relief, fiscal pressures have led many states to drastically cut programs that provide emergency cash assistance to avoid homelessness and hunger, according to a report issued Thursday by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and the Center for the Study of the States, an affiliate of the State University of New York at Albany.
Nonprofit groups, like the seven charities supported by the Neediest Cases, report great increases in requests for food, rent assistance and clothing. The United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, for example, has provided a record amount of money -- more than $900,000 -- this year for homelessness prevention.
To help those families the federation has used money provided to them by the Neediest Cases. Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then the publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled. The newspaper covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected is passed on to the seven charities.
Contributions like the one from Mr. Newman's company indicate that some see today's economic problems as a challenge to give more. In the letter attached to the check, A. E. Hotchner, executive vice president of Newman's Own, wrote: "It seems to Paul and me that, when times get tough, it behooves those who are doing well to increase their efforts to help those who aren't, rather than to pull back. If there was some way to communicate this spirit to the affluent, it might help fill the void which is being felt so keenly this Christmas."

HEADLINE: Fed Cut Explosive for Bonds

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices in the credit markets exploded and short- and long-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board lowered the discount rate by a full percentage point, to 3 1/2 percent.
The cut in the discount rate, the biggest in a decade, was followed later by confirmation that the Fed had also pushed down its target for the overnight Federal funds rate by half a percentage point, to 4 percent. 
 The move stunned and delighted credit market participants as well as stock traders. Over the last few days, both markets had come to the reluctant conclusion that the Fed would delay another round of cuts in short-term rates for several weeks.
Aside from the timing of the announcement, traders and analysts were surprised by the size of the cut. Based on recent statements by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, few credit market participants had any reason to suspect that the next rate reduction, when it came, would be more than a modest half-point cut in the discount rate and a quarter-point cut in the funds rate.
 
'Gift Beyond Comprehension'
 "For most people, this is a gift beyond comprehension," one government bond trader said.
Over the near term, analysts said that most of the beneficial impact of the Fed's move would be seen in further reductions in heavy debt borne by corporations and individuals.
The fact that many commercial banks followed the Fed's lead and lowered their prime lending rates by a full percentage point, to 6 1/2 percent, will help in that process, analysts said, since many consumer borrowing rates are tied to the prime.
"Moving rates a percentage point is going to wake a lot of people up," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. "I heard several people say they were definitely going to refinance their mortgages now."
Most of the explosive reaction to the Fed's move came within an hour after it was announced yesterday morning. Traders said that with Christmas approaching, most market participants deserted their desks shortly after midday.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 104 30/32 , up 29/32 , to yield 7.57 percent, compared with 7.65 percent late Thursday and 7.76 percent on Dec. 13.
 
Secondary Market
 In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 103 7/8 late yesterday, up 29/32 , to yield 6.95 percent.
Yields on the new two-year and five-year notes sold earlier this week also fell.
The 6 1/8 percent five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 6.03 percent. And the 5 percent two-year notes were offered in when-issued trading at a price to yield 4.83 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates plummeted.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 3.70 percent late yesterday, down 32 basis points, or 32 one-hundredths of a percentage point. Three-month rates have not been this low since May 1972. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 3.81 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by 27 basis points, to a late offered rate of 3.90 percent.
The Fed's stunning move did not immediately create a stampede among corporations to refinance old debt or to offer new debt issues. That is not likely to take place until sometime in January, participants in the investment-grade corporate bond market said.
One company that did take advantage of the huge rally was the Commercial Credit Corporation, which offered $200 million worth of four-year notes at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Lehman Brothers won the securities.
The 6 3/8 percent notes, which mature Jan. 1, 1996, were reoffered to investors at a price of $99.774 to yield 6.44 percent, 83 basis points over the prevailing yield on Treasury securities of comparable maturity.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Oscar A. Ornati, 69, Economics Professor

 BODY:
Oscar A. Ornati, an economist who focused on poverty, discrimination and the social responsibility of businesses, died on Sunday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan.
He died of complications of cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Ornati taught 25 years at New York University and became chairman of the Management Department at its Stern School of Business. Earlier he worked on housing and developing affirmative-action programs at the United States Office of Economic Opportunity in 1965 and 1966.
Working as an arbitrator, he helped settle a printers' strike at The New York Times in the 1960's. He also advised the postal workers' union. Among the issues he studied were the minimum wage, wage-and-price controls and finding jobs for the poor. Last year he developed an index of employment in 24 regions of the country.
Born in Trieste, Italy, he came to America in 1939. He served in the Army in Africa and Italy from 1943 to 1945. After the war he earned his bachelor's degree from Hobart College and a master's and doctorate at Harvard University. He taught at Cornell University and the New School. He received a Fulbright Fellowship and the Order of the British Empire.
He is survived by his wife, Marilyn Lifshitz; three children, Lee, Susan and Molly, all of Manhattan, and a sister, Margherita Rasoli-Roth of Genoa, Italy.

HEADLINE: The Cuomo Money Morass: $5 Billion and No Quick Fix

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The fiscal morass that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo cited today as his reason for staying out of the Presidential race consists of gaps totaling at least $5 billion in the current and the next state budget. The Legislature has not made any headway in closing either, despite six weeks of intensive negotiations here.
But while a Cuomo candidacy was widely seen as a new dynamic that could have made resolving the problem even more difficult, there was little immediate sense today that the converse might be true: that a decision not to run would automatically pave the way for an agreement. 
 Minutes after all the drama came to an end and the Governor made his announcement, the Democrats who control the Assembly met to pass their plan to close the $875 million gap in this year's $30 billion budget, which they said relied on significantly less borrowing than the package advanced by the State Senate.
But the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., quickly condemned the Assembly program as "an unacceptable Band-Aid solution" and complained that it "raises taxes, relies on fiscal gimmicks and contains no real welfare or Medicaid reform."
 
And Now, Vengeance?
 And Mr. Cuomo, who angrily lashed out at the Republicans for what he described as their obstruction of previous efforts to forge an accord, went all of a minute and a half into his announcement before he talked of summoning the Senate back to Albany on Monday to hammer away again at budget talks.
Given that the Republicans did not help Mr. Cuomo to strike a deal in time to meet his deadline for entering the New Hampshire primary, there has been considerable speculation here that the Governor might strike his own vengeance now. He could hold out for a tough program of cuts in suburban school aid and other programs whose protection by the Republicans has been a cornerstone of their ability to hold onto their Senate majority. They are all running for re-election next fall; Mr. Cuomo is not.
The Governor did not say whether he would now pursue new and harsher remedies for the state's ills. But significantly, he seemed to cast considerable doubt on whether he would be willing to work with the Senate any more on a 15-month stretched-out budget.
This plan, which would simultaneously attack both deficit problems, would have freed the Governor to hit the campaign trail. It remains attractive to the Senate, in large measure because it could blunt the pain of many of the cuts the Legislature would have to make now to cut the current budget deeply enough to produce a balance in its remaining three months.
 
Like Talking About a Diet
 But without ruling the plan out, Mr. Cuomo struck a contemptuous tone toward the Senate at his Capitol news conference when he was asked whether it remained on the table.
"The 15-month plan is where it has been from the beginning," the Governor said, "a wonderful, wonderful idea. 'I'm going to lose weight.' There's a terrific idea. Thirty pounds. Wonderful. That's in this category. They say, 'Let's lose 30 pounds.' Meanwhile, you're eating sundaes and you're eating heroes. You're not going to lose 30 pounds, and that's where the 15-month plan is."
The discipline Mr. Cuomo was referring to would be the ability to decide now on spending cuts and other actions that would carry well into 1993. Given the crisis atmosphere that has become the hallmark of budget-making in the Capitol -- where the Governor and the Legislature have failed, for seven years in a row, to fashion budgets by the legal deadline -- there certainly has been plenty of skepticism here that they could agree on a plan, in effect, months ahead of time.
The heart of the dispute remains the insistence by the Senate that the cuts focus on the expanding state spending for Medicaid and welfare, up nearly 20 percent over the past year, in large part because the recession has swelled the rolls for these programs.
 
'Don't Look Back'
 Both the Governor and the Assembly have condemned many of the Republicans' proposals for cutting these services as an attack on the poor, and faulted others for containing what they say are excessive estimates of savings.
Aside from the budget battle, left very much intact today, there was clear regret written on the faces of many of his aides during his announcement this afternoon, which came just 90 minutes before the deadline for entering the New Hampshire primary. The excitement of working for a potential Presidential nominee behind them, they now turn back to the exhausting task of budget-cutting.
Another disappointed bystander was the state's Lieutenant Governor, Stan Lundine, who would have largely run the state in Mr. Cuomo's absence and would have become the Governor had Mr. Cuomo become President. But he sought to cast his discontent less a matter of personal loss than of larger regret.
"I think he's a great American," Mr. Lundine said. "I think he'd be a great candidate; I think he'd be a great President. But you make decisions at the appropriate time. Today he felt was the appropriate time, so he's made a decision. And now, you don't look back."

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Japan 'Dumps' Mini-Vans

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The Commerce Department issued a preliminary ruling today that Japanese mini-vans were being sold for less than fair value in the United States. But the agency said they were being underpriced by less than Detroit's auto makers had contended.
The ruling that the Japanese were "dumping," as the practice is known, came as the United States trade deficit with Japan is increasingly becoming a political issue in the approaching Presidential primaries. Hours before the Commerce Department delivered its verdict, several Democratic leaders in Congress from car-producing states proposed legislation to limit Japanese auto makers' sales in the United States. 
 The ruling also came as Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, President Bush's close friend and future chairman of his re-election campaign, has arranged for the chief executives of the Big Three to accompany the President on his planned trip to Japan, New Zealand, Australia and Singapore.
The Commerce Department declined to comment on whether Mr. Mosbacher played any role in today's decision. Similar suits have been resolved by having junior officials plug the prices of each part and other expenses into an elaborate computer model and then wading through the printouts.
Most of this process is determined by law, although many decisions must be made along the way, such as which parts are considered standard equipment and the expenses associated with large volume sales to auto rental companies. Commerce secretaries have traditionally avoided participating in these many small decisions because rulings in trade cases often become the basis of extensive legislation.
The preliminary ruling today found that a duty of 7.19 percent should be imposed on imports of the Mazda MPV and a duty of 0.95 percent on the Toyota Previa. Both companies must pay these duties either in cash or by posting a bond until the issuance of a final ruling, expected on May 31. The International Trade Commission, an semi-independent agency that reports to both the Congress and the President, would then have to certify by July 15 that the Japanese imports were also financially hurting the American companies before permanent duties could be collected.
The United States recession has resulted in heavy losses for American car makers and made it easier for them to prove that such injury occurred. Detroit's high profits in the late 1980's had discouraged the Big Three from filing trade cases until now.
Any other Japanese company that enters the United States mini-van market before the final ruling comes out will be charged a duty of 4.23 percent, which is a weighted average of the Mazda and Toyota duties.
 
Victory Is Claimed by Mazda
 Mazda claimed victory in today's ruling, pointing out that Detroit had sought duties of nearly 30 percent. Detroit auto makers said they welcomed the ruling but hoped that the final determination next year would result in higher tariffs.
Anti-dumping cases of the sort brought by the Big Three this year against Mazda and Toyota are allowed by legislation that seeks to prevent foreign companies from using profits in their home countries to subsidize exports until they cripple competitors or drive them out of business. But some economists contend that anti-dumping legislation is a way for powerful industries to win protection at the expense of consumers, who benefit from low-priced imports.
Today, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri; Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, and four other representatives from Michigan announced that they would introduce legislation imposing limits on imports of Japanese cars if the bilateral trade deficit does not fall enough.
The six legislators from car-producing states called for a cap on most sales of cars made by Japanese companies. The cap would include not only imported cars but also some of the cars produced by Japanese-owned factories in the United States.
The bill bears some similarities to the proposal Mr. Gephardt made as a Presidential candidate in 1988, and the heat of today's rhetoric was reminiscent of that campaign. Jobs in the auto and auto parts industries "are the ladders families in America climb to reach for the American dream," Mr. Gephardt said.
The Administration greeted the proposal coldly. Mr. Mosbacher told a press briefing at the White House that he understood the frustration of Congress with Japan's persistent trade surpluses. But he added, "The way to do this is by letting Japan know that they're out of step, as far as a trading partner, with the rest of the world, and we hope and believe that they will see it's time to do it, not to mandate it legislatively."
The Japanese Embassy in Washington also criticized the plan. "The introduction of the unilateral measures or the introduction of artificial quotas are not welcome," Hiroshi Hirabayashi, the embassy's deputy chief of mission, said at a news briefing today. "It's against the interests of not only the exporters but also the consumers of importing countries."
 
Legislation Prospects Unclear
 Prospects for the legislation are unclear, particularly as long as General Motors maintains its recent uncertainty about whether to seek legislative responses to the success of Japanese car imports. Although Mr. Gephardt and his colleagues have been drafting today's bill since February and consulted with the auto companies repeatedly, General Motors said in a statement today that it was not ready to comment on the legislation because it needed time to study the document.
By contrast, Toyota immediately criticized the bill for including some cars produced by the Japanese in the United States. The bill would "force lay-offs by labeling work done by American employees at the newest and most productive auto plants in the U.S. as 'foreign' labor, pitting one American community against another," Toyota's American subsidiary, Toyota Motor Sales, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: A Fed Grasp For The Reins

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
The striking action of the Federal Reserve today in pushing the interest rates it directly controls to their lowest levels since the 1960's may have been a desperate attempt to wrest control of the economy back from the politicians.
For almost a decade, the dominant view in Washington has been that the astronomical budget deficit means that the White House and Congress have no leeway to cut taxes or increase spending, the normal Government response to bad times. Only the Federal Reserve through its monetary policy, the thinking went, could keep the economy on its feet. 
 But the Fed's steady decrease in interest rates since 1989 seems to have been inadequate. And recently, within the central bank and among economists across most of the ideological spectrum, the sense has been growing that President Bush and the Democrats who control Congress would try to fight the recession next year with a pre-election bidding war over tax giveaways.
The result, these experts fear, could be a new spike in the deficit, already approaching a stratospheric $400 billion this year, a situation that could cause serious long-term damage to the economy.
Testifying Wednesday before the House Ways and Means Committee, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, conceded that earlier this year he had miscalculated the strength of the economic recovery and said that the economy now was clearly struggling. But he cautioned the legislators against a "quick fix" and encouraged them to let the business cycle run its course.
To many authorities, by cutting the discount rate a full percentage point, the largest one-day drop in more than 10 years, Mr. Greenspan was basically saying to the politicians: "I'm in command. Trust me."
The theory may have been that such a large rate reduction would convince the public and politicians that someone in the Government was taking bold steps to address the economic misery.
Still, it may be too late to head off the politicians. Under President Bush, the nation's economy has grown a total of less than 1 percent in the last three years, the slowest three-year run in almost half a century except for the back-to-back recessions in 1980 and 1982. Democrats and Republicans alike have urged the Federal Reserve to act more forcefully. But until today, Mr. Greenspan had insisted on incremental reductions in interest rates, a quarter of a point or half a point at a time.
Now the politicians seem determined to move first thing next year. Incumbents simply cannot sit silent when their constituents are troubled. They must fire their ammunition even if the target is out of range .
This illustrates the difference in the world views of politicians and economists.
The White House and Congress, on the verge of an election year, look at what was announced this week: General Motors said it would close 21 plants in the United States and Canada over the next few years and eliminate more than 70,000 jobs; industrial production, one of the main measurements of current business activity, fell by an unanticipated four-tenths of 1 percent in November, and housing starts are off by so much that the worst year for home builders since World War II is a cinch.
The politician's instinct is to try to drive the country out of recession by cutting taxes and increasing consumption. Consumption, incidentally, is already running at about 67 percent of the country's total production, close to an all-time high.
Economists, who do not have to worry about elections, look at the numbers and see a relatively mild recession. "It's hard to see what all the shouting is about," said Benjamin M. Friedman, a professor of political economy at Harvard.
 
A Matter of Perception
 The real problem, in the view of Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Friedman and most other economists, is that the long-term prospects for the economy are poor unless the deficit can be reduced and savings, investment and productivity increased. The despair the politicians observe, these economists say, is caused not by the sharp pain of relatively few people today but by the nagging fear of many millions, perhaps justified, that they will not do as well as their parents and that their children will be even worse off.
So the economists believe it would be foolish for the President and Congress to approve a package of politically popular but probably counterproductive measures to give the economy a quick kick but cause long-term weakness.
No one on the outside knows what goes on in the Federal Reserve's board room. But the speculation around the capital and on Wall Street is that Mr. Greenspan, who has close ties to the Bush Administration, had wanted to move more aggressively for some time but had been thwarted by other members of the Reserve Board.
As evidence, those who hold this view observe that Wayne D. Angell voted against today's rate cuts and that two other members -- John P. LaWare and Edward W. Kelley Jr. -- have dissented in other instances recently. A fourth member, David W. Mullins, said in a speech last week that the economy was really not so bad, on balance. The other two members, Susan M. Phillips and Lawrence B. Lindsey, did not join the board until last month and cast their first votes this week.
One of the most politically savvy economists around, Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, suggested in an interview that the Federal Reserve's moves today might help head off ill-advised legislation by giving cover to politicians who do not want to shoot from the hip.
One such politician, Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, thought it might indeed bolster his position. "If it pushes down long-term interest rates," Mr. Panetta said today, "it is my hope that Congress and the President will be able to focus on measures to promote long-term economic growth rather than a short-term quick fix."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 20.12, to 2,934.48, in Busy Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed broadly higher yesterday in the heaviest trading in nearly a year, as investors took the Federal Reserve's rate cut as a signal that it was serious about jolting the economy to life. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced to 2,934.48, up 20.12 points for the day and the week.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 318.4 million, barely eclipsed by the 318.9 million shares traded on Jan. 17, the day after the Persian Gulf war started. There were nearly twice as many advancing issues as losing ones on the Big Board: 1,138 to 618. 
 Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president and head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers, said yesterday's market was a little more than technical. It was not only influenced by the "triple witching" -- the expiration of options on individual stock, index and futures contracts during the last hour of trading, but also by the Fed's cut in the discount rate, he said, adding, "And it was difficult to figure which played the more important role."
The New York composite was up 2.22, to 213.13, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.52, to 387.04. On the American Stock Exchange, the composite rose 0.62, to 367.22.
Trading on the Nasdaq was also active and moved the composite up 1.23, to 535.76, while the Russell 2,000, an indicator of smaller issues, slipped 0.13, to 176.07.
Traders said buying was seen across most of the market, particularly in issues influenced by interest rates.
Wall Street stocks surged at the opening on news that the Fed had lowered the discount rate by one percentage point, to 3 1/2 percent.
Some analysts doubted that the rally could be sustained, citing the triple witching, which normally adds volatility to trading, and year-end selling by investors for tax purposes. In addition, they said the cut in the rate, the largest since 1981, would increase concern over the economy.
With the discount rate now at its lowest level since 1964, stocks eased off session highs but remained firm through the day, as a strong bond market added support.
The rate cut "clearly indicated that the Federal Reserve is deeply concerned about the failure of the economy to make a recovery," said Hugh A. Johnson, a senior vice president of the First Albany Corporation.
Elsewhere in the market, Nicolet Instrument said it expected its stock price to recover after investors assess the company's statement that its fiscal 1992 year-end earnings will not reach the previously expected record levels. Trading was halted yesterday at 1:58 P.M. for about a half-hour on order imbalances, meaning that there was an excess of buy or sell orders that was almost impossible to match with its opposite. The stock closed down 4 3/8, at 11 7/8.
Traders said Scimed Life Systems, which makes coronary angioplasty catheters, rose 5 3/8, to 73 1/2, after it reported better-than-expected results for the third quarter. Scimed said that excluding a $28 million charge from the settlement of patent litigation with Eli Lilly, the company's operating profits had more than doubled.
A number of analysts raised their ratings and earnings estimates for the company yesterday.
Lockheed fell 1 3/8, to 43 5/8, as Steven Binder, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, cut its rating to "avoid," from "hold," traders said.
In other activity, Amgen and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation both gained, as they will both soon be added to the S.& P. 500 index. Amgen rose 2 to close at 60 1/4, and Freddie Mac gained 4 1/8, to 108 3/8.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toys 'R' Us Opens Doors in Japan

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Toys "R" Us opened its first store in Japan today, and judging by the 17,000 people who showed up, an American company may have finally found a weapon to crack the formidable Japanese market. It's called children.
In the first half-hour after the doors opened at 10 A.M. in the suburban hamlet of Amimachi, 1,500 people arrived, many of them mothers and grandmothers led by their pint-size charges. They made their way through the gymnasium-size structure, eyeing the Barbie and Ken dolls, battery-powered fire engines and Pampers lining aisles nearly as wide as many residential streets in Japan. 
 The layout is nearly identical to most of Toys "R" Us's American stores, with one big difference: shoplifting is so rare in Japan that there are no hidden cameras and few other security measures.
"I get disoriented from all of this merchandise," said a young father, who appeared on one of the numerous evening news programs highlighting the opening. "There's too much."
The warehouse-like approach and big discounts of the Paramus, N.J., chain are revolutionary for the consumer-backward Japanese retailing industry. Retailing here is tied up by a labyrinthine distribution system that forces consumers to pay among the highest prices in the world.
"This is a breakthrough for Japan," said Takayuki Suzuki, a retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch Japan and a former department store executive. "It is going to make one of the most backward parts of the economy more efficient."
For Toys "R" Us to win approval to put its store in Amimachi, about an hour and a half from Tokyo by train, took a three-year battle with everything from national laws to protective local business councils. Bitter trade negotiations between the United States and Japan also played a part.
More than a third of the 15,000 products in the store are imported -- though not all from the United States -- far more than in the average Japanese toy store. The company expects that figure to increase to 50 percent shortly.
There is still some heated opposition to the changes. Small toy merchants in some instances have slowed the opening of what the company hopes will be 100 stores over the next decade and have forced reductions in the size of the sites.
In some ways, Friday's Toys "R" Us opening has turned the tables in the trade wars, with Japanese companies now charging that a big, well-financed foreigner was forcing them out of business with predatory methods.
"Honestly speaking, I have to say I am mad at them and what they are doing," said Akira Namba, executive secretary of the Japan Association of Specialty Toy Retailers. "They press for everyone to do things the American way."
 
Dealing With Manufacturers
 One key to the Toys "R" Us formula is that as the largest toy retailer in the world, it has the muscle to go around wholesalers and deal directly with manufacturers. That cuts costs and gives it a big competitive advantage, something unheard of in Japan. It was considered a watershed when Toys "R" Us secured an agreement from Nintendo, the booming Japanese computer game company, to buy direct.
The company says more than 50 other Japanese toy makers have made similar deals and that others will in time, which may sound the death knell for smaller merchants that cannot offer the variety or discounts of Toys "R" Us.
"Look, this isn't the first time we're meeting a lot of these people," Robert C. Nakasone, the company's vice chairman, said of the Japanese toy makers. "I think we're going to be able to resolve all of these issues very favorably."
Still, what it took to open the store is an important illustration of what really causes change in Japan and who generally benefits the most.
Unquestionably, American pressure on the Japanese Government forced an easing of the laws that had made it extremely difficult for retailers to open large stores, and the no-nonsense executives of Toys "R" Us were among those giving the negotiators the most encouragement.
 
Bush Coming to Next Opening
 So proud are American officials of this achievement that President Bush is expected to fly next month to the opening of Toys "R" Us's second Japanese store, in western Japan near the historic city of Nara.
But what made the American pressure so effective was that many Japanese Government officials were already convinced that the changes were needed. The vocal battling by the United States during what was known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, or S.I.I., talks, helped the Japanese bureaucracy overcome domestic resistance from entrenched smaller merchants.
"Before, we had a proposal for these changes, but without a timetable," said Hajime Furuta, director of the Distribution Industries division at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. "S.I.I. gave us a timetable. Because we had already discussed this at length, we had a good idea of what we wanted to do."
Of course, those areas where there is no such common interest are the ones in which the Japanese fight hardest and give the least ground to the United States.
 
Benefits for Japanese
 Although it is little discussed, the greatest beneficiaries of the legal changes have thus been Japanese retailers. Before the law was eased, the Government approved usually fewer than 600 new applications a year for large retail stores, and some of those had taken 10 years to be completed. Over the last year, 3,000 new applications have been approved, of which the overwhelming majority are Japanese.
Asked how many foreigners were showing an interest, Mr. Furuta said, "Very few, unfortunately."
"We're sort of surprised that we haven't had any inquiries yet," an American official said. "If Toys 'R' Us does not make it, I don't think you're going to see many others." The exceptionally high land prices and complex distribution system have deterred American retailers.
But there is a reward for those who, like Toys "R" Us, can afford years of red ink before turning a profit. Japan's consumers are used to paying exceedingly rich prices, particularly for toys. Toys "R" Us can thus offer discounts but still earn much larger margins than in the United States.
 
Discount on Barbie
 A Barbie doll (the same blond, blue-eyed darling that is sold in the United States) packaged in a costume ball gown goes for the equivalent of $19.52 at the new Toys "R" Us. The doll is $26.50 at a large Japanese store, but the price is just $14.99 in the United States.
A package of four containers of Play Doh is $6 at Toys "R" Us, $7.50 in a Japanese store and $2.69 in the United States.
Some goods, like the high-end Aprica baby stroller, made in Japan, are actually cheaper at Japanese discounters than at Toys "R" Us.
But Toys "R" Us did strike a tactical success in finding a strong local partner to help it negotiate the bureaucracy as well as find good sites. Its Japanese subsidiary is 20 percent owned by McDonald's Company (Japan) Ltd., which has the license for operating the American fast-food restaurants in Japan.
 
McDonald's Came From U.S.?
 Under the control of Den Fujita, a well-known entrepreneur, McDonald's has enjoyed such success here that some younger Japanese are surprised to learn the chain originated in the United States.
The partnership has helped both companies. Most of the shopping centers being built with local partners around Toys "R" Us outlets will include a McDonald's, as well as an outlet of another American franchise Mr. Fujita controls in Japan, Blockbuster Video.
"The concept is brilliant, even in Japan," said Mike Allen, the retailing analyst at Barclays de Zoette Wedd Securities here. "People have already shown that when they are given a choice they are willing to drive or whatever to get discounts. The problem before was not tradition or culture, but that they had no choice."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Shoppers crowded into aisles bordered by floor-to-ceiling shelves filled with toys as Toys "R" Us, the American toy retailing chain, opened its first store in Japan yesterday in suburban Amimachi, near Tokyo. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Tumbles in Reaction To Cut in the Discount Rate

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday in reaction to cuts in two key interest rates, which makes the United States currency less attractive to investors.
Gold rose $1.40 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, closing at $358.60 an ounce. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $358.50, up $1.00. 
 The Federal Reserve stepped up its battle to revive the economy by cutting its discount rate, the interest it charges when it lends to banks, from 4 1/2 percent to 3 1/2 percent, the lowest rate in a quarter century.
The central bank also signaled that it had lowered the target for the Federal funds rate, the interest that banks charge each other, from 4 1/2 percent to 4 percent. It marked the 15th time the Fed had pushed this rate lower since the recession began in July 1990.
The nation's largest bank, Citicorp, and several other banks announced they would cut their prime rates, the benchmark for many consumer and business loans, from 7 1/2 percent to 6 1/2 percent, the lowest level since 1977. "The dollar plummeted on news of today's interest rate cuts," said Scott Knous, an analyst with Thomson Financial Networks.
Lower rates mean investments in dollar-denominated securities like Treasury bonds are worth less in relation to those denominated in other currencies.
The drop in interest rates followed the move by Germany's central bank on Thursday to increase that nation's rates, further widening the difference in rates between the nations and supporting the mark.
The dollar fell more than 2 pfennigs, to 1.5340 marks in New York, from 1.5575 marks late Thursday. In European trading, the dollar fetched 1.5335 German marks, down from 1.5730.
The dollar fell to 127.55 yen from 128.15 yen in late New York trading. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar had fallen 0.38 yen, to a closing 128.32 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 127.45 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.8585 in New York from $1.8365. In London, one pound cost $1.8618, more expensive than $1.8253 late Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's prices, included 1.3630 Swiss francs, down from 1.3805; 5.2455 French francs, down from 5.3255; 1,165.75 Italian lire, down from 1,180.25, and 1.1553 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1565.
Silver closed at $3.839 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up from $3.827 late Thursday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Heating Oil Prices Plunge In Mild Start to U.S. Winter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Heating oil futures fell to a 17-month low yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange because of abundant supplies and slack demand resulting from unseasonably warm weather. Other energy futures also fell.
Heating oil for January delivery plunged 2.38 cents to 51.08 cents a gallon, the lowest settlement of a near-term heating oil contract since July 11, 1990, when near-term deliveries finished at 50.38 cents. 
 Crude oil for February delivery fell 60 cents, to $18.52 a barrel. January unleaded gasoline dropped 1.33 cents, to 52.24 cents a gallon, and February natural gas fell 2.2 cents, to $1.453 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Wholesale heating oil prices have plummeted by 29 percent since Nov. 4, when near-term deliveries traded near 72 cents a gallon.
 
Inventories Built Up
 At that time, refiners building up inventories for the winter produced extra heating oil in case the Soviet Union was unable to export enough fuel oil to satisfy Europe's demand.
But Soviet exports to Europe have been unimpeded by the country's transition of power. Meanwhile, winter in the United States is off to an unusually mild start, resulting in large domestic supplies.
"This is a classic situation of the trade preparing too much for the heating oil season," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil Inc., a New York trading company.
Bob Baker, energy analyst with Prudential Securities Inc., said the weak economy has also hurt heating oil because it is used as diesel fuel. With industry in a slump, fewer trucks are rolling on the highways.
Cattle futures extended Thursday's sharp losses on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a continued reaction to an Agriculture Department report suggesting a backlog of slaughter-ready cattle. Pork futures were narrowly mixed.
Live cattle for February delivery dropped 0.78 cent, to 69.37 cents a pound. January feeder cattle fell 0.85 cent, to 76.15 cents a pound. December live hogs rose 0.15 cent, to 41.32 cents a pound, and February frozen pork bellies fell 0.35 cent, to 36.75 cents a pound.
December gold futures rose $1.40, to $358.60 a troy ounce; December silver rose 1.2 cents, to $3.839 a troy ounce.
Grain and soybean futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade. Analysts said foreign demand for American agricultural products could grow as a result of lower interest rates and a weaker dollar.
March wheat rose 3 3/4 cents, to $3.90 1/2 a bushel. March corn rose 1/2 cent, to $2.53 3/4 a bushel, and March oats rose 1/4 cent at $1.35 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Fed's Interest-Rate Cuts Welcomed by Business

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
From chief executives to car dealers, business people across the country welcomed the Federal Reserve's sharp cut in interest rates yesterday as a dramatic confidence-building gesture that should help revive the sluggish economy.
No policy move, they stressed, could be expected to reverse, single-handed, the reluctance of consumers and companies to spend and invest. But they added that the Fed's action did show that Washington was concerned about the economy and was making a concerted effort to turn things around. 
"It's a good sign," said John B. McCoy, chairman of Banc One Corporation, the big bank based in Columbus, Ohio, which cut its prime lending rate yesterday after the Fed move. "They're dead serious, and they're trying to get this thing fixed."
 
The Biggest Winners
 The Fed's decision to cut the discount rate by a full percentage point, to a 27-year low of 3 1/2 percent, will ease the borrowing costs for all businesses, because most loan charges are tied to that rate. The biggest winners should be those most sensitive to interest-rate swings, like home builders and small companies.
But the business people noted that a lack of confidence in the economy, not borrowing costs, appeared to be the main stumbling block to a recovery. "The real thing that's going to end this recession is for the consumer to have enough confidence in his economic future to spend again," said Frank Anderson Jr., a Chevrolet dealer in Raleigh, N.C., whose car sales are down more than 30 percent this year. "The rate cut seems to be intended as a confidence builder, but it will take a while to get to the man or woman on the street."
 
A Cycle of Fear
 W. John Devine, the chairman of Child World Inc., a toy retailer based in Avon, Mass., said consumer confidence was undermined by the steady stream of layoff announcements recently. "Some people are losing their jobs and many more are afraid of losing their jobs," he said, "and spending isn't going to bounce back until that cycle of fear is broken."
Though not immediately, consumers should soon see the benefits of lower rates. For example, the millions of American homeowners who hold adjustable-rate mortgages will find that their monthly payments are reduced the next time the rate is reset. Those mortgage rates are usually linked to rates on one-year Treasury bills, which have dropped two and a half percentage points in the last year.
The effect of lower mortgage payments on recent home buyers will be the equivalent of two weeks' additional pay, estimates David Wyss, research director of DRI--McGraw Hill Inc., an economic consulting firm. "That should be when consumers feel the big effect," he said.
 
Renegotiating Mortgages
 Homeowners with fixed-rate mortgages are renegotiating loans at a record pace to take advantage of falling interest costs. "We're refinancing so many mortgages we can't keep up with the paperwork," said Mr. McCoy of Banc One.
Lower rates should also help American exporters. Lower interest rates weaken the value of the dollar, making United States exports cheaper for foreign buyers and increasing the cost of imported goods for Americans. Already, exports have been a source of strength for the otherwise weak American economy, with the sales of goods and services increasing 8.5 percent over the last year, said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
 
Good for U.S. Exports
 The Fed cut, combined with the German central bank's decision on Thursday to raise its rates, should serve to enhance the competitiveness of American goods even more. "It's terrific; it should definitely help American exports," said Brian McLaughlin, president of the Hurco Companies, an Indianapolis machine-tool maker that gets half of its $82 million-a-year business from overseas sales.
The depression in real estate, especially along the two coasts, has contributed considerably to the recession. Lower interest costs should help builders and developers, but the trend of declining rates has not revived construction up to now. "It helps in reducing the cost of financing, but it doesn't fill the buildings," said David Shulman, a real estate analyst at Salomon Brothers.
There are an estimated 515 million square feet of vacant office space in the 50 largest American cities, or a 19.5 percent vacancy rate, about twice normal levels. "So lower rates will ultimately help the commercial real estate market, but it has taken a lot longer than in previous recessions," Mr. Shulman said.
The residential market is also mired in a slump. Falling rates are helpful, but they may no longer be the key factor in building activity, said Michael Hobbs, a residential contractor in Connecticut. "The two key elements in consumer confidence are your home and your job, and I can't think of a time when people have been less certain about the security of their job or the value of their home," Mr. Hobbs said.
That mentality, he said, had to shift before people would invest in real estate again. "The money is out there, but it's sure not flowing," Mr. Hobbs said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John B. McCoy, Banc One Corporation -- "It's a good sign. They're dead serious and they're trying to get this thing fixed." (Associated Press)
