HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
Nets Fail To Confuse The Bulls

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 20

 BODY:
Bill Fitch remained as coach of the New Jersey Nets tonight, the Nets held in their confused and losing pattern and a sellout crowd hardly seemed to notice, as all eyes were trained on Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls, who bullied the Nets, 115-98.
Jordan, the man who defies gravity, also conquered the Byrne Meadowlands Arena laws of nature, filling it for pro basketball for the first time this season with 20,049 fans. Two were named Marla Maples and her date, Donald Trump, the fourth-row guests of minority Nets' owner Joe Taub. 
 While Taub would not comment if Trump had advised him on the Art of the Deal, he did have much to say on his failed attempt to land Jim Valvano on the Nets' bench, replacing embattled Coach Bill Fitch.
"I was not only authorized to meet with Jim Valvano, but all the other owners knew about it and Jerry Cohen was with me," Taub said, referring to the club's president and one of its seven board of directors. Asked how his story could be so contrary to the one presented to the media Wednesday by Alan Aufzien, one of two majority owners, Taub insisted: "I'm telling you the truth."
The truth about Fitch's status -- and Valvano's, for that matter -- remained elusive, with Fitch saying he hoped that the coach's trapdoor would remain closed for a while so the club "could get back to concentrating on basketball." On Valvano, to whom Taub reportedly offered a five-year deal worth almost $3 million last Monday, or any other potential successor to Fitch, Taub said, "Right now I'm in a holding pattern."
All he knows, he said, is that the majority owners, Aufzien and David Gerstein, who invited him to rejoin the board last spring as an adviser in basketball-related decisions, pulled the rug out from under him, causing him "considerable embarrassment."
Asked why he made the offer if he only had the authority to speak with Valvano, Taub said, "This is something new for me. I had control when I was here before. It's very difficult to work under these conditions."
He hinted that he would be interested in regaining controlling interest of the team, which he had until the mid-1980's. Failing that, he said he might sell his interest.
Aufzien also attended the game, but did not appear to speak with reporters. Taub said the two said hello, but did not discuss the Valvano debacle. "I was busy with Donald and Marla," he said of the on-again, off-again, on-again couple, strangely similar to the Nets and their organizational decision-making process.
 (Meanwhile, Saturday's edition of The Charlotte Observer reported that Valvano had agreed late tonight to become the Nets coach.)
 
Another Recession
 The Nets, meanwhile, continued in their perpetual state of recession. Their most encouraging time tonight came with 3 1/2 minutes remaining in the first half, when they took a 44-37 lead over the Bulls, who had fallen into a lull with Michael Jordan resting and Scottie Pippen sitting next to His Airness (as the result of a few ill-advised solo attempts).
But with both future United States Olympians back in the lineup, the Bulls snapped to and snapped the Nets out of whatever dream they might have been entertaining. Two Jordan free throws began a 9-0 run, with Jordan and Pippen each contributing long jumpers, and Jordan finding Horace Grant, who scored a team-high 28 points, for a fast-break dunk that punctuated the rally and gave the Bulls a 3-point halftime lead.
"Their defense just picked up," Sam Bowie said. "I know a lot of people come out to see Michael take off from the free-throw line but what impresses me most is their defense, their rotations and how they help out whenever there's a mismatch."
There was only one mismatch in the third quarter, and that was between New Jersey and Chicago. Jumpers by John Paxson and Jordan got the Bulls off on a 17-6 tear, and the only unanswered question from there was whether the Nets could crack 100 points against one of five National Basketball Association defenses that on average hold their opponents to double figures.
They couldn't.

 
 
REBOUNDS
 One of the Nets' minority owners, DONALD UNGER, who owns 4 percent of the team, said he is interested in selling his shares . . . MICHAEL JORDAN scored 24 points; MOOKIE BLAYLOCK led the Nets with 18. KENNY ANDERSON played 18 minutes, missing all 7 of his shots.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
When Broadcast Matter Is Considered Offensive

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The ball is over; the mask comes off, but the music lingers. There, from behind the blob, emerges Patricia Bowman, former Alleged Victim and accuser of William K. Smith in the rape trial that resulted a week ago in his instant acquittal. And there, on a San Francisco news program is the President of the United States sharing his worry "about so much filth and indecent material coming in through the airwaves and through these trials into people's homes."
Should the entire trial have been blobbed out? Should Ms. Bowman's face and name have been left in? What are Ms. Bowman and Mr. Bush trying to tell the nation? 
 Mr. Bush's expression of worry was delivered Tuesday in a batch of quickie television interviews with local news anchors in selected markets, mainly devoted to a revelation that struck him on the road to the Presidential campaign: the country is really in a recession. His reference to the Smith trial may be taken as condolence to the unemployed for having their minds polluted while sitting home all day with nothing better to do than stare at the tube. (Did Mr. Bush himself spend a lot of time watching the Palm Beach story? Or did Marlin Fitzwater have all the fun?)
The President did not recommend that the jobless find something more wholesome to occupy them, like shopping at J. C. Penney and giving a lift to the economy; his point was that CNN and Court Television should not have shown the Kennedy trial. The man who had benefited from some of the dirtier uses of the tube in campaign history was offended.
In accord with the prevailing principle, borrowed from the left, that every disagreement comes down to an issue of "rights," Mr. Bush advanced the following startling proposition: "I think the American people have a right to be protected against some of these excesses. While people have a right to a fair trial, I think the American people have an overriding right to let those matters be decided behind closed doors."
Now that is revolutionary: The President of the United States, guardian of the Constitution, invoking the citizenry's right to be protected against being informed. The possibilities are tremendous: If television news stopped carrying those interviews with people on unemployment lines, the nation would not be feeling so low. If only all news could be controlled like the coverage of the war against Iraq, this would be an era of uplift.
Is it necessary to point out that the Kennedy-Smith trial was a true news event? A serious charge was brought against a member of a prominent political family, raising issues of wide interest and concern. Granted, it also stirred prurient juices, but CNN and Court Television presented the proceedings in a straightforward, sober way. The suggestion that news organizations be cracked down on because some people, even the President, might not like what is being reported and others might like it in undesirable ways does not spring from the Bill of Rights.
As for Ms. Bowman, even before her appearance Thursday night on "Prime Time Live," the round-faced, brown-haired young woman could be seen on CNN, "A Current Affair" and elsewhere. But in a scoop for Diane Sawyer, it was only on ABC that face, name and voice came together in an on-screen interview.
With the exception of NBC News, television, like most of the press, respected Ms. Bowman's desire for a degree of anonymity, even though everybody in Palm Beach must have known who she was by the start of the trial. As long as stigma attaches to a woman who says she has been raped, the voluntary decision to conceal her identity seems an act of chivalry. And if such protection reassures women who might otherwise be reluctant to come forward, so much the better. If it encourages dubious charges, so much the worse. More important, the jurors were able to see both accuser and accused.
Whether the blobbing helped or hurt Ms. Bowman's image and the image of other alleged rape victims is as unclear as her television image itself. One viewer might feel sympathy for a woman trying to keep some semblance of privacy after the humiliation of what she said she had been through; another might wonder what she is hiding. Court Television's electronic checkerboard made her seem like a creature from space.
So what did the newly unveiled Ms. Bowman have to tell Ms. Sawyer? Not much about that night. On introduction, the camera moved slowly up her torso, past the crucifix -- and there was the face. That was the big moment. For the next half hour, in response to the sympathetically skeptical questioning of Ms. Sawyer, Ms. Bowman filled in no memory gaps and delivered again the phrases ("He raped me") and tears that had failed to persuade the jury in West Palm Beach. Seeing her face probably did not change many opinions: Viewers who had detected a ring of truth behind the blob could hear it still; those who had been jarred by the clang of an improbable script would be jarred again.
One can only speculate on her motives for coming out. (Roy E. Black, Mr. Smith's lawyer, may have asked for it by telling reporters and talk-show hosts that the accuser was "disturbed.") But the motives of "Prime Time Live" are plain enough. What program could resist the opportunity to be first with Ms. Bowman and squeeze a little more mileage out of the case before audience interest waned, even if that meant yet again airing accusations against a man who had just won acquittal? Not the worst treatment of the case the tube has carried but far from the best, it served "Prime Time's" ratings, at the expense of Mr. Smith.
Evidently ABC lawyers are not worried about a threat from Mr. Smith's lawyers that Ms. Bowman's account might now be considered libelous, but Thursday's edition of "Prime Time Live" was the sort of trivial scoop, with a flimsy pretext of news, that lends plausibility to Mr. Bush's pieties.

HEADLINE: For Car Renters, New Options for Insurance

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In the consumer jungle of automobile rentals, the foliage is getting thicker.
The issue is insurance. Until recently, renters faced a simple question: Do I want it or not? Many consumer advocates say such coverage is a very poor deal and should probably be turned down. 
 "As an insurance product, it's very unlikely to be worthwhile," said Stephen C. Burgess, the Florida Insurance Department's consumer advocate.
The rental companies, hearing the complaints, have recently responded by presenting customers with as many as three coverage choices. But some of those choices may be even worse deals for the renter than the old option.
For the last 20 years, the conventional pattern at car-rental counters was to push hard to sell the renter what most companies call the collision damage waiver, an extra-cost clause in the rental contract that puts the financial responsibility for accidents on the rental company, not the driver. Others use different names for this coverage but never officially "insurance," because that would make the clause subject to state regulation.
Whatever it is called, it is generally extremely expensive, often $14 a day to cover the value of the car. The Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car-rental company, estimates that the cost to the rental companies is only $1.50 to $2 a day.
Worse, it may be nearly worthless to the renter, because the insurance policy on the car that the renter left at home in the driveway will often cover the rental car, too.
Collision damage waivers have been criticized over the years as providing "a huge profit center," said Liz Clark, a spokeswoman for Alamo Rent A Car, which is the nation's fifth-largest car-rental company. So 18 months ago, Alamo came out with a new set of offerings called Waiver Savers. Stepping off the shuttle bus from the Orlando, Fla., airport, a traveler arriving at Alamo's counters will wait in line and get a sales pitch from an overhead video monitor.
The videotape points out that many people who have car insurance of their own face a $500 deductible. For $3, Alamo will sell the renter the first $500 of coverage, reducing the deductible to zero. Or if a renter wants a little more coverage, perhaps because it is a business rental and the rental contract covers all but the first $3,000, Alamo will sell $3,000 in coverage for $6.
For customers who want full insurance, because their own policies are not applicable or because they are afraid to file a claim under them, Alamo charges $9. The tape also plays down the value of insurance that applies automatically when certain credit cards are used, pointing out that in most cases such insurance is secondary, leaving drivers to try to collect under their own policies first.
The benefit of buying coverage at the rental counter, Ms. Clark said, is "peace of mind."
That may be, because for the renter, the boon does not appear to be financial.
 
$6 vs. 60 Cents
 Although the price tags are smaller on the new coverage options, the lowest one has become substantially less economical. Selling coverage of $500 for one day at $3 means that the company is charging $6 for $1,000 worth of insurance. Before Alamo introduced its menu, it was charging a tenth that amount -- about 60 cents a day per $1,000 -- or $14 for full coverage on a full-size car.
But, Ms. Clark pointed out, "$3 is negligible compared to the cost of a vacation." The policies sell well, she added.
Hertz still offers full protection at $12 a day, but responding to the competition, it has added a $1,000 option in Florida, priced at $5 a day. Again, the new choice means less expense for the renter, but it also represents a higher cost for $1,000 worth of coverage: $5 vs. about 50 cents.
A spokesman for Hertz, Joseph M. Russo, agreed that neither deal was particularly attractive from the customer's point of view. "That's why Hertz supports the elimination of the collision damage waiver," he said.
The company was a backer of a New York State law, which went into effect in 1989, that eliminated the waiver, making insurance part of the basic cost of renting a car. Illinois also bans waivers.
 
Loss of Rental Income
 The Budget Rent-A-Car Corporation still offers the collision damage waiver, but it points out that the waiver has its advantages. Budget, among other companies, charges for the loss of rental income when one of its cars is in the body shop for accident repairs. Tim Hermeling, a spokesman for Budget, said the collision damage waiver would cover loss of use.
"We believe it should be handled similarly to airline insurance," Mr. Hermeling said of rental-car coverage. "It's there if you want it. If you don't want it, don't take it."
Mr. Burgess, the Florida consumer advocate, would like to bring all damage clauses under state regulation, like other insurance. "It walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, but it's not a duck," he said.
He will try again in the next session of the Florida Legislature, he said, but is not optimistic. The car-rental companies, he said, "have a lot more clout than a lot of people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After stepping off the shuttle bus from the Orlando, Fla., airport, customers get a sales pitch for Alamo's Waiver Savers on a video monitor. (Ben Van Hook for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "There's No Such Thing as a Free Ride"
 
Drivers who rent from off-airport rental companies should think twice before boarding the "free" shuttle bus.
 A growing number of airports impose a tax of up to 10 percent on all off-airport rentals by customers arriving by shuttle bys. Some companies do not list the charge separately.
 Rental companies that operate on airport property have lobbied for this. They point out that they must pay a commission to the airport, typically 10 percent, and argue that taxing their off-airport competitors dimply provides a level playing field. The off-airport companies say that renters are being taxed without benefiting. Customers can often avoid the tax by taking a cab to the off-airport rental companies, presenting their receipts as proof. The cab fare is usually less than $5, and the trip is often faster. For a rental of a week or more, this can save money
 
Auto Rental News, a trade magazine, has compiled a list of airports that impose surcharges on companies that rent cars from lots outside the airport property. Here is a list of the larger airports imposing the charge, and the percentage they add to the rental bill.

HEADLINE: What the 70 Days Cost

 BODY:
In the way he said no yesterday, Mario Cuomo showed America the complexity that New Yorkers long ago discovered in their Governor: He is eloquent, and exasperating. His political behavior can be masterful, if occasionally also martyred. He brims with sophistication, but sometimes only with sophistry.
He will not run for President -- he cannot run, he said -- because the State Senate Republicans are viciously obstructing critical budget negotiations. Yet almost in the next breath, he couldn't resist displaying how well he, the voice of "the big steelworkers with the thick fingers who can't handle computers," might have flayed George Bush. 
 It took some time before he finally seemed to say that after 70 days of highly publicized cogitation, he had decided definitively not to challenge the six announced Democratic candidates.
What have these 10 weeks cost? In the end, once the other candidates make up for lost time fund-raising, they probably will not have lost much. The protracted pondering has made people exasperated with him, not them. But by now putting his Presidential aspirations on the scale in the "wrestling negotiations" over the budget, Mr. Cuomo may yet accomplish something constructive.
The delay in deciding, down to the last 90 minutes before the New Hampshire filing deadline, did nothing to enhance his reputation. He has replaced Dan Quayle as the target of television talk-show hosts. The public did see Mr. Cuomo's rare intelligence. None of the Democratic candidates are yet his equal at filleting George Bush's record. Yet he offered precious little substance. This time in the sun gave Mr. Cuomo his chance to contribute to the national dialogue and he made little of it.
It was probably inevitable that his dalliance with Presidential politics would hurt at home, where Republicans control the Senate. Efforts to close New York's huge budget gap were never destined to go smoothly; legislators always resist budget cuts, especially nearing an election year. But the Governor's larger ambitions gave Republicans little incentive to resolve the crisis, as he must have anticipated from the beginning.
Now, by giving up those ambitions, Mr. Cuomo forces the Republicans to deal with the gripping problems. New York faces a budget gap approaching $4 billion, the largest anticipated deficit in memory. And the economy shows no signs of improving. It's a task of daunting difficulty, closing the budget gap while saving vital services.
The Governor says he retreated from the Presidential campaign because a "threat hangs over the heads of New Yorkers that I have sworn to put first." Perhaps his political sacrifice, perceived or real, will shake up legislators and force them to confront their own responsibility.

HEADLINE: Wrong Symbolism on Mayoral Pay

 BODY:
From the beginning, Mayor David Dinkins's voluntary 5 percent pay cut was more important for its symbolism than its impact on New York City's budget. It didn't save a lot of money, but by taking that small cut in his own salary and those of about 800 managers, the Mayor was saying that he understood the impact of the recession and was willing to do his bit. That's what mayors are supposed to do -- set a tone.
That is why Mr. Dinkins's latest decision -- to rescind the cuts -- is so disappointing. In a city where more than 138,000 jobs have disappeared in the last year, including 6,000 in city government, people need a sense that their most prominent political leader cares about their plight. 
 The Mayor reversed himself because the cut would reduce city pensions, which are based on earnings. The Mayor said that would not be fair. His Corporation Counsel, Peter Sherwood, says the salary reduction also hurts morale among staff members. But even if a case can be made that senior staff should now get their full salaries, there is no good reason for the Mayor to restore his own.
Borough President Ruth Messinger of Manhattan, her Bronx counterpart, Fernando Ferrer, and City Council President Andrew Stein all continue to accept 5 percent reductions in their salaries. The City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman, took the 5 percent cut, then reduced that to 2 percent.
The Mayor could even accept his full salary and, like Council Speaker Peter Vallone, return 5 percent to the treasury. That keeps pension rights intact but sends a signal of modest sacrifice. For a struggling city, that show of empathy means a lot.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Behind Mel Miller's Downfall

BYLINE: By DOROTHY J. SAMUELS

 BODY:
Mel Miller's days as one of the most powerful politicians in New York State are over. His conviction last week on Federal fraud charges meant automatic expulsion from the State Assembly, and a new Assembly Speaker, Saul Weprin, now serves in his place.
But questions linger about the case, prompted by the high political stakes and the relatively minor nature of the charges on which Mr. Miller was ultimately convicted. Was this a reasonable prosecution for the United States Attorney in Brooklyn, Andrew Maloney, a Republican, to bring against the Assembly's top Democrat, or was it overreaching? 
 The case history suggests no dark partisan motive. Mr. Maloney's office apparently stumbled upon the shady real estate transactions that gave rise to the prosecution during the course of another investigation. Mr. Miller is right that an ordinary citizen probably would not have been indicted on the same set of facts. But that by itself doesn't prove prosecutorial abuse.
A U.S. Attorney must always be selective in choosing which acts of wrongdoing to pursue, and high-profile cases can have a real deterrent value. In general, the public probably has more to fear from prosecutorial timidity, when evidence leads to a high public official, than from the reverse.
Nevertheless, it's disquieting that a top leader of state government has been toppled, and may serve prison time, for acts that, while surely unethical, seem grist more for a bar association disciplinary proceeding or civil lawsuit than prosecution.
The indictment charged that he and his law partner and Assembly counsel, Jay Adolf, cheated law clients out of $300,000 in profits they might have made from investments in cooperative apartments. The jury acquitted Mr. Miller on the two more troubling charges -- that he profited by mailing forged documents and by fraudulently gaining control of an elderly woman's apartment. But another charge stuck: Mr. Miller was convicted of breaching his fiduciary duty as a lawyer by cutting himself in on a lucrative deal to buy apartments in a Brooklyn building without telling his clients.
It's true that lawyers owe their clients a duty of undivided loyalty. It's also true that the sleazy dealings confirmed by the trial cast substantial doubt on Mr. Miller's fitness to continue in high office even if the jury's verdict had acquitted on all charges. Indeed, many admirers of Mr. Miller's work in Albany say they are amazed by his arrogance in assuming he could get away with playing so fast and loose with ethics.
By secretly buying apartments for himself, Mr. Miller was found to have cheated his clients of an economic opportunity. The person identified by prosecutors as the principal fraud victim testified he would hire Mr. Miller again, fueling suspicion the case would not have been pursued but for Mr. Miller's stature. But that doesn't decide the fraud issue. There were other investors who didn't testify, and an unhappy victim isn't a necessary element of the crime.
Whether Mr. Miller's chiseling rises to a theft of "property" under the Federal mail fraud statute is a close legal question. It will be a centerpiece of Mr. Miller's appeal. The law may well be sufficiently elastic to cover Mr. Miller's tawdry transactions. But it would stretch fairness to impose a prison term when the usual penalty, according to experts in legal ethics, is disbarment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

LENGTH: 752 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Government to Pay for New York Thruway, 35 Years Late

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 --
When Daniel P. Moynihan, then a professor at Syracuse University, went to the 1960 Democratic Convention, he fought for a plank in the party platform calling for the Federal Government to repay New York for building the New York State Thruway. It was one of the few commitments John F. Kennedy's campaign managers declined to include in an almost bottomless grab bag of promises.
But this week Mr. Moynihan received the $5 billion commitment. Culminating a 30-year battle by the Senator, President Bush in Dallas signed a $151 billion transportation bill that includes authorization to pay New York $338 million a year for 15 years for having built the 570-mile highway, now the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, and contributing it to the interstate highway system. The money can be used for any transportation-related purpose. 
 The bill provides similar payments for roads in all other states. New Jersey will receive $2 billion and Connecticut $1.7 billion.
The Thruway decision is a testament to one politician's perseverance and to the powers of seniority in Congress.
But Senator Moynihan, a New York Democrat, says the decision also stands as an exclamation mark to a philosophical shift in the way New York and the surrounding states relate to the Federal Government.
Since Franklin D. Roosevelt assembled his Democratic coalition 60 years ago, New York legislators and others from the Northeast often approached the Federal budget as a tool for social engineering, writing bills to send money around the country in an effort to change customs and habits.
 
Getting and Spending
 As a result, Mr. Moynihan says, the region has received less back for the money it sends to Washington than any other area in the country. In its most recent annual survey of Federal spending and taxing, the Senator's office found that New Yorkers last year paid an average of $1,178 more in taxes for each person than they received in Federal outlays. Connecticut residents had a $2,011 deficit, and New Jerseyans fared worse, suffering a per-capita deficit of $2,487. New Mexico residents, by contrast, received $2,776 more a person than they sent to Washington.
In recent years, however, long-simmering anger over the imbalance has risen to a political fever pitch.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, a Republican from Long Island, has sustained his career by ceaselessly billing himself as an advocate of parochial concerns. Senator Bill Bradley, the New Jersey Democrat, was nearly defeated in the 1990 election in good part because of a feeling that he neglected constituent service for national issues. And Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, accused by opponents of failing to focus on his economically hard-pressed state, is facing an unexpectedly difficult re-election campaign.
Mr. Moynihan, chairman of the Water Resources, Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, has long argued that the interstate system was a paradigm of the Northeast's approach to the Federal budget.
 
An 'Astounding' Oversight
 The 1956 legislation establishing the interstate system was in large part drafted and guided through Congress by lawmakers from New York. But in what Mr. Moynihan calls an "astounding" oversight, they did not include provisions to repay New York for building the Thruway, whose first section linking Rochester and Lowell had opened two years previously.
In recognition that some states had already spent lavishly out of their own pockets, the legislation did call for a study to document the value of any state roads contributed to the interstate system -- an implicit promise to repay those states. But the study was never performed, and the money never repaid.
Mr. Moynihan failed in numerous efforts to get the money. This year he included a provision for the study in his transportation bill, the first comprehensive rewrite of the country's transportation policies in 35 years. Since it only called for a report, the provision did not attract much attention.
"I decided I might as well go for broke," Senator Moynihan said. He proposed authorizing a 15-year repayment schedule for state road contributions, with the payout to begin in 1996. With the political powerhouses of California and Texas also in line to be major beneficiaries -- California getting $10.1 billion and Texas $6.8 billion -- a critical mass of support was reached.
In the rush to adjourn before Thanksgiving, the proposal was passed by Congress without debate.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 27, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about Senator Daniel P. Moynihan's efforts to have the Federal Government repay New York State for rebuilding the Thruway misstated the amount of repayments authorized by Congress last month for two other states. California will get $1.6 billion and Texas $1.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Previews, That Broadway Malady

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
You know a broadway musical has become a citywide joke when an 8-year-old boy is dishing it in the men's room at intermission. At the performance I attended of "Nick and Nora" -- one of the designated press performances near the end of the much-delayed production's ninth week of previews -- I overheard this exchange between a father and his young son:
Father: "They made a mistake being so similar to 'City of Angels.' " 
 Son: "But 'City of Angels' was different. It wanted to be funny."
Father: "Yeah, and this one, well, it wants to be . . . "
Son (sarcastically): "Dad, I think they're going for sophistication."
That "Nick and Nora" failed to find sophistication, or laughs, or anything else that might amuse an audience for an evening, is old news now. A week after the critics came, the show closed, and its contents, which were guilty of no sin graver than mediocrity, have probably already been forgotten by most everyone who sampled them. What cannot be so easily forgotten, however, is the circus that preceded the opening of "Nick and Nora." While the show itself was just an innocuous, if professional, flop, its noisy preview period was a true amateur night, a public relations catastrophe for a Broadway theater industry that surely does not need to trumpet further its artistic disarray and indifference to the consumer.
During its 71 previews at a $60 top ticket price, "Nick and Nora" was seen by roughly 90,000 people. Most of them, one can assume, were a captive audience, in that they had purchased their nonrefundable tickets in good faith in advance, sometimes at the premium charged by worthy organizations holding theater parties. This audience turned on the show with a vengeance, as became apparent once the advance sale was depleted and word-of-mouth could catch up with the box office.
After six weeks of crowded previews, attendance at "Nick and Nora" began a free fall, according to the figures reported in Variety. The public had thus rendered its verdict well before the critics arrived -- a producer's dream that turns into a nightmare when the show is poor -- and, given the ferocity of that opinion, it is unlikely that even favorable reviews could have saved "Nick and Nora" by that juncture. When the negative reviews finally did arrive, they were merely autopsies confirming the corpse's death by natural causes.
Along its not-so-merry way to oblivion, "Nick and Nora" grew into something bigger than just another Broadway flop: its title became a rallying cry for audiences who have long been infuriated by Broadway's disregard for the rights of ticket buyers. "Forbidden Broadway" wasted no time in satirizing "Nick and Snora" while it was still being revised, calling its full-price previews "a rip-off." Disgruntled preview patrons took to writing journalists with their complaints, demanding that critics review the musical immediately, ready or not, and the outcry spread so far that, at one point, I picked up the phone to find a radio interviewer from Cardiff, Wales, on the line inquiring into the delayed opening of "Nick and Nora."
As if this were not notoriety enough, the city's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mark Green, presumably prodded by columns such as those by Linda Winer in Newsday and Greg Evans in Variety, got into the act, demanding that productions like "Nick and Nora" label their previews clearly in advertising so that, in Mr. Green's words, consumers could be "put on notice when they are seeing a work-in-progress as opposed to a finished product." While "Nick and Nora" was far from the first Broadway musical to fudge the distinction between previews and post-opening performances in much of its advertising, it was nothing if not the wrong flop in the wrong place in the wrong time. It caught the public's eye not just because it was the most troubled original American musical of the Broadway season but because it was the only original American musical of a Broadway season mired in recession.
Mr. Green's efforts to regulate theatrical advertising were a partial success. He got Broadway and Off Broadway producers to agree to a compromise that will require previewing productions to indicate that fact in all newspaper advertising except the daily classified directory of shows. But the infamy "Nick and Nora" achieved during its unhappy life is less an issue of truth-in-advertising than competence-in-producing. At a time when the American musical has been steadily eroded by runaway production costs and ticket prices and a continuing talent drain, the spectacle created by "Nick and Nora" seems like the coup de grace.
It is not a figment of the audience's imagination that the preview process has spun out of control for Broadway musicals. The process is running amok -- and alienating what loyal audience Broadway has left -- and no one in the industry seems to care. In response to Mr. Green's complaints demanding the labeling of previews in advertising, Daniel Brambilla, an attorney for the League of American Theaters and Producers, the Broadway trade association, told a reporter for The New York Times: "The next thing they'll be doing is ask us to publish the bad reviews. It's absurd. There is nothing deceptive about this. It's been going on for decades."
Mr. Brambilla is wrong. It has not been going on for decades in the way it is now.
To see how much the preview system has deteriorated, and how much the paying audience is being exploited, one does not have to go back very far. The first musical to play extended previews on Broadway was "Wish You Were Here" in 1952. That show had to forsake the then-standard out-of-town previews -- tryouts in cities like New Haven and Philadelphia and Boston -- for the same reason many musicals do today. Its sets, which featured an on-stage swimming pool, were too unwieldy and costly to send on the road. "Wish You Were Here" limited its previews to three and a half weeks, all of them sold to charity benefits, with no preview tickets on sale at the box office (or advertised) to the general public. The show then opened to poor reviews on a hot June night when the air conditioning in the Imperial Theater broke down.
Leland Hayward, the producer, and Joshua Logan, the director, hated the preview experience of "Wish You Were Here" for reasons that would be echoed by many musical-theater hands who followed them. They vowed "never again to try out a show in New York," Variety reported. "Every revision of the book or music or even altered bits of staging became a hot Shubert Alley flash. . . . Some professionals made a minor career of attending preview performances, then rushing off to spread the latest tidings." Though "Wish You Were Here" gradually became a hit, its success was attributed to revisions made in a panic after the opening, rather than in previews, and to the popularity of Eddie Fisher's recording of the title song.
Only five months after the "Wish You Were Here" experiment, the tight preview principles it established were broken. "Two's Company," a much troubled revue starring Bette Davis, became the first show to insist that it should have two weeks of critic-free previews on Broadway in addition to its lengthy out-of-town tryout (in three cities, no less), so that further revisions could be made with a new director. (Among the show doctors who worked on "Two's Company" was Arthur Laurents, author and director of "Nick and Nora.")
But "Two's Company" never got to carry out this scheme; the previews were abruptly canceled when Davis took ill, or said she did. It was in early 1954, with the play "The Immoralist," that the producer Billy Rose first delayed a previously announced opening and held paid public previews for artistic reasons, begging critics to ignore the production's first week of performances while Daniel Mann took over the direction from Herman Shumlin. The New York Times (among others) sent a reporter to file an unofficial report on the first preview anyway, and he described the production as "often lifeless." Brooks Atkinson wrote a favorable review a week later, after the official opening, but the audience, in a pattern that would also be repeated in years to come, did not have faith in a play that had postponed its opening with such publicity. "The Immoralist" closed in three months.
Throughout the 1950's, previews remained the exception, not the rule, and no production dared approach the three-and-a-half-week preview period of "Wish You Were Here." But by the mid-1960's previews had proliferated -- for shows that had out-of-town tryouts and those that did not -- and it became standard practice for producers to offer compensation to the audience for attending them by reducing ticket prices. Harold Prince was the first producer to acknowledge that the old opening night was dead as an institution since it no longer was, in fact, a premiere. He went so far as to relieve the by-now artificial, not to mention inhumane, opening-night pressure on actors and critics by inviting the press to cover any of the last three previews (of 21) of "Cabaret," in 1966. (The practice is now standard.) With that show, he also allowed theatergoers to pay reduced preview prices for regular performances, if they were willing to gamble on the show's quality by purchasing tickets well in advance of opening night.
Previews were always clearly labeled in the 1960's as well as reduced in price. (For straight plays, back when Broadway still produced them on a regular basis, preview periods were also very short, since dramas cannot be doctored as musicals are and rarely attract the large advance sales needed to support extended previews.) But as producers gradually found out that they could get away with cutting corners, they did. In the 1970's, preview periods got longer -- a necessity as out-of-town tryouts became increasingly out of financial reach -- but fewer and fewer shows reduced the price of preview tickets, especially musicals whose tickets were in greatest advance demand and needed no added inducements to be sold to the public.
In the go-go 1980's came the next step: the blurring or end of labeling previews in advertising and in the signs around the box office, with odd locutions such as "performances begin" substituting for the former phrase "previews begin." Once full-price previews ceased even to be easily identifiable as such, public disgruntlement started to increase, finally to reach firestorm proportions with "Nick and Nora."
During the entire history of musical previews on Broadway, however, one principle has remained constant. With only scattered exceptions, hit musicals tend to have compact preview periods (a month or less) and open on the date originally announced. Flop musicals postpone their openings repeatedly and extend the preview period beyond a month -- usually to the very week, as it just happens, that the advance sale runs out. The musicals that have at various times set records for number of Broadway preview performances, or flirted with doing so until the critics stormed in, are hardly an honor roll. They include "Hot Spot," "Golden Rainbow," "Dear World," "Sarava," "Merlin" and "Legs Diamond." Most of them had stars -- from Judy Holliday to Angela Lansbury to Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme -- who could guarantee an advance sale that would keep preview houses near capacity for about six weeks. After that point -- around the 50th preview -- bad word-of-mouth would almost always sap business, just as it did at "Nick and Nora." Then the "opening" would at last be held.
Were any of these bombs improved by previewing for as long as six, seven and eight weeks in New York? Not enough to make a difference. While there are many examples of promising musicals that have been fine-tuned, cut or even substantially improved (by the addition of a major number or two) during a month of Broadway previews, the musicals that take much longer than that tend to be out-and-out disasters waiting for a miracle that never arrives. No matter how long the preview period, after all, it is still impossible to rewrite, recast, restage and redesign an entire misbegotten Broadway production that has left the rehearsal studio and is playing eight exhausting performances a week. Even in the days of tryouts on the road, the list of musicals that were transformed from true catastrophes into swans is minuscule.
Was the press right to wait to review repeatedly delayed and patently commercial productions until tens of thousands of customers had wasted their time and money on them during extended Broadway previews? Probably not; at least an interim report might have been called for after the first month, particularly if the price scale and advertising implied to the public that these productions were completed, rather than works-in-progress.
Is there a solution to this conflict between the interests of producers eager to protect a huge investment, and those of audiences who have a right to know what they are buying when they invest $60 or more in a Broadway musical ticket? At the very least, the commercial theater's leaders, if such a breed exists, might address the problem frankly and engage the public in a dialogue about the situation instead of trying to see how much fudging they can get away with until the press or the government blows the whistle.
Or is it already too late to save the endangered Broadway musical and retain its audience? In a depressing coincidence, "Nick and Nora" held its delayed opening on the same weekend that the Nederlander Organization disclosed the sale of the Mark Hellinger Theater to the Times Square Church, ending that house's career as a legitimate theater as firmly as if it had been torn down. The Hellinger is inextricably linked in theatrical legend to its most famous tenant, "My Fair Lady," the great American musical of the Broadway theater's last golden age; its loss is a symbolic blow to Broadway tantamount to the demolition of the Morosco Theater, the original home of the archetypal great American play, "Death of a Salesman," a decade ago.
Following five weeks of out-of-town tryouts in 1956, "My Fair Lady" opened at the Hellinger after one charity preview performance. It ran almost seven years. Some of the Hellinger's tenants in the subsequent three decades have included "Dear World" (49 previews, 132 post-opening performances), "Merlin" (69 previews, 199 performances) and, its last theatrical attraction, "Legs Diamond" (72 previews, 64 performances).
As with "Nick and Nora" (71 previews, 9 performances), the bloated preview periods of these shows accomplished little beyond the antagonizing of Broadway's once-loyal advance-ticket buyers. After being badgered repeatedly by musicals that are not ready to open, is it any wonder that this audience is no longer large enough to prevent theaters like the Hellinger from being closed?

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: The Flatiron District

 BODY:
BETWEEN the Civil War and World War I, the elegant stores, restaurants and hotels that multiplied between 14th and 23d Streets, from Broadway to Sixth Avenue, made the area the city's most glamorous shopping district.
On and near Broadway between 15th and 23d Street were, among others, Lord & Taylor and Gorham silversmiths. Sixth Avenue (now Avenue of the Americas) was home to B. Altman, the Hugh O'Neill Store and -- the biggest, grandest of them all -- the huge Siegel-Cooper department store in an ornate six-story building. 
 Today the area enjoys a new vitality, fueled by a migration of chic clothiers, restaurants and nightspots. By 1989, said Marilyn Young, a broker with the Ambrose Mari-Elia realty agency, the area had become "as hot as a pistol" for residential sales.
Most New Yorkers call the neighborhood the Flatiron District, a name taken from the wedge-shaped Flatiron Building on 23d Street where Fifth Avenue and Broadway cross. The 21-story building, designed by Daniel H. Burnham & Company of Chicago and completed in 1902, was among the first in the city to have a steel skeleton.
After World War I, as shopping -- and shoppers -- moved uptown, the Flatiron District became little more than a dreary, sparsely populated place that people passed through on their way to such desirable destinations as Gramercy Park, Chelsea and Greenwich Village. Its cavernous loft spaces housed warehouses, light manufacturers, artists and photographers.
Not until the early 1980's did some conversion to office use start, with advertising agencies and publishing houses leading the influx. Other businesses, lured by relatively low rents and large spaces, soon followed, and by the mid 80's residential conversion had begun.
In the last five years the district's commercial activity has become somewhat like the fast-paced growth of SoHo several years earlier. Retailers on Fifth Avenue include Armani, Joan and David, Kenneth Cole and the Gap; on Broadway, Preferred Seating, Paragon, ABC Carpet and The Wiz. Among the restaurants are Prix Fixe, the Union Square Cafe and Metropolis Cafes, Cal's, Mesa Grill, America and Lola, and -- for lunch and afternoon tea -- the Book-Friends Cafe on West 18th Street.
"It's as though these beautiful old Romanesque buildings are finding new lives," said Laurie Beckelman, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission. "And the best part is that the restorations being undertaken, like the Giorgio Armani store, for example, preserve the spirit of the area's history."
The Armani restoration, at 110 Fifth Avenue, at 16th Street, was completed in 1989, and Emporio Armani opened on March 14 that year. Two months later the Landmarks Preservation Commission created the Ladies' Mile Historic District, which runs roughly from West 24th to West 14th Street and from west of Avenue of the Americas to just east of Broadway.
Along the Avenue of the Americas there is some occupied office space, but several parcels, like the 750,000-square-foot former Siegel-Cooper store, are vacant or nearly vacant.
"Just as expansion was starting to go westward," said William L. Haines, president of the Lower Fifth Avenue Association, "Sixth Avenue and its resurgence coincided with the recession."
DESPITE the relative newness of the area as a residential center, bargains are rare. Except for a few buildings along 23d Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, apartment prices are generally no lower than in more established neighborhoods. Still, those looking for airy loft spaces with the convenience of being close to midtown and Wall Street find the district attractive.
Buyers can expect to spend about $400,000 for a 1,300-square-foot loft, said Pamela Leibman of the Corcoran Group, and renting a similar sized one-bedroom loft will run about $2,000 a month, said Alan Chaprack of Quality Living Realtors, rental agents.
Few loft buildings offer doorman or concierge services.
Most of the modern apartment buildings in the area are condominiums. Ms. Young of Ambrose Mar-Elia said one-bedroom condominiums are in the $225,000 range. Rents in the modern buildings range from $1,000 to $1,250 for a studio and $1,350 to $2,300 for a one-bedroom.
Not unlike the rest of the New York City, the languid real estate climate has meant slow-moving sales in the Flatiron District. Ms. Young said she listed a 2,400-square-foot loft with an asking price of $750,000 this summer, and interest has been light.
On Dec. 8, 35 units at Grosvenor House, a new condominium at 22 West 15th Street, were auctioned and 29 were sold. Of the 134 units in the building, where sales opened in 1989, 38 remain unsold.
Bruce Bobrow, a 47-year-old clothing manufacturer who moved to the Grosvenor House in 1989 with his wife, Julie, 35, a retailer, said they "love the excitement" of the neighborhood.
"It's like living in Paris -- the architecture, the shopping," he said. "We do lots of shopping up and down Fifth Avenue."
Some longtime residents of the area say gentrification is not without costs and are bitter about development. They say the newfound interest in Ladies' Mile (as the purists prefer to call their neighborhood) is more of a slick selling tool for the real estate industry than an indication of substantial community improvement.
Dr. Jay Kuhlman, a veterinarian who has practiced at 37 East 19th Street for 22 years, said only half-jokingly: "Used to be, there was nowhere in this neighborhood to eat. Now there'e nowhere in the neighborhood I can afford to eat. I guess you could say it's a mixed blessing."
Nevertheless, many residents say the increased traffic in the Flatiron District makes them feel safer. A spokesman from the 13th Police Precinct -- which takes in 14th to 30th Street, from Seventh Avenue to the East River -- said that no statistics were kept on individual neighborhoods but that reported crimes have decreased precinctwide.
But Joan Ramer, district manager for Community Board 5, disagrees. "Before, with fewer people around here, robbers were less apt to hang around," she said. "Why would they want to stake out an area with such slim prospects?"
There are no public schools in the area. Most children attend either P.S. 40 in the Gramercy Park area or P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village. St. Francis Xavier High School, a Roman Catholic school for boys, is on West 16th Street.
THE proliferation of hot nightspots draws thousands of people to the district almost nightly, giving those who live there their biggest headache. But, since the neighborhood is zoned for commercial rather than residential use, that problem is not likely to be alleviated anytime soon.
On West 20th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, for example, are four clubs and an aerobic dance studio that, their neighbors say, send thudding bass vibrations through their apartments day and night. They are further annoyed by crowds of young revelers -- often drunk -- on the streets from 10 P.M. till the early morning hours.
"My advice is: If you're thinking of living here -- don't," says Richard Goldman, a photographer whose home/studio is at 36 West 20th Street. "Ever since the Limelight came here nine years ago, other clubs have followed. And we have witnessed nothing less than the rape of a neighborhood."
The Limelight, at the northeast corner of Avenue of the Americas and 20th Street, is a disco in a converted church.
To be sure, living in a "hot" neighborhood like the Flatiron poses problems. Still, for some the noise and congestion are not a bad trade-off for such amenities as neighborhood cafes and the greenmarket at Union Square Park. And while some of the newer tenants may be chic and trendy, there are veterans of the area who have shared in the area's prosperity.
The Old Town Bar and Restaurant, a neighborhood fixture for more than a century on 18th Street between Broadway and Park Avenue South, was virtually unknown five years ago. But its manager, John Sisson, says the casual watering hole and eating place has experienced a tenfold increase in business since 1985.
"It's definitely more 'yuppified' than it used to be," said Mr. Sisson. "But there's no attitude; they're not so bad. In here, everybody mixes together."

Rally Round the Pavement: When the Lower Fifth Avenue Association was just getting started in the early 80's, says William L. Haines, its president, it got wind of a city plan to repave Fifth Avenue from the East 80's only as far south as 23d Street. The issue became a rallying point for the group. It convinced city officials that the Flatiron District was an up-and-coming area and the city changed its plan, repaving as far south as 12th Street.

HEADLINE: Chilly Days Bring Cold Comfort on Slopes

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
WHEN up to four inches of snow fell on most of the state on a recent Friday, hundreds of skiers turned out at Connecticut ski areas the next day, eager to take advantage of the first snowfall of the season. The snow was just frosting on the cake, though, since all five ski areas already had good bases of man-madesnow.
"But the snowfall made skiers think skiing," said Dave Harlow, the general manager at the Powder Ridge ski area in Middlefield, near Middletown. He was referring to what ski operators refer to as "the snow in the backyard syndrome": most skiers, and particularly novices, are only inclined to go skiing if they see snow on their own lawns. 
 The ski operators' time of plenty was quickly over. By Monday unseasonably mild weather and heavy rain had melted practically all the snow in backyards and on ski slopes. Continuing rain and high temperatures forced all five ski areas to remain closed last weekend and left the ski operators wondering whether they were to endure another abysmal ski season.
By early last past week, though, a cold front had moved across the state, enabling snow-making machines to blanket many trails with man-made (ski operators abhor the term "artificial") snow. A light snowfall across the state on Tuesday got people thinking about snow again, and by Wednesday all the ski areas in the state had reopened for business. All that bode well for the week between Christmas and New Year's, which is traditionally the busiest ski week of the year. Last year, although about six inches of snow fell across most of the state on Dec. 28, rain, fog and mild weather made ski conditions poor during most of Christmas week.
Two mild winters in a row have hurt all the state's ski areas, as well as those to the north. Even more injurious have been the effects of the current recession, which has led to the demise of two long-established Vermont ski resorts, Magic Mountain and Ascutney. Most ski industry analysts say that the recession, particularly if it is coupled with another unseasonably warm winter, could severely damage other ski resorts in the region.
But some Connecticut ski operators say the recession may benefit them. "Skiers are still going to go skiing, but they're going to be watching their money more closely than ever," Mr. Harlow said. "They're not going to be as inclined to go north and spend an arm and leg on a condo to go skiing." Other ski operators in the state agreed that they could benefit, to a degree, from the tight economy.
"I think we're more recession-proof, since practically all of our skiers are day trippers," said the president and general manager at Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall, Carol Lugar. "People are going to stay closer to home, and that could help us."
While some ski resorts in Vermont now charge more than $40 a day for a lift ticket, prices at Connecticut ski areas have remained about the same as last year, $30 a day or less. Four of the five ski operators have not passed onto their customers the cost of the expanded state sales tax. "We're absorbing the $1.08 sales tax on each ticket," Mr. Harlow said. "Which means the ticket, before taxes, is $25.92. By comparison, last year it was $26."
Lift-ticket prices on weekends this winter will range from $30 at Mohawk, the state's largest ski area, to $20 at the Woodbury ski area, the smallest. Weekend prices at Powder Ridge and Ski Sundown in New Hartford are $27, while at Mount Southington near Waterbury they are $26.
"We've actually lowered some of our prices," said Rick Carter, the general manager at Ski Sundown, about 15 miles northwest of Hartford. "For example, our beginner's package, which includes a lift ticket, equipment and a group lesson, is now $25, $3 less than last year."
As it was at most Connecticut ski areas, business was down at Ski Sundown last season. "The weather was generally lousy, and after a while people got discouraged," Mr. Carter said. "We were open 90 days, which is about average for us. But business was off by about 20 per cent.
Other ski operators said the economic climate also hurt business last season. "It was a very tough year," said the general manager at Mount Southington, Ed Beckley. "There was the bad weather, the economy and the Persian Gulf war. People didn't want to go out and have a good time skiing while the war was going on."
 
'Very Heartening'
 Mr. Harlow said he was surprised when about 1,000 skiers turned out at Powder Ridge after the season's first snowfall.
"It was very heartening, to say the least," he said. "We get as many as 2,500 people on weekends during the middle of winter. But usually we have only several hundred during our first weekend."
Another good sign, Mr. Harlow added, was that group sales for the winter season are up from last year at Powder Ridge. The ski area, which has 14 trails, is also continuing its policy, initiated last year, of allowing skiers to exchange lift tickets for a later date if they are dissatisfied with the conditions, as long as the exchange is made within an hour after the ticket is purchased.
While skiing was not good last December, conditions improved markedly in January and February. But the absence of snow throughout the state once again had a negative psychological impact on the state's ski areas, which rely on man-made snow far more than the ski behemoths to the north.
"We were open 100 days, which is about average, and we had great skiing," Mr. Harlow said. "But we didn't have many customers."
In an effort to attract more customers, Mohawk Mountain has just installed lights for night skiing. Until last week it was the only ski area in the state that operated only in the daytime.
 
'More Socially Conscious'
 Mrs. Lugar said her father, Walter Schoenknecht, who opened Mohawk Mountain in 1947 and is credited with inventing man-made snow a few years later, often talked about putting in lights, before he died in 1987. "But he decided against it, because it seemed to go hand in hand with alcohol and a party atmosphere, and we're a family oriented ski area."
These days, however, "people are more socially conscious," Mrs. Lugar said. "So we don't think there'll be any problem. And there's a big segment of skiers out there that wants to ski at night, particularly people who don't have time to ski during the day."
Mrs. Lugar is hopeful that the profits from night skiing can help pay off some of the bills remaining from a tornado two and a half years ago that tore down several hundred trees at Mohawk and damaged some buildings, she said. "Our insurance only covered one-third of the costs from the tornado," she said. "And so we were left in a financial hole. So we had to expand our skiing base."
With 23 trails and a vertical drop of 660 feet, Mohawk, 28 miles north of Danbury, is Connecticut's biggest ski area, followed by Ski Sundown, which has 16 trails and a 625-foot drop.
So far this year the state's smallest ski area area, Woodbury, which has a vertical drop of only 300 feet, has been open the most. While the four larger ski areas remained closed over Thanksgiving weekend because of unseasonably warm weather, Woodbury opened the day before the holiday and remained open all weekend and through most of the following week.
"We've expanded our snow making, and we probably have more snow-making equipment than any other small ski area," said Rod Taylor, the owner and manager of Woodbury, which is also well known for the reggae concerts held there during the summer. "That's why we were able to open so early. We're hopeful of recouping from last season, when we lost a lot of money, mainly because we couldn't make enough snow for cross-country skiing, which is a big part of our business."
So, too, is snowboarding, a fast-growing sport, in which people slide down trials on what look like oversize surfboards. About half of Woodbury's customers are now snowboarders.
 
'Nine Days Last Season'
 Perhaps the worst hit have been the state's five other cross-country ski-touring centers, which are totally dependent on natural snow.
"We were only able to open nine days last season, and, unfortunately, only two of those days were on weekends," said Heidi Martin, the executive director of the Winding Trails Cross-Country Ski Center in Farmington, near Hartford, which has 12 miles of trails. "We need a snowstorm of at least eight inches before we can operate, and that hasn't happened very often in recent years."
At that, Winding Trails has fared better than some cross-country ski centers in the state that have not been able to open a single day since the last winter with appreciable snow, in 1988.
"When there's no snow, we have to rely on hikers," Mrs. Martin said. "And now we're thinking of opening the trails to mountain bikers."
 
 
 
WHERE TO SKI IN CONNECTICUT
 Here is a list of the five downhill ski areas in the state:
Mohawk Mountain, Cornwall; 23 trails, 640-foot vertical drop; 672-6100. Off Route 4, four miles east of Route 7.
Ski Sundown, New Hartford; 16 trails, 625-foot vertical drop; 379-9851. Off Route 44, between Avon and Winsted.
Powder Ridge, Middlefield; 14 trails, 500-foot vertical drop; (800) 622-3321. Off Powder Hill Road, about three and a half miles east of Intersttate 91 and the Wilbur Cross Parkway in Meriden.
Mount Southington, Southington; 12 trails, 425-foot vertical drop; 628-0954. One mile west of Exit 30 off Interstate 84.
Woodbury Ski Area, Woodbury; 15 trails, 300-foot vertical drop; 263-2203. Eight miles north of Exit 15 on Interstate 84 and near Route 67 north.
Information on ski conditions at all the areas in the state is available by calling toll free (800) 282-6863.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 10; Column 6; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 344 words

HEADLINE: Two-Families

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Talking column on Dec. 8 on the application of the New York City housing antidiscrimination regulations to two-family houses was more than a little dismissive of the reasons such dwellings with an owner-occupant present have been exempt heretofore. 
 Yes indeed, for many resident owners of two-family houses, renting the other apartment is in fact very much like bringing a guest into one's home, to a degree that people who live in apartment houses cannot conceive. If the host cannot select a guest who will be compatible, the consequences can be terrible, for there are no supers or managing agents or co-op boards to intercede in the ensuing disputes, which have the unhappy property of being disputes between neighbors and also ones between landlord and tenant.
Nearly everyone who buys a two-family house has done so till now in the knowledge that we may choose our neighbor-tenant-guest. No doubt racial and other objectionable criteria for choice have been used by two-family house owners.
But often, the criterion used, which now will provide a pretext for a complaint to the authorities, has been entirely sensible -- selecting people who seem likely to be easy to get on with, rather than a new tenant who seems hostile or adversarial from the outset, for example, by bickering about minor provisions of the lease. From now on, an applicant who has been rejected for that reason can depict himself or herself as having been rejected for a prohibited reason.
If the new regulations produce a large volume of complaints and penalties, some owners, perhaps many of them, will withdraw their units from the rental market. That would be too bad, because the 100,000-plus units are an important part of the city's reasonably priced housing stock. Once again, the housing ideologues will have had it their way: more regulation at the price of less and worse housing.
 
DICK NETZER
 
The writer is professor of economics and public administration at the Robert F. Wagner School of Public Service at New York University

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:

KWANZAA IN YONKERS
The African-American cultural festival of Kwanzaa created in 1966 by Dr. Maulana Karenga, a California professor, as a festival of African-American life, will be celebrated by the Yonkers Public Library Thursday through Dec. 31. 
 A symbolic candlelighting ceremony representing the principles of Kwanzaa will open the celebration at 7 P.M. Thursday at the Getty Square Branch, 7 Main Street. Dr. Eugenia Bains, who teaches in the black studies department of the City University of New York, will be the guest speaker.
In African-American homes where Kwanzaa is observed, candles are lighted for each of seven nights, symbolizing the seven principles of the festival: unity, self-determination, collective work and responsibility, cooperative economics, purpose, creativity and faith.
Those attending the opening are encouraged to wear African dress, and they will be invited to sign a wall of names, which will remain on display throughout the Kwanzaa period.
Among other events is an informal fashion show of African clothes to be held Saturday at 1 P.M. in the Grinton I. Will Branch at 1500 Central Park Avenue. And on Tuesday from 1 to 3 P.M. Adazake Lynn Beville will tell stories in the children's room of the Getty Square Branch. Special exhibitions in both libraries will contain background information about Kwanzaa.
Admission is free; the phone number for more information is 337-1500.
 
'FRIENDS OF THE DRAGON'
 Loquacious the Dragon is the leading character in an original family musical called "Friends of the Dragon, or No Smoking Please," to be performed today at 4 P.M. in the Schoolhouse Theater, Croton Falls.
Produced for a third year by Barnspace Productions, the show was written by Janna Goodspeed, with a score by Lew Zwick. Performers of many ages participate.
Loquacious and his reptilian sidekick, Anguilla, travel the road to Friendship, losing their way but finding themselves in the process. On the journey, the two fire-breathers meet many strange and comedic characters that children have enjoyed each Christmas. Tickets are $6.
Another family-oriented program at the Schoolhouse is a performance at 2 P.M. Friday of Amy Harlib's "One-Woman Chinese Kung Fu Story Theater." Ms. Harlib, wearing the dramatic costumes of ancient Chinese swordsmen, puts on an awesome display of double-edged sword techniques, martial arts, gymnastics and yoga, which she combines with Chinese opera and storytelling of traditional Chinese folk tales.
She developed her performance by drawing on her partly Asian ancestry and from the years she spent in Taiwan in the mid-1980's researching theatrical and martial arts. Admission will be $5. Call the box office at 277-8477 for tickets to both programs. The theater is on Owens Road off Route 22.
 
CHRISTMAS DAY HIKE
 Residents of the Croton area might be interested in taking a break from roasting turkeys and unwrapping presents to participate in a two-mile Christmas Day hike around Old Teller's Point at Croton Point Park.
Christoper Letts, a naturalist-educator with the Hudson River Foundation, will start the tour at 2 P.M., covering the tidal marsh and reef in Croton Bay, a brick one-room schoolhouse and the Underhill wine caverns. Mr. Letts will discuss the influential Teller and Underhill families and the significance of the Point during the Revolutionary War. And he will talk about the Kitchiwank Indians, who were the original occupants of the area, and what has happened to them since they signed a treaty with Dutch settlers in 1645.
The afternoon will end with a cup of hot cider served in front of a roaring fire at the Senasqua Lodge, where the sun can been seen setting behind the Tappan Zee Bridge. Participants will meet in the parking lot of Croton Point Park on Croton Avenue, rain or shine. There is no charge for the program.
 
'A JOURNEY TO AFRICA'
 A segment of the Community Holiday Festival held at Lincoln Center each year will be sponsored by the Westchester Council for the Arts and Con Edison. It features the Ishangi Dancers in "A Journey to Africa," and the program begins at 2 P.M. Saturday in Alice Tully Hall.
The West African dance troupe is led by Baba Ishangi of Ghana, performing in costumes and using 15 native musical instruments from various parts of Africa.
Ishangi serves as a narrator, explaining the religious and secular significance of the songs, movements, masquerades and instruments. One dance performed on stilts is called the Dance of the High Spirits.
Generally, the message of this melange of African cultures is one of the sacredness of the earth, the reverence for family life, respect for elders and the belief that ancestors are part of one's extended family.
Tickets are free and can be obtained by calling 925-6075 or 428-4220.
 
A 'BEANSTALK' MUSICAL
 One of the Traveling Playhouse's most beloved productions is its one-hour musical based on "Jack and the Beanstalk," to be performed Saturday at 1 P.M. in the Yorktown Performing Arts Theater at 1974 Commerce Street in Yorktown Heights. Kay and Ken Rockefeller, directors of the White Plains troupe, constantly revise and update the production, which may account for its continued popularity.
The story line hews closely to the original tale of poor Jack, who trades his mother's cow for a handful of seemingly worthless beans, then climbs the vine that grows from one of the beans into a sky-high world of castles, ogres and hens that lay golden eggs. New songs were written by Richard Kinter, George Corrin designed the sets and Harriet Leigh the costumes. All tickets are $7 and can be reserved by calling 962-6665.
 
LOW-KICK WASSAIL BOWL
 Early American wassail bowls contained a mixture of mulled -- or warmed -- ale and wine, perked up with spices and sugar and garnished with roasted apples. The wassail drink of mulled cider to be served to visitors at George Washington's Headquarters Museum today from 3 to 6 P.M. may not have the same kick, but then the Colonials had horses that knew the way home, something that automakers have not yet devised.
Brandy mace cakes and other toothsome 18th-century sweets called jumbals, king cakes and rout drop cakes will be served around a hearth fire where the cider is kept warm. Recipes for the wassail and cakes will be available.
The museum, once the home of an 18th-century farmer and commandeered by General Washington as headquarters for the Battle of White Plains in 1776, is decorated with handmade folk art ornaments and lighted by candles.
The museum is on Virginia Road in North White Plains, reached by Route 22 or the Bronx River Parkway. Admission, refreshments and recipes are free. Call 949-1236 for more information.
