HEADLINE: ALL ABOUT: MOTORCYCLES;
Selling Bikes After the Wild Ones Have Settled Down

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
IT'S fun to think of motorcycle history in terms of celebrity cachet. James Dean and Marlon Brando made motorcycles sexy and sinister. Malcolm Forbes associated them with well-heeled capitalists. Ronald Reagan visited a Harley-Davidson plant and presto, motorcycles symbolized America's renewed manufacturing competitiveness.
But behind the scenes, the motorcycle business is a lot less glitzy than the parade of flashy names might indicate. In fact, it is downright depressed. The recession, creeping couch potatoism and an explosion of consumer electronics products vying for the dwindling discretionary dollar have created a shrinking market for motorcycles. 
 According to the Motorcycle Industry Council, a trade group in Irvine, Calif., there are 7.3 million bikes on the road, down from 7.7 million in 1985. Don J. Brown, a motorcycle industry consultant also in Irvine, said sales of new street, dirt and sport bikes will reach $1.33 billion for 266,000 units this year, almost identical to last year, but a drop from the $1.9 billion in revenues and 680,000 bikes in the industry's peak year of 1984.
Dealers report that their only vibrant sellers are accessories -- like mugs with motorcycle logos, helmets and helmet decals.
Honda and the other Japanese companies have had the worst time of it, because the yen has made their products prohibitively expensive. But even America's Harley, which says it sells every bike it makes, is not sanguine. "A shrinking market is difficult for everyone," said Michael E. Keefe, Harley's director of marketing communications.
The council describes the typical rider as a 32.5-year-old man with household income of $39,200; a decade ago, he was about 27 and had household earnings of $17,800. "Far from being a rebel, the typical cyclist is the guy next-door," said Gary A. Christopher, the American Honda Motor Company's manager of motorcycle product evaluation.
The manufacturers are actively wooing that guy. Through the council, they have formed Discover Today's Motorcycling, a publicity campaign that positions motorcycling as safe, fun and something an educated, well-mannered person would do. American Honda's own $75 million campaign, "Come Ride With Us," has the same goal.
 
Competing With Japan
Harley's Problem Is Too Few Bikes
 For a while, it looked as though Harley-Davidson would get an easy ride.
Through much of the 1980's Honda, Kawasaki, Yamaha and Suzuki, the four Japanese manufacturers that dominated the American motorcycle market, focused primarily on high-performance sport bikes -- bikes that could go 175 miles an hour, that let their riders crouch forward in racer stance as they took corners at hairpin angles.
The problem, motorcycle experts say now, is that the Japanese were so busy innovating they forgot to hark to their market. "Every year would bring a different looking, faster bike," said Paul Dean, editorial director of Cycle World Magazine in Newport Beach, Calif. "That meant a steep depreciation rate, incredibly high costs for replacement parts and huge insurance premiums."
By the late 1980's the Japanese were erring at the other extreme. Recognizing that they were cannibalizing each other's sales as the market shrunk, they set out to woo new riders. They advertised in magazines like Life instead of biker books, they spurned new high-tech products in favor of non-racy bikes like Honda's Pacific Coast, a midsize touring bike that even has a luggage trunk.
"We were trying so hard to get the yuppies that our core group of cycle enthusiasts felt abandoned," said Honda's Mr. Christopher.
Against that backdrop, Harley cleaned up. It made big, clunky cruisers with lots of macho image but little glitz, whose basic design hadn't changed in years. A weak dollar helped it compete on price.
Mr. Brown said Harley had nearly 31 percent of the street-bike market in 1991; second-seller Honda had 26 percent. R. L. Polk & Company, a Detroit company known for its auto industry statistics, said that in 1985, Honda had nearly 47 percent of the street-bike market, with Harley at a paltry 9.4 percent.
But Harley's sales have been constrained by capacity. The company has a new paint facility and two new assembly lines about to open, but for now it cannot make more than about 70,000 bikes a year. And it exports about 40 percent of them.
The result is that Harley dealers remain on allocation. "I have six customers for every motorcycle I get," said Michael J. Lombardi, a Harley dealer in Staten Island.
The Japanese, meanwhile, are back in stride. They are offering new sport bikes to win back enthusiasts, and small off-road bikes that offer an unintimidating introduction to biking.
While they are unlikely to woo away the Schwarzenegger wannabes -- he rides a Harley -- industry experts think they have a good shot at riders who want a bike that is smaller than a Harley.
 
As Machines Age
Used Bikes Are Selling -- For Now
 Bikers aren't the only ones getting older. So are their machines.
According to the motorcycle council, the average motorcycle in 1985 was less than five years old; last year it was about 9.5. Dealers got more than 14 percent of their revenues from selling used bikes last year.
In Harley's case, one reason why the used market is thriving is that demand for new bikes outstrips supply. For the Japanese bikes, which are more plentiful, the reasons are rooted in the steeply rising prices. "People are saying, 'Let someone else take the depreciation,' and looking for good used bikes," said Mr. Dean of Cycle World..
The vibrant secondary market is unlikely to last much longer, though. As fewer new bikes are sold, the number of bikes coming into the used market must perforce dwindle. That means that the most popular used bikes will become harder to find, and concomittantly more expensive.
Mr. Brown, the consultant, predicts that sales of used motorcycle will drop as much as 25 percent in the next four years. "That means new bikes will soon sell well again," he said.
 
The Requisite Helmet
Sales Are Insured As States Pass Laws
 Bike manufacturers may be wimpering, but helmet makers are all smiles. The reason: Unlike bike sales, helmet sales have seen nary a blip. Though the council does not break out sales of helmets, sales of peripheral equipment reached $1.66 billion last year. There are eight million helmets in use.
"Our business has grown 20 percent a year, and there's no reason to think that will stop," said Patrick Donnelly, director of sales for the Shoei Safety Helmet Corporation, the Los Angeles company that is the largest helmet maker.
Helmet sales are bound to increase even further, as more states pass laws requiring riders to wear helmets. California, a major holdout, just passed such a law, effective Jan. 1. Most experts say a Federal law is inevitable.
New helmet technology also is spurring sales. Stores already are selling Italian helmets with a thermal control system that makes them cool in summer and warm in winter. And David A. Bottell, a California entrepreneur, is looking for a manufacturer to make the Protector, a new helmet designed by Lawrence A. Bernstein, the California inventor, that uses special side panels to enhance peripheral vision and hearing. "Those are the things riders complain about most," said Mr. Bottell.
Mr. Bottell is getting high-profile vocal support from Gary Busey, the 47-year-old actor who almost died in a cycle accident three years ago.
Scarcely two months after his accident, Mr. Busey was railing against mandatory helmet laws. His argument: Helmets took away too much hearing and peripheral vision. Now, he claims that motorcycle industry representatives took advantage of his post-accident emotional vulnerability to get him to castigate helmet laws. With almost religious zeal, he is holding press conferences, lobbying in Washington, and otherwise trying to insure that helmets are made mandatory throughout the country.
"There's a reason God let me come back alive," Mr. Busey said. "And that's to make sure that we don't see more kids with the life smashed out of their bodies because they aren't wearing helmets."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Economic Warfare, 1991 Style

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IT IS NOT only the Soviet Union that evaporated in 1991. So too did the concept of economic cooperation among the leading Western economies.
That became clearer than ever last week, as the German central bank turned its back on the interests of most of Europe, let alone the United States, and jacked up interest rates.
The Bundesbank's surprisingly strong move left its discount rate at 8 percent, or more than double the 3.5 percent rate that this country's Federal Reserve adopted as it cut its rate by a point on Friday. 
 If nothing else, the Bundesbank's move showed that all the talk of international cooperation that emanated from the European summit at Maastricht was little more than empty words, a feeling that was reinforced by signs that the world's trade talks are unlikely to produce agreement. The Bundesbank is worried about rising inflation at home -- 4 percent is deemed too high -- and about requests from labor unions for 6 percent raises. It is also miffed that its good advice a couple of years ago, cautioning against the monetary unification of Germany on terms that grossly overvalued the East German currency, was ignored by the politicians.
It was quickly noted that the national leader most likely to suffer as a result of the Bundesbank's actions is John Major, the British Prime Minister who led the resistance to Germany's effort to unify Europe's economy under German domination. There have been signs that Britain was emerging from its recession and hopes that interest rates might drop. Now rates are unlikely to fall, and could rise, as Britain's election campaign begins.
But the German action will hurt not only those who opposed Germany in the European summit. France, a German ally, is likely to feel compelled to raise its interest rates soon, despite the shakiness of its economy. For both France and Britain, the alternative is likely to be a devaluation of their currencies against the mark.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman who only five months ago saw clear signs of recovery in this country's economy, now sees signs of stagnation, a situation that will be worsened as Germany's move dampens Europe's economies.
Mr. Greenspan is responding on several fronts. The decision to cut interest rates again got the most attention, but perhaps even more interesting was his attack on bank examiners, who he said are appraising real estate loan collateral "on a liquidation basis" when they should be giving the banks some slack. "I've always argued that it is the purpose of commercial banks to make illiquid loans," he told a Congressional hearing, adding that it was unfair to appraise property based on what it would get if sold today.
That kind of regulator bashing, coming from the chief regulator himself, may or may not encourage banks to make more loans. But it certainly reinforces the impression that Potomac panic is on the rise as the election nears.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Bundesbank's One-Two Punch

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
A BOXER in the ring knows that he is going to get punched. But sometimes he is surprised by the force of the blow. He will recoil, shake his head and wonder what has happened.
That is what occurred on Thursday when the German Bundesbank, which is becoming the rogue elephant of Europe, raised its two key interest rates -- the Lombard rate and the discount rate -- by half a percentage point each. 
 The Bundesbank move was not a surprise. An increase had generally been expected soon because the bank is intent on fighting domestic inflation regardless of the economic pain it causes its allies. But the size -- twice the expected increase of a quarter of a percentage point in the Lombard rate -- and the timing were a shock.
The Bundesbank's decision has an impact throughout Europe because of the dominance of Germany in the European Monetary System. Even though France, Britain and other European colleagues would like to slash interest rates to revive falling economies, the rules of the monetary system force them to follow German interest rates to keep their currencies within the system's set ranges. In this case, the French may have to raise their rates, and other countries may not be able to cut them, as they had hoped.
So there was a collective shaking of heads in Europe as analysts cleared their minds and studied the impact of the rate increase, which raised the Lombard rate to 9.75 percent and the discount rate to 8 percent.
First, it was not brotherly nor was it in line with the theme of European economic unity reaffirmed just two weeks ago. For markets, the rate increase seems to tip the scale in favor of bonds over stocks in Europe, analysts said. The rise in interest rates means slower economic growth and even lower company earnings. This makes stock investments look a little riskier than bonds.
The Federal Reserve Board's cut of the American discount rate to 3.5 percent from 4.5 percent on Friday will probably add to the upward pressure the Bundesbank has applied on European interest rates. The move strengthened the mark in the monetary system, forcing other European currency values closer to the point where interest rates may have to be raised.
The resulting rise in European currencies against the dollar could also hurt the sales of European exporting companies, like chemical and automobile manufacturers. And it will depress the earnings of European companies that have significant operations in the United States.
But looking to the middle or end of next year, the impact on investing decisions is a little harder to divine. The move by the Bundesbank may finally signal the top of the interest rate cycle in Europe, and so interest rates may finally begin to fall and thus give stocks a lift.
"I do not doubt that 1992 will be a good year for continental bond and equity markets," said Andrew Garthwaite, who does international asset allocation at S. G. Warburg Securities in London. "But the first quarter of next year will not be good and bonds will do better than equities."
Guy Rigden, director of strategy at UBS Phillips & Drew in London, was a little more shaken by the Bundesbank blow. The rate increase, he said, confirms his switch in the balance of his recommended portfolio back toward bonds. "I had bonds overweight three months ago and moved back into equities, and that was a very poor move," he said. "And you can quote me on that."
A key for stocks will be the timing of a fall in interest rates. But while analysts said this is the top for official German rates, they do not know when they will drop.
"It gets the top behind you, but it is incorrect to expect the Bundesbank can cut fairly soon," said Warren Oliver, an economist at UBS in London. He expects no reduction before May or June. And if the important German wage negotiations do not go well, he said, "it could be all year" before there is a cut.
Outside of stock and bond markets, the rate rise increases tension in the European Monetary System because of the pressure it puts on other members to keep interest rates high while their economies are sluggish or in recession. This pressure raises talk of realignment, which would mean currency devaluations and is unsettling to investors in markets like Britain and Italy.
And there is the political impact, which could also spill over into the stock market in Britain. The Bundesbank rate increase means that the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major has little room to lower interest rates before the 1992 election. High rates play into the hand of the rival Labor Party. Mr. Oliver of UBS said a interest rate cut the firm had penciled in for the first half of the year is now in doubt.
The timing of the Bundesbank's cut is also of interest. It appears the decision could have been made two weeks ago at the central bank's last meeting. But that meeting came just before the critical session in Maastricht, the Netherlands, on European monetary and political union. And the Bundesbank needed all the support it could get, especially from the most reluctant participant there, Prime Minister Major.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Of Stars and Moonbeams

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
HER father, Edmund G. (Pat) Brown, was Governor of California from 1959 to 1967. Her brother, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown, held the same post from 1975 to 1983 and is now a Democratic Presidential candidate. But there are those in California political circles who believe that Kathleen Brown could prove to be the family's real star.
Ms. Brown was elected California's Treasurer last year in her first run for statewide office. As Treasurer, she oversees the sale of state bonds and manages the state's investment portfolio. And she holds the job at a time when California faces its worst financial crisis in decades. 
 The state has been battered by unemployment in key industries like aerospace and construction, its tax revenues are falling short of expectations and its budget deficit is mounting. Standard & Poor's recently downgraded California's AAA bond rating a notch and Moody's Investors Services warned that it would take similar action if the state could not resolve its fiscal woes.
Ms. Brown, 46, compared S.& P. to "the Grinch that stole Christmas," arguing that California's economy remains fundamentally strong. She has also been promoting steps she said will help the state bounce back, including increased spending on roads, schools, water systems and other infrastructure.
While her lineage has given her considerable political visibility, it also carries with it some baggage, not the least of which is the inevitable comparison to her brother and what some people consider his lingering "Governor Moonbeam" image.
Ms. Brown, who graduated from Stanford University and earned a law degree at Fordham University, has always said she supports her brother, but has also subtly distanced herself from him, referring to herself during last year's campaign as "a different shade of Brown."

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Breaking Away, With a $2 Billion Piece of Carbide

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
BEFORE too long, H. William Lichtenberger will be busy playing the name game.
Until last week, Mr. Lichtenberger was president and chief operating officer of the Union Carbide Corporation. But then Carbide announced that it would be spinning off its industrial gases division in the next few months and that Mr. Lichtenberger would be the new company's first chairman and chief executive. The business will get its own shareholders -- and will soon need its own name. 
 "We are best known in this country as Linde," Mr. Lichtenberger said, referring to the brand name used by the division for its products in the United States. But since a German company owns the rights to that name outside the Western Hemisphere, it will not do for a global business.
About 50 percent of the sales of Union Carbide industrial gases are made outside the United States. In 1990, the division had sales of $2.38 billion, representing roughly one-third of the parent company's total.
The spinoff is the centerpiece of a Carbide plan, which also includes selling $500 million in other assets, to reduce the parent company's debt and increase its attraction to investors. Without the gases division, Carbide sales will be concentrated in basic chemicals and plastics.
Whether this is the most propitious time for the gas division to go it alone is far from certain, of course. Mr. Lichtenberger said sales of industrial gases, like oxygen, nitrogen and helium, largely track the overall health of the American and worldwide economies. "Gases are used by people who make things, from integrated steel mills to the corner auto body shop," he said. "So when people are not making as many things, there is a problem."
Yet environmental concerns both in this country and abroad are providing some opportunities for sales growth, even in a sluggish economy, he added.
"Just about any process that requires heat runs cleaner when you add oxygen to it," he said. And the cryogenic techniques used to liquefy air are applicable to capturing unwanted volatile organic compounds before they are released.
Mr. Lichtenberger, who is 56 years old, has an extensive background in the gas business. After earning both a liberal arts degree and a B.S. in chemical engineering from the University of Iowa, he joined the gas division at Carbide in 1959. Since then, he has held assignments in research, engineering, operations, sales and marketing. He also had overseas assignments, including serving as vice president for the industrial gas business for Union Carbide Europe from 1978 to 1980. He left the gas sector in 1985, when he was appointed president of the company's solvents and coating materials division.
Although he will be independent, Mr. Lichtenberger will not be far from his former colleagues at Carbide. The company sold its headquarters building in Danbury, Conn., in the mid-1980's and then leased it back for 20 years.
"We will have part of that rental obligation in the new company," he said. "I can't see that changing in the near term."

HEADLINE: Are Interest-Rate Cuts Any MAtch for This Recession

 BODY:
For economists, these are puzzling times. The recession was supposed to be short and shallow, but it has lasted 17 months -- 11 months is the average. And the tumble was no less deep than in other recessions. The recovery,  supposed to be vigorous,  has stalled. Last week the White House acknowledged something was amiss: "The economy is going very slow," said Marlin Fitzwater, a White House spokesman. On Friday,  the Federal Reserve again cut the discount rate, this time by an eye-popping  full percentage point, to 3.5 percent. So where is the economy headed? Has the Administration's  reliance on interest-rate cuts as its major policy lever worked?  Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear Stearns & Company Inc., Marc A. Miles, executive vice president of H. C. Wainwright & Company Economics Inc. and Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company Inc., shared their views with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times. 

Q. Is the economy recovering?
 
Mr. Kudlow: Yes, I think there's an unmistakable recovery developing. It's slow and it has caused a tremendous amount of impatience from the public and from the politicians. It is a recovery that has some holes in it. I wouldn't say it's touching all cylinders. But my basic sense is that lower interest rates are a powerful recuperative element in the economy, as is lower inflation.
 
Q. Mr. Sinai, you have an elaborate forecasting model for the economy. Does your model say the economy has recovered?
 
Mr. Sinai: No, no, no. The model doesn't really want to produce anything other than a sideways movement in the economy for another two or three quarters and then a very modest upturn. Typically, recoveries average 6 1/2 percent growth after the downturn has run its course. But this upturn will only have 1 1/2 to 2 percent growth from the fourth quarter of this year to the fourth quarter of next year. Not very many households and businesses will feel that's really a recovery.
 
Mr. Miles: We're very bullish right now. We're bullish about the economy, the stock market and the bond market. All the signals we use are pointing up at this point. There are lag times before growth kicks in.
 
Q. Which signals are those?
 
Mr. Miles: Interest rates are the major signal of what's coming. That's what we've been using for the last decade or so to anticipate trends in the economy. We've estimated that the average time between the drop in interest rates and when you get the maximum positive kick is between 12 and 18 months. Interest rates on three-month T-bills have fallen about 350 basis points since mid-1990. We're looking for higher growth and longer growth. We see '92 and '93 as back-to-back years of 4 to 5 percent growth.
 
Mr. Sinai: He must be working for Bush!
 
Q. When do you see those levels of growth beginning?
 
Mr. Miles: Well, you're asking for a level of precision I don't think any of us have.
 
Q. You mean you don't have an estimate?
 
Mr. Miles: My guess is somewhere around the beginning of the year with the growth rate accelerating into the middle of 1993.
 
Mr. Kudlow: My fourth-quarter figures look pretty flat. But I'm not as pessimistic as Allen on the recovery. I expect a much better first half of 1992, in fact a much better 1992 over all. My numbers suggest about a 3 percent growth rate.
 
Q. What is the effect of the interest-rate cuts?
 
Mr. Kudlow: If we look at the declines in mortgage rates and corporate interest expenses, we come up with something around $40 billion to $50 billion on an annual basis. This is slowly stimulating the economy.
 
Q. Does that make the effect of those cuts similar to a tax cut?
 
Mr. Kudlow: I hate to put it in the Keynesian sense.
 
Q. Will they stimulate the economy as Mr. Miles is suggesting?
 
Mr. Kudlow: They're more like incentives, along with lower inflation. They enable real earnings to improve, the quality of real income to improve. Lower inflation is important with respect to capital investment also. If the inflation rate falls and interest rates fall, it is like getting a de facto cut in the capital-gains rate.
What concerns me more is the long-term economic outlook. With just a 3 percent growth rate for the next four or five years, the U.S. economy will remain below its long-term post-World War II average growth rate. That will put output levels almost $2 trillion below what they would otherwise have been by 1996. At the current growth rate, I estimate there will be six million fewer jobs created than if we had a normal recovery.
 
Q. And you still call it a recovery?
 
Mr. Kudlow: It's a recovery in the technical sense, yes. Some key variables are moving upward.
 
Mr. Miles: This recovery is on track. Industrial production is higher now than last spring. Everything that is happening in the economy is consistent with the history that lower interest rates are associated with weaker growth in the near term but more growth down the road. So, yes, in the near term -- now -- the economy, the recovery, has not been very strong. But it is picking up steam and it is getting stronger.
 
Q. In 1982, the economy was led out of the recession by the entrepreneur. New businesses were formed and jobs were created. Is that happening now?
 
Mr. Kudlow: Not at all. What concerns me -- and it's consistent with the weakness in jobs -- is the lack of any new business formation, new business starts. In fact the whole entrepreneurial sector is moribund. That's different from 1982.
In the last three years the policy signals from Washington -- and the actual legislation -- have been against risk-capital investing. Whether we're talking about the increase in the capital-gains tax or the lengthening of depreciation or the elimination of the passive loss in real estate or the heavy-handed regulation of banks and savings and loans, or the interference with the junk-bond market or the regulatory-related cost increases on businesses from such measures as the Clean Air Act and the Americans With Disabilities Act. All of these are noble objectives. But their consequences are turning out to be rather anti-business and anti-capital formation. It has created uncertainty about the future. People are afraid to make commitments of three, four, five years for venture capital investment.
 
Q. Is that the reason you think the recovery will be subpar?
 
Mr. Kudlow: That's right. It takes a lot to derail the American economy, particularly at these interest-rate levels and inflation levels. But if economic policy is operating against the innovator, against the entrepreneur, against the risk-taker, we're going to see a very low rate of employment increase.
 
Mr. Miles: I never underestimate the ability of Washington to make a bad situation worse.
 
Mr. Sinai: You need lower interest rates and lower inflation to sow the seeds of future growth. But the economy is still missing three things: jobs, income growth and profits. Real income growth has been puny. We've lost more than one million jobs in the last year. And of course profits have been squeezed for three years. I agree; the entrepreneurial incentives are very low.
But we have also had tax increases during the recession that have acted like a brake on growth. That's never happened in the post-war period. We've always used fiscal stimulus. This time Federal taxes were increased by $17.6 billion and state and local taxes increased by $15.4 billion. Another $17 billion in increases are due in 1992. Add to that cutbacks in defense spending in real terms. That's a lot of fiscal restraint to put on a weak economy.
 
Mr. Miles: We're going through an adjustment back to a period that's closer to the 50's and 60's with low inflation and low interest rates and that takes some time. People are shifting away from assets that used to be inflationary hedges. Housing prices are dropping; art prices are dropping; gold prices are dropping. The price of about everything is dropping except baseball cards.
 
Q. Who wins from this switch?
 
Mr. Miles: The stocks of companies that produce basic consumer staples will do better in this longer-term environment -- stocks with stable, consistent earnings, that is. So will small cap stocks -- growth stocks -- where the bulk of the earnings are in later years. Utility companies will do well. They went out of favor in the 1970's with all their long-term debt, but with interest rates falling they are likely to become attractive again. Look at banks. Banks made their money in bygone days by the spread between the rate at which they borrowed money and the rate at which they lent it. That became uncertain for them in the 70's. Now we're going back to a period where the spread will be more dependable and banks will thrive.
 
Q. You're optimistic about banks?
 
Mr. Sinai: We all are. Of the various sectors of the economy, I would say finance is best -- banks and security houses. Banks are expanding and will continue to expand over the next year. The residential side of home building and buying will do better over the next year -- a mini-recovery in housing. The financial side of housing is very favorable. I think manufacturing is going into a slide.
 
 Mr. Kudlow: I like the story on finance. But I think we're going to see surprisingly good manufacturing performance, not only for domestic, but also for international purposes. One of the best initiatives of the Bush Administration has been its revival of Latin America trade. United States capital goods producers, manufacturers, construction companies are going to help rebuild Latin America. I wouldn't be surprised if by the end of the 90's, our exports to Latin America exceed our exports to Western Europe.
 
Q. There is a lot of talk in Washington about tax cuts and other measures to stimulate the economy. President Bush said he will reveal new economic measures during his State of the Union Address next month. What new measures are needed?
 
Mr. Miles: There is a panic going on in Washington and there's a lot of emphasis on doing something. But doing some thing does not necessarily mean you are doing what is right. It is a recipe for creating problems. I haven't seen a proposal coming out of Washington that I like. Most of the proposals involve taking from one group and giving to another: giving to the middle class based on the number of children -- which might make a lot of obstetricians happy -- or taking from the upper-income groups based on their income. I can't see any of this really stimulating the overall economy. I don't see anything positive coming out of all this talk in Washington. The best thing they could do in Washington is just go home.
 
Q. What about further interest-rate cuts?
 
Mr. Miles: It will create more uncertainty.
 
Mr. Kudlow: I happen to agree with Marc on that. I agree with Marc that whenever policy reform is in the air there's a risk it will do more harm than good.
We made a lot of big changes in the '86 tax bill -- some of them I like, such as the lower income-tax rates; some of them I dislike, such as the capital-gains changes and the depreciation. It seems to me that in legislative and in economic terms most of the impacts of the '86 tax bill were felt by around 1988. And I think it's not a coincidence that in the past three years the economy has been stagnating. We've had 0.7 percent real growth in the last 11 quarters.
To me the most egregious mistake in the 1986 tax law revision was the hike in capital gains, curtailing pass-through of depreciation, the abolition of any real estate benefits, the luxury tax and the income-tax hike.
 
Mr. Sinai: The Federal Reserve is moving toward a 4 percent discount rate by the end of the year. And as a prescriptive policy, I would say that shortly after the first of the year it should move the discount rate to 3 1/2 and the Federal funds rate to 3 3/4.
On the fiscal side, I would favor a minimal to modest dose of fiscal-stimulus, short-run measures that would help move growth up toward 1 1/2 or 2 percent on the low side, but measures taken that would also help us in some of our longer-run secular growth problems. And I'll tell you what those are. On the growth side, tax cuts -- and I don't care what form, lower Social Security taxes, income credits for members of a family or lower marginal rates. I happen to like lower marginal rates for $75,000-and-under families and a capital-gains tax reduction. I would also prefer a payroll tax break.
 
Mr. Kudlow: I agree we need a cut in the capital-gains tax.
 
Q. Are you worried these stimulative measures might increase the budget deficit?
 
Mr. Kudlow: I can get through whole days, even weeks at a time, without worrying about the budget deficit.

HEADLINE: Some Quality-Testing Methods

 BODY:
BEFORE looking at policy illustrations, it makes sense to compile a list of companies you might want to do business with. Good financial planners are beginning to shop from a short list of insurers that meet specific criteria.
For example, Andrew Wray, a planner in Memphis, looks for an insurer that has been rated A+ for the past 10 years by A. M. Best & Company in Oldwick, N.J., the only agency that has been rating insurers at least that long. The insurer also must be rated at least AA by one of the other three leading ratings agencies: Standard & Poor's and Moody's Investors Services in New York and Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Mr. Wray rules out any insurer that has a rating below a "contingent A" by Best, an AA- by S.& P. or Duff & Phelps or an Aa3 by Moody's. Ratings from these companies are available by calling the company and asking for the ratings desk. 
 It is also important to know how the insurer has treated existing policyholders. Some apply the same interest rate across the board, adjusting older policies to reflect the company's more recent experience.
But others sort policyholders into groups, marketing new products with competitive rates but leaving existing policyholders with lower rates. "You want to know how fairly they treated old policyholders in the past," said Harold Evensky, a Miami planner.

HEADLINE: Business Is Booming At Consignment Shops

BYLINE: By DEBORAH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Picture a boutique where a Chanel suit sells for less than a third of its original price. Or a shop offering Ralph Lauren boots for $70, an Armani blouse for $150 or a sequined evening suit by Bob Mackie for $550 -- instead of, say, $3,000. Wishful thinking? Not at all. These and similar bargains were recently spotted at consignment shops on Madison Avenue.
From coast to coast, resourceful shoppers with an eye toward a bargain are reaping the benefits of buying recycled designer clothes at consignment shops, which have become one of the country's booming recession-time businesses. People are buying everything from children's overalls to men's dinner jackets and women's sparkling sequined ball gowns at a fraction of their original cost. 
 Consumers benefit from consignment shops in two ways. People with clothes to discard earn back some of their original investment, while budget-conscious shoppers gain access to designer clothing at low cost.
 
Picking and Finding

 
 "If you pick through them, you'll always find something," said Marlene Brown, a substitute teacher at Public School 6 in Manhattan, who shops at the consignment shop Encore, 1132 Madison Avenue, at 84th Street.
One day Mrs. Brown went to Hermes to buy a navy blue patterned scarf. "They were over $200 and I couldn't find one that I liked," she said. "Then I went past Encore and something called my name and boom, there it was: the perfect navy scarf with red and gold. It was $85."
Natasha Anzell, a market research supervisor, raves about Designer Resale, 324 East 81st Street. "I only buy labels," Ms. Anzell said, "and the first time I walked in here, I bought a Donna Karan navy blue crepe suit. It was stunning and brand new. I paid about $150."
Consignment shops accept high-quality used clothing in perfect or near-perfect condition and sometimes clothing that has never been worn. They then sell them at a third or less of the original cost and generally pay those who offer the clothes 40 or 50 percent of the selling price.
"We're getting clothes from women who used to dump them, or give them to their housekeeper or relatives in Hungary," said Laura Fluhr, owner of Michael, a long-established resale shop at 1041 Madison Avenue in New York.
 
Money for Throwaways

 
 Emilie Tribich, for example, a Manhattan woman who confesses to being something of a shopping addict, earned close to $1,000 this year on clothing that she and her husband consigned for sale at the Exchange Unlimited in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan. "It's a tremendous amount of money for stuff I would throw away," she said.
The consignment market has traditionally catered to women and children, but in the last few years, some men's shops have opened up, and business is flourishing. At Gentlemen's Closet in Houston, sales are up by 61 percent over last year, according to Toni Coleman, the owner. The biggest demands, she said, are for clothes by Giorgio Armani. "We sell them as fast as we get them."
Armani suits that would retail for up to $1,200 are $179 to $199, Ms. Coleman said. Tuxedos are also strong sellers. They range in price from $70 to $150, less than one might spend to rent one.
There are no figures available on the exact number of consignment shops, but membership in the National Association of Resale and Thrift Shops, based in Chicago, has increased from 150 five years ago to 850 members today. A flourishing offshoot, particularly at this time of year, is the growing business of renting party clothes, not just men's tuxedos, but women's gowns and accessories.
"People are more concerned than ever about being smart shoppers," said Trudy Miller, the organization's president, who runs a shop in Chicago Heights called Second Thoughts.
Despite the sharp increases in the industry, there is still a stigma attached to the idea of wearing someone else's clothes.
"We're trying to overcome that all the time," Ms. Miller said, "but those who feel uncomfortable with the idea of wearing used clothing probably haven't been in resale shops. Once we get them in the door we can convert them to customers."
But some of those shoppers might not mind taking advantage of a special sale at the Gene London Studio, 897 Broadway (between 19th and 20th Streets), which is not normally open to the public, through Jan. 7, including today. Castoffs from celebrities like Cher, Madonna and Elizabeth Taylor as well as thousands of other clothes made for the film industry by Gene London will be available. The sale also includes designer clothes by Chanel, Norman Norell and Scaasi, and men's clothing at as little as 10 percent of their original cost.
To keep high quality and current stock, many resale shops have strict guidelines about the merchandise they accept. When garments are brought in, they are carefully inspected for signs of wear and tear. As much as half the merchandise offered to consignment shops is turned away, some proprietors say.
At Michael, pieces must be "perfect," no more than a year and a half old (the shop can usually tell if an item is dated) and in women's sizes ranging from 4 to 12. (Larger sizes don't sell well.)
"The better the quality, the faster it goes," said Ms. Fluhr of Michael, the Manhattan shop. The biggest demands, she said, are for clothes from Chanel and Armani.
On a recent visit to the shop, the racks included clothing with both names at less than half their retail cost. A navy Chanel suit, size 8 (at least $2,700 new), was on sale for $750. A silk chiffon Armani blouse, size 8, was $150, down from more than $600 new. A black satin Chanel bag was $275; new ones start at $800.
At the Encore shop just a few blocks up from Michael on Madison Avenue, a recent visit uncovered some enticing new items. Short unworn black leather boots by Ralph Lauren, size 10, were $70, instead of roughly $225. Unworn Chanel flats, size 10, were $200, down from more than $400.
While bargains abound at consignment shops around the country, some proprietors say that the best buys for shoppers in consignment shops are on formal wear that is often worn just once, as opposed to a suit that might have been worn repeatedly.
It's possible to find choice items any time of the year, but arm loads of top clothing often arrive at the end of August and March, when people clean out their closets.
The children's market is well suited to recycling since clothing is worn for such a short time in smaller sizes. At Second Act, a children's wear shop on Madison Avenue in Manhattan, the items that sell best are the most practical ones.
"The smock dress or the Austrian coat sit here," said Joan Blake, the owner. "People are only buying truly what they need" -- like jeans, corduroy pants and winter boots.
Many consignment shops maintain a low profile, aware that buyers may not want to announce to the world where their Chanel clothes -- or even children's garments -- come from.
Unlike Bloomingdale's and Saks Fifth Avenue, said Ms. Fluhr of Michael, "We don't put our name on our shopping bags."

 Here are some of the better known consignment shops in New York:

HEADLINE: Chess

BYLINE: By Robert Byrne

 BODY:
There are players who look for easy marks because they don't want to risk losing. They are not interested in glorious adventures. But there are others who want to cross swords with the very best, to prove themselves in a hot crucible. The latter are more likely to become champions.
One of the latter is the United States champion 17-year-old Gata Kamsky of Brooklyn. In the elite Interpolis International Tournament in Tilburg, the Netherlands, Oct. 17 to Nov. 4 he made a highly respectable even score. But that gave no hint of how his games went with the world champion, Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, and with Kasparov's countryman and challenger for the title, Anatoly Karpov. 
 Kamsky twice got the upper hand against Kasparov, only to see this illustrious opponent escape with two draws. Kamsky's first game with Karpov was a level draw all the way, but he won the second with the type of solid, tenacious positional play for which his opponent is famous.
In the 1990 world championship match in New York and Lyons, France, Karpov used this Exchange Variation of the Gruenfeld Defense to score one victory and three draws against Kasparov. But this was the first time he has used 9 Rb1 and it is doubtful that the provoked 9 . . . a6 represents any kind of weakness for Black.
The method chosen by Kamsky was straightforward: exchange queens so White cannot try for a mating attack and play 13 . . . e6 to restrain the d pawn, and economical development. His 20 . . . Nb5! was unpleasant for Karpov to meet. Thus, 21 Be3? loses to 21 . . . Nc3, while 21 d5 ed 22 ed Nc3 23 Bc3 Rc3 yields Black a chance to bring about exchanges that could permit him to approach and win the d pawn with his king.
Karpov chose e5, yet this immobilized his center pawns and encouraged Kamsky to embark on a strategy of infiltration.
Kamsky's exchange of bishop for knight with 28 . . . Be1! was based on the idea that with pawns fixed on e5 and d4, the white QB was restricted in scope. Moreover, it was correct to stop Karpov from playing 29 Nd3 and then either 30 Nc5 or 30 Nf4.
On 46 g4, Kamsky declined to grab a pawn with 46 . . . Na5 because that would have let the white rook penetrate on the c line and, with the QB, organize counterplay against the black king.
Instead, he produced a beautiful pawn sacrifice with 46 . . . Ra1 47 Rc3 Rh1 48 Kg3 g5! 49 hg h4. After 50 Kg2 Re1, Karpov could not play 51 Kf2? because of 51 . . . h3!, nor 51 Bc4 because of 51 . . . Bc4 52 Rc4 Kg6 53 f4 (53 Kh3 Re3! 54 Kh4 Rf3 puts the white king in danger of such machinations as . . . Ne7, . . . Nd5 and . . . Nf4) Re3 followed by 54 . . . Rg3, recovering the pawn with a death grip on the light squares.
Facing the threat of 56 . . . Rg2 and 57 . . . h3, Karpov played 56 Rd3 and was immediately crushed by Kamsky's 56 . . . Rg2 57 Kf1 Re2! 58 Ke2 Bc4. The ex-champion played 59 d5 ed 60 Kd2 Bd3 61 Kd3, but after 61 . . . d4!, he could not stop the two passed pawns except by losing his bishop.
After 72 . . . a5, there was no point in going further with 73 e6 fe 74 Ke6 a4 75 f6 Kg6 76 f7 Nd8. Karpov gave up.

HEADLINE: It's a Mean One;
There's No Place To Hide From The Economic Blues

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FROM the beginning of the Bush Presidency, the tune from Washington on the economy was upbeat. At first, the soaring 1980's were said to be ending in a soft landing. When the recession hit last year, it was promised to be short and mild. By late last spring, the policymakers were assuring the country that the corner had been turned and new prosperity was at hand.
Last week, the music changed. 
 In an abrupt about-face, the White House acknowledged for the first time what millions have perceived and Democrats have harped on for weeks. "The people of this country know that the economy is in trouble," said Marlin Fitzwater, the press secretary, "and it doesn't make any sense to play games."
To dramatize his determination to ease what he began calling "tough times," Mr. Bush went to Texas the next day, donned a hard hat and said: "Yes, there are layoffs and many families are having a rough go of it, and the American people want action. And action is what they'll get. And I want every American to know that getting the economy back on track is my No. 1 priority."
While the President was traveling, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the Government's most influential economic policymaker, was telling Congress that his optimism earlier this year had been unjustified and the economy now was flagging.
On Friday, in an almost desperate effort to reverse the momentum, the Fed took the dramatic step of reducing the discount rate by a percentage point to 3.5 percent, the lowest since 1964. It was the first time in 10 years that this key rate, what the central bank charges banks for loans, had been cut by a full point in one day.
Why the turnabout? In part it was because the raw data on the economy could no longer be denied. In part it was because at the start of the week, John H. Sununu was replaced as White House chief of staff by former Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who advocates a new public relations approach. The most important reason was probably that as the election year neared, the President was being battered by Democrats accusinghim of being out of touch with many ordinary Americans.
 
Little Consumer Confidence
 The week's economic statistics were indeed stark: The Federal Reserve reported that industrial production, one of the main gauges of current business activity, fell by an unexpectedly large four-tenths of 1 percent in November. Housing starts were off 2.1 percent last month, almost guaranteeing that 1991 will be the worst year for home builders since World War II. A Commerce Department survey found that businesses plan to increase investments in plants and equipment next year by only 5.4 percent, much less than what could be anticipated in a normal recovery. New applications for unemployment benefits in the first week in December reached one of their highest levels in more than eight years.
The data did not tell the whole story. Consumer confidence, as measured by the index of the Conference Board, a widely followed business research group, is at one of its lowest points ever. Mr. Greenspan said the mood of the country was much worse than economic conditions warranted. "There is a deep-seated concern out there, which I must say to you I have not seen in my lifetime," he told the House Ways and Means Committee. People, he said, are worried "about whether the current generation will live as well as previous ones."
The real killer came Wednesday, when General Motors announced that it would close 21 of its plants in the United States and Canada over the next few years and eliminate more than 70,000 jobs. The timing of the announcement the week before Christmas multiplied the shock.
 
Cue From Reagan
 In a political sense, an underlying aspect made the layoffs even worse. The jobs being abolished at the automotive plants are the kind of high-paying manufacturing jobs that were the foundation of the flourishing American middle class in the 1950's and 1960's. The basis of the Democratic campaign against the President is that while fat cats thrived in the Reagan and Bush years, the middle class faltered badly. Robert C. Stempel, G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, whose compensation last year was $1,074,695, is one of a group of business executives going to the Far East with the President late this month. After a meeting about the trip in the White House Thursday, Mr. Stempel was ushered out a back door to avoid reporters.
Mr. Skinner took over in the West Wing of the White House Monday morning and put out the word that he wanted an "inclusive approach" to policy development "to let valued advice get to the President."
Since before Thanksgiving, the Democrats have been hammering the President on the economy at every opportunity. At last Sunday night's debate of the six Democratic Presidential candidates, the one common theme was that Mr. Bush had no notion of how people were suffering. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa set the tone in answer to the very first question about why he had decided to run for President.
"I started thinking about what was really happening to this country," Mr. Harkin declared. "And I saw more and more people going out of work. I saw families without hope.
"And then what I saw was, I saw a President completely out of touch with the American people," he added. "George Bush doesn't understand ordinary, hard-working Americans. He has no concept of what's going on. He's isolated from the American people."
Each of the other candidates chimed in with a similar piece. The Democrats have taken a cue from Ronald Reagan. He was elected President in 1980 in large part because he articulated how disturbed ordinary people were by the social excesses of the 1960's and 1970's -- more crime, more welfare, racial tension, freer sex, lack of patriotism. The Democrats hope they can win next year by emphasizing how upset people are by the economic binge of the 1980's that favored wealthy investors over working people.
The effect on the President of the staggering economy and the constant pounding from the Democrats was unmistakable. After the war against Iraq, about 90 percent of Americans said they liked the way he was doing his job. The most recent national poll, taken by the Washington Post and ABC News from Dec. 11 through Dec. 15, showed his approval rating at 47 percent, the lowest of any President at this stage of his first term since World War II except for Gerald R. Ford. Only one person in four in this latest poll approved of the way Mr. Bush was handling the economy.
There is little mystery about what caused the economic problems. The country is suffering a hangover from the mergers, rampant speculation, overbuilding, heavy borrowing and irresponsible Government fiscal policy of the 1980's. Businesses, banks and families are now cutting back.
Still, there is no consensus about what to do to get the economy back on its feet. No leading politician, least of all the Democratic Presidential candidates, has suggested radical surgery. Dozens of lawmakers are sponsoring one kind of tax cut or another, many of them involving a tax reduction focused on the middle class, and the Administration will probably go along. But few experts believe that a tax reduction of, say, $300 a family, within the range under consideration, would make much difference overall.
A tax cut that would give the economy a quick jolt would also increase the budget deficit, which could reach a stratospheric $375 billion this year anyway. That could spook the financial markets. The rise in interest rates that could come from an increased fear of inflation might offset whatever kick the economy got from consumers' spending their newfound wealth and might damage the economy over the long run.
But reducing Government spending and enacting inducements for consumers to save, which would stimulate investment and improve the situation in the long run, would put an immediate drag on the economy, the wrong prescription for curing a recession.
But as a political matter, sitting tight and riding out the recession, as Mr. Greenspan and several other prominent economists counseled, is out of the question. The President and the Democrats who control Congress are incumbents, and incumbents cannot afford to sit on their hands while businesses fail and workers lose their jobs.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
How an Old Government Reactor Managed to Outlive the Cold War

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
THE last surviving piece of equipment for making nuclear fuel for the American arsenal, the 37-year-old K-Reactor, was designed to survive a one-megaton blast from a Soviet bomb at a range of two miles. But today environmentalists are more worried about a different kind of blast; they note that the outmoded reactor would not survive a far smaller internal explosion without dumping at least part of its radioactive entrails into the piney wetlands of western South Carolina.
Last week the Secretary of Energy, James D. Watkins, said what had long been obvious: since the other big competitor in the nuclear arms race is giving up, much of the American bomb-production system is no longer needed. But as he spoke the K-Reactor, on the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C., was awakening from a three-and-a-half-year slumber to resume the production of tritium for bombs. Mr. Watkins said it would run as a backup until an alternate source was found. While the Energy Department was busy converting its mission from making weapons to dismantling and decontaminating its troubled bomb factories, Mr. Watkins reiterated that a new reactor may be in the wings. 
 It was the latest in mixed signals as the Government tries to adapt its nuclear weapons complex to a new age. The Department of Energy has spent about $1 billion on re-opening the K-Reactor, one of five built in the early 1950's for the production of plutonium and tritium. The reactor was closed in 1988 because of safety problems. When department officials took reporters on a tour of the site earlier this month they said they planned to spend a billion more.
To some extent the problem is simply inertia in what sometimes seems less a defense program than a public works project. The Savannah River Site, like most government nuclear reservations, dominates the economy of the surrounding region and has powerful political patrons.
But the situation also reflects the Government's uncertainty about what the nuclear future holds. Given the delays the department has encountered in building plants far simpler than reactors -- for example, it recently built and abandoned a new factory for making submarine fuel, a few miles away -- officials seem determined to insure that no matter how many nuclear powers this country faces a decade from now, in the former Soviet Union or elsewhere, it will have a way to make tritium. This could be done with a new reactor or a particle accelerator, but for now the job is left to the coddled K-Reactor, which officials insist is safe since it will be run at only 30 percent power.
 
Cleaning Up Wastes
 The K-Reactor is now dedicated solely to making tritium, which is used to enhance explosive yield, allowing for smaller, more maneuverable bombs. But tritium, like all radioactive elements, slowly decays. It is transformed at the rate of about 5.5 percent a year, meaning that even a shrinking arsenal will require tritium production eventually. Weapons in the field, or at least their tritium reservoirs, must be returned to Savannah River to be replenished.
But with the cold war becoming a memory, some environmentalists are pushing to give up the plant, which lacks many modern safety features. Even in accident-free operation, they say, the reactor creates liquid wastes even more difficult to handle than those from civilian reactors, which are in solid form. The Energy Department chops up its fuel and dissolves it in acid to recover unused uranium and the plutonium.
And tritium itself is nasty to deal with. The gas is so difficult to contain and so readily taken up by the body that visitors to the K-Reactor must "provide bioassay samples" (urinate in a cup), twice -- once before they enter and once when they leave.
Some environmentalists say that as disarmament proceeds, it would be safer to scavenge tritium from retired warheads. A study recently completed for the Energy Research Foundation, a South Carolina environmental group, concluded that recycling could probably supply the remainder of the arsenal for about a decade. But the Energy Department wants a longer supply.
Engineers have long been aware of the advancing age of the K-Reactor and the four similar reactors built nearby; one was permanently sidelined by a crack in the reactor vessel. In the late 1970's, when the plants were approaching what some already thought was the end of their useful lives, the Carter Administration cut back tritium production, believing that international tensions were easing. Then President Reagan embarked on a huge arms build-up, and the reactors began new production schedules. Through the 1980's, some in Congress fought for a new production reactor, but the department, still trying to get the most bang for the buck, delayed. Last Monday, Mr. Watkins said that a new reactor might be built, but that it would be smaller than previously planned.
For now, though, the focus is still on the old plant, where in preparation for re-start, operators have completed a 1,000-hour training course, and have been divided into five platoons, enough to insure round-the-clock manning of the control room, vacations and days off, and one shift always in training. The plan is for the reactor to run until October 1992, when workers will remove the aluminum-clad cylinders in which tritium has been produced. Recovery of the gas must wait until early 1993, when heat and radiation have died down.
But as might be predicted for an old machine that has been idle for years, preliminary testing found new squeaks and rattles. In a test, operators withdrew all 66 control rods, one at a time. When raised in unison, these rods allow the neutron flow that sustains the chain reaction; when lowered, they shut the reaction down. But one rod refused to fully lower, so the mechanics and engineers went back to work. Now they say startup will be soon.

HEADLINE: THE END OF THE SOVIET UNION;
11 SOVIET STATES FORM COMMONWEALTH WITHOUT CLEARLY DEFINING ITS POWERS

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALMA-ATA, Kazakhstan, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Eleven former republics of the Soviet Union formally constituted themselves today as the Commonwealth of Independent States, dedicated to reversing their slide toward economic and political chaos.
Putting aside seven decades of central dictatorship, the republic leaders meeting in the Kazakh capital, near the Chinese border, negotiated and signed a broad commonwealth agreement that guarantees their separate sovereignties but leaves unsettled such important issues as how to create an acceptable system of command to administer common military policy and nuclear weapons control. 
 The top governmental body will be a council of heads of state and government, assisted by committees of republic ministers in key areas like foreign affairs, defense and economics.
 
Next Step: Ratification
 Full operations are promised to begin no later than Jan. 15, after ratification by the 11 republics' parliaments. The Baltic states, which regained independence in September, are not participating, nor is Georgia, which instead sent an observer to the talks.
To emphasize their resolve to move beyond the Kremlin, the commonwealth leaders pre-emptively accepted the resignation of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, even though it has not yet been submitted.
Their evident urgency to see him leave was reflected in their decision to promise, "with respect," a generous pension once he is in retirement.
 
'Want Him to Go Gently'
 "We respect Gorbachev and want him to go gently into retirement in December, as he himself wants," said President Boris N. Yeltsin of the Russian federated republic, who is head of the biggest and most powerful of the new commonwealth's constituent parts and who has been Mr. Gorbachev's chief reform antagonist through the last four turbulent years.
"We do not want to carry on the tradition since 1917 of burying our heads of state and having to rebury them later or having to pronounce them criminal," Mr. Yeltsin said. "A civilized state should end this practice."
There was no direct reaction from Mr. Gorbachev, who has suffered a breathtaking fall from power and grace since the failed coup in August. But in an interview with CBS News, he indicated that he would resign shortly after receiving official notification of the results of the Alma-Ata meeting.
"As soon as I receive official documents and see that the commonwealth is a reality, within a few days I will then take my decision," Mr. Gorbachev said. The Soviet leader said that for the meantime, he and the Defense Minister remained in control of the "nuclear button."
Mr. Gorbachev, who initially denounced the commonwealth as illegal and dangerous, today spoke of the new association as an accomplished fact. But he warned Americans that they too faced a difficult transition, saying: "I don't think the transformation will be easy and simple from one partner, the Soviet Union and its leadership. Now you have to deal with 10 new politicians."
Today was the first full working session of the expanded commonwealth. It is designed to be the vehicle for the survivors of the fallen Soviet empire to head toward free-market prosperity and full democracy. It grew out of the founding body announced 13 days ago by Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia, the three Slavic republics, when they met in Byelorussia and pronounced that the Soviet Union had ceased to exist.
 
Democracies Ruled by Law
 The meeting today went a considerable step beyond, for not only was the new association enlarged and sealed with pledges of peaceful collaboration, but also the heads of state began settling some differences.
In a joint declaration, the leaders set forth their intent to "build democratic states ruled by law and to develop relations between them on the basis of mutual recognition of inalienable right to self-determination, equality, non-interference in each other's internal affairs, renunciation of the use of force or threat to use force, economic or other levers of pressure."
The agreement next must be submitted to the republics' parliaments for ratification. Once they certify this with authorities in Byelorussia, the commonwealth is under way.
The leaders also yielded to President Yeltsin's view that Russia should take over the Security Council seat in the United Nations held until now by the Soviet Union. The Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, said later that this was critical for the general nuclear control strategy of eventually seeing Russia succeed the Soviet Union as the single guarantor of disarmament.
The broad-stroke agreements constituted an important political accord but left almost every difficult, concrete issue to be decided later, including such basic matters as the economy and Government financing, the precise scope of the new coordinating agencies, borders and citizenship.
The agreements signed today did not specifically mention a common currency or the ruble, but spoke of adherence in principle to the agreement from the Byelorussia meeting, which did call for a common currency. Today's agreements also noted that some republics had expressed reservations on the Byelorussia agreement.
The refining of the agreements was left to the uncertain hands of the republic parliaments.
In line with this, the four republics with long-range nuclear missiles on their soil -- Russia, Byelorussia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan -- again insisted that they were in agreement on joint weapons safeguards, and they issued a statement to this effect. This issue is a central one being pressed by the Bush Administration and other governments as one of the prices for early recognition of commonwealth members.
"This document will answer all the questions being asked by other states," said Kazakhstan's President, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev. The Bush Administration has various questions and uncertainties and wants to send nuclear disarmament specialists next month to see to some of the problems.
The document may not prove entirely reassuring, for Kazakhstan appears to be continuing to insist that it be treated on a par with Russia rather than joining Ukraine and Byelorussia in eventually ceding nuclear controls to Russia.
 
Military Command Unresolved
 And republic leaders could not agree immediately on the related issue of a new military command. This focuses on the precise design of a permanent defense council that is to administer commonwealth military policy.
Such important commonwealth members as Ukraine are especially insistent that the new defense council offer no opportunity to revive central totalitarianism, nor conflict with republic plans to form separate armies.
The commonwealth members put off the military command issue, scheduling it as the topic of a meeting Dec. 30 in Minsk, the Byelorussian capital, which is to be the commonwealth headquarters. As a temporary measure, the republic carried over until the end of the year the central remnant of the union's Defense Ministry, led by General Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov.
The commonwealth agreement was signed in the heart of this snow-decked mountainside city north of the Chinese border. The ceremony was held at the House of Friendship, a bulky exercise in socialist overdesign, where legions of republic leaders, ministers and patronage retinues showed up for the new post-Communist roundtable, smiling and squinting in the TV lamplight of world attention.
The commonwealth members held a news conference this evening, seated by small freshly minted flags of their sovereign republics under a huge bronze-toned medallion that still bore the hammer and sickle of Communism.
On the issue of approval by the republics' parliaments, various sorts of political flurries are expected. The Ukraine Parliament, which is wary and nationalistic about the commonwealth, has underlined its right to withdraw. Ukraine's lawmakers, passing the earlier commonwealth agreement after the Byelorussia meeting this month, made some adjustments in the agreement before approving it.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Silent on Recognition
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Bush Administration offered congratulations to the 11 former Soviet republics on formation of a new commonwealth today, but stopped short of saying when it would formally recognize the new governments.
"We hope the agreement will help to provide a stable and peaceful environment to permit the individual republics to pursue democracy and market economy reforms," said White House spokeswoman Judy Smith.

 Leaders of 11 of the 12 former Soviet republics proclaimed a new Commonwealth of Independent States at a meeting in the Kazakh capital, Alma-Ata. They agreed on the following points.
 
EQUAL BASIS PROTOCOL
 
The 11 republics will be considered co-founders. This was a principal demand of the leaders of the five Asian republics after the Slavic republics, Russia, Byelorussian and Ukraine, formed the commonwealth Dec. 8. The eight republics agreeing to join the commonwealth are the five Asian republics (Kazakhstan, Turkmenia, Uzberkistan, Kirghizia and Tadzhikistan) plus Armenia, Moldavia and Azerbaijan.
 
ALMA-ATA DECLARATION
 
This document recognizes the independence of the 11 former Soviet republics and their current borders.
 
MILITARY COMMAND
 
A temporary military command will exist until Dec. 31. The 11 leaders are to meet again on control of the military on Dec. 30 in Minsk, the headquarters of teh commonwealth. Yevgeny I. Shaposhnikov, the Soviet Defense Minister, is to lead the interim command.
 
UNITED NATIONS STATUS
 
The republics agreed that Russia would take over the Soviet Union's seat on the U.N. Security Concil. Russia and the two republics already represented at the United Nations, Ukrain and Byelorussia, will push for all the other republics to have U.N. seasts as well. (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: THE END OF THE SOVIET UNION;
Baker Doubtful Commonwealth Will Last Long

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Dec. 21

 BODY:
After a week of visiting the crumbling Soviet Union, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d left believing that the republics' new commonwealth has little chance of long-term survival, and that Washington will soon be dealing with a dozen independent states with different policies and varied prospects for success.
By that view, the former Soviet republics are now so enamored of the idea of independence that they cannot work together for long in a meaningful commonwealth, with joint economic and military policies, until they feel the real costs of coming apart. 
 That assessment was given to reporters traveling with Mr. Baker as he prepared to return to the United States today to brief President Bush on his visit to Russia, Kirghizia, Kazakhstan, Byelorussia and Ukraine -- all of which will probably be recognized by Washington before the end of the year.
 
Brittle Commonwealth
 Summing up Mr. Baker's overall impressions, reporters were told: "Whether there is a commonwealth or not, we are going to end up dealing with sovereign, independent nations. Instead of dealing with one foreign minister, it might well end up being 12."
"The richness of our relationships will depend from republic to republic on the degree to which they embrace democracy and free markets" as well as the republics' fulfilling their assurances to the United States on nuclear security, an official said.
The "only thing that is for sure," reporters with Mr. Baker were told, "is that you should have gone out and bought some Rand McNally stock some time ago" -- referring to the map company, which must revise its publications.
Mr. Baker's visit, destined to be the last by an American Secretary of State to the Soviet Union, was a bizarre journey in many ways, turning up a few clues from three scenes in particular.
The first scene could be called sauna diplomacy.
Last Wednesday, Mr. Baker visited Kazakhstan, near the border with China. As he was meeting there with President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the Kazakh leader suggested that he and Mr. Baker get away from the conference table for a more informal chat -- in his sauna.
So at 1:30 A.M. the two men drove up to a villa in the mountains, stripped naked, and, with a State Department interpreter in tow, retreated into the sauna. There, as the snow fell heavily outside, the Kazakh from the steppes of Central Asia and the Texan from Houston, discussed the fate of the Soviet Union until almost 3 A.M.
Earlier in the day, while Mr. Baker was visiting Bishkek, the capital of Kirghizia, the President of that republic dressed Mr. Baker in a multicolored Kirghiz robe and hat, so he could get a better feel for the local color.
And Mr. Baker did see a lot of local color. In fact, if he drew one conclusion from his trip, it was that the United States is going to have to deal with a lot of different local colors -- probably too many -- from now on.
Mr. Baker concluded that forces pulling the Soviet Union apart are so strong that the individual republics will soon be pursuing their own homemade economic policies -- with their own currencies, degrees of free-market drive and possibly protectionist practices.
Republics like Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Kirghizia, which are rich in natural resources, have quick-footed leaders eager to cut deals with Western businesses, and relatively homogeneous populations. But the prospects are less clear for republics like Russia, which has a high potential for infighting among the leadership and 100 ethnic minorities that could pull the republic apart further from within.
In fact, reporters were told that Mr. Baker left Russia feeling that "things have broken down there -- everything has broken down." The distribution system has collapsed, middle-class families are having to forage for food and crime is rampant. Without emergency food shipments, officials said, social unrest is likely in the cities before the winter is out.
If the West is lucky, reporters were told, the commonwealth will be able to maintain at least a common defense policy that will allow for a single, unified command over nuclear weapons until they can be dismantled in every republic except Russia. But even that remains questionable.
 
Toeing U.S. Line
 Another scene could be called the pro-American competition.
Wherever Mr. Baker went on this trip, leaders seemed to be competing to see who could seem the most pro-American, pro-democratic and pro-capitalist.
President Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan told Mr. Baker that he now keeps a copy of the "Baker five principles," in the top drawer of this desk. Those principles were laid out by Mr. Baker as a sort of informal yardstick for United States relations with the newly independent republics. They are very general principles -- things like "we support democracy and the rule of law" and "the safeguarding of human rights."
The leader who managed to seem most pro-American was Askar A. Akayev, President of Kirghizia, who said at his news conference in Bishkek with Mr. Baker: "I think if one looks at the memorable speech of the Secretary of State that he gave on Dec. 12 at Princeton and those principles which he enunciated there, and also the fact that the United States has taken a leadership position in not only implementing those principles but also in all the programs and aid that the United States is heading up, this will give us an opportunity to make this transition thanks to the United States."
Those extraordinary displays by former Soviet officials were at once encouraging and disconcerting to the Baker party. They were encouraging because the values the leaders were espousing were Western values instead of worn-out Marxist ones, but they were worrisome because some of the performances seemed as thin and empty as the apocryphal "Potemkin villages" the Russian field marshal supposedly built along the route of Catherine the Great's tour of the Crimea to impress her.
Mr. Baker had a news conference in Kiev with President Leonid M. Kravchuk, during which Mr. Kravchuk seemed to say everything Mr. Baker wanted to hear. Later, Dora Chomiak, a recent Princeton University graduate who has been working in Kiev, commented on the coverage of the Baker visit by American correspondents.
"It's pretty funny," said Miss Chomiak, who works for the Ukrainian-American Renaissance Foundation. "I mean, I hear you reporting that Kravchuk promised this and Kravchuk said that, and I have to tell you he says a lot of things that the people want to hear, but a lot of it never gets done. Or when it does, it's sort of slapped together. Right after Kravchuk signed the first commonwealth agreement in Brest, he came back to the Parliament here to get it ratified and it was really a farce. I mean, they didn't debate it. Half the members didn't even know what they were voting on."
A third scene could be called Greetings and Farewells.
When Mr. Baker's delegation got word that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia intended to meet them for the first time ever in the Kremlin, seated in the same room, at the same table and in the same chair in which President Gorbachev used to meet them, they bristled. They saw it as a crude attempt by Mr. Yeltsin to rub Mr. Gorbachev's nose in his political defeat. When Mr. Baker shook hands with Mr. Yeltsin that day in Catherine's hall, he looked stiff and uncomfortable.
Eight hours later, Mr. Baker was holding a news conference with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. It was an emotional scene as they met in the building where they had done so much business together. Mr. Shevardnadze bear-hugged several members of Mr. Baker's staff when they left. Mr. Baker kept calling him "my friend and colleague."
Why will Mr. Baker miss Mr. Shevardnadze? Reporters traveling with the Baker party were told: "I will miss him because he was a man of great integrity" and because "he's a very reasonable, rational person."
American officials don't like Mr. Yeltsin. In part it is because they believe he is less predictable than Mr. Gorbachev and in part because he did in their friends. The terms they use to describe him are: "crude," "populist," "peasant-like," "impulsive."
"By the end," said an American official, "Baker could deal with Shevardnadze as though he were an allied foreign minister. Yeltsin is more gruff, feisty, rude. Even though we like his politics more, we still find the man off-putting. The way he drove the final nails into the coffins of Gorbachev and Shevardnadze, with such alacrity, made us all shudder."
The "funny thing" is, though, the official said, "Yeltsin was always closer to our ideas of what needed to be done inside the Soviet Union than Shevardnadze or Gorbachev. He was actually listening while we were lecturing and the other guys were not. But it was like in deposing Gorbachev he deposed our friends, and it is going to take time to get over that."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 2; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 699 words

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

INTERNATIONAL 3-16
