HEADLINE: A Side Effect Of Rates Cuts

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
It has been an article of faith among economists and government officials for decades that when the economy goes bad, the Federal Reserve can fix the problem by lowering interest rates. Lower rates make it cheaper for consumers to take on expensive purchases like cars and appliances and for companies to invest in plants and equipment.
In this slump, that solution has not worked, at least, not yet. But on Friday the Federal Reserve signaled its determination to keep trying, with a vengeance. It slashed the discount rate a full point, the steepest cut in 10 years, to a 27-year low of 3 1/2 percent. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the economic recovery seemed to have stalled earlier this year, after regaining about half the recession's losses. 
 Many economists think that the medicine will produce the desired recovery, although few think it will be an especially strong one.
But if economists and politicians typically think of lower interest rates as unalloyed good news, for millions of Americans, particularly the elderly, lower rates are bad news. The fact that rates for savers have fallen faster than rates for borrowers has slowed the recovery.
"Almost every time I turn around, my electricity bill goes up, or my water bill or my telephone bill," complained Joann Brokaw, who is 62 years old and was buying presents for her grandchildren last week in Columbus, Ohio. "At the same time, the money I have coming in is going down." She said she was earning 9 1/2 percent on bank certificates of deposit a year ago. Now the interest she receives is down to around 5 percent, and heading lower.
A Gallup Poll, taken for Fidelity Investments over Thanksgiving weekend, found that more people over 50 years old thought they had been hurt rather than helped by lower interest rates. But a clear majority of respondents under 50 believed lower rates had improved their financial position.
There does not seem to be such a sharp split among economists. Even before the latest rate cut, all but one of the more than 50 economists polled earlier this month by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter, believe the American economy would grow in 1992. The dissenter thought there would be no growth but no decline either.
But in previous recessions, the interest paid on savings has fallen much more rapidly than rates on auto loans, credit cards or home mortgages. A year ago, the average six-month bank certificate of deposit was paying 7.14 percent; now it is 4.46 percent, a decline of 2.68 percentage points. But the rate for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage has fallen only 1.10 percentage points, to 8.38 percent.
While all six-month C.D.'s taken at higher rates have expired, most mortgages have not. The Commerce Department estimates that the average effective mortgage rate in the third quarter of this year was 10.1 percent, only a bit lower than 10.2 percent in late 1990. And because mortgage debt has risen, the Goverment estimates that America's collective mortgage interest bill is rising fast enough to offset declines in other interest payments.
 
Potential Help for Recovery
 In 1980, before the 1981-82 recession, Americans received $1.39 in interest income for every dollar they paid in interest. By 1982, at the bottom of the economic cycle, that figure had risen to $1.67. That boost helped to get the economy started again. There was a similar, although less explosive, rise during the mid-1970's slump.
But during the 1980's Americans took on more and more debt, and by 1988 the figure was down to $1.17. It climbed to $1.28 last year, but this year appears to have dipped a bit, largely because interest rates on savings have fallen so rapidly. That means that as incomes from jobs have fallen during the recession, there has been less interest income to make up the slack.
There is no mystery why some rates have fallen more rapidly than others. The banking system, suffering from a hangover brought on by bad loans in the 1980's, needs higher profits. "Banks are dealing with serious balance-sheet problems," said Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "They can't pass it through to their best customers, so they are passing it to you and me."
 
Bailing Out the Banks
 In fact, all bank borrowers are paying part of the cost of helping banks cope with their problems. On Friday, many big banks cut their prime lending rates to 6 1/2 percent. Even at that level, the prime rate is 3 points above the discount rate, at which the Federal Reserve lends money to banks. By contrast, when the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate to 4 1/2 percent in late 1971, the prime rate was reduced to 5 1/4 percent, only three-quarters of a point higher. The result is that business borrowers are paying far more now than they were then, a fact that may be dampening growth.
Another factor holding down growth is that long-term rates have not fallen nearly as far as short-term ones. Mr. Greenspan attributes that tendency to a continuing fear of long-term inflation and has cited it as a cautionary sign against large tax cuts that could rapidly increase the deficit. Twenty years ago, when the discount rate was 4 1/2 percent, the yield on long-term Treasury bonds was 4.98 percent. Now the yield on 30-year Treasuries is 7.57 percent. Thus the benefits of a lower discount rate are not being fully realized by corporations that issue bonds to finance new plants.
 
Less Credit for Some
 Moreover, there has been a fundamental change in the availability of credit in the last two years, with the creation of a two-tier system. The top tier, which includes many people and the most financially secure companies, is able to borrow at ever-lower rates and can borrow large sums. But those not deemed to be part of the most credit-worthy group can find it extremely difficult to borrow at all. In 1991, it appears that records were set both for the issuance of corporate bonds, as quality companies refinanced their debt to save money, and for defaults on existing bonds, as companies facing financial problems were unable to find lenders.
Unfortunately for the prospects of immediate recovery, many who have access to capital are reluctant to use it. "People don't want to borrow because they have too much debt already," said Nancy Lazar, an economist with International Strategy & Investment Group in New York. And Ed Yardeni, the chief economist of C. J. Lawrence, notes, "Businesses do not respond to lower rates as much as they do to better sales." He believes that fiscal stimulus, through a tax cut, is still needed.
 
Homeowners' Predicament
 The tighter credit standards have also hurt some homeowners who seek to refinance their mortgages to take advantage of lower rates. To do so they need to get new appraisals of their homes, and to again get their incomes approved. If the appraisals show the homes are no longer worth the amount of the mortgage, or if the borrowers' incomes have fallen, it may be impossible to refinance the loans.
Many consumers have no doubt been hesitant to spend because of rising layoffs, which have caused consumer confidence to plunge. "You have re structurings going on in manufacturing and spreading to service industries," said Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley. "That fear is now hurting a whole new part of America, the people wearing the white collars as well as the blue collars."
Still, if that fear wanes, and if the lower interest rates endure, they could be ushering in a period of growth for the American economy. "Huge interest savings will occur," said Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist of Bear, Stearns & Company. "The whole cost structure will be lowered for American business, making it more competitive." And those savings, he said, will help the economy recover from the excesses of the 1980's.

HEADLINE: THE END OF THE SOVIET UNION;
Hard Realism Wins the Day

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The formation of the commonwealth on the still-warm corpse of the union was hardly a pretty process. But after six years of illusions and false starts, it had a certain crude realism to it.
It began with what was basically a power play by the leaders of the three Slavic republics, who met in a Byelorussian wood on Dec. 8 and devised a plan to overthrow the old union and declare a new league around themselves. 
 With roughly three-quarters of the former union's land and wealth, the Slavic leaders presented the sketchy scheme on a take-it-or-leave-it basis to other republics and began pulling the rug out from under the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
When the other republics came on board today in Alma-Ata, Kazakhstan, the agreements were in the same rough vein. The critical issue of the army and its nuclear arsenal was left unresolved, the exact authority of the new coordinating structures was not defined, the constitutional legality of the agreements was left moot, economic reforms were not spelled out -- and even then the agreements were declared open to revision.
The haste and crudeness of the process were underscored by the fact that it was hard to glean a ringing historic quote in the vein of the American Declaration of Independence from any of the documents adopted by the 11 republic leaders, all of them former Communist officials now espousing democracy and national causes.
 
Unlike Previous Efforts
 Yet that very roughness and ruthlessness imbued the new commonwealth with a harsh realism and directness that set it apart from all the previous failed efforts to find a formula for a new association among the republics.
From the time Eduard A. Shevardnadze resigned as Foreign Minister a year ago, warning of an impending coup, efforts to stem the drift of the republics were all doomed.
First Mr. Gorbachev tried raw force, sending troops into the Baltics and even into Moscow. Then he shifted to the "9 plus 1" process of forging a new union treaty, but as long as the Communist Party and its vast instruments of power were functioning, they resisted, in the end trying the desperate coup in August.
After the coup failed, Mr. Gorbachev at first seemed to recognize that the drive for sovereignty among the republics was real. Yet stripped of his party and much of his power, the President himself became the final obstacle.
Whatever he was told, whatever he was shown, he continued to insist that the center had to survive, that without it the Soviet Union would become another blood-soaked Yugoslavia. No matter that the problem in Yugoslavia was precisely in trying to maintain an artificial union; Mr. Gorbachev repeatedly and insistently fought to keep his center intact.
 
Roles of Russia and Ukraine
 Whether it was Ukraine's nationalism or Russia's ambition that broke the chain is for historians to decide. Probably both. By November, Ukraine made it clear that it would not take part in anything that smacked of the old center, and Russia moved to annex the ministries, properties and powers of the central Government.
There was another problem, too. The collapse of the center had set loose 12 widely disparate republics, each with inexperienced new leaders coping with heaps of domestic problems and struggling to consolidate fragile powers, each with its own ambitions and fears.
Against this background, the decision of the three Slavic leaders to unilaterally declare a new course had a crude logic. Multilateral negotiations were fruitless, the center was discredited, something had to be done fast, and only the Slavic republics could do it.
In effect, the only answer was to go back to the beginnings, to start with the nations that founded the Soviet Union and to see if they could found something more promising, with more sovereignty for the republics and less chance for a dominating center to grow.
 
Positives vs. Negatives
 Nobody could say for certain what chances the commonwealth had.
On the positive side, it resolved the basic conflict between regional ambitions and the need for coordination. It also gave the republics a new chance to start critically needed reforms, and it offered them an acceptable framework within which to cooperate and coordinate.
On the other end of the scale, there was the danger that the centrifugal forces had already thrown the republics too far apart for any cooperation, and that the new commonwealth would suffer the fate of all its predecessors.
There was no telling what would happen to the agreements once they were put before local parliaments. Already the Ukrainian Parliament issued a statement reserving the right to back out and stubbornly insisting that it will have its own army and currency. Russia's ruthless takeover of all former government and Communist parties was likewise assuming an unseemly haste, irritating other republics and laying the foundation for future disputes.
The new leaders are imperfect, their methods are clumsy, their commonwealth is shaky, their act lacks class. But perhaps it could not have happened any other way: the old order had to die before a new one could rise.

HEADLINE: Japan Irked as Bush Visit Turns Into a Trade Quest

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Japanese leaders are reacting with anger and dismay to President Bush's decision to travel here next month with an entourage of executives from the American automobile and other industries to increase pressure on Tokyo to open up its markets to American exports.
Senior Japanese officials say they do not see any possibility of significant concessions on automobile imports, and fear is rising in Japan that the visit could end up deepening mistrust and recriminations between Americans and the Japanese instead of easing tensions as it is supposed to do. 
 Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has responded cautiously to Mr. Bush's promise to "relentlessly pursue our mission to create jobs and restore prosperity" on the visit to Japan. The Prime Minister said Friday at a news conference that Japan must "concede where it should" in the trade area, but that it must also stand up to the United States when it feels that problems are the result of American policies.
"Economic issues are growing severe," Mr. Miyazawa said, trying to show some sympathy for Mr. Bush's political problems. "But happily we are able to speak frankly and avoid misunderstandings. Even if we engage in debate, the outcome won't be war."
The increasing chill in the atmosphere surrounding the President's visit, which is scheduled for Jan. 7-10, testifies to the difficulty of relations between the two economic superpowers these days and to the political constraints faced by Mr. Bush and Mr. Miyazawa.
The visit was originally scheduled for earlier this month to coincide with the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, as a gesture of reassurance by the United States that Washington and Tokyo have forged a new "global partnership" out of the ashes of war.
But Mr. Bush canceled the original visit to turn his attention to growing domestic problems. Meanwhile, the various plans that Japan had hoped to showcase on the visit have gone down in flames in Parliament.
The main disappointment was the dooming of the Government's hope for legislative approval of a measure to have Japanese troops take part in United Nations peacekeeping forces. This week, Mr. Miyazawa saw the collapse of a separate plan, a tax to finance foreign aid.
Japanese diplomats concede that no big new proposal exists to demonstrate Tokyo's readiness to play a global role commensurate with its economic status. Their hope had been to counter Washington's disappointment that Tokyo has done nothing more than write $13 billion in checks to support the American-led war against Iraq.
 
Premier's Base Weakens
 Mr. Miyazawa's political base has weakened in recent weeks because of his own problems, including a budget deficit that has forced him to raise taxes in an election year. He may also have trouble delivering money to support a supercollider project in Texas, another demand tied to the Bush trip.
Nor does the Government appear ready to make any significant concessions to open up its markets to imported rice, another step demanded by the White House as a way of revitalizing the moribund international trade negotiations known as the Uruguay round.
The prevailing view in Japan is that the United States has not taken its share of steps to increase the competitiveness and quality of its products, particularly in the automobile industry. The pressure on Japan to import American auto parts is widely viewed here as infuriating.
Asahi Shimbun, Japan's leading newspaper, said today in an editorial that Mr. Bush seemed to be waging "gunboat diplomacy in economic areas" and that he should ask American car manufacturers to learn a lesson from Western Europeans, who are more successful in selling automobiles in Japan.
"Why do European cars sell better in the Japanese market than U.S. ones?" the newspaper asked. "American manufacturers should be more aware of the basics of business, which require producers to make goods catering to the tastes of consumers."
A senior Japanese diplomat said he sympathized with Americans who feel anxiety in witnessing the collapse of their car industry, but added, "Personally, I have no sympathy for American automobile manufacturers."
As depicted in the Japanese press, the American car makers have done little to showcase their products here, tailor them to Japanese tastes or forge relationships with retailers, whereas European manufacturers have done all those things.
But since automobiles count for perhaps three-quarters of the $41 billion trade imbalance between the United States and Japan, there have been steps by the big auto manufacturers in recent weeks to try to remedy the situation. Nissan, Toyota, Honda and others have announced that they will set new targets to import more American parts and to use more American parts in their automobile plants in the United States.
Government officials maintain that all these steps were done voluntarily, an assertion that few experts believe. Leaders of the Japanese car industry said this weekend that they did not see any likelihood of further steps. And their criticism of the American automobile industry is seen as potentially embarrassing to the White House if it becomes more outspoken.
Even some American diplomats involved in the planning of Mr. Bush's trips admit that they were surprised by the White House's decision to turn the President's visit into an exercise in trying to sell automobile parts.
A prominent president of a major bank in Japan, asking not to be identified, ridiculed Mr. Bush. "I would have thought after your great victory in the gulf, your President would feel confident enough to leave trade issues to his subordinates," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. REVIEWS FOCUS OF SECURITY DATA

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
In an order to policy makers, President Bush says he envisions a reshaping of the nation's intelligence-gathering functions to include a greater focus on shortages of natural resources, global health problems and other issues that have not previously been considered central to insuring national security.
In the order, known as a National Security Directive, the President does not suggest dramatic cutbacks in the intelligence bureaucracy. Instead he proposes a remolding of its functions to adapt to new, more diffuse requests for data and analysis resulting from the collapse of the Soviet Union, while still meeting the needs of American military security. 
 Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, briefly discussed the Presidential order in a speech on Dec. 4, calling it "the most far-reaching directive to assess future intelligence priorities and needs since 1947." But the text of the order, obtained by The New York Times, offers much more detail on the role of intelligence envisioned by Mr. Bush in the next decade-and-a-half.
 
Re-examining Priorities
 "We are in transition from watching Soviet operational readiness to wondering about the control of Soviet nuclear weapons," the order, dated Nov. 15, says. "The Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have been transformed, the Warsaw Pact dissolved and Soviet activism (especially in the Third World) dramatically curtailed. There is growing interest here at home in our intelligence services tackling new issues and problems.
"Together, these developments urgently require a top to bottom examination of the mission, role and priorities of the intelligence community."
Unless choices are made and priorities are set, the document warned, "our capabilities will spread too thin to satisfy even the highest priorities and our inability to plan and invest long-term will leave us with inadequate intelligence assets to protect our vital interests and our security."
The order has been sent to 20 agencies and departments of the Government. Some, like the State, Defense and Treasury departments, have in-house intelligence bureaus, while several others are nontraditional users of intelligence, like the Environmental Protection Agency, the Department of Health and Human Services and NASA.
 
Bypassing Intelligence Officials
 In a clear indication that Mr. Bush is looking for an entirely new approach, the order states that in the first phase of the review, policy makers will draft lists of their anticipated needs and that intelligence bureaus "should not be involved." The order faults senior policy makers for having traditionally "neglected their critical role in setting intelligence priorities and requirements."
"You need people who have no equity in the current system," said one Administration official involved in the review process. "One can argue that intelligence people are looking to preserve their current roles."
The directive raises questions about new global problems in which American intelligence may need to become more involved.
"Will we need more and different intelligence information on international aspects of the environment, natural resource scarcities (such as water), global health problems, international research and development efforts, and so on?" the order asked. "What kinds of economic intelligence do we need?"
At the same time, the order asks agencies whether they can do without. "What information are you receiving now that you will not need at all or where you can accept far less detailed knowledge?"
The review will be comprehensive but will be conducted very quickly, a task that Mr. Gates referred to in his speech as "a monumental undertaking."
The bureaus and agencies will respond to the directive by mid-January, and a report will be submitted to the National Security Council for review a month later.
Once the council approves a plan, Mr. Gates will make his own recommendations for structural changes, budgets and possible new legislation, and present them to the National Security Council by March 20.

HEADLINE: Foreign Millionaires in No Rush to Apply for Visas, U.S. Finds

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The United States put its new "millionaire visas" on the market this month, offering American citizenships to big-time investors. But it discovered that among the world's rich, there are not many takers.
After months of preparation and publicity, the Government has just issued its final regulations for the special visas, which offer permanent residency status to foreigners who invest $1 million or more in a business that employs at least 10 people. 
 After almost three weeks, only 177 potential investors, much fewer than the Government initially expected, have applied for the 10,000 visas, which are the first step toward citizenship.
This hesitancy by foreign millionaires contrasts with the avalanche of nearly 19 million applications that the Government received two months ago in a first-come, first-served lottery that offered 40,000 visas to people from 34 selected nations.
Immigration lawyers say a host of fine points contributes to the reticence of rich foreigners, who can easily find other ways to stay in this country. But these difficulties are only a part of a larger debate about the program, which was created last year under a new immigration law.
Critics of the visa program say the nation is abandoning its historic ideals on immigration, which have traditionally held open America's doors to the tired, the poor and the oppressed. They say that for the first time, sheer wealth is a criterion for citizenship.
"The new concept is, 'What is in it for the United States?' " said Arthur C. Helton, an immigration specialist with the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. "This is a matter of concern in that it may signal a turning away from more traditional humanitarian bases, including family unification and protecting refugees from persecution."
But the visas are drawing praise from others who say that at last America is putting its national interests ahead of sentiment and seeking new citizens who can invigorate the economy.
"I believe we've done a great job with boat people, and I think that a few yacht people are not going to hurt America," said Harold W. Ezell, a former regional commissioner for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, who is now a middleman for potential millionaire visa applicants. "They're going to be good for America in creating jobs and investment."
The 1990 immigration act took a similarly pragmatic approach in nearly tripling the number of permanent residency visas offered to people with special job skills, to 140,000 a year. The shift was seen as a move to compete with other nations for the world's most accomplished people, including its wealthy entrepreneurs.
The bulk of the nearly 700,000 immigrant visas authorized by law each year will continue to be issued following traditional criteria, primarily for family reunification.
 
Competing for the Rich
 The investor-visa program, which offers 10,000 residencies a year, puts America in a competition with Canada and Australia to lure wealthy investors. In Canada, for example, thousands of foreigners, particularly Asians, have won residency over the last four years by investing in or starting businesses.
But a number of factors make the American offer less attractive than those of its competitors: It demands a higher investment, it requires the hiring of a fixed number of employees and it calls for a audit in two years to assure that the investment and the employees are still in place.
Immigration lawyers also say a number of potential investors have been frightened off because citizenship will mean they must pay United States taxes on all their earnings worldwide.
"It's certainly not as user-friendly as the Canadian or Australian models," said H. Ronald Klasko, an immigration lawyer who recently traveled in Hong Kong, Singapore and Taiwan to gauge interest in the visas.
For wealthy investors, the symbolism of the American flag apparently carries less weight than the dynamics of the marketplace.
"I was a little bit surprised at the lack of raging anxiety for the immigrant investor category," said Mr. Klasko. Many people in Hong Kong, a target of the program because of the impending takeover by China in 1997, showed interest in investing in the United States, he said, but expressed worry about the complications and the tax obligations involved in getting a green card.
An immigration lawyer who has talked with potential European investors, Palma R. Yanni, said: "I don't think people are going to plop down $1 million for a green card and say, 'This is all I want.' Sophisticated investors are going to want a real return on their money."
 
Another Option
 For such people, there is already a mechanism in place, the E-visa that allows a non-immigrant investor to live in the United States as long as he runs a business in this country. All that is missing is the chance to become an American citizen.
"That's the traditional form of investor visa, the one that's been around for years," said Charles Powell, a business lawyer who is advising a number of potential immigrant investors. This visa requires a smaller investment, often in such businesses as laundries or restaurants, and does not stipulate the creation of jobs.
"I sent a flier to people who I knew had $1 million and were already here on E-visas," said Mr. Powell. "I said, 'Here's your opportunity to get a green card,' and I got very little response. I was very surprised at that. I thought I'd at least get one or two people who would actually go through the process, but I didn't."
Among the drawbacks, lawyers said, was an employment requirement that their clients found unrealistic.
"The law has a basic flaw built into it," said Martin Lawler, a lawyer who advises potential investors to start out slowly with an E-visa. "It requires 10 employees for $1 million, when generally speaking, business attorneys tell me, it takes at least $1.5 million to $2 million to carry 10 people."
Another drawback is the requirement for a government review after two years, a hurdle that effectively makes the initial $1 million investment a high-stakes gamble.
Although immigration lawyers and middlemen like Mr. Ezell say they have had inquiries from entrepreneurs in several nations, the common theme seemed to be caution, and none of their clients agreed to be interviewed.
Among the potential investors is a Taiwanese woman who is looking at opportunities at a marble factory and a seafood import business, a German rock music promoter who wants to put down roots here, an Iranian family hoping to transfer its construction business and a Japanese woman seeking to invest $1.3 million in a foundry.
Mr. Ezell's clients include a Taiwanese couple living in Beverly Hills on an E-visa who have already invested more than $1 million in a preschool that employs about 10 people.
"They have made a major commitment to America," Mr. Ezell said. "This business of theirs is over a million bucks, and they have spent $4 million on their home in Beverly Hills. They want their son to be raised here and educated here, and this is the way they want to do it."

HEADLINE: How Final Curtain Fell on a 10-Week Melodrama

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The melodrama that ended on Friday at the Capitol, where a grim Mario M. Cuomo declared that he was taking himself out of the Presidential race, began exactly 10 weeks earlier, at a breakfast meeting of 150 of his financial supporters at the Regency Hotel in Manhattan.
After months of issuing a standard refrain, that he had "no plans and no plans to make plans" to run, Mr. Cuomo told his friends that he had at last concluded that he would "think about" a campaign for President. 
 "It literally sent a ripple through the room," said one person who was there. "Everybody was turning their heads at each other, and you could see people whispering, 'Did you hear that?' "
Mr. Cuomo prefaced and followed his comment with a warning that the state's budget problems were even more severe than the public perceived. He implied that without a solution, he could not run.
 
Looking Out at '92 From the Edge
 And it was the budget morass that Mr. Cuomo depicted on Friday as the lone obstacle to a campaign.
In the hours before his announcement, Mr. Cuomo called several close advisers from his study in the Executive Mansion and read to them from two statements that he kept revising with his pen even as he spoke.
One was a declaration that he would seek the Democratic nomination and included a defiant assertion that Presidential politics from the Republicans who had blocked a budget deal would not keep Mr. Cuomo out of the race. That statement will presumably remain consigned to his desk.
"He was agonizing about it, he really was, right up until the end," said Vincent A. Tese, State Economic Development Director and one of Mr. Cuomo's closest advisers. After Mr. Cuomo called around 2 P.M. and said he was out of the race, Mr. Tese added, "I could hardly hear his voice on the telephone."
The image of Mr. Cuomo's putting his sense of duty to his sworn oath above his desire to run is a compelling one, especially because he had had expressed enthusiasm to aides that national polls showed him within striking distance of President Bush. But it also shows that his decision making always included the option, perhaps inevitable, that he would not run. For perhaps more than any other state official, Mr. Cuomo knows the recent history of rancor and lateness that mark budget making here.
The issue that may never be fully resolved is whether Mr. Cuomo genuinely thought he could hammer out an early deal with the Republicans to attack the state's fiscal ills. That would have stood in stark and welcome contrast to all recent history of budget making here. Given that history, it is clear that his path to the Presidency always included a detour, a way that he could stand at the very edge of a formal campaign and then turn back. And that is what he did.
 
The Heart, the Head And the Budget
 After the breakfast in October a process of public introspection unique in the annals of American politics began, as Mr. Cuomo's debate with himself eclipsed the attention commanded by the other candidates already in the race and kept the Democratic Party in suspense until the final few minutes before his announcement.
"What does my heart tell me?" he asked himself in late October on a cable-television program on Long Island. " 'Go out and tell them, Mario. Take your best shot, whether you win, lose or draw.' "
But, Mr. Cuomo quickly added, he was still "working on my head," which was focused on the budget. By that time, he had announced a $700 million gap in the state's current $30 billion budget -- it has since grown by $200 million -- and an even more severe problem in the next spending plan.
"Let's be realistic," he told a call-in radio program on Nov. 14. "How can you deal with the Presidency if you've got a $700 million hole?"
 
Overshadowing The Message
 The people who talked to Mr. Cuomo about the Presidency in October and last month said that his attitudes on running soared and fell almost solely on the status of the budget talks. He rationalized that the Republicans would go along with his proposal for a 15-month budget because such a plan was more in their interest than yet another patchwork solution to the immediate deficit, which would guarantee another bloody fight and harsh cuts in the spring and summer, when they would be preparing for re-election campaigns.
Mr. Cuomo complained to reporters that the accounts of his indecision were misplaced. "You don't make a decision until you have all the facts," he said over and over. He also complained that the accounts obscured his speeches and policy statements about reviving the economy through a net investment-tax credit for machinery and pollution control and infusion of cash into the Federal Reserve system for banks to loan to businesses.
 
Hamstrung By Problems
 As the weeks wore on, Mr. Cuomo appeared to be giving conflicting accounts of his conditions for candidacy. One day he said that without a solution to the budget, he could not run. A few days later he said that he did not need to resolve the problems, that he just had to be sure that "my running for President won't make it more difficult, won't make it worse for the state."
Early this week he said that even without a budget accord he might run, if he concluded that the Republicans were purposely obstructing a pact to keep him from the race.
"They would no longer have the motive to slow you up," he said. "And that would save the state, by running for President."
But in private conversations he consistently conceded that he could not envision running, unless he could argue plausibly that he was controlling the state's fiscal problems.
 
Burning the Wires To Concord, N.H.
 J. Joseph Grandmaison, a former chairman of the New Hampshire Democratic Party, received his first call from an adviser to Mr. Cuomo, John Marino, shortly after Thanksgiving. Mr. Marino told Mr. Grandmaison that he was calling at the Governor's request and that he was trying to gather as much information as possible about the New Hampshire primary.
"He did not ask for support," Mr. Grandmaison said. "He just asked me to help him as a friend."
Over the next two weeks, Mr. Grandmaison and Mr. Marino spoke several times on the phone. Mr. Marino was always careful to speak of the Governor's candidacy in the subjunctive. "At no point did John say anything but 'if,' " Mr. Grandmaison recalled.
As the filing deadline drew nearer, the questions from the Cuomo camp grew more practical, like how the other Democratic candidates were doing in New Hampshire.
"I went out of my way to say the other candidates were doing well," Mr. Grandmaison said. "I told them they should recognize that the other candidates had been on the ground, building organizations."
On Dec. 13, Mr. Grandmaison suggested that with a week before the deadline, the filing details should be considered and an application for the primary ballot should be obtained. Mr. Marino wanted to know whether that could be accomplished discreetly. Mr. Grandmaison told him that it could not.
It was then decided that Mr. Grandmaison would pick up a primary form on Monday in Concord and send it by overnight mail to Mr. Marino in New York City and that the press in Albany would be alerted. If the Governor decided to file, he was supposed to do so on Thursday or Friday.
On Tuesday, Mr. Grandmaison started to worry. Mr. Cuomo might arrive in New Hampshire in 48 hours, trailing dozens of reporters, and none of the details of his arrival like buses, lights and sound systems had been tended to.
That evening Mr. Grandmaison met in his house in Rye, N.H., with a half-dozen Cuomo supporters to plan for the Governor's appearance. The next day, they reserved buses for Thursday or Friday and alerted a sound technician for both days. They also scouted around Manchester for a campaign headquarters and solicited bids for office furniture.
Also on Wednesday, Mr. Marino finally asked Mr. Grandmaison for a tentative schedule of the tentative events in New Hampshire, so he could fax it to Mr. Cuomo in Albany. That was the first time, Mr. Grandmaison said, that he sensed any involvement by Mr. Cuomo in the preparations.
By Thursday morning, no word had come from Mr. Cuomo. At that point a legal problem developed. According to some interpretations of the New Hampshire election law, a candidate who does not deliver a primary application in person has to have it delivered the day before the deadline. That, some of Mr. Cuomo's advisers said, meant that he had until only Thursday afternoon to mail his application.
At midday, an aide to Mr. Marino was dispatched to Concord with the Governor's signed ballot application and a certified check for the $1,000 filing fee. At 3 P.M., Mr. Grandmaison met the aide at the airport in Concord, put the application in the trunk of his car and drove downtown to await a decision on whether or not he should hand it to the Secretary of State. That afternoon, Mr. Grandmaison recalled, "I remember John's saying he was the most optimistic he had been" that Mr. Cuomo would run.
At 4:45 he placed a last call to Mr. Marino. No decision had been made. The application was not filed.
It seemed clear that if Mr. Cuomo was going to file, he was going to have to go to New Hampshire, for legal and political reasons. On Thursday night, an advance team was dispatched from Albany and New York City to Concord. In Albany, a long and inconclusive meeting between the Governor and the legislative leaders broke up with no budget agreement in sight.
Friday dawned with still no signal from Mr. Cuomo. At the Albany airport, the two chartered planes, costing $30,000, waited to take Mr. Cuomo and an entourage of reporters to Manchester, N.H. By 7 A.M. reporters began clogging the halls of the Capitol.
By midmorning the hallway outside the Governor's office in Albany began to resemble a crowded subway platform, with reporters and camera crews' milling around wearily. Top aides still did not know whether Mr. Cuomo was going to run or when or where he would announce his decision.
Mr. Cuomo spent the morning at the Executive Mansion. He called the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, no relation to John, and continued to press for a budget settlement, but neither side put forth new proposals.
Mr. Cuomo also called several friends and advisers to read them the differing versions of his announcement. They could hear his pen's scratching across the pad as he revised his remarks.
"I said, 'Don't make too many handwritten corrections, because one day, this might be auctioned at Sotheby's,' " a spokesman for the Economic Development Department, Harold Holzer, said.
At 1 P.M., Mr. Grandmaison decided that there was no longer time to have Mr. Cuomo fly to Manchester and drive to Concord to file. The flight plan was changed, so that the planes would fly directly to Concord. About 2 o'clock Mr. Cuomo called several close advisers and told them that he was not running. At about that time, the crowd in Concord, which had grown to include scores of reporters, began to note that there probably was not even enough time for the Governor to fly from Albany for the 5 P.M. deadline.
"At 2, without anybody's saying anything, you realized the likelihood had become substantially reduced," Mr. Grandmaison recounted.
That a decision had finally been reached -- though not what decision -- became apparent to reporters at about 3:15, when a news conference was called. Mr. Grandmaison, calling from a pay phone, had received word that the Mr. Cuomo was not running. At 3:30, 90 minutes before the deadline, Mr. Cuomo faced the press in Albany, and Mr. Grandmaison delivered the news to reporters in Concord.
"He decided fully when the budget was fully decided," Mr. Cuomo's son Andrew said. "From day 1 he said, 'I needed a budget.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo ending weeks of speculation by announcing on Friday that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for President. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Cocaine War's Biggest Success: a Fungus

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
In the war on cocaine, a humble root fungus is having a greater impact on Peru's coca leaf harvest than the will of Washington.
Leaving a trail of wilted bushes in its path, the fungus, a strain of fusarium oxysporum, has devastated about 10 percent -- or 15,000 acres -- of the coca fields in the Upper Huallaga Valley over the last two years. Bushes in the valley provide leaves for about half the world's cocaine production. 
 By contrast, an American-supported manual eradication effort was quietly ended in the valley in July in face of armed opposition by guerrillas and lack of interest by Peru's Government.
Coca growers charge that the United States is spreading the fungus with helicopters based in Santa Lucia, an American-built base in the Huallaga. American officials say the fungus is endemic to the Huallaga and is spreading naturally because of single crop cultivation.
"Eradication as a policy of the Peruvian Government does not exist and will not exist in the near future," said a Western drug expert here.
In an economy where living standards are at 1965 levels, Peruvian military officers frequently bribe their superiors in Lima for the privilege of transfers to the Huallaga Valley. Landing fees charged pilots of drug planes taking off for Colombia range from $1,500 to $5,000.
Military coordination has recently improved as the United States has pushed to turn Santa Lucia into a national center for antidrug operations.
Since operations began at Santa Lucia last year, the helicopters' fuel capacities limited operations to a 100-mile radius from the base. But in a coordinated operation last month, American and Peruvian pilots ferried Peruvian troops and antidrug police to Palma Pampas, a major trafficking center 400 miles southeast of Santa Lucia, where the police seized radios, ledgers, generators, laboratory chemicals and 372 pounds of cocaine base.
This month, Peru's Air Force is taking possession of 10 new Brazilian-made Tucano aircraft, which are suitable for intercepting small planes. But one year after an intercept campaign was begun, the air force has made few seizures from an air bridge that links Peruvian growers in the Huallaga and cocaine chemists in Colombia.
"We need a radar system for alerts, but there is no money in the national budget," Peru's new Prime Minister, Alfonso de los Heros, said in a recent interview here.
Acting on American-supplied radar intelligence, Peruvian air force planes forced down a trafficker's plane on Dec. 2, seizing 1,200 pounds of cocaine base. On Dec. 7, air force planes intercepted two planes flying south from Colombia. One crashed into the jungle, and the other reportedly turned back to Colombia.
A plan to wean growers from coca to alternative crops like corn, rice and bananas appears to have had success only in areas where fungus and high labor costs have cut profit margins. In the Huallaga, for example, growers have seen the profit on a kilo of coca leaves shrink from $1.50 to 10 cents in two years.
But as some farmers move to legitimate crops, other coca cultivators are pushing the agricultural frontier into Peru's Amazon lowlands.
"Coca keeps expanding," said one international agricultural expert who works to promote alternative crops in Peru. "We could spend $1 billion to turn around the Upper Huallaga, and then two years later there would be a new Upper Huallaga somewhere else."
With Peru's countryside in crisis because of guerrilla turmoil, coca cultivation now supports an estimated 1 million people out of a national population of more than 22 million.
Aiming to overthrow Peru's civilian government, guerrillas of the Shining Path movement disrupt food production, but protect coca leaf growers. In return for "war taxes," the group negotiates higher producer prices from Colombian buyers, settles disputes among growers and provides protection from the police.
"Where coca goes, Sendero goes," the international expert said, using the group's Spanish name. "They are principally in the jungle for economic reasons -- to get arms and money."

HEADLINE: Political Talk

BYLINE: By Sam Howe Verhovek

 BODY:

 
Lining Up Endorsements
 Even before Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had taken himself out of the Presidential race, other Democratic candidates were preparing their assaults on New York for the primary here next April.
On Dec. 10 Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas held a fund-raiser at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan that pulled in more than $250,000, said Governor Clinton's director of finance in the Northeast, Paul R. Carey, who is the son of former Gov. Hugh Carey, under whom Mr. Cuomo served as Lieutenant Governor. The elder Mr. Carey attended the fund-raiser even though he has not officially endorsed anyone in the race, his son said. 
 And last week, just days before Mr. Cuomo's announcement, the Clinton campaign lined up an endorsement from Joseph E. McDermott, the president of the Civil Service Employees Association, the largest union of state workers in New York. State employees, whose salaries have been frozen for more than a year, are locked in a bitter struggle with Mr. Cuomo over salaries.
Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, meanwhile, announced the opening of his New York campaign office last week, declaring, "We plan to wage an all-out campaign here and will run to win."
And now that Mr. Cuomo is a non-candidate, several of these candidates have begun calling his supporters for help; for instance, within an hour of the Governor's announcement Friday, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska was on the phone with Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, who said publicly that he was still hoping Mr. Cuomo would somehow get back into the race.
"Now New York becomes much more interesting," Paul Carey, the Clinton aide, said. "There's certainly more potential here than there was 24 hours ago, especially for fund-raising."
 
Cuomo Fever Spreads
 As one politician decides, another begins to ponder. While Mr. Cuomo was capturing headlines with his political ruminations, a familiar name in New Jersey was nourishing a different kind of will-he, won't-he speculation.
Brian M. Hughes, the 35-year-old son of former Gov. Richard J. Hughes, last week announced formation of a campaign advisory committee to explore his candidacy for Congress in 1992.
The younger Mr. Hughes is an assistant to the executive director of the Governor's Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse, a $23,000-a-year job that, his press statement was quick to point out, is not a political appointment.
If he decides to challenge the Republican incumbent, Christopher Smith, it would Mr. Hughes's first try for political office. A decision on his candidacy is months away, but Mr. Hughes, a Democrat, already has the oratory of a candidate.
"The incumbent, Chris Smith, clearly is out of touch with the day-to-day economic needs and worries of real people here in New Jersey," Mr. Hughes said in his statement. "After nearly 11 years in Congress, he's as insensitive to those needs and worries as are the rest of the Republicans in Washington."
Mr. Smith could not be reached for comment on his potential challenger.
 
The Death of Town Hall?
 If you think it's hard to keep up with the dissolution of the Soviet Union, consider this:
Change-NY, a conservative anti-tax group, has proposed that local governments in New York be disbanded. No more Carthage, N.Y. No more Corinth, N.Y. No more Naples, N.Y. The only exception would be large municipalities like New York City.
Change-NY is financed by some of the state's most vocal conservatives, including Lewis Lehrman, the Republican candidate for Governor in 1982, and Herbert London, the Conservative Party gubernatorial candidate in 1990.
The point of the plan, simply put, is to save money. Services provided by the local governments would be taken over by counties. The group estimates that the state would save $441 million this way and that local taxpayers would save $3.1 billion. (But think of all the money schools would have to spend on new maps!)

HEADLINE: After Years of 'Potential,' Will Cuomo Star Still Shine?

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 21

 BODY:
From July 16, 1984, when he captivated the nation with his keynote address to the Democratic National Convention, until Dec. 20, 1991, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo enjoyed the elevated political status of the "potential Presidential candidate."
The presumption that Mr. Cuomo might someday reside in the White House has bolstered his approval ratings in New York, given him a broader forum for his views and helped him command speaking fees of up to $20,000. 
 "I don't mind you people speculating," Mr. Cuomo said of the press in an interview last year. "It's probably good for me."
Now that Mr. Cuomo has taken himself out of the 1992 Presidential race, that speculation should end, at least for a few years and perhaps forever. And the impact on the political future of a man regarded as one of the Democratic Party's brightest hopes could be significant, both within the recession-wracked state he must continue to govern and in the party whose nomination he declined to pursue.
Mr. Cuomo's longtime friends and aides said the Governor understood that the choice he announced on Friday and the drawn-out process leading up to it might tarnish the shine on his political legacy.
"The decision not to run was the harder of the decisions to make," said Meyer S. Frucher, a former aide who speaks to the Governor regularly. "Mario Cuomo knows there is no glory and certainly no relief in staying and slogging through the budget and economic issues of the state.
"The allocation of losses is always a politically damaging and heart-wrenching problem. There are never winners and he knows it. He knows that he sentenced himself to an agonizing process that virtually any politician in America would attempt to escape."
 
Freedom from Obligations
 That agonizing process continued today as Mr. Cuomo summoned legislative leaders to an afternoon budget meeting in his conference room. Less than 24 hours after a throng of reporters had camped out in front of Mr. Cuomo's office to learn whether he would seek the Presidency, the Governor was back to the mundane and painful business of cutting the state budget.
"Events of the last 24 hours or so have freed me up from some political obligations," he said. "I'm going to use that freedom I didn't anticipate to focus even harder on the budget and the State of the State and that's what I'll be doing in the forseeable future."
There were no signs today that the budget impasse that Mr. Cuomo blamed for blocking his candidacy would dissolve any time soon. And if it does, new gaps in the state budget and new rounds of partisan fighting with the Republicans who control the State Senate are bound to emerge.
Some lawmakers and legislative aides questioned whether Mr. Cuomo's decision to pass up a Presidential race would diminish his popularity in the state and weaken his influence in the Capitol. Some have suggested that the Governor could essentially become a lame duck going into the second year of his third four-year term.
 
Control Already Gone
 But in actuality, it has been several years since Mr. Cuomo exerted significant control over even the Assembly, the Democratic house in the Legislature. Earlier this year, for example, the former Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, proposed a major increase in the income tax that had been rejected by Mr. Cuomo.
Lee M. Miringoff, a poll taker who has measured Mr. Cuomo's popularity in his nine years in office, said there was less connection now between Mr. Cuomo's national aspirations and his statewide political power than there might have been four years ago, before the recession and four consecutive years of budget deficits had sapped the governor's popularity.
A statewide poll taken in October by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, which Mr. Miringoff directs, showed that Mr. Cuomo's approval rating was at an all-time low of 44 percent. That was down from 75 percent in January 1988, when the economy was flush and Mr. Cuomo was still being mentioned as a potential candidate in that year's Presidential election.
"I think when the economy was good, his national aspirations fueled his popularity," Mr. Miringoff said. "I think his popularity now is more tied to the state of the recession in New York and the continuous bad budget news coming out of Albany."

HEADLINE: POLLUTION LIMITS DEBATED FOR CARS

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
State air pollution regulators and representatives of the automakers squared off for a debate Wednesday over whether New York should adopt California's tough standards on tailpipe pollution, and succeeded in making the audience, about 80 auto dealers, very nervous.
But perhaps because of heightened environmental consciousness among their customers and among the dealers themselves, the New York State Automobile Dealers Association has not taken a position on the rules. The reason, one dealer suggested, is that the people who sell cars do not trust either the Government or the auto manufacturers. 
 New York and 10 other states from Virginia to Maine have pledged to adopt the standards, which will require that, beginning in the mid-90's, cars emit far less carbon monoxide, a poison, and far less of the chemicals that cause smog. But the manufacturers, mounting a state-by-state resistance campaign, flew a team from Detroit to urge the dealers to oppose the rules.
"You will all remember 1981," said Al Weverstad, General Motors' manager of emission compliance, referring to the year when Federal regulations required yards of extra vacuum tubing in every car, creating balky engines that caused what Detroit calls "driveability problems."
 
Warning of Price Increases
 "Every time you force the technology, you take that risk," he said, arguing that if the new rules are adopted prices will rise by $1,000 a car, performance will drop and consumers will simply stop buying. Mr. Weverstad said that everything from baking bread to pumping gasoline to using hair spray adds chemicals to the air.
But Thomas Allen, director of the Division of Air Resources of the Department of Environmental Conservation, said the automobile industry was being told to spend only a modest amount, per ton of pollutant removed, compared to what factories and other polluters were being ordered to do.
"To point at everybody else's ox and say, 'gore that one, get the fuel guys, get the hair-spray guys,' is not fair," he said.
None of this cheered the dealers gathered at a Holiday Inn near La Guardia Airport. They are having a miserable year because of the recession, and are not anxious to take on anything that a customer will not love.
"Think of the last thing they tried to sell that didn't run on gasoline: diesels," said Henry Famularo, the service manager at Penn Toyota in Roslyn, L.I. Sitting next to him was Frank Apollo, service manager at Sunrise Toyota in Oakdale, L.I. "We have a few of those kicking around, very few," he said. "People thought they were buying a car like a gasoline car, only it's not." The diesels started differently, drove differently and had to be maintained differently, he said, and buyers disliked them.
 
Several Possible Changes
 Just what design changes the new rules would require is uncertain, but the cars available in a few years could include pre-heaters on catalytic converters that could make them slower to start, or incorporate more radical changes, like using natural gas or electricity instead of gasoline.
Despite their wariness of new technology, though, the dealers are not rushing to Detroit's defense. Mark Schienberg, executive vice president of the Greater New York Automobile Dealers Association, an affiliate of the statewide group, said that before condemning the California rules, the dealers were waiting to see that "this is not another air bag situation."
In that case, he said, the dealers enthusiastically backed Detroit's contention that air bags were impractical, too expensive and perhaps dangerous, until Chrysler Corporation abruptly switched positions and began using them as a selling point.
"Down the road, five years from now," he said, "I don't want Lee Iacocca riding around in a California car saying it's the best thing ever invented, and us getting another black eye."
 
A Selling Point?
 Jason Grumet, an assistant to Mr. Allen at the Department of Environmental Conservation, also referred to the air bag case. "My sense is that the one thing moving cars off your lots now is air bags," he said. He predicted that dealers could make a selling point of cleaner cars, too.
The dealers are clearly divided. "New York has had an air pollution program for 20 years, and I don't see any difference in the pollution," said Jim Farley, a Volkswagen dealer in New Hyde Park, L.I. "They haven't proved to me that they're able to solve the pollution."
Bob Bialer of Forest Hills Chevrolet criticized the system under which California passes rules that require inventions, but agrees to review the rules every two years and change them if the necessary technology has not been developed. That, he said, was like playing "chicken" by standing in front of oncoming cars and waiting for them to swerve.
Mark Herrmann of Mark Buick in Yonkers said that he was not eager to offer anything for sale that would reduce customer convenience, as seat belt interlocks did in the 1970's. And if new pollution standards led customers to defer their purchases because they did not like the new cars, that would hurt sales tax receipts as well as dealers' revenues.
But he added: "We do have a moral, social responsibility, not only to our children, but to our grandchildren. I don't know which way you should go."

HEADLINE: Business Diary

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

DATELINE: December 15-20

 BODY:

ECONOMY
 
Earth to Washington: The Recession Continues
When Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified before Congress, last week he cautioned the House Ways and Means Comittee not to move hastily on a plan to cut taxes even though, he admitted, "the economy is struggling." Cutting taxes is a "quick fix," he said. He also said he may have underestimated the country's economic woes. The White House, with a new chief of staff, is worried about how the economy will affect President Bush's standing in the polls also changed its view about the economy. "The recession continues," it said reversing its view that a turnaround had occurred. On Friday, Mr. Greenspan put those new insights into action. The Federal Reserve pushed the discount rate, what the Fed charges banks for short-term loans, down a full percentage point to its lowest level in nearly 30 years -- 3.5 percent. There is nothing like a looming election to focus the mind.
 
Little Hope From a Lower Prime
If banks can borrow more cheaply from the Fed, the argument goes, they can charge their best customers less when they drop by for a loan. That should get the country going. Last week at least part of that scenario played out. The most aggressive banks in the country began cutting their prime rates. (Banks compete with each other to make loans, after all). The first to cut its prime was Morgan Guaranty Trust & Company, the nation's fourth largest bank. It cut a full percentage point, to 6.5 percent from 7.5 percent. But will cuts in the prime add enough snap to get the economy going? "Not in the near term," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at CRT Government Securities. "Monetary policy was already easy enough for an expansion." he said. The real problems, Mr. Levy said, have to do with debt-encumbered consumers and overbuilt real estate.
 
A Record Housing Bust
Buy a home and pretty soon you'll have to gussie it it up with everything from drapes to dishwashers. That's why economists say the housing industry is a leading indicator for the rest of the economy. But last week's numbers did not exactly presage a boom. According to the Commerce Department, housing starts fell by 2.1 percent in November. "We are now guaranteed the lowest annual total since World War II," said David F. Seiders, a housing industry economist.
 
Vox Populi or Else
Bedtime reading at the White House must be Lao-tse, the ancient Chinese philosopher who said the best way to lead a country is by following the voice of the people. In September, the White House declared the recession over. Then last week Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said "for all practical purposes the recession continues." The reason for the switch? "The people of this country know that the economy is in trouble and it doesn't make any sense to play games," he said. That's candor.
 
Reading the Economy's Entrails
For the economic mavens studying each minor move of the economy, last week's revision of the gross domestic product did not do much to calm their frazzled nerves. According to the Commerce Department, G.D.P. inched up in the third quarter by a meager 1.8 percent. Since recessions usually end in a torrent of growth -- 6.7 percent is average -- last quarter's figures put the recovery in doubt. "It's a double dip," said Josh Stiles, an analyst at IDEA Inc., a research firm in New York.
 
Yet Another Bad Omen
Industrial output is the Government's gauge for measuring the tangible economy (it excludes services). It even includes the output of the nation's mines. After languishing for three months, industrial output fell by four-tenths of 1 percent, the Federal Reserve said last week. That decline -- led by the automobile industry -- is worrisome because it forecasts further shrinkages in the labor force.
Business is not exactly infused with confidence right now, and its spending plans show it. According to a survey by the Commerce Department, business plans to increase its capital outlays by a timid 5.4 percent next year -- half the rate in the 1980's.
 
COMPANIES
Stempel Stymied
Paleontologists say it took nearly a minute from the time a dinosaur's tail was nipped to the time it felt the pain. For the General Motors Corporation, that nip came way back in the 1970's when imports first started creeping in. Since then, the No. 1 auto maker has been fumbling its way toward competitiveness by trimming jobs and output. Last week, Robert C. Stempel, the company's chairman, said G.M. would become competitive by doing more of the same. The company will trim its work force by 70,000 and close 21 assembly plants. But Mr. Stempel did not say which jobs or plants would go, casting a pall over the holiday season for the entire workforce. With losses this year expected to be as high as $8 billion, Mr. Stempel said he had to act. "G.M. will become a much different corporation," he said.
 
Drexel's Joseph Gets a Rap
Last week, Frederick H. Joseph, the former chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., admitted he probably hadn't done enough to supervise his firm. It was on his watch that Drexel came to dominate the junk-bond business. It was also on his watch that the firm collapsed and Michael Milken, the head of its junk-bond desk, was sent to jail. For his errors, the New York Stock Exchange rapped Mr. Joseph's knuckles -- very softly. The Exchange censured him and barred him from associating with or owning a member firm for two years. The agreement "is an appropriate resolution to a difficult issue," Mr. Joseph said. "One I can now put behind me so that I can go forward with my career." The settlement allows Mr. Joseph to remain as a consultant to Drexel at $350,000 a year.
 
Obviously, This Guy Is No Joker
At least one investment is rising in value. Comic books. Last week at Sotheby's, Harold M. Anderson, the owner of a baseball museum based in Florence, Ala., paid $55,000 for the first Batman comic book ever printed. Mr. Anderson spent $229,845 on 21 books.
 
The Faith of American Express
With the travel business in a slump and so many airlines filing for bankruptcy, you have to have a lot of faith to spend $100 million to buy a travel agency. The American Express Company must be imbued with it. Last week it said it was buying closely held Lifeco, the nation's fifth-largest agency, with $1.20 billion in ticket sales. American Express is the No. 1 travel agency, with $3.25 billion in sales. With the acquisition, American Express will become twice the size of its nearest rival, the Carlson Travel Network. That will give it extra clout to negotiate fares with the airlines -- the ones that stay in business, that is.
 
McDonnell Douglas Gets Choosy
Corporations are supposed to believe in the invisible hand of the market -- but in a pinch there's always the Government. McDonnell Douglas announced it was shopping for a new site on which to build a factory for the MD-12X, its newest passenger jet. Since it will employ about 10,000 workers, McDonnell Douglas wants a building that's roomy, on about 600 acres and adjacent to an airport. But it also wants hundreds of millions of dollars in aid from state and local governments, including tax breaks and worker training programs. Nine sites around the country are competing.
 
Sandoz Rides to the Rescue
When Sandoz Ltd., the big Swiss drug company, said it was acquiring 60 percent of Systemix Inc., for $391.8 million, it was part of a familiar pattern. A group of sharp-minded scientists follow their ideas but suddenly need big money to commercialize them as products. That's when the giants step in. Systemix, is developing ways to separate stem cells from bone marrow cells for the treatment of cancer and AIDS.
 
INTERNATIONAL
An Inharmonic Divergence
 While the United States was pushing its interest rates down last week, the Germans were raising theirs. In a global economy, that combination may not only be disharmonious, but downright dangerous. The Bundesbank raised both of its key rates -- the Lombard and the discount -- by one-half of a percentage point. That puts them at 9.75 percent and 8 percent respectively. That's a tremendous spread compared with 3.5 percent discount rate and 6.5 percent prime rate in the United States. Since investors seek the highest yields, many are expected to flee the dollar and buy German marks. That could drag the dollar down sharply. "The Germans made their move with total disregard for its impact on any other country," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in New York. Letting the dollar fall a little, is not a catastrophe. But "there is a one in three chance of the dollar going into free fall." If the dollar collapsed, "there is nothing we could really do to support it," he said.
 
Maxwell on the Defensive
Last week, the Maxwell Communications Corporation, the largest of the late Robert Maxwell's holdings and the one with the greatest presence in the United States, made a move that riled its British creditors. The company filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Maxwell Communications owes its creditors about $2.37 billion. The move was aggressive and defensive. Since Britain does not have a Chapter 11 law, filing in New York was designed to keep the company from being broken up by its creditors to pay back its loans. Maxwell owns Macmillin Inc., the big publisher, and the Official Airline Guide, which publishes airline schedules. After the filing, even Britain's most stiff-lipped bankers were concerned. "We are absolutely livid," one of them said. They haven't been that exercised since, well, Mr. Maxwell was alive.
 
Any Way to Run an Airline?
Not only is the Soviet Union collapsing, running out of food and trying to determine who controls its tens of thousands of nuclear weapons but now Aeroflot, the world's largest airline, is running out of jet fuel. Aeroflot, the national airline of a country that has all but ceased to exist, closed 92 major airports in the republics and announced that 38 others were on the verge of shutting down. Passengers were left stranded throughout the Soviet Union.
