SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 30; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2038 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Record in Leading Arkansas: Successes, but Not Without Criticism

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
Bill Clinton, whose record over 11 years as Arkansas Governor is a centerpiece of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, likes to cite a recent Newsweek poll in which America's governors rated him the nation's most effective Governor.
It is worth remembering, however, that the poll before the last Presidential election accorded the honor to Michael S. Dukakis. 
 Mr. Clinton can point to numerous achievements as leader of one of the nation's poorest states. They include his relentless efforts to increase educational financing and standards, the expansion of health-care services to the poor and to schoolchildren, a national reputation for innovation in government, and a state economy that is growing faster than the national average.
"I think his record as Governor is probably the best record that I know of any Governor, especially when you consider it's not something he just did over a few years, but that it's over 11 years, and he has consistently been on the cutting edge," said Gov. Zell Miller of Georgia, who is supporting Mr. Clinton in the state's Democratic primary.
 
With an Eye to Dukakis
 Mr. Clinton's record will probably be closely scrutinized because unlike an individual lawmaker, a governor can produce a real record in terms of developing and implementing programs. But as Mr. Dukakis painfully learned, a governor's record can be both fragile and an inviting political target.
While the record Mr. Clinton runs on is geared more to long-term change than was Mr. Dukakis's fleeting "Massachusetts Miracle," the Arkansan could be vulnerable on taxes, which increased and became more regressive during his tenure, and on issues like the environment and the social service bureaucracy.
And Mr. Clinton faces the recurring criticism that he has learned the art of political survival too well -- ducking tough battles on issues like tax equity.
"He spends too much time taking care of his enemies and not enough time taking care of his friends," said Tommy Robinson, a former Congressman who ran unsuccessfully for the Republican nomination for governor in 1990. "Clinton wants everyone to love him."
It is an argument the Governor is quick to dispute.
"Show me another surviving governor who got elected five times during the tough times of the 80's, that got more done and changed more lives and stood up to more interest groups and raised more money for education," Mr. Clinton said in a recent interview
His record on education is widely viewed as the high mark of his tenure. The question some critics ask is whether it is a symbol of his accomplishments or a reminder that his overall record could have been better.
 
Snapping Back
Caution and Success From Early Defeat
 Arkansas is hardly an auspicious springboard for a national campaign. At 2.5 million people, it is the least populous state in the South. Its largest city, Little Rock, has a population of only 174,000, and its economy is dominated by traditional industries like lumber, poultry and oil and gas.
"This is a tough, tough state," said Diane Blair, a political science professor at the University of Arkansas, who is an expert on Arkansas politics and a supporter of Mr. Clinton. "There's a tremendous resistance to taxes. There's an enormous suspicion of activism, particularly by government. He's had to make a lot of tough judgments, and I think on balance his judgments have been excellent. This is a state in which the things that need attention will always outweigh the amount of attention any one individual can give them."
But others argue that governors of bigger states face challenges more complicated than does the leader of a state whose population is only slightly smaller than Chicago's.
A Rhodes Scholar and Yale Law School graduate, Mr. Clinton was first elected in 1978 when, at the age of 32, he became the nation's youngest Governor. His career has been shaped by his lowest moment, which came two years later.
Angered by an increase in automobile license fees and what was taken to be Mr. Clinton's somewhat imperial style, voters kicked him out of office, replacing him with Frank White, a little-known Republican.
Chastened, Mr. Clinton resolved to run again. In 1982, he easily defeated Mr. White and has been Governor ever since.
In his first term, in 1978, he offered a far-ranging package of liberal proposals. Since then, he has painstakingly picked his issues, built his coalitions and chosen his fights. To admirers, that has shown a shrewd ability to use his political capital where it could achieve results. Critics have seen it as timidity in taking on powerful interests.
 
Advances in Education
 Few criticize his record on education.
"A lot of Southern governors have done a lot of talking about education, but the rubber meets the road when you start paying for it," said Dr. Kern Alexander of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, who wrote a brutal indictment of Arkansas's educational system in 1978. "Despite coming from a very poor state, he has done more than talk about it."
Using as a standard state and local revenue per pupil adjusted for personal income, Professor Alexander said Arkansas, which is 47th in per capita income, now ranks 23d in the fiscal effort to support public schools.
Mr. Clinton's push for educational change began in 1983. The program was tough, calling for teacher competency testing that enraged teachers' groups, and it was expensive, calling for a 1 cent increase in the sales tax.
The program, which established standards for teachers and students, mandated smaller classes and elementary school counselors, and established the nation's first eighth-grade test that students must pass before beginning high school.
Other educational programs followed in 1989 and 1991. They included the nation's second program to allow students to choose the schools they would attend, some mergers of inefficient small districts, $1,000 yearly college scholarships for qualifying middle-income and poor students, increases in teacher pay and a revamping of vocational education programs.
Between 1983-84 and 1990-91, the percentage of Arkansas high school graduates going to college rose to 48 percent, from 38 percent. In 1983-84, only 46 percent of the state's high schools offered physics courses and 68 percent, chemistry. Now, they all do.
 
Improving Health Care
 Mr. Clinton also gets high marks on efforts to improve health care, particularly in poor areas. In recent years Arkansas has allocated $15 million for early childhood education and begun new programs in prenatal care and health care for poor children. The Governor has not wavered on some controversial health issues, like the health department's program to distribute condoms to high school students through school clinics.
"He has a real desire to invest in health issues," said Joycelyn Elders, the state's health director. "He has always backed me in tough situations like when he took on the Legislature and fought his guts out for my health department budget."
While employment is expected to grow at a rate of 3 percent this year, compared to a net loss for the nation as a whole, Mr. Clinton cannot take credit for an economic boom. From 1980 to 1990, Arkansas's population grew by only 2.7 percent, as against a 9.7 increase in that of the nation as a whole. In 1980, per capita income in the state was 75.4 percent of the national figure; in 1990 it had only inched up to 76.8 percent.
Business leaders say the Governor's economic-development efforts, including tax incentives, fostering international trade and enhancing job training, have helped Arkansas outpace the nation and its neighboring states in terms of employment growth, growth in manufacturing jobs and income growth in recent years.
Even his critics say Mr. Clinton truly believes in making government work, can be a master at working with the Legislature, has generally hired strong administrators and has a passion for innovative programs, whether one of the nation's first programs to require that welfare recipients work or adopting an Israeli program that teaches parents of 4,500 low-income families how to read to and teach their pre-school children.
 
Answering Critics
Dealing With Taxes And Social Policy
 Still, as much because of Mr. Clinton's abilities as his shortcomings, many critics see what has not been accomplished as clearly as what has been.
Conservatives say he has been too quick to raise taxes. Liberals say he has approved a series of tax breaks for businesses while relying primarily on the sales tax, regarded as the least progressive tax, to improve education. Arkansas is one of only 18 states that tax food at the same rate as other retail sales; the state sales tax is 4.5 percent but local taxes bring the average sales tax to 6 percent.
Mr. Clinton says that his tax policies largely reflect a state Constitution that requires a three-quarters vote of the Legislature to approve any tax increase other than sales taxes and that he pushed for and then supported a ballot proposal for tax reform, a proposal that voters rejected.
As evidence of a broader tax policy, he points to the Legislature's approval last year of an increase in the corporate income tax to help finance vocational education. But some lawmakers grumble that he is taking credit for a program they developed and passed.
"I would say the record of Arkansas since he's been Governor is mixed," said Michael Ettlinger, director of state tax policy at Citizens for Tax Justice, a research and advocacy organization. "I'd say other state income taxes have gotten more progressive, and their's have gotten a little less progressive."
Mr. Clinton is also widely criticized for his environmental record. A study by the Institute for Southern Studies, a research group in Durham, N.C., listed Arkansas 48th among the states in its recent Green Index, which ranked states in terms of the severity of their environmental problems and the rigor of their environmental enforcement.
"I would give him at best a 5 on a scale of 1 to 10," said Chuck Cremeen, president of Arkansas for Environmental Reform.
The Governor concedes that in the tradeoffs he has made economic issues probably took precedence over some environmental ones.
"When I got back in office, I literally had to worry about people being able to keep body and soul together," he said. "And I decided to focus my political energy and my political capital on doing the big things that I thought would help people most over the long run."
Among the state's most glaring problems now is a lawsuit over its juvenile-care system, which charged repeated incidents of abuse at foster homes.
To some, Mr. Clinton is a better idea man and crusader for selected issues than a consistently attentive executive.
"Human services, welfare, I think those things sort of bore him," said John Brummett, editor of Arkansas Life magazine and a longtime newspaper columnist. "They're necessities of government, but they're just sort of messy. There's not a lot of political capital in championing those things as there is in championing education."
Still, even many with criticisms wonder if anyone else could have done better. Because of its poverty, Arkansas has been particularly hard hit by cutbacks in Federal programs. In 1980, Federal money made up 36 percent of the state's revenue; by 1988, it was down to 21 percent.
Few dispute Mr. Clinton's contention that many of the problems are part of a national crisis common to every state.
"One of the reasons I decided to run for President," he said, "was that as the longest-serving Governor in America I had to face the fact that there are limits to what any governor can do in the absence of a national strategy to compete and succeed in the global economy.
"I think you have to ask, What's the standard? I think the standard is, How do you do against the competition? Are you better off than you were when you started? Are you going in the right direction? And have you been willing to change and innovate? It seems to me that's the standard, and I think the results are pretty good."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 29, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article and a chart last Sunday about Bill Clinton's record as Governor of Arkansas misstated several comparative population figures for Arkansas and the United States. Arkansas's population was 2,350,725 in 1990, according to the Census Bureau; it grew 2.81 percent from 1980. The United States population grew 9.78 percent, to 248,709,873.

HEADLINE: Trying to Play by the Rules

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS

 BODY:
KATHY BIRK, the manager of Dean Witter's branch here, is known among colleagues and competitors for her dedication to playing by the rules. It's a passion that didn't come casually. When she took her first job as a stockbroker for Prudential Securities in 1980, she felt most comfortable selling ultra-low-risk investments. Her favorite annuity, National Investors, seemed so safe that she even sold it to her parents, who invested the bulk of their savings in it.
One day, abruptly, National Investors went bankrupt, leaving her clients, as well as her parents, in the lurch. She felt terrible. Even worse than the losses, she was haunted by her belief that Prudential's head office had deceived her, keeping the stock of National Investors' parent company on its "buy" list up until the day the annuity went into receivership. 
 "I couldn't believe no one had tipped me off," said Mrs. Birk. "Someone had to have known what was going on." Soon, she quit.
Looking back, she faults herself for having believed in others so blindly. Her chilling experience, during which she considered quitting the business entirely, highlights one of the root tensions in the retail end of the financial services business: The conflict between selling and responsibility to the customer. "We're all in the business of making money," said Mrs. Birk, "but you have to be able to look at yourself in the mirror each morning."
Kathy Birk, according to Andrew J. Johnson, one of the Dean Witter brokers who works in her office, is a stickler for rules. "She is by the book, by the book, by the book," he said, shaking his head as he recalled how she has pestered him to follow her instructions.
But in these back-to-basics days of managing other people's money, Mrs. Birk believes that investors in Indianapolis -- in the whole country as a whole for that matter -- want two things: a safe, simple and predictable financial product and a broker who is equally safe and predictable.
 
Return of the Little Guy
 More than four years after the 1987 stock market crash, which deeply frightened and repelled small investors, individuals are returning to stocks and mutual funds. Bottom-of-the-barrel interest rates have pried them away from safer, but low-yielding, investments like certificates of deposit.
Financial services firms like Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. that are geared toward individual investors are reaping sizable rewards from the shift -- net income for the firm's securities division shot up to $119 million through the first nine months of this year, from just $82 million a year earlier.
Just two years ago, the brokerage business was wailing about the flight of small investors, badly spooked by the market crash, and wondering if they would come back. After the crash, thousands of small investors filed complaints against their brokers, accusing them of pushing unsuitable investments, misrepresenting the risks and returns on investments, doing poor research, churning customers' accounts to earn higher commissions and, in some cases, out-and-out stealing.
The crash, and the subsequent complaints by small investors, were played out against the larger tapestry of the freewheeling, greedy atmosphere that gripped Wall Street during the 1980's and the crop of giant-killer insider-trading scandals that dominated the business news pages.
Now, Mrs. Birk and others contend, only where brokers win the lasting confidence of their customers can profits like those Dean Witter is now enjoying be assured long term. Compliance -- that is, following the rules -- has become the watchword for brokerage house branch managers, though the extent to which many managers are genuinely serious about compliance and not merely playing lip service to the idea is not fully clear.
 
Who to Trust?
 Mrs. Birk insists she is deadly serious about compliance. "The arrows are coming from every direction," she said, referring to customers' disillusionment with the industry.
Indeed. She owes her job to complicance problems Dean Witter had in Indianapolis in 1985.
A broker in the office employed a trading strategy using high-risk instruments, options in this case, which were inappropriate for unsophisticated middle-income investors. Several customers filed complaints, but the broker had already left the firm by then. (Dean Witter refuses to reveal the broker's name, making it impossible to determine from public documents whether the individual was ever disciplined or still employed in the securities industry.)
The office manager, who was responsible for supervising the broker, then stepped aside, returning to the stockbroker ranks in the office, a job he still holds.
After three months of leaving the position vacant, Dean Witter selected Mrs. Birk, who had joined the Dean Witter office two years earlier. "She basically got the job by default. Nobody else wanted it," said Mr. Johnson, who has been with the office since 1979.
Mrs. Birk was left to pick up the pieces. The case went into arbitration and a settlement was eventually reached with the customer that cut sharply into the office's net income. Mrs. Birk's bonus, tied to office earnings, suffered -- despite the fact that she had become manager after the incident occurred.
No Wall Street firm is free from compliance problems, but Dean Witter had a reputation among state securities industry regulators as a firm somewhat more concerned with boosting profits than with playing strictly by the book. "Our compliance record is very good now, certainly better than it was seven years ago," said James Flynn, Dean Witter's director of corporate communications in New York.
In Indianapolis at least, Mrs. Birk seems to have led the way in making a financial services branch office succeed and earn strong profits while building a reputation as a straight shooter.
"She balances as well as anyone I've seen," said Thomas O'Neil, Dean Witter's regional director in the Midwest, referring to the line a branch manager walks between a broker's needs, a client's interests and a head office's directives.
From the time she took the helm of the office, located in Carmel, a suburb at the northern edge of Indianapolis, through 1990 revenues have grown by an average of 18 percent a year. Last year, Dean Witter closed its downtown branch and merged it with the suburban office, making Mrs. Birk sole branch manager.
Office revenue this year is near $9 million, among the best of any Dean Witter office in the country. Mrs. Birk's earnings are now in six figures, and she is up for promotion to senior vice president next month.
"This business is not as mysterious or romantic as a lot of people think," Mrs. Birk volunteered, sitting squarely behind her desk in a no-nonsense blue suit. "The bottom line is sales."
To sell financial products, Mrs. Birk said, she primes her brokers any way she can. She expects discipline and resilience, and encourages an entrepreneurial attitude, leaving each broker to find an individual way to rack up sales. She nurtures and prods them, alternating her support and sympathy with a demanding toughness.
She recalled the time she drove to a nearby bar to retrieve a broker who had left early from a scheduled evening shift: "It was embarrassing for him. But I thought: 'How can I expect others to work hard when they all knew where this guy was?' "
 
Keeping Tabs
 But if the bottom line is sales and a significant portion of her income and that of her brokers is based on how much they sell, how can compliance be job No. 1, as she asserts it is?. Her answer is a simple one: Dean Witter's raison d'etre is to make money for its parent, Sears, Roebuck and Company; the way to do that is through sales; the way to assure those sales, particularly over the long haul, is to treat customers fairly and honestly. And that means, among other things, keeping an eye on what your brokers are up to.
There are plenty of temptations, many far less egregious than putting the unsophisticated in high-risk stock options or churning an account. For example, brokers earn a slightly higher commission on Dean Witter in-house mutual funds. And they rely largely on the head office in New York for research on specific stocks, which can put them at the mercy of a sell-side analyst overly optimistic about a particular investment the firm would like to see pushed.
So she may grumble about having to sift through the tall pile of white and yellow order tickets that await her at the end of each day, but she doesn't feel comfortable until she does. Compliance -- and her bitter lesson at Prudential -- compel her to hammer at her brokers again and again with a salient lesson: sell clients only those investments that are suitable to the client's individual needs.
"I tell them every day, 'Listen to the client's objective. Pay attention to it.' " she said. At weekly staff meetings she doesn't hesitate to bring up cases in which she questions a broker's judgement.
Miriam Dant, Indiana's Securities Commissioner, said Mrs. Birk is one of the few financial service branch managers in Indianapolis who does not act afraid or combative when asked for information about a specific transaction or broker at her firm and that she cooperates fully with all inquiries.
Mrs. Dant added that, although the number of complaints filed against brokers in Indiana has been growing over the past 10 months -- most of them alleging churning of accounts -- no formal complaints have been filed against Kathy Birk's office.
"They run a pretty clean office," said an official of the North American Securities Administrators Association, based in Washington. That group and the National Association of Securities Dealers maintains a database of registration and licensing information on brokers, including complaints against them.
When the official searched the database for the name of every broker in Mrs. Birk's office last week, only two pending complaints by customers from the last five years were found, both from 1991. One was so recent that while Mrs. Birk knew of its existence, she had not seen it and couldn't comment.
Mrs. Birk said the other involves an elderly customer, now ill with Alzheimer's disease. She contends Dean Witter correctly carried out the customer's instructions, delivered prior to the onset of his illness.
Common-sense advice, rather than any divination of high-risk opportunity, is the major task for a retail broker. Mrs. Birk and her staff devote much of their time to patient explanations to customers of the benefits of, for example, a diverse portfolio.
On a recent morning in the Carmel office, a steady stream of assistants and brokers came through Mrs. Birk's office to seek an approving signature. Most required only a quick glance and a flash of the pen; others, a little more discussion.
"Now look at this one," she said, studying a letter from a client. The client, whose work had apparently taken him out of town, wrote to ask that funds from his maturing C.D. be switched into a stock in which he already had a position.
"We can do that," she said hestitantly, "but it certainly wouldn't be in his best interest." She arranged for the customer's broker to talk to him before making the trade.
Mrs. Birk oversees an office with 36 brokers and trainees, only one woman among them. She maintains that gender is not an issue in her office, even though she sees certain advantages to what she describes as her nonmale style of management, emphasizing mediation and conciliation.
 
Job Qualifications
 In a business still dominated by men, her own path upward has not always been easy. Mrs. Birk said she was hired as a trainee broker at Prudential Bache in 1980 because she was a woman. But her boss paid her $400 a month less than the four male trainees who worked beside her. "I didn't make an issue of it," she said. "I thought: 'I'll show him.' "
Mrs. Birk, in fact, said she would not hire a job applicant with the qualifications she offered at the time. But she said she does not do female applicants any extra favors, despite her own example as someone who needed a chance to grow into the job for which she wasn't fully qualified.
As for her knack for mediation and nurturing, she said, previous superiors set a standard in her mind of what not to do: dominating colleagues and staff, bullying, insisting that they be obeyed and not questioned.
Mrs. Birk has sometimes wondered, she said, if her approach compromises her control. She recognizes the danger of being perceived as soft. But in the end, she said, she trusts her sense of where the balance lies.
"I'm a better leader than a follower," she said.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
From the Frigid North Is Carved a Native Terrain

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
THE idea for Nunavut, a land where Canada's Eskimos could rule themselves, had been around for a long time before it was accepted by Ottawa last week. Still, the announcement that a fifth of the country will be carved from the Northwest Territories and entrusted to 17,500 Eskimos caused many Canadians to pull out maps for a look at the great white vastness that has been at the heart of much of their romance about themselves. A sample of what Nunavut, meaning "our land" in the Eskimos' Inuktituk language, will entail:
The Land -- An American serviceman stationed in the Arctic in World War II described the region as "nothin' but miles and miles of miles and miles," a region that most Canadians know little of. The "true north" of which they sing in 'O Canada' is officially designated as beginning at the 60th degree of latitude, 1,500 miles beyond the summer cottages that are the furthest north that most Canadians venture. Another 1,500 miles lie between there and Alert, the last settlement before the North Pole. Under Ottawa's proposal, most of this will become Nunavut. 

History -- Human activity has been traced back 4,000 years; contacts with Europeans began with Norsemen around the 11th century A.D. Then came maritime explorers hoping to short-cut their way to China, missionaries, and all manner of roughcut adventurers. Ottawa remained largely uninvolved until a 1939 court ruling deemed the Eskimos to be a federal responsibility. After World War II, interest was led by the Pentagon, which was concerned first with building early-warning radars against a Soviet bomber attack, later with the hide-and-seek of nuclear submarines beneath the polar ice cap.
Living -- For the Eskimos, or Inuit as most prefer to be called, a nomadic life based on hunting of polar bears, seals and whales has been in decline. Most communities now cluster around government centers like Resolute. Unemployment, alcoholism, suicide and sexually transmitted diseases are at chronic levels, causing some Inuit to advocate a return to traditional life styles. Others see salvation in an end to paternalism. Thus Nunavut, and the prospect of the Inuit controlling at least part of the $1 billion that Ottawa spends annually on its Arctic domain.
Economy -- To win Ottawa's consent, Inuit leaders made major concessions on land and resource ownership. They will have title to barely one-sixth of Nunavut's 770,000 square miles, and mineral rights over 14,000 square miles. The rest will remain "Crown land," or Ottawa's. While Inuit negotiators demanded mineral rights in some of the most geologically promising areas, this was a lottery. Development of known oil, gas and gold reserves has been minimal, and much prospecting remains to be done.
Politics -- With barely 2,500 "outsiders," an Inuit political majority in Nunavut is assured. But some Inuit fear that they could eventually be outnumbered. Franchise qualifications are among details to be settled, with Inuit leaders favoring a five-year residency requirement. Others worry that Nunavut's start-up costs, estimated at $500 million, together with $160 million a year in annual outlays beyond what it costs to administer the territory from Yellowknife, the Northwest Territories capital, will drain scarce funds. These and other issues will be debated in a plebiscite on Nunavut among the Northwest Territories' 52,000 residents sometime in 1992.

HEADLINE: Mr. Gephardt's Irresponsible Economics

 BODY:
Representative Richard Gephardt, the House majority leader, and several Democratic colleagues gave the nation a wrongheaded and irresponsible economics lesson on trade with Japan last week.
Mr. Gephardt, Senator Don Riegle and four Michigan Representatives said trade deficits with Japan help explain why the U.S. is trapped in recession and why nearly one million Americans have lost their jobs. Mr. Gephardt's elixir: Shut out Japanese cars unless Japan eliminates the trade deficit over five years. 
 But any attempt to cut back imports would destroy as many American jobs as it would protect. If Americans bought less from abroad, the dollar would rise in value -- making U.S. exports increasingly expensive. That would drive down sales, throwing tens of thousands of Americans out of work, from farmers to aeronautical engineers.
It's reasonable for the U.S. to target specific industries where Japan violates international rules to block U.S. exports. But Mr. Gephardt wants to target the whole country on the basis of an overall trade balance. Yet trade balances are not a measuring rod for unfair trade practices. The U.S., as one sobering example, is running a $20 billion trade surplus with Europe. Does Mr. Gephardt believe Europe should retaliate?
Mr. Gephardt's bill would protect Chrysler, Ford and General Motors. But, by jacking up prices, protectionist legislation could cost American taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars for each job saved. Why doesn't Mr. Gephardt bury his protectionist bill and instead ask taxpayers to fork over, say, $80,000 to each auto worker displaced by Japanese imports. That would be cheaper for taxpayers, better for the auto worker . . . and honest.

HEADLINE: U.S. Shouldn't Concede Asian Market to Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Accolades for "Power of the Yen Winning Asia" (Business Day, Dec. 5). American business faces an uphill struggle in East Asia and the Pacific, but it is not a struggle we should forfeit. It is important to remember how much the Asia-Pacific market means to the United States. 
 Trans-Pacific trade accounts for 35 percent of all our trade (about 50 percent greater than trade with Europe). But Japan's dynamism means that it dominates the region economically. (Recent levels of new United States investment in Asia have been roughly equal to Japan's, although the continued capital crunch here and a corresponding glut in Japan indicate this will not be the case for long.)
Much of Japan's lead in Asia may be attributed to proximity: Japan dominates the region as the United States dominates the Western Hemisphere. But given the relative size of the United States and Japanese economies ($5.2 trillion versus $2.8 trillion), Japan's growing power in the Asian market is remarkable.
But it would be overpessimistic to assume that Japan is destined to absorb its neighbors economically and to lock out non-Japanese trade and investment. Continued growth in United States exports, along with small but important market-opening successes in bilateral negotiations with Japan and others in Asia, illustrates that neither American companies nor our Government is willing to cede the region to Japan alone. If this approach is maintained, and if the United States can address chronic fiscal deficits, low personal savings and lack of focus on education, there is no reason we cannot compete as effectively in Asia as elsewhere.
Moreover, Japan's economy and society are evolving in ways that can benefit United States trade and investment. After three decades of remarkable growth under an export-led strategy that has been of great benefit to Japanese business -- but less so to Japanese consumers, who still pay what we would consider outrageous prices for many basic goods and services -- Japan is shifting its priorities from heavy reliance on investment and manufacturing abroad and to domestic infrastructure development. The Japanese Government will need to examine economic and business arrangements that have locked out foreign competition. Other East Asian countries may similarly reorient as they move to industrialized status, creating additional demand for American goods and services.
Perhaps the most immediate concern is saving the multilateral trading system. The United States and Japan need to rescue the floundering Uruguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations. Locking Japan and its East Asian neighbors into binding commitments to liberalize their markets -- by, for example, opening up to foreign agricultural products (in Japan) and improving protection of patents and other intellectual property (in the rest of Asia) -- will help American companies doing business there.
The increasing drift toward economic regionalism in Asia and elsewhere may be unavoidable. But a strong set of enforceable global trading rules can help mitigate the problems for the American economy that may be caused by Japan's dominance in Asia.
 
JONATHAN HUNEKE
Mgr., Investment Policy, U.S. Council for International Business
New York, Dec. 5, 1991

GRAPHIC: Drawing

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
What's To Debate?

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
Mario Cuomo warned the nation that he would not run for President unless New York's massive budget crisis was resolved first. Those who thought he was merely playing games found out last week that he meant what he said.
 That's a welcome change from the usual political double talk and deniability. But there's no use pretending, as some Democrats are doing, that the party's chances for 1992 have not been hurt. Mr. Cuomo would have been the most commanding and articulate figure the Democrats could have put up -- and articulateness is one quality, among many, badly needed in the White House. 
George Bush is undoubtedly relieved that Mr. Cuomo has taken himself out ofthe race; but the President is by no means out of the woods. A gaggle of Administration experts met with him last week to debate his economic options, including whether to declare an emergency that would permit him to break last year's budget agreement with Congress.
 What's to debate?
 General Motors has announced it will close 21 plants, lay off 9,000 white-collar workers in 1992 and eliminate more than 70,000 jobs in the next few years. The company's troubles are not all due to the recession, but a sluggish economy speeded this long-needed "restructuring" of what used to be the flagship of U.S. business. And all those lost jobs won't help recovery.
 For the week ended Dec. 7, first-time claims for unemployment insurance rose by 79,000 -- about twice the number forecast, and a strong sign that the economy is not slowly recovering, as usually claimed, but is contracting.
 In the New York metropolitan area, more than 400,000 jobs have been lost since 1989. In Manhattan alone, job losses in the last two years have wiped out all the private-sector growth of the 1980's, and there are now fewer non-government jobs than there were in 1980.
 And that's only a sampling of the pre-Christmas bad news, with stores still uncrowded and layoffs increasing everywhere. And since G.M. has not specified which of its plants it will close, uncertainty about their personal futures must be a matter of real worry for most of that huge work force.
 Chairman Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve -- which dropped the discount rate a full point on Friday -- has conceded that he had underestimated the seriousness of the situation, and that "the economy is struggling." But Mr. Greenspan, in testimony to the House Ways and Means Committee, continued to insist that nothing should be done that might increase the budget deficit.
 There's the rub for the White House. In last year's settlement with Congress, it was agreed that any revenue losses or increases in spending would be offset by gains or cuts elsewhere, so that the deficit would not rise. Mr. Bush would have to declare an emergency to break the agreement, which he has so far refused to do.
 But all the options discussed at the White House this week would run up the deficit. They apparently included an increase in the personal exemption for income-tax payers, a tax credit for middle-income earners and a one-year cut in the onerous and regressive Social Security payroll tax.
 With a Presidential election coming up, the struggling economy is an acute political concern for the White House. With so many unemployed and so many fearful of losing their jobs, taking stimulative action might well be more immediately popular with voters than holding the line on the deficit. So some Administration aides want to send Congress a stimulative proposal designed to have bipartisan support and win quick passage.
 Others argue for a distinctly Republican proposal, based on conservative ideas, like Mr. Bush's familiar call for a reduced capital-gains tax. Such a plan, they concede, might win little Congressional support but would provide a strong conservative platform for the campaign. Mr. Greenspan, meanwhile, cautions against "short-term fiscal stimulus" that might not be helpful to long-term growth.
 This debate seems mostly defensive and technical: What's best for the Administration politically? What's best for the economy in the long term? There's little suggestion of acute Administration concern for the human misery of recession -- which occurs in the short term and surely seems like an emergency to those who suffer it. Mario Cuomo, better than anyone else, could have dramatized that for the nation.

HEADLINE: Credit Cards Cost Exactly What They Say

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Credit Cards Cost More Than You Think" (letter, Dec. 16) by Prof. S. A. Ravid reflects fundamental misunderstanding of credit-card interest. 
Most customers have the use of the borrowed funds from the purchase date until the payment due date on their statement. In some cases, this grace period can be as long as 50 days. Then, even when payment is due, most customers can repay the entire outstanding balance interest-free. In effect, interest is waived for them, though they borrowed money, regardless of the amount.
 If the customer pays the entire principal balance on the due date, the customer has had an interest-free loan. If the customer pays less, he or she will have to pay interest at the stated rate. The interest rate does not increase with the amount of payment.
 Finally, and perhaps most important, none of this is a secret. Everything is disclosed by the card issuer, as required by the Federal Truth in Lending Act. Credit cards do not cost more than you think. They cost exactly what they say they cost -- no more, no less.
 
STEVEN I. ZEISEL
Senior Counsel, Consumer Bankers Association
Arlington, Va., Dec. 16, 1991

HEADLINE: U.S. Shouldn't Concede Asian Market to Japan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Accolades for "Power of the Yen Winning Asia" (Business Day, Dec. 5). American business faces an uphill struggle in East Asia and the Pacific, but it is not a struggle we should forfeit. It is important to remember how much the Asia-Pacific market means to the United States. 
 Trans-Pacific trade accounts for 35 percent of all our trade (about 50 percent greater than trade with Europe). But Japan's dynamism means that it dominates the region economically. (Recent levels of new United States investment in Asia have been roughly equal to Japan's, although the continued capital crunch here and a corresponding glut in Japan indicate this will not be the case for long.)
Much of Japan's lead in Asia may be attributed to proximity: Japan dominates the region as the United States dominates the Western Hemisphere. But given the relative size of the United States and Japanese economies ($5.2 trillion versus $2.8 trillion), Japan's growing power in the Asian market is remarkable.
But it would be overpessimistic to assume that Japan is destined to absorb its neighbors economically and to lock out non-Japanese trade and investment. Continued growth in United States exports, along with small but important market-opening successes in bilateral negotiations with Japan and others in Asia, illustrates that neither American companies nor our Government is willing to cede the region to Japan alone. If this approach is maintained, and if the United States can address chronic fiscal deficits, low personal savings and lack of focus on education, there is no reason we cannot compete as effectively in Asia as elsewhere.
Moreover, Japan's economy and society are evolving in ways that can benefit United States trade and investment. After three decades of remarkable growth under an export-led strategy that has been of great benefit to Japanese business -- but less so to Japanese consumers, who still pay what we would consider outrageous prices for many basic goods and services -- Japan is shifting its priorities from heavy reliance on investment and manufacturing abroad and to domestic infrastructure development. The Japanese Government will need to examine economic and business arrangements that have locked out foreign competition. Other East Asian countries may similarly reorient as they move to industrialized status, creating additional demand for American goods and services.
Perhaps the most immediate concern is saving the multilateral trading system. The United States and Japan need to rescue the floundering Uruguay Round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations. Locking Japan and its East Asian neighbors into binding commitments to liberalize their markets -- by, for example, opening up to foreign agricultural products (in Japan) and improving protection of patents and other intellectual property (in the rest of Asia) -- will help American companies doing business there.
The increasing drift toward economic regionalism in Asia and elsewhere may be unavoidable. But a strong set of enforceable global trading rules can help mitigate the problems for the American economy that may be caused by Japan's dominance in Asia.
 
JONATHAN HUNEKE
Mgr., Investment Policy, U.S. Council for International Business
New York, Dec. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
America's in the Balcony as Europe Takes Center Stage

BYLINE: By JOSEF JOFFE; Josef Joffe is editorial page editor and columnist of Suddeutsche Zeitung in Munich.

DATELINE: MUNICH, Germany

 BODY:
IS United States influence in Europe going the way of the dollar?
For much of this century, the mighty greenback was worth more than four Deutsche marks; today, it has sunk below 1.60. Not that long ago, about the time when Stormin' Norman had flattened the last Iraqi berm, folks were celebrating the birth of a "unipolar" world in which one power towered above the rest -- and that was the United States. But where is the United States today? 
 Something must have happened on the way to the top of the power pyramid. In Europe, you have to look very hard to see No. 1.
 
A New Shuttlemeister
 True, Messrs. Bush and Baker have recently been preoccupied with other items, notably the Middle East and the former Soviet Union. The Secretary of State has logged more miles crisscrossing the Middle East than the shuttlemeister, Henry Kissinger, did in the 1970's. Just last week, the best minds of the State Department were wrestling with the question whether, apart from tea and coffee, cookies ought to be served to Israelis and Palestinians loitering in the halls of Foggy Bottom.
To be fair, it is right and fitting that President Bush should be spending more time in a recession-weary America; after all, it is only 317 days until election time. And it is just as urgent that Mr. Baker should try to round up as many Soviet nukes as possible before they wind up in the global cash-and-carry market and thence in the hands of such New World Order stalwarts as Iran, Libya and North Korea.
But in the meantime, others are calling the tune in Europe, hardly an insignificant place on the geopolitical map. The last time the United States played a starring role in the Old World was circa 1989-90, when the Bush Administration brilliantly stage-managed German reunification. That wasn't as hard as getting the Syrians to shake hands with the Israelis, but it was an impressive feat nonetheless.
Wary of German clout, France and Britain had to be coaxed and cajoled. Still dreaming of selling Germany's unification for Germany's neutralization, Moscow had to be checked and reassured. And all the while, Washington had to keep a gentle leash on Bonn lest it stray from the path of Western virtue.
In 1989-90, the United States was leading; today it is lagging. Two years ago, Washington did all the right things in Europe: making sure that Germany was reunified in the West, managing the demise of the Soviet empire so that it would go out with a whimper and not with a bang, harnessing Europe's resources in the war against Iraqi imperialism. This was not a bad beginning for the New World Order.
But today? The most significant events in Europe are unfolding without, and sometimes against, the United States. In Maastricht, the site of the most recent summit meeting of the European Community, the Twelve poured the foundations for a mighty economic-monetary bloc that might yet spell more trade troubles for the United States -- and for global free trade in general.
 
A Power Play
 Just last week in Brussels, curtains rose and revealed an astounding, indeed historical, power play on the European stage. Virtually alone in opposition for months, Germany had practically Germanized the community's Yugoslav policy overnight. (At this point, only readers who know the difference between Slovakia, Slavonia and Slovenia might want to proceed; Slobbovia doesn't count.)
Since the early fall, Bonn had been pressing for the recognition of the two breakaway republics of Slovenia and Croatia, the latter the target of a bloody expansionist war unleashed by Serbia. Just as strenuously, France, Britain and the United States tried to resist, on the grounds that recognition would demolish the last chances for a political settlement.
Bonn persisted -- and won. Now the entire European Community is set to recognize Slovenia and Croatia by Jan. 15.
To many Americans, Balkan politics might be about as real as those grainy Hitchcock classics in which old ladies vanish in sooty trains and Slavic heavies in operetta uniforms plot for power and profit. But in Europe, the war of the Yugoslavs has been a double watershed. In the first place, it revealed -- like a bolt of lightning -- a landscape strewn with short-fused powder kegs stretching eastward from Berlin and Vienna. In the second place, it dramatized Europe's new power relationships.
 
Left Behind
 On the one hand, the United States didn't care, and was left behind. On the other hand, Germany claimed -- and won -- the seat at the head of the table, outmaneuvering Britain and the Netherlands while tying France to its side.
Does it matter? On one level, it does not, because the German power play, arguably, was executed for a reasonable cause. Europe's hand-wringing did not stop the slaughter, and maybe a united front will instill a bit more caution among the "Greater Serbia" nationalists.
On a deeper level, though, the Yugoslav tragedy might remind the United States that Europe -- the fountainhead of most significant conflicts in the past 500 years -- is neither pacified nor peripheral to American interests.
Right now, the United States is forgoing, perhaps in a fit of absent-mindedness, a great chance to shape the fate of Europe behind the former Iron Curtain.
Eager as they are for American assistance, Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia et al. have learned to look to Bonn-Berlin, and thence to Brussels, for money and guidance. The southern ex-Soviet republics are looking toward Turkey and Iran. In Washington, however, there isn't even a pale copy of those grand designs that, in the 1940's, gave unto Europe what mattered most to America: stability, prosperity and democracy.
Certainly peace in the Middle East is a must, and so is a strategy that would relieve Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Byelorussia of the wherewithal for a nuclear civil war. But Europe is still the greatest chunk of power next to the United States. Americans may be coming to believe that Europe can take care of itself, but this has proved a dubious proposition in the past.
Today, the siren songs of neo-isolationism are being intoned by the left and the right. Historically, the isolationist impulse was always directed against Europe, not against the world as such. But the United States will not be No. 1 in the world if it becomes irrelevant in Europe.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1687 words

HEADLINE: The Atchison, Topeka And the Bullet Train

BYLINE: By Tony Hiss; Tony Hiss, a staff writer for The New Yorker, is writing a book on transportation. His most recent book is "The Experience of Place."

 BODY:
THE nine railroad books sitting on my desk -- a sampling from the cream of the latest crop -- are extraordinary documents: bold and buoyant and some of the first fruits produced by the emerging post-interstate approach to transportation thinking. This approach is a collaborative process that looks ahead a generation or so to a unified network of transportation links in North America, a system in which high-speed trains, medium-speed trains, light-rail lines, scenic roads, bicycle paths and even hiking trails will have taken on the same importance the interstates and the airports have already assumed.
This is an area in which breathtaking ideas bubble up almost overnight and then, with equal suddenness, get taken seriously -- people in New York City, for instance, are proposing to outshine London, Paris and Tokyo by healing an old wound, tearing down the much detested building that houses the Amtrak railroad station on 34th Street and replacing it with an exact replica of the soaring Roman vaults and great greenhouse skylights of the original 1910 Pennsylvania Station by McKim, Mead & White that once stood there. Similarly, an open-space group based in Washington wants the country to designate and preserve at least 10 percent of the highways we already have as a national system of scenic back roads. And the National Park Service's 1990 National Trails Agenda Project recommends "that a trail exist within 15 minutes of most Americans' homes." 
 As for the printed page, here are nine straightforward, substantial and well-researched books about trains in which all the authors, editors, photographers and publishers involved have successfully managed to break away from the old self-conscious, hangdog and almost occultist "railroadiana" conventions of so many postwar books about train travel -- books in which the tone was either wistful or aggrieved, and railroads were presented as part of a time that was either just about to be irrevocably sealed off from modern life or else already had been. None of that here. Strangled sobs and gnashed teeth have been blue-penciled (or delete-keyed) from their pages, and instead trains are presented as a given, a permanent asset reinvented again and again by succeeding generations.
Although these books address themselves to three centuries of railroading (19th, 20th and early 21st), most of them anchor their subjects firmly in the urgencies of the 1990's: Jack Simmons' magisterial work, THE VICTORIAN RAILWAY (Thames and Hudson, $39.95), for example, shows us the lasting effects of the successes and failures of the mid- and late-19th-century British environmentalists and preservationists (who, of course, didn't yet have these words for themselves). The preservationists beat back one scheme to run a railroad directly through Stonehenge, and trounced another one that would have built an iron viaduct down the middle of the Thames. But Mr. Simmons concludes that the "massive and hideous bridges" put up in 1864 to take trains into Charing Cross station -- bridges still in use today -- have "damaged the face of south London irreparably."
George F. Scheer 3d's BOOKED ON THE MORNING TRAIN: A Journey Through America (Algonquin, $19.95) even makes it plain just how rapidly a new assessment of America's transportation situation has overtaken people in this country. Mr. Scheer's book is one of two under review here about the transforming effects of traveling over every one of the thousands of passenger route miles in the Amtrak timetable -- the other is the newly reissued MAKING TRACKS: An American Rail Odyssey (Owl/Holt, Paper, $14.95) by Terry Pindell. As Mr. Scheer acknowledges in his epilogue, with disarming candor, he began work on his book in the mid-1980's thinking he might end up with yet one more tome for the overstocked shelves of railroad lugubriousness: "I thought I might be writing a requiem for Amtrak and for passenger rail travel in the United States. As it has turned out, I was longer than I ever imagined getting into print, and, more surprisingly, in the interim Amtrak has grown stronger rather than weaker" and "seems now to be more popular among travelers, more sound fiscally, and more secure politically than at any previous time."
There are some further signs in this stack of books that railroading can once again be treated as a full partner in the transportation equation: the subject is capturing the imagination of people who until recently haven't been known for writing about, or taking pictures of, railroads -- George Scheer is host of a late-night jazz program on the National Public Radio station in Chapel Hill, N.C.; Terry Pindell is an English teacher who's been a candidate for mayor in Keene, N.H.; and Gary J. Benson, who took the unforgettable full-color photographs of modern freight trains in ROLLING THUNDER: A Portrait of North American Railroading (Norton, $49.95), was best known, before he became fascinated with railroads in 1986, for his work documenting the heroism and frustrations of big-city firefighters. Nicholas Faith, a London journalist who has written books about wine and about auction houses, tells us at the beginning of THE WORLD THE RAILWAYS MADE (Carroll & Graf, $22.95) that his new book was in fact sparked by a series he wrote for The Economist in 1985 entitled "Return Train," which, "somewhat to my surprise, established that virtually every country in the civilised world was investing heavily in railways."
Three of the books on this list -- Mr. Benson's "Rolling Thunder" plus books about the Santa Fe and the Canadian Pacific railroads -- are among the most gorgeously and lovingly produced railroad books of the year. Two of the books here -- Mr. Benson's and SUPERTRAINS: Solutions to America's Transportation Gridlock (St. Martin's, $35), by Joseph Vranich -- would easily qualify for an all-categories list of the most compelling books of 1991.
However little regard you have for freight trains, particularly now that they've done away with cabooses, spend even an hour turning the pages of Mr. Benson's book (it also carries a short, information-packed text by Fred W. Frailey) and you will find it hard ever again to look unfeelingly at a battered diesel hauling a clanking string of empty coal cars. Gary Benson does for freight trains and their settings what Ansel Adams did for Yosemite. The photographs here are shockingly beautiful, even achingly so, because they use the overarching strength of the landscape and the seasons -- purple mountains, orange deserts, numbing cold, shimmering heat -- to make visible a more fragile kind of strength, today's giant freight trains. These mile-long trains weigh tens of millions of pounds and must be pulled through the countryside by diesel-electric engines that, working in tandem, have as much power as 15,000 horses. "Rolling Thunder" shows us that the strength of these trains endures only because all day and every day they get renewed by the 230,000 men and women who staff America's freight railroads.
Mr. Vranich's "Supertrains" is another horizon enlarger, but instead of showing us an asset we've already got, he focuses on a yawning void, our almost 40-year-long campaign to persuade ourselves that we don't want the high-speed trains that dozens of other countries -- including the Portuguese and the South Koreans -- are now busily acquiring to save themselves from both gridlock and from what Mr. Vranich calls "winglock," meaning intolerable airport delays. The news that Mr. Vranich brings is that we've done such a first-rate job of hypnotizing ourselves on this subject that many people haven't noticed that demand for high-speed trains has become a powerful new grass-roots cause in this country.
This new movement, as Mr. Vranich has discovered, already has enough momentum so that, despite continuing hostility from many in the Bush Administration, the first components of a 21st-century American network of high-speed train lines -- a 250-miles-per-hour German magnetic-levitation line (Maglev) in Orlando, Fla., and the first stage of a 167-m.p.h. line from Dallas to Houston -- will be up and running before the end of the century. Mr. Vranich even has a long-term hope for American transportation -- quiet would once more descend on the land: a six-car, 250-m.p.h. Maglev train makes less sound "than the noise generated by one automobile on an interstate. . . . Cows don't even look up."
VISIONS & VISIONARIES: The Art & Artists of the Santa Fe Railway (Peregrine Smith/Gibbs Smith, $34.95) by Sandra D'Emilio and Suzan Campbell is also a picture book, the first to make public a generous selection from the Santa Fe's largely unknown and immense collection of dazzlingly colored oils and watercolors by Taos and Santa Fe artists and by painters the railroad lured to the Southwest by offering them studio space on the rim of the Grand Canyon.
SURVEYING THE CANADIAN PACIFIC: Memoir of a Railroad Pioneer (University of Utah, $24.95) by R. M. Rylatt is the first publication of a deservedly treasured family heirloom. Rylatt had been quartermaster of a British survey party in the Canadian Rockies in the 1870's, and in later life he quietly set down for his children in a leather-bound journal a matter-of-fact account of his harrowing adventures. In the same book he drew for them a series of remarkably accomplished watercolors of the untrammeled wilderness landscapes that had caught at his heart.
Finally, a word of praise for OLD RAILS' TALES (Press of San Francisco, 2440 16th Street, No. 234, San Francisco, Calif. 94103; Cloth, $46.95; Paper, $34.95), volume one of an up-to-the-minute American railroad oral history edited by Alan Allen. This book is so in touch with modern railroading that it even records the energetic, compassionate and no-regrets reminiscences of Pat Lollis, a Californian born in 1953 who worked for the Santa Fe Railway as an engineer from 1974 until 1989 and who was, as she notes, "the first woman to run an Amtrak train out here" for the railroad as well as "the first woman engineer in California for Santa Fe."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Gorgaon, an engine built in 1841 for the Great Western Railway in Britain. (From "The Victorian Railways"); France's T.G.V. is the fastest train in the world. (French National Railway/from "Supertrains")

HEADLINE: After the Rate Cuts, What?

BYLINE: By ROBERT JOHNSON; Robert Johnson is managing director of global trading at Bankers Trust.

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve's one-point cut in the discount rate on Friday underscores the seriousness of the current recession, reinforcing that this is not a garden variety recession. The fear and pessimism among debt-laden consumers and business executives are stronger than is usual at this stage of the business cycle, reflecting deeper doubts about the long-term health of the economy -- doubts that might themselves prolong and deepen the downturn.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, touched on some of this in his testimony before Congress last week. And Friday's strong move by the Fed suggests that he is even more worried than he has publicly acknowledged. 
 There are three valid causes for such extreme pessimism: The traditional tools of macroeconomic policy appear ineffective, economic cooperation among the allied nations seems to have broken down, and the private sector has no clear source of strength to propel the economy.
Monetary policy has had difficulty jump-starting the economy because interest rate reductions by the Fed have not entirely reached consumers and businesses. Troubled financial institutions have used them instead as a means to rebuild their earnings flows to survive. Futhermore, lenders appear to be reluctant to extend credit at any interest rate if they believe there is risk of default.
And even if interest rate reductions were passed through to the public, fresh spending might not result, as consumers would likely use the money to reduce their private debt load. Eventually, debt reduction will liberate purchasing power. But the linkage between rate reductions and renewed spending is weak in the near term.
Many fear that fiscal policy cannot be effective in the current environment. Any move that enlarges the budget deficit may cause long-term interest rates to rise and depress the economy. And tax cuts may not have a strong stimulative impact because the proceeds may also go toward paying down debt or purchase imports.
The second cause for fear is the weak private sector. The construction industry is moribund. Debt-laden businesses have been unwilling to spend and eager to close plants and lay off workers. This has put further pressure on wages -- and exacerbated fears encouraging further consumer retrenchment, contributing to a downward spiral.
Executives have also been reluctant to expand capacity because of a budget deficit that will ultimately have to be reduced by a combination of taxes increases and spending cuts, both of which will depress the economy in the future.
The third source of fear is that we cannot rely on other countries to spark economic growth. Exports from the United States have been the silver lining in this recession, but are simply too small a percentage of American economic activity to levitate the economy. And the buyers of our goods -- including the Japanese and the Europeans -- are watching their economies slow down, diminishing their appetite for American products.
Furthermore, the Asian and European economies, which have built their postwar success on a strategy of export-led growth, are not ready to make the profound changes in their laws, regulations and political structures necessary to buoy worldwide economic activity.
This is particularly troublesome because the United States's ability to influence other nations to make these transformations is more limited than ever since World War II. The collapse of the Soviet Union reduces the value of the defense umbrella that the United States provides to its allies. And our flagging influence was made clear last Thursday when the German Bundesbank aggressively raised interest rates in the face of a slowing German and world economy; Japan may be on the verge of raising taxes. Those we call allies are taking actions that add to the deflationary pressures on the United States.
So what should be done?
President Bush, who has formidable skills as an international diplomat and leader, should pressure Japan and Germany to adopt stimulative policies and urge that European and Asian markets be opened. Domestically, interest rates could be reduced a step further if necessary. Lower rates will lead to refinancing and could arrest the decline in the values of property and lift consumer sentiment. They will also weaken the dollar, helping to spur foreign direct investment in this country and leading to greater profitability for exporters.
On the fiscal side, a package concentrating on a burst of spending on public works and education would provide the maximum stimulus for the economy, but would be difficult to enact after a decade of ideological combat centered on the evils of Government spending.
Finally, to influence psychology, our nation's leaders can learn from the example of Magic Johnson. He showed courage and strength in acknowledging his illness. Last week's statements by Mr. Greenspan and Samuel Skinner, the new White House Chief of Staff, acknowledging the severity of the current economic condition, are to be applauded. Accepting that you have an illness is the first step in overcoming it. The next step is constructive action -- the task to which the Administration and Congress must now turn.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1501 words

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PYONGYANG, North Korea, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Revolutionary slogans are strung across drab office buildings and apartments. Loudspeakers exhort workers with picks and shovels at construction sites to toil for the glory of President Kim Il Sung. Statues and pictures of the "Great Leader" beckon everywhere.
North Korea is the land that the 1990's forgot. Seemingly immune to the historic forces toppling or weakening Communist systems throughout the world, officials here speak of "mistakes" made by other Communist governments that they can avoid. 
 "We know about the changes in the world, but they have not affected us," said Li Song Chol, a 28-year-old runner studying to be an athletic coach. "We Koreans have built our own socialist economy. We believe in ourselves. We have chosen our own system. Our faith will not be shaken."
 
Questioning U.S. Pressure
 Mr. Li was sitting in the dim recesses of a nightclub for the city's elite, where he and a group of male friends were having a night off from their wives. Around them were fountains, rock formations and colored lights making the club look like a honky-tonk grotto.
As is the custom in this prim society, the men danced with one another. But Mr. Li stayed behind to make a new point about the main topic in the news these days: American pressure on North Korea to stop developing a nuclear bomb.
"We don't believe we have nuclear weapons," he said firmly. "We have no ability to make them. Why are you Americans putting such pressure on us? It is very dangerous to world peace."
 
Following the 'Great Leader'
 Outside of North Korea, one of the most closed societies on earth, experts speak of a nation gripped by crises: a stricken economy, poor harvests, food and fuel shortages, declining industry and an oppressive government.
Human rights groups speak of a smothering totalitarian environment. North Korea's people are said to be indoctrinated from early childhood to follow the Great Leader, and his son and successor, Kim Jong Il, the "Dear Leader," and to espouse the doctrine of juche, or self-sufficiency.
Because Mr. Li and the others spoke through a Government-supplied interpreter, who presumably reported on what he heard, there was no way to know to what degree the interpreter's presence inhibited the expression of their true feelings. But here in Pyongyang, random conversations over a day and a half revealed only the mildest signs of distress, and there are no discernible signs of dissent. Indeed, the uniformity of political opinions makes it appear that Pyongyang is a city for the loyal elite, who are well treated.
The streets are crowded but not congested with cars. Pedestrians cram into buses, subways and trams. Stores downtown carry a variety of goods, though hardly in much abundance.
On the subway, two young women who said they were off to buy flowers to place at the Revolutionary Martyrs' Tombs had nothing but compliments for the subway, with its gleaming vaulted ceilings, colored chandeliers, mosaic friezes and piped in music.
"As far as we know, there are no unemployed people in our country," said Pak Il Hwa, a 25-year-old bookkeeper for the municipal bus system.
People said that rice was rationed and that they faced delays in getting meat, dairy products and such household goods as soap and drugs. A housewife said her family ate three meals a day but meat only once or twice a month.
"Koreans are not people who like to eat meat," said Ryu Chun Sim, who was buying pencils for her children to use for homework, adding cheerfully that she liked the fact that prices were the same everywhere, even in remote areas. "Articles are supplied in a planned way," she said.
 
Patriotism and Red Pins
 At nearby counters of the five-story Pyongyang Department Store No. 1, the counters and display racks were packed with goods, some of them expensive. A man's suit cost $125 -- two month's salary, a guide explained. In the store, which was unheated, all the shoppers wore little red pins featuring President Kim. The guide said that although wearing such pins is voluntary, everyone wishes to show their patriotism.
Mrs. Ryu said she was proud to be a member of the Workers' Party and was aware of recent developments regarding North Korea, including the recent signing of a treaty with South Korea.
"The agreement was a great event for us," she said. "We consider it a first step toward achieving unification. But now the implementation may bring some problems. You Americans can help us by persuading your Government to withdraw nuclear weapons in South Korea."
The fact that President Roh Tae Woo had announced this week that South Korea had been made nuclear free was not publicized here.
 
Monuments to Kim
 Pyongyang has had two bursts of construction. In 1982, in honor of the President's 70th birthday, the city put up an immense Arch of Triumph, a 60-foot bronze statue of the Great Leader and a huge obelisk with a red torch-like set of lights on top.
Then in 1988, the nation completed a vast complex of stadiums, rinks and amphitheaters in the hope of becoming co-host of the Seoul Olympics. Spurned by the Olympic Committee, North Korea held its own huge Youth Festival in 1989 and finished a vast stretch of 20-story apartment complexes nearby.
What the citizenry truly thinks of these granite and marble edifices at a time when North Korea has defaulted on its external debt is impossible to say. But what may have been a note of dark humor crept into one man's comment on the 105-story structure for a hotel that remains uncompleted after years of delay.
"It is the will of the people to build such a big hotel," he said, shaking his head. Seeing a foreigner share in the skepticism, he quickly added that although North Korea had been belittled before in its ambitions, the country would prove its critics wrong again with this hotel, 5 fewer stories than the towers of the World Trade Center in Manhattan.
 
Birthday Apartments
 This year, yet another new construction enterprise is under way, this time in honor of President Kim's 80th birthday next April. In the southern part of the city, another vast complex of 50,000 new apartments is going up. The site is filled with workers tramping through the mud and being exhorted by martial music and a voice shouting over a loudspeaker such things as: "We must manage our economy in our own way following the instructions of President Kim Il Sung!"
The workers had few bulldozers or cranes, and were joined by battalions of army troops brought in to speed things up. A guide was asked why, if everything was so wonderful in North Korea, there was a need to harangue workers with such propoganda.
"We need it to mobilize the people in a proper way," he said. "It makes people work harder in a creative way."
 
Sports and the Party Line
 There seem to be plenty of diversions for the people of Pyongyang. There are public baths where men can relax and get a massage and an enormous array of sites for sports. At the city's big ice rink, a group of high school speed-skating teams were competing as a small crowd shouted. Two huge "Children's Palaces" -- closed this winter, perhaps because of fuel shortages -- house dozens of rooms for after-school studies and such activities as singing, dancing, painting and music making.
A group of high school students wandering the streets in the evening explained that they had been studying the revolutionary teachings of President Kim since the age of 6 or 7. At least, they said, the high school course on these teachings was an easy one, since they had been exposed to it all their lives.
One thing missing from the streets of Pyongyang has been bicycles. Outsiders and defectors say the Government does not permit bicycles because they give too much mobility to the people. But a few bicycles are now being allowed in North Korea, a stunning contrast to the bicycle-filled streets of China.
In their casual comments, the people here speak of a society under siege and threat by the United States and its nuclear weapons, suffering under economic pressures but determined to go their own way.
 
Linking Peace and Business
 While not wanting to admit that the system has failed, people here acknowledge that things could be better if there is a rapprochement with Seoul or Washington. "If we have peace, then business can improve," said a businessman aboard a flight from Beijing to Pyongyang.
With a briefcase loaded with imported chocolates and a bag stuffed with bottles of cognac, the businessman said opportunities were growing for North Korea to sell gold, silver and precious and non-ferrous metals abroad, especially to Japan. But everything else reminds the North Koreans of the evils of capitalism.
Even an English lesson on the radio reinforced the message, offering these as sample sentences for listeners: "I made some bad investments and it looks like I may go broke." "My brother's company went broke last May." "She is so extravagant. No wonder she is broke."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Financial Desk
