HEADLINE: Experts Doubt Cutbacks Alone Will Save G.M.

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 22

 BODY:
When the General Motors Corporation announced last week that it was closing 21 plants and shedding 74,000 workers in the next three years, its chairman, Robert C. Stempel, said the changes would enable the world's largest auto maker to "meet the competitive challenges of the 1990's."
But many experts are not so sure that G.M. can halt its inexorable decline just by getting smaller. 
 Time and again in the last decade, G.M. has closed plants and laid off workers, each time proclaiming that a "leaner and meaner" company was ready to take on the world. G.M., the experts say, needs more than a trimmer waist; it needs a change of mentality.
 
A Repeat Ahead?
 "What they've announced doesn't answer the interesting question," said James Womack, an automotive industry consultant. "G.M. is going to get smaller, but will there be a similar event four years from now?"
The changes announced Wednesday, which will cut G.M.'s North American work force by 18 percent, should help staunch the horrendous losses in the company's North American operations, which have reached $15 million a day in the last year. But the company's waning financial state has hurt its chances for recovery.
The plight of General Motors -- and of the nation's No. 2 and No. 3 auto makers, Ford Motor and Chrysler -- is a vivid symbol of the nation's struggling manufacturing base.
 
Victim of Success
 Forty-five years ago, Peter Drucker, now a professor of social sciences at the Claremont Graduate School in California, extolled G.M. as the epitome of a successful corporation. Now, he says, it has become "a victim of its own success," unable to break with managerial habits that are outmoded.
Why, for example, does G.M. insist on retaining its five car divisions -- Cadillac, Buick, Oldsmobile, Pontiac and Chevrolet? Fifteen years ago, they were marketed to different socioeconomic segments. Now most people's choice of vehicle reflects "life style" rather than just their pocketbooks. Chrysler's Jeeps and mini-vans, for example, are bought by people of many different economic backgrounds.
The five divisions require separate design departments, marketing and advertising campaigns and dealer networks, which all contribute to the bloat at G.M., which has more white-collar workers in North America than the Toyota Motor Corporation has workers of all kinds in the world. Mr. Stempel said Wednesday, when the huge cutbacks were announced, that the five divisions would be retained.
In recent years, G.M. has been trying to forge new and better relationships with suppliers, dealers and employees. Its goals are to develop models more quickly and to manufacture them more efficiently, hoping to lure back the millions of customers who have defected to foreign brands.
But there are formidable roadblocks: G.M.'s institutional resistance to change, its enormous bulk and an outdated management style that controls rather than delegates.
Ford and Chrysler are also altering their management styles. But having slimmed down during their financial troubles in the early 1980's, they are not so bloated with overcapacity or as inefficient as G.M. Each G.M. worker, for example, produces about 13 cars a year, compared with 45 a year at Toyota.
And almost anyone who has dealt with "the General," as G.M. is known in the auto industry, can offer an anecdote about its sometimes overbearing, sometimes rigid management style.
One supplier rolled his eyes as he described efforts to trim G.M.'s costs -- which failed inside G.M.'s bureaucracy. An engineer moaned about endless meetings, mountains of paperwork and vicious office politics. A Chevrolet dealer complained that his telephone calls to divisional headquarters were not returned.
This is not to say General Motors is not trying. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of consultants have been hired to hold seminars explaining the importance of change and how to accomplish it. Top executives have participated in sensitivity training.
Now, management experts say, as white-collar employment shrinks in the next three years, G.M. must learn to eliminate redundant or irrelevant activities. It must hold fewer meetings, ask that fewer forms be filled out, impose fewer controls on supervisors -- instead of just reducing its headcount.
G.M.'s top-heaviness has a direct impact on manufacturing efficiency, which becomes strikingly clear to anyone who strolls through the Honda Motor Company's plant in Marysville, Ohio, as well as through G.M.'s plants and offices.
Honda's top manufacturing executive, for example, is dressed in overalls, often greasy; has a desk in a room with 40 other engineers and often works near the assembly line. G.M.'s manufacturing executives wear expensive suits and spend most of their time in nicely decorated offices and meeting rooms.
 
Stumbling Block for Supervisors
 Some old-line American manufacturers have been able to nurture a new culture in their operations, but only through radical action. Dennis J. Gormley, chief executive of the Federal-Mogul Corporation of Southfield, Mich., which makes bearings and other engine parts, discovered that production-line workers were eager to accept more responsibility, but some of their supervisors got in the way.
In the last two years, Mr. Gormley said, he has replaced the plant managers in 80 percent of his company's 20 American factories because they could not or would not cede responsibility to subordinates.
In most G.M. plants, hourly workers have been pushed to become more involved in quality control, designing parts and dealing with suppliers. But many managers, who roam the plants in white shirts and ties, still impose too much authority, and G.M. has been slow to weed them out.
 
Workers Feel Betrayed
 What will make matters more difficult now is that many G.M. workers feel betrayed and threatened. They live with an ax dangling over their heads, because the company said it would eliminate 74,000 jobs but did not identify which ones, or where. At least a third of those cuts are expected to come within the salaried ranks.
When General Motors began its innovative Saturn project in 1985, it said the attempt to embrace the ideas of worker empowerment and greater participation by dealers and suppliers would eventually become a model for the parent company. But the plant in Spring Hill, Tenn., has started slowly, and its influence within G.M. remains minuscule, compared with that of Chevrolet, Pontiac, Buick, Oldsmobile or Cadillac.
Motivated workers and flexible factories can yield enormous gains in marketing. The best Japanese car makers are able to make a profit with far fewer sales of a specific model than G.M., partly because their engineers and factory workers can set up machines faster, solve glitches without supervision and keep the cost of model changes low.
Because model changes cost them more, G.M. and other American companies must build hundreds of thousands or millions of a given model to break even. And to sell hundreds of thousands of cars of one model, say a Chevrolet Caprice, the company chooses a bland design.
 
Motivating Individual Workers
 Professor Drucker warned G.M. as far back as the 1940's that it was doomed eventually unless ordinary workers somehow could be motivated to contribute more than physical or menial labor. At about the same time, W. Edwards Deming, an influential consultant and statistician, was helping Toyota ignite a manufacturing revolution that today is sweeping factories around the world.
The revolution has not yet set G.M. on fire, and many people who follow the auto industry think perhaps it never will.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 633 words

HEADLINE: A Record Crowd in New Hampshire's Primary

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 22

 BODY:
A record 63 candidates filed by Friday's deadline to run in New Hampshire's Presidential primary on Feb. 18, the first in the nation. The 36 Democrats, 26 Republicans and 1 Libertarian will compete for the support of the state's 511,307 registered voters.
The number of Democrats on the ballot is so large that the New Hampshire Secretary of State has said the size of the candidates' names as printed on the ballot will have to be reduced. 
 Virtually anyone can get on the ballot in the state's Presidential primary by paying a $1,000 filing fee. It is not necessary to list one's occupation or other credentials. In 1988, 39 names were on the ballot; in 1984, there were 27.
Two Republicans and two Democrats filed to run for Vice President.
Following are the names of the candidates, by party in the order they registered, on the 1992 ballot.
